name: Puhemies.
text: — The first item is a statement from the Commission on the European Values Instrument for support of civil society organisations promoting democracy, the rule of law and fundamental values in the European Union (2018/2619 (RSP)).

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission considers the strong, free and vibrant civil society in the EU and in all our Member States as very important. Civil society organisations and independent human rights bodies play an essential role in promoting, safeguarding and raising awareness of EU common values. They are also key players when it comes to ensuring the effective enjoyment by everyone of rights under EU law and under the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU. The importance of preserving and protecting the civil society space is particularly clear in times when fundamental rights and values are under pressure. We are aware and concerned about alarming reports and studies, including from the EU Fundamental Rights Agency and the Council of Europe, which point to a pattern of pressures civil society is facing in many parts of the European Union. Policymakers in every democracy should engage in a regular and transparent dialogue with civil society and independent human rights actors, both as allies and as critical minds, and support the development of a sustainable environment for these actors to strengthen their role and perform their functions independently and effectively. As reflected in the draft resolution you are going to vote on today, this also entails a positive obligation at all levels to provide these actors with adequate financial support. The EU budget can provide value added in upholding common European values such as democracy, freedom, the rule of law, fundamental rights, cultural diversity, equality, solidarity, sustainability and peace. Working together with national budgets and complementing other efforts at European and national level, the Union has been providing concrete support to civil society and independent human rights actors in many key areas. With a view to the post-2020 EU budget, we are exploring ways to create a values framework in the EU budget with broader funding programmes in a scope aimed at promoting and protecting EU values. We want to further enhance synergies between the current different funding programmes to give EU value an ever more prominent and visible place in our funding priorities. We want to reach a critical mass of funding to have an impact on citizens’ daily lives. In this context, we are determined to make the best of this opportunity to strengthen the added value that the EU finances can provide to support, empower and build the capacity of civil society and other independent actors whose activities promote, safeguard and raise awareness of common values at national and local level and help the strategic enforcement of rights under EU law and the Charter. Maintaining our civil society strong, independent and pluralistic requires our joint efforts, and we welcome the continued engagement of the European Parliament on this matter.

name: Michał Boni
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, democracy, the rule of law and European fundamental values cannot be taken for granted. They need active cultivation. A vibrant civil society is best suited to strengthening these values and preventing democracy from eroding. However, the performance of these tasks needs access to funding. This is why it is vital that we invest our resources in a strong civil society for the sake of our fundamental values and the future of the European project. This is what the proposed European values instrument is all about. Its focus is on grassroots civil society actors who operate at local and national level, where European values are confronted with significant challenges across Europe. So far, the EU has not developed adequate instruments to this end. We know what the European crucial values are and have discussed them many times. What is also key is to open the space for dialogue between various pluralistic organisations with their views on the civic future of Europe. It is the best background to practise democracy, to give citizens a real opportunity to participate in democracy. This is the only way to keep and develop democracy in Europe, especially in the era of post-truth politics. This instrument should be user-friendly, transparent, accountable, responsive to urgent needs and easily accessible to local civic actors. Only in this way will it bring added value. I strongly hope that the Commission will approve the idea and that adequate resources will be allocated to the European values instrument in the next budget.

name: Josef Weidenholzer
text: Mr President, on behalf of the S&D Group. We should always bear this in mind: good coexistence and long-term stability can only be guaranteed if the state, the economy and society are in a balanced relationship. In the times of communism, we were able to see what it means when the social element is missing. The state, dominated by the party, stifled the commitment of free people. Not least the rise of civil society eventually led to a peaceful revolution. Tadeusz Mazowiecki once put it this way: “Everything depends on the power of society, on its spiritual values, on its wisdom in asserting human rights and the rights of the nation.” But what was undisputed for a quarter of a century and became a cornerstone of the new European self-image, which seems to be forgotten today. From a European perspective in particular, it is necessary to look at this connection. We cannot accept that the civil society sector is again under threat. It should certainly not be an excuse that this seems to be a global trend. Many developments are also worrying in Europe. Administrative measures and policy campaigns are narrowing the area of civil society, as our Fundamental Rights Agency recently stated in a worrying report. If we do not take these well-founded concerns seriously, we will be jeopardising the European project in the long term. We should firmly oppose these trends. Civil society is not opposed to politics, as is often feared and claimed. We need civil society as a critical and sometimes unpleasant partner. This is the only way to ensure that we as politicians do not stand out. It is therefore necessary to promote civil society at European level. And, love Ladies and gentlemen, what is possible for political parties must also apply in this context and, above all, to those organisations that are committed to the values of the European Union.

name: Marek Jurek
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Madam President! The idea that the authorities of some state, but also the authorities of the European Union, would mean an open commitment to the deformation of public opinion, so would be a denial of the freedom on which public opinion and democracy should be based. Unfortunately, such concerns may be justified since European Union authorities have so often expressed concern or criticism over the election results in Austria, Italy, Hungary. It is therefore not excluded that those who lead the union of our states are afraid of the outcome of the next democratic general election, so it is time to remind you again: the European Union is the union of our states, not your ideology. Of course, if this mechanism arises, we will judge it by fruit, we will verify whether it truly serves everyone, but the intentions with which it is created are serious, legitimate concerns.

name: Sophia in 't Veld
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I would like to pick up where Mr Jurek left off. First of all, a little correction: it is not a union of Member States, it is a union of citizens and citizens may actually have very different views. What will happen when this instrument is adopted, is that we are actually going to strengthen democracy. Why? Because one of the tasks of civil society is to actually challenge people who are in power. It is to challenge governments. It is called checks and balances, it is the very core of democracy and, yes, that means that civil society could, for example, challenge your government or the Hungarian Government. I think that would be extremely healthy for democracy in those countries and other countries. It is very funny that the European Union has instruments to support NGOs and civil society outside the European Union but not inside.  Therefore, I very much welcome the initiative by Michał Boni. It is also in line with the position adopted by the European Parliament in October 2016 in the report on the DRF Pact so I very much welcome this. I think the report by the Fundamental Rights Agency about the state of civil society also highlights the urgent need for such an instrument. In this context, I would also like to strongly condemn the recent targeting of NGOs and people working for NGOs in Hungary. I think that is a very dangerous development and it should be condemned by this House. Finally, Madam Commissioner, I have just one question because I think the Commission should also seriously implement other instruments aiming for accountability, like the preparatory action on the litigation fund and we have just met with your people this week. But I am also a little bit worried to hear that the Commission explicitly excludes the instrument of litigation or litigation costs as eligible activities, like under the recent call for proposals for the EU Programme for Employment and Social Innovation. Litigation is a very important instrument, allowing citizens and NGOs to create this sphere of fundamental rights and the rule of law so please give your support to litigation as well.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue—card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Raymond Finch (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Ms in 't Veld, do you not think that financially supporting these social actors means that they will be beholden to governments and to the European Union, and therefore will actually act in their interests rather than independently and in the interests of people as a whole? I find it utterly incredible that anybody would believe that those who will now have a financial interest will be able to act independently.

name: Sophia in ‘t Veld (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – In a democracy, we fund lots of organisations that serve the public interest, such as political parties like your political party. You are receiving funding, so does that impair your independence? I do not think so. We have a long tradition in the European Union of giving financial support to civil society: does that make them less independent? I do not think so. They are also accountable. There are rules on transparency – which, incidentally, are being abused by some governments in the European Union – so no, I think it is a good thing. It strengthens democracy, and I wholeheartedly support this initiative.

name: Jean Lambert
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, this year is marking the 70th anniversary of the adoption of the Universal Declaration on Human Rights by the United Nations in Paris at the time and therefore I think it is a good opportunity for us to consider what is actually happening on those issues within the European Union. We'd like to say that we promote democracy, rule of law, human rights on the international stage. I chair one of Parliament's delegations and I know that the support that we give for human rights organisations in countries where those rights are under attack and where defending them can lead to torture, imprisonment, impunity for those who attack such defenders and repressive laws designed to stop such bodies being effective, is crucial and really important to keeping democracy alive at the grassroots.  Worryingly, I think we're seeing an increasing number of these signs in a number of our Member States. Legislation designed to stop the effective working of organisations defending human rights, rule of law and democracy. Media attacks on the concept of defending human rights. The Fundamental Rights Agency, talks about the stigmatization of human rights defenders. Politicians who want to withdraw from the European Convention on Human Rights and we see journalists who put their lives on the line by investigating corruption. So the European Values Instrument I think is an important proposal, designed to support organisations who uphold and promote the values on which the EU claims it is founded and these are universal values. This is not a selective choice. This was the choice made by those who have joined the European Union and I think that that direct support is crucial and will only strengthen the way in which the European Union can say that it is acting without double standards but applies the same standards internally as we do externally.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for reminding us that we are not talking really about European values, but about universal values: we have freedom of the press, we have the respect of human rights, and we have democracies also in other parts of the world: take Japan, or take Chile, or take Korea as an example. Don’t you believe that the constant reminding that these values are European gives the dictatorships, for instance in China, the right to say they that have their values whereas we have our values?

name: Jean Lambert (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – I think the Member has a point, and I think that at times it’s very well worth our while reminding ourselves that these are universal values. But, nevertheless, in terms of the European treaties, in terms of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, we have also given ourselves a really high standard to live up to, and therefore I think if we are not seen to be doing that ourselves we also give other countries an opportunity to say that we speak, as it were, with two different voices. So this is why I think that the instrument is important in helping us maintain our own standards where we’re also talking to others about universal rights.

name: Barbara Spinelli
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, for various reasons it is worth creating an instrument in support of civil society organisations that defend and promote the principles of Article 2 of the Treaty. First of all, I would like to remind you that the European project was born in the post-war period not to create a vast market but to protect citizens from the diseases of democracy and the poverty that had devastated it. It was born from the will of countries that came out of fascism, Nazism and, away, welcomed countries that came out of dictatorships: Greece, Portugal, Spain, Eastern countries. It's time to return to the roots of that project: according to the mechanisms protecting the rule of law in member states, they are often perceived as top-down devices, falling from above instead of starting from bass, bottom-up. This is why it is important to support NGOs dealing with rule of law monitoring, advocacy and litigation. Secondly, the crisis of parties and the poverty that returns give NGOs a new centrality: it is they, often, who mediate between power and society. Their strength and independence is as valuable as that of judiciary and media. Thirdly, the Union devotes funds, and rightly, to defend democracy in third countries, including candidates but does not spend anything on the Union's national and local NGOs: a disparity that must be overcome. Fourthly, the support of NGOs in the Member States is virtually guaranteed today only by the EA Norway fund and philanthropic associations: it is often perceived as support that comes from outside and created misunderstandings. In order to overcome such misunderstandings, it is also better to have, in parallel, an instrument which is responsible for the European institutions.

name: Jörg Meuthen
text: on behalf of the EFD Group. — (DE) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. We are talking today about the fact that a committee decided in an urgary procedure that the European Union should subsidise so-called civil society organisations directly from their caskets. I already have a big problem with the procedure. How can it be that an own-initiative report on such an important issue is not adopted duly adopted in committee on which there are amendments and, above all: public discussions? You have opted for a backroom procedure. The committee authorities have sat down to decide in a small circle something that would throw the previous support system over the heap. In your resolution, you call for the introduction of a special instrument to promote European values, firstly financially and directly. Money for these organisations is therefore bypending the government and parliament of the Member State. Of course, you are thinking of Hungary and Poland in this new instrument. This House and the Commission complain that Poland and Hungary did not adhere to the much-invoked European values. I see this the other way around: Hungary and Poland are defending European diversity. They are fighting to preserve the nation states. They are fighting to ensure that things are not ruled from the distant Brussels ivory tower, but they are fighting for subsidiarity. They are the real defenders of Europe. It's perfectly clear to me that doesn't fit your plan. They want a centralistically governed unitary Europe. And you are ready to pull all the tabs for this. You know that you never have a majority in the electorate for this. But you can't choose another people. That's why you're trying to fabricate a consensus. They want to influence public opinion. I don't need to tell you that this is undemocratic. It is also non-liberal and violates the spirit of separation of powers. Don't you notice how ridiculous you are when you accuse Orbán and the Poles of violating the liberal-democratic “comment” while trampling on Western democracy? I'm afraid not. Because you won't listen to me. I can only give you one last question on your wrong path: Don't you want to finally learn lessons from Brexit? The way you do it, you are about to break down everything that Europe actually means. I find this most unfortunate.

name: Gerolf Annemans
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (NL) Mr President, for the ENF Group too, this instrument of values is a questionable thing, a nasty form of interference and guardianship of the European Union over the Member States. In many cases, it is simply nothing more than promoting and subsidizing the political opposition in Member States that do not like the European Union. The example par excellence is, of course, the Hungarian situation where, for example, the Helsinki Committee openly says, 'When we criticize the government's position on migration, then we want to hold the government accountable to the Geneva Convention'. Pure political interference from an organisation funded 80% by Mr Soros and which you are now going to supplement with European subsidies. It's just an example. The European Union wants to punish countries and Member States which are not in line, which, on immigration and also on the role of the European Union itself, differ from the opinion expressed here by those in power, and that is the sadder thing. This instrument is not only wasting money, it is also a fierce violation of important principles such as subsidiarity and sovereignty.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE).
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, the Europeans have undergone tough trials. Through concerted efforts, they created a community ruled by peace and respect for democratic principles. Democracy, rule of law, freedom of speech, equality, those are constant values. However, we have somehow forgotten that the principles we choose to live by are not self-evident. Today, such foundations of the democratic establishment, such as the division of power or an independent judiciary, are undermined. I'm referring to Central Europe in particular. Poland, Hungary, Czech Republic and Slovakia. The media is often under political pressure. In this situation, it is necessary to support civil society. Indeed, she can seduce a successful struggle to preserve European values. We need a tool that would financially support civil society. It will be some of the best spent money ever. I support the draft resolution.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I couldn’t resist answering the point made by Mr Henkel. He talked about European values. It is not that European values are exclusive to the European Union; it is that the European Union is not just an economic entity, a single market, it is that values go along with that and they are not exclusive because we also observe universal human rights. That is the point. The point is that, with that, a strong independent civil society is essential. The Fundamental Rights Agency recently said that NGOs within the European Union are facing overall budget cuts and economic crisis. NGOs are diminishing, so this work by Mr Boni, supported by all the major political groups, is essential to ensure that that important part of democracy is supported, and supported independently. This flexible instrument is important, and supported, because it provides that distance between the NGOs and the European Union, but allows them to be active and vibrant. These are the core values that are shared by all EU Member States, but we have a duty to support grassroots organisations that are defending human rights independently. Without active and critical civil society we would not be a Union based on democracy, rule of law and fundamental rights. I, myself, was a Chair and a director of an NGO. I know about flexible funding, which is often difficult with regard to bureaucratic EU funding. That’s why it is essential that here, in the Parliament, we support a European values instrument, which supports the work of local NGOs and national NGOs that are doing such important work on the ground. This is a very good moment for the European Parliament and we should support Mr Boni’s work. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue Card question. — Honourable Member, You have received a serious applause after your speech, although I have already noticed that many people in this Chamber will probably agree with you. But, along the very nice words, I would still like to ask whether you see an opportunity for this instrument or the political formula around the instrument to deal with the situation that, for example, in some countries, such as Hungary, the adoption of this financial instrument may even result in imprisonment. Thank you very much.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – Before Mr Boni produced this work, we had a lot of meetings with NGOs; a lot of preparation was done. This is why I say it was a good moment for the European Parliament. As the Commissioner has said, a lot of preparatory work was done and I do believe there are many challenges in those Member States, but I think that because of that work – and indeed we are meeting with civil society following this debate – we will provide a mechanism that is more flexible than now to ensure that support happens. But you’re right to say that it will be a challenge, because independence with EU funding is not an easy equation, but it’s critical. Just on this final point: an earlier point was made that with funding doesn’t come independence, but with civil society many of these NGOs would simply go bust.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR).
text: Mr President, I read the letter calling for the European instrument of values. NGOs asked for financial support so that they could promote European values. That sounds noble, but the letter didn't wrap any more wipes on it. For example, it was read that the euro-critical voices, and not the policy pursued, are to blame for the malaise in Europe. A negative attitude on the part of the population towards the Union was also criticised. My delegation, N-VA, naturally fully supports the rule of law. That is also evident from our commitment to Catalonia. We therefore want to strengthen the renowned EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights and to act against defaulting authorities. This value instrument, however, tackles the citizen. What is the purpose of that? The citizens realise that Europe has failed in the area of migration and are displeased by its pivotal desire. Double morals and backroom politics. Is it the intention to win back voters with a good news show and use their own taxpayers' money to do so?

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, there can be no functioning democracy without a functioning civil society. It promotes the rule of law and accountability. There can be no fully functioning human rights catalogue without an active society, as it helps to implement international human rights standards. But the shrinking space for these organisations is in fact a reality.  On my latest mission to Hungary, I met with civil society organisations promoting human rights and women’s rights. I witnessed their struggles, which are much related to a lack of adequate funding, a tactic by the Hungarian government to prevent these organisations from functioning.  Civil society organisations need our help to carry out their work. Therefore, I call on us all, the European Union, to set up the European Values Instrument to ensure funding and support for these organisations. Together we can defend our common European values.

name: Terry Reintke (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, fundamental rights are under attack in the European Union. Some rights that we have actually taken for granted in the past are suddenly in question again and it is not the first time, because despite the fact that we call them European values, they have been undermined also in Europe in the past and this has always ended in catastrophe. But this continent is stronger. Our citizens are stronger, and that is why it is so important that we support the brave people who are defending fundamental rights in the European Union right now, because they are not only defending their own rights, they are defending all our freedom and all our democracies at the same time, and in these difficult moments, we have to stand together as Europeans and stand up for what this Union is founded on.  For these people, it is important to have our solidarity. But at the same time, I really think it’s about time that we also pay them credit for what they have been doing in the past and that we support them with a fundamental values instrument.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, a strong and well-developed civil society is the best antidote to the erosion of a democratic regime and to the resurgence of new authoritarianisms. Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union states that the Union is based on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, values which, unfortunately, are being quite eroded and are not the ones that are guiding the main policies of the European Union at present. The role of civil society is essential to observe the fulfillment of these values. For this reason, where it is difficult to carry out its activities independently and effectively, this instrument should be applied to ensure that it can carry out its activity. The question is: What will the European People's Party do? Will he be on the side of Orbán or civil society organizations? Will he vote with those who want democracy, freedom, equality to be respected or will he stand by the new far-right forces that remind us of the worst in our history?

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF).
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. As important as friendship and cooperation on our continent is, it is detrimental to intervene politically in the policies of other states here in Brussels's ivory tower with a discussion of values and to interpret these values at will in the way that fits into one's own business. Let us be honest: you are discussing Hungary and Poland here today, and both Hungarians and Poland are old parts of the European family of peoples, are proud parts of the European family of nations. And what election results are being presented here, for example, in Hungary: two-thirds of people are in favour of Orbán being able to continue here. Two-thirds of parliamentary seats are won, and we should be treated with respect here. Orbán was the only person who respected the European regulatory framework here at the beginning of the refugee crisis and tried to protect the borders. And what did he get for it? Nothing but scolding. This is the wrong way. Ladies and gentlemen, take note of the fact that pluralism, diversity and also the way to provide its own state with a sovereign structure must be possible on this continent, and we treat each other with friendship, not scolding, as you do. (The speaker agreed to answer a question under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question under the 'blue card' procedure. — Madam President, dear colleague, you said that it is not good to finance NGOs through this instrument. Do you think that it is better to be financed from Russia or other occult institutions and organizations? Do you think it is better for the European Union, which was created on the basis of a treaty and in which countries, states have adhered to common rules? We must also have instruments for measuring and supporting democratic institutions, among other things civil society. What do you think is better: the outside funding I'm getting now, let's face it, some NGOs?

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Answer to a question about the 'blue card' procedure. I'm not quite sure now if I got your question right. But in order to finance NGOs, one can only state in principle that, of course, NGOs must be free within their framework of action and must also be able to act regardless of political influence. From my point of view, I don't see any problem at all. What I do not like is that here, from a thousand kilometers distance, other states are dictated to what they have to act, how they have to think. We are a European family of peoples, and we also allow other accents to be set here in different countries.

name: Francis Zammit Dimech (PPE).
text: — Sinjura President, naħseb aħna naqblu lkoll li s-soèjetà ivili hija vui importanti ħafna biex isservi bħala mezz ta' skrutju ta' gvernijiet. In day, l-importanza tiegħu tikber meta jkollok istituzzjonijiet li suppost huma indipendenti, però li jinħakmu mill-gvern, in allura ma jibqgħux jagħmlu r-rwol tagħhom. Nagħti żewġ eżempji reenti minn Malta. Kellna attivisti ambjentali li marru u ħarġu biex jipproteġu żoni li suppost huma barra mill-iżvilupp biex jibqgħu protetti bħala żoni ambjentali. Kellna wkoll attivisti li qed jaħdmu biex toħroġ il-verità kollha rigward il-qtil tal-ġurnalista Daphne Caruana Galizia. Fiż-żewġ każijiet kellek xkiel flok għajnuna mill-gvern. Għalhekk, [hemm] il-ħtieġa li s-soèjetà ivili ngħinuha, anki bi strument financier. Għaliex? Għaliex dik hija l-vuði ta' min m'għandux forom oħra ta' parteðipazzjoni, u dik hija l-vuði, iva, li tista' tħares il-valuri Ewropej li fuqhom hija mibnija l-demoà tagħna, tas-saltna tad-drkitt, tad-drkitt in anki tal-ħarsien tagħna tad-drittijiet fundamentali kollha.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, unfortunately it has long been that essential values of European construction, such as political pluralism, independence of the judiciary or fundamental rights, cannot be taken for granted: alarming setbacks occur, and not only in Hungary or Poland. We know well that democracy requires not only strong institutions, legitimized by the vote, but civil society and non-governmental organizations that are capable of sustaining themselves in the face of any risk of persecution. And that is why the disaffection of this rise of populism, xenophobia and a decline in the values and essential pillars of European construction in particular in the younger generation must be combated with an instrument like this, an instrument that makes sense: the instrument supporting and supporting the essential values of the Union. But it must be complementary to existing funds in the Member States, from national funds, and should learn from the successful experience of funds already implemented, such as the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights, and above all it must be compatible with the moral, legal and political support that non-EU organisations deserve. governmental organizations who are at risk, for example that of Spanish volunteers Proem-Aid or Proactiva Open Arms, who risk criminal proceedings for sacrificing everything to save lives at sea. This is completely unacceptable. Not only financial support to non-governmental organizations, but also political and legal support to non-governmental organizations.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: Madam President! Do you know the word respect? Let me quote briefly: Latin respectus, “looking back, consideration, consideration”, also respecto, “look back, take into account”, refers to a form of appreciation, attention and reverence to another living being or an institution. I would like to ask the question: do we still have respect for other governments here in Europe? I tell you that we do not have to like the PiS party, Orbán, the Romanian Government or even the politically influenceable system of the judiciary in France, but we would do well to respect it. Unfortunately, this skill is lacking here in this house. This is a great pity, because this is anti-European, which is destroying Europe. My appeal is: let us have the courage again to be European, to trust ourselves, to talk to each other instead of about each other. I invite you to go out, risk an empty Parliament and meet the people again. I am doing this throughout the constituency of Germany, and it would be good for everyone here to listen to their nation states again.

name: Puhemies.
text: 'There are now two blue cards, Representative Zimmer and Representative in't Veld, but I'm afraid we need to save some time for the “catch the eye” floor. I'm sorry, but you know what's going to happen here at 10am when President Macron comes in. Now the last pre-requested intervention, Representative Carlos Coelho, a minute, please.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is clear that, throughout Europe, we have witnessed a deterioration in the core values of our Union: the rule of law, democracy or even fundamental rights. And this degradation is supported by fringes of the population, influenced by governments that seek only the internal market, not the Europe of values. It is clear that we are constantly in a process of continuing learning and improving the functioning of the European project and democratic systems. But at the same time, as we have repeatedly said and called for in this House, we cannot make a move on defending and promoting our founding values. Supporting those who promote these values in civil society and fight against populist derives is therefore vital. The Union's next financial framework must therefore provide for a budget line dedicated to financing these non-governmental organisations. Supporting the promotion of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights is to promote the European Union. Let us not be afraid to affirm what we believe and what we stand for. Thank you very much, Michał Boni.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: — Madam President, civil society is undoubtedly a project of European civilization, created centuries ago, which somehow played an important role in controlling those who had political power and administrative power. Today, through the resolution, we are trying to create an instrument to support, promote fundamental, universal values through NGOs, NGOs, NGOs. But I would like to draw attention to one thing: if non-governmental organisations, if civil society is excessively funded by the public funds granted by the policy, then there is a risk or fear that this civil society becomes dependent on this policy, become a parastate rather than represented the vitality of civil society. So we need to encourage that civil society organisations are financed from many parts, including by private capital, maetees and so on, of the economy.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: — Madam President, civil society is not opposed to political society. On the contrary, it must complement it for a living democracy. Citizens have the right and even a duty to express themselves on all matters affecting them. Unfortunately, there are a number of deviations in political developments both within and outside Europe. Indeed, civil society must have the means to resist these drifts. We must therefore help all these non-governmental structures to preserve democracy in Europe and, from this point of view, I naturally fully support the initiative. I would like to take this opportunity to recall the role of both the Committee of the Regions and the Economic and Social Council, which we must continue to finance properly. Finally, I would have liked the European parliamentary intergroups to receive specific funding because they are a forum for debate between parliamentarians and civil society.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: — Honourable Chair, civil society organisations in the vast majority of Member States are abundantly financed by taxpayer money. The fact that they receive large funding from the government calls into question their non-governmental character and independence in action. Such a model of civil society funding is the target of increasing criticism — a path unjustified, but very often justified. In some states governments really make it harder for civil society to work and that's for every condemnation. However, in the good part of Europe, organisations promoting what the EU institutions wholeheartedly support have simply lost public support and trust. Although they are still abundantly funded from budgets, their ideas and projects don't reach people. This instrument will only deepen this gap. Providing additional funding to associations out of taxpayer pockets with an instrument that cannot be influenced by citizens will strengthen distrust and resistance — both towards civil society but also towards the European Union. The end effect will be completely opposite to the one that is sought to achieve.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE).
text: Madam President, thank you Mrs Jourová for being here again today, for supporting this strengthening of civil society and, above all, for talking about fundamental rights and European values. I would like to recall today something that we should keep in mind every day, which is the right to truthful information that citizens have, citizens around the world, but above all European citizens. We will never be grateful enough to the President of Russia, to Putin, for having put this threat to the right to truthful information on our agenda, for having put into our concerns, this is one of the fundamental rights, which implies one of the basic freedoms, which is the freedom of press and freedom of expression. That is why I would like to thank all the movements and all the efforts on the part of the European Union to take this very seriously and to see that this is not just a threat to security, it is a threat to democracy, and that is why we must make every effort to insist on education.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Madam President! I would like to call for the immediate and mass protest of European taxpayers against this disgraceful initiative, the essence of which is as follows: they intend to destabilise Hungary and Poland by aligning European Union funds to, so to speak, non-governmental organisations with the obvious aim of undermining and smashing democratically elected governments, this is what we see in Hungary. The other target group is NGOs supporting mass migration, and they want to give money to them as well. We must protest, and I ask my fellow Members from the People's Party that if they do, anyone who hears what I am saying now will look at me and make eye contact. How will the People's Party vote on this issue? The whole of Europe is watching your future, which is decisive for the future of Europe. Very... (the President withdrew the floor from the representative)

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to say to Ms Morvai very directly that civil society is not the enemy. A civil society that is active and working effectively is a help and strength to democracy. This instrument is about making sure that NGOs can be organised and transparent in their work with the use of public funds: that is something that we should support. I think it is also really important to talk in this Chamber about values, because it seems to me that there are many, many different layers of values, but the European Union stands for very important ones: democracy, the rule of law and freedoms. The NGOs working in it work to those freedoms. Of course they irritate governments and political parties, but that is their job and that is their function. They are also effective in making us do our job more effectively. So I welcome this initiative, Commissioner, and I am looking forward to your response.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I will try to summarise my comments after this discussion in this vibrant European Parliament and in a rather competitive atmosphere. I want to say that by supporting civil society we are not promoting any specific ideology. We are upholding the values enshrined in the Treaty and in the Charter of Fundamental Rights. I speak about universal values and one speaker spoke about Japan and South Korea. I am negotiating with Japan, South Korea and the United States the issues of protection of privacy and I can tell you we are speaking here about individual freedoms, we speak about universal values. This must be emphasised. Many times I have received advice from many politicians saying that ‘if the people want to have a say, if they want to be heard, let them join political parties’ or ‘let them come once in four times to elections’, and – the advice continues – ‘be silent in the meantime’. That’s not my way of thinking because I think that the purpose of such advice is that a silent crowd is so easy to handle, and the EU doesn’t want to handle a silent crowd, we want active people. We do not fear active people in the EU. What we want to achieve with this special financial support is not the support of NGOs. We want to support civil society organisations working in specific fields of policy which cover discrimination, the rights of children, the fight against sexual violence and many other things which we frequently discuss here in this House. We share the view that we need the cooperation of civil society. This House is are right: the NGOs must remain independent. That’s why it is so important that the EU will not be and cannot be the only source of financial support. There must be a financial framework with multiple channels, and I am sure this will remain the case in the EU. So again my declaration today is that we are supporting it. We have to find the right process for such financing and I am ready to cooperate with the European Parliament on preparing the smart plan for this intention.

name: Puhemies. –
text: I have received a motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure. The vote will take place on Thursday, April 18, 2018. 1 See Minutes. Written statements (Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. — NGOs take the essence of the new instrument: EU funding for NGOs acting for fundamental values and the rule of law. According to this, the Union will take over the support of certain NGOs — but only those that, according to him, protect the undefined rule of law with sufficient vigour, attack democratically elected governments, want to even counteract with sufficient volume they support the will of the majority of democratic voters, or even an objective such as mass migration to the EU. According to the new instrument, from Brussels, they will tell from outside which NGOs are useful to the EU, from outside, which organisations are needed by voters at national or local level. That's absurd. What will the organisations funded by the EU be independent of? If the essence of NGOs is to build from the bottom up, it is reversed by the 'top-down' funding. Its independence is precisely the external EU funding of the selected NGOs, and the responsibility of the NGOs is therefore omitted. So this new instrument is taking the very essence of democracy. The fact that this debate was once again used by the Left to attack Hungary proves precisely that this instrument is not intended to be used for anything other than to legitimize the specific democratic interpretation of the Left.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. — Today we talked about the proposal to have a European instrument to finance and support civil society organisations promoting democracy, the rule of law and fundamental values within the EU. I believe that there is a need for a strong civil society, but that is equidistant and transparent in terms of activity and funding. That is why it is good to have a unified European instrument for measurement, evaluation and financing. At the same time, transparency from NGOs is needed, in terms of funding and activity, in order to credible them. We must not flee from the truth, we know that there are NGOs financed by other non-European countries in Europe, and we must ask ourselves what is best? Should we ensure transparent European funding for independent NGOs or should NGOs that fight to tear down democracy be funded? In democracy, we need strong institutions, but also a civil society with a high level of responsibility and civic education.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — Democratic fundamental values: the rule of law and fundamental rights cannot be taken into account even in the European Union, as shown by events in Hungary, Poland and Slovakia. In this situation, the EU has a duty to support civil society organisations, which represent citizens' universal rights and democratic values, in order to preserve fundamental values. It is not enough, however, to provide ad hoc support! There is a need for long-term support - budget-allocated and targeted - which reaches organisations in the Member States, including at local level. By doing so, we can directly help European citizens exercise their democratic rights and preserve the rule of law. I believe that these financial resources should be used primarily where they are most needed: in countries where fundamental rights and the bodies that enforce them are most vulnerable. Particular attention should be paid to the situation of the most vulnerable freedoms: the rights of children, minorities, freedom of speech and the press, and freedom of self-assembly. However, the provision of financial assistance is not a substitute for effective legal and political action by the Union institutions. We know that the European institutions cannot carry out the work of national governments and local governments and civil society organisations, but they can provide considerable financial and legal support.

name: Christine Revault d’Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: in writing. — Civil society organisations work for all European citizens, whether Hungarian, Polish, Greek, Romanian or French. In fact, they are trying to work for them because they are hampered by some governments that impose legal and financial restrictions on them or even threaten them. It is a policy that is damaging to them, and I am thinking especially of women, because organizations struggling for their rights are a prime target. A report by the European Agency for Fundamental Rights published in January 2018 tells: Polish authorities have attacked offices of women's organisations that have participated in anti-government protests, protests in favour of the right to abortion while the ruling party is trying to tighten one of the most important laws restrictive European policies in this area. To enable these organisations to continue to exist, the European Parliament proposes a new financial instrument enabling the European Commission to grant grants to organisations active in the defence of fundamental rights in Europe. This is a concrete demand, quickly achievable and can help millions of European citizens. The Commission cannot shirk when our core values are undergone.

name: Le Président. –
text: Mr President of the French Republic, dear Emmanuel, welcome to the European Parliament. Today is an important day: we have the opportunity to discuss with you the future of Europe, to listen to your ideas and proposals. I would like to thank you for your decision to participate in a real debate. Everyone knows the rules: the President of the Republic normally gives a solemn speech, but the President of the French Republic told me that he wanted to have a real debate with MEPs. That is why I thank you for having decided to discuss as President with us. Today, as a result of what has happened in Syria, we will also have a debate in the evening on the situation in the Middle East: Parliament is therefore looking forward to listening to you and discussing with you. I therefore thank you very warmly, once again, for being with us. You are in Strasbourg, in your country, where an event will take place on 1 June: thousands of young people will be in the European Parliament to discuss the future of Europe. I invite you to join us in discussing with these young people, since you are resolutely committed to trying to reduce the distance between institutions and citizens so that we can all work well together towards a stronger Europe closer to our fellow citizens. Thank you very much, Mr President, for being here with us.

name: Emmanuel Macron
text: President of the French Republic. — (FR) Mr President of the European Parliament, Mr President of the European Commission, Ministers, Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen. I am very happy and honoured to respond to your invitation on this day, Mr President, so that, as you have recalled at the moment, can freely discuss the situation in our Europe in a particular context. To discuss freely because the proposals and the speeches, I made them several months ago, especially at the Sorbonne, and it is this time of exchange that seems to me today indispensable in this place where you make our Europe live every day in its diverse sensitivities, its divergences and its convergences, by building the essential compromises that advance it. We will exchange our views in a particular context which, I believe deeply, makes our responsibility even greater. A context which is first and foremost one of divisions and, sometimes, doubts within Europe, a context where Brexit continues to be discussed and worked — I want here to welcome the work carried out for several months by Michel Barnier — but also that of a doubt that arises in many of our European countries and which, month after month, has been able to emerge sensitivities that call into question what sometimes seemed to be fundamental. A context in which a form of European civil war reappears, where our differences, sometimes our national selfishness, seem more important than what unites us in the face of the rest of the world. A context where the fascination — and I will return to it — illiberal grows every day. A context where geopolitical threats — and we will certainly return to it in the discussion — give Europe a greater responsibility every day. A context of major international conflicts, such as Levant or the Sahel, but also of the emergence of great authoritarian powers and a clearly elaborated strategy aimed at challenging the framework of multilateralism in which Europe had taken its full place, and which was also the framework of its influence, in which we had collectively built peace. Today we are debating at a time that is also the major transformations linked to digital technology, global warming and its consequences, which deeply question the foundations of the industrial society that founded our great compromises, give rise to fears, lead us to revisit some great balances and impose on us to rethink the action grammar that is collectively ours. Therefore, this moment gives us a special responsibility. We cannot act as if, in a way, our discussions were ordinary. This is the moment that separates us from the forthcoming European elections, where we will have to live our struggles for the ideals that have made us. To begin our discussion, I just want to share with you two strong convictions. The first is that if we decide to abandon our commitment to democracy and all that it carries in Europe, we will go wrong. The second is that, in this context, we can and must build a new European sovereignty through which we will provide a clear and firm answer to our fellow citizens that we can protect them and respond to these world disorders. (Applause) Indeed, in this world and at this difficult time, European democracy — I believe it very deeply — is our best chance. The worst mistake would be to abandon our model, I dare say, our identity. Here, in Strasbourg as in Brussels, you bring to life every day this democracy in Europe that Tocqueville spoke of. Our identity is first of all democracy that respects the individual, minorities, fundamental rights, what was called the name I still claim, liberal democracy. I do not want to let settle down this mortiferous illusion which, let us never forget it, here less than elsewhere, has pushed our continent into a chasm, this illusion of strong power, of nationalism and of the abandonment of freedoms. I reject this idea, which even reaches Europe, that democracy would be doomed to powerlessness. In the face of authoritarianism that surrounds us everywhere, the answer is not authoritarian democracy but the authority of democracy. (Applause) Because this freedom emancipates and protects the individual. A Parliament like yours, ours, is a European miracle. Peaceful gathering of the elected representatives of the peoples of Europe to deliberate together in their differences, strong and heavy in their history and in what has sometimes divided them, is a unique model in the world. This treasure, we have been making it live for seventy years. Let's not get used to it. We took every risk and went through the worst to get there. And if we want to be even more concrete, let's look around us, compare and sometimes look at those powers that can fascinate some with an alleged effectiveness. In which other place in the world do we have this same requirement, obviously in terms of economic, geopolitical, diplomatic and military matters, but also respect for minorities, freedom of conscience, equality between men and women, respect for privacy? Where else, at this point, with the same vitality and strength? So there are divisions between countries, within this Chamber itself, but beyond these divisions, this democratic model that brings us together is unique in the world. Europe's identity is more than a liberty-conscious democracy, it is a culture unique in the world that combines this passion for freedom, a taste for equality, attachment to the diversity of ideas, languages and landscapes. This European model is neither abstract nor dated. Today, it is embodied in our common commitment to the protection of the environment, climate and health. It is now developing in our approach to the digital revolution where only Europeans are so committed to freedom of innovation as well as to fair regulation and the protection of their privacy. This identity clearly distinguishes us from the authoritarian powers above all, but today, we must see it well, from some of the closest allies. Our American partner, with whom we share so much, today faces the temptation of disengagement and rejection of multilateralism, climate issues or trade issues. This model, I am convinced, is powerful as no other and fragile just as fragile because its strength at every moment depends on our commitment and our demand. Every day we have to defend him together. So, in order to live up to this commitment, the first condition is truth and responsibility. Some, blaming all our ills to an honest Europe, fleeing their own responsibilities, tell us with aplumb that the people no longer want Europe. They offer golden lanes. Sometimes we believe them. They then evade their responsibilities when they should lead their people to the end of this adventure. Others wisely argue that we should not hasten the steps so as not to abrupt the peoples, that it would be the game of the populists. They would like to get used to music that we know well, that sometimes paralysis, not becoming aware of the time that is ours. I believe that nothing is more wrong to say that it would be convenient, indeed, to dissolve the people or excite their passions in order to avoid proposing a path, to criticize without proposing, of destroying without rebuilding. It's not the people who abandoned the European idea, it is the betrayal of clerics that threatens it. We must hear the anger of the peoples of Europe today. It is not pedagogy that they need, but a new project, a requirement for daily efficiency, and those who trade in the anger they stirred, propose for the only future the endless path of returning to yesterday's nationalist tearing. We have experienced all the ways and consequences. In order to revive the people's Europe, we must therefore agree to act differently, drawing from the source of democracy. Let's look at things in the face: how can we be satisfied with European elections in which less than one citizen in two moves to vote? So, in the coming year, let us build the reality of a structured debate on convictions and proposals. Today we cannot do the same as yesterday, that is to say, refuse to talk about Europe, distribute places, blame Brussels or Strasbourg of all the evils. Continuing to do this is deciding to have a game of dupes that may be more comfortable for each of us, but that will not solve any problem. Like you, I believe in the nobility and complexity of democratic choice. As representatives of the peoples of Europe, you embody it. You make choices every day, you define compromises, you forge solutions, because you have received the mandate of the peoples, and our common duty is to bring this European democracy to life, which is so young. That is why, ahead of the elections and the time constrained for election campaigns, we must bring the debate to life, create this European public space which we have often left in the wasteland. It is in this spirit of experience and innovation that I proposed citizen consultations this year. I will launch this one in France this afternoon. A frank, open, rough and difficult debate, but indispensable to find out what brings together and separates, to get out of the simplistic alternative of yes or no to a question which is generally not considered presuppositions or implicit texts, and to have democratically a critical debate on our Europe. I am pleased that all Member States have agreed to share this approach. I know the commitment of President Juncker and the European Commission in this action and I want to thank him for that, and I also appreciate your essential role, Mr Tajani, in this exercise. I want to thank you too. I invite everyone in your countries and throughout Europe to animate and participate in these essential debates, because they are a condition for this democratic vitality. The second conviction that I want to quickly share with you is that of the necessary European sovereignty. To defend the European idea is not to defend an abstract idea, the dilution of our own sovereignties. No, it is to take note of the fact that, in the face of these great upheavals of the world, these great transformations, at this moment we are experiencing, we need sovereignty stronger than ours, complementary and no substitute which alone will allow, in the face of great migration, global insecurity and economic, social transformations and environmental issues, to provide the right answers. That is this European sovereignty in which I believe. (Applause) On this subject, you have done a lot and I want to congratulate you on it, but by the end of the legislature, in spring 2019, we need to achieve tangible results on several fronts: immigration, by unblocking the poisoned debate on the Dublin Regulation and relocations, but also by overcoming this debate, building the external and internal solidarity that our Europe needs. I propose to create a European programme which directly supports financially local authorities hosting and integrating refugees. (Applause) The second subject will be the taxation of digital technology following the Commission's proposal, by creating a short-term tax that puts an end to the most shocking excesses. I support this proposal. It is essential, and it will allow, I hope, to find ways of own resources for the upcoming budget. The reform of economic and monetary union is a third essential front before the end of this legislature by defining a roadmap for step-by-step progress on banking union and the establishment of fiscal capacity to promote stability and convergence in the euro area. Finally, what holds us together is not just a currency or a treaty, it is a sense of belonging, in other words a culture. And I could mention, because it is essential, the establishment of European universities that is actually progressing or the deployment of Erasmus, but here I want to stress one of your ongoing work, which I think is essential, that of copyright, the protection of creators and artistic creation. This abundance that infuses our societies is the broth of culture without which Europe would no longer be a continent of vital diversity and creative genius. (Applause) On these four fronts, this legislature has a special responsibility and you have understood what France's position will be. But beyond that, we must build this full European sovereignty to protect our fellow citizens. In the area of internal security, external security and defence, we have made a great deal of progress in recent months, and I welcome the work being done by this House on the European Defence Fund. Faced with all the tensions of the moment with some neighbours such as Russia, Europe has shown a face of unity and of sovereignty. We need to continue this work. Sovereignty is also economic and commercial. Here, too, we have shown this united face, and I welcome the progress made in recent months, at the initiative of the Commission, on economic and commercial sovereignty in defending our strategic investment sectors. These were essential advances in pursuing, in the commercial field — and we will certainly return to that in the debate — a united, voluntary position in terms of developing our economic opportunities but protecting our legitimate interests, both of our workers and our consumers. I believe in this economic sovereignty, which we must pursue through the competitiveness that each State builds through its reforms, by the indispensable solidarity that we must develop further within Economic and Monetary Union and by a more realistic trade policy. Sovereignty is also climate and energy sovereignty. It is indispensable. We will have to open the debate quickly to increase the European contribution under the Paris Agreement. We are in the process of completing discussions on the energy and climate package, but it is clear that we will have to open a new stage. Several of you have already committed themselves to this, and I hope that in the coming months we can reopen the debate on a carbon floor price. France will push the idea of a minimum price and France will support the idea of a border tax on CO2. It is neither a technical lubie nor a technical instrument, it is the condition for a credible energy transition. The fourth sovereignty that we must carry further is that of health and food. In our daily policies, in our budget choices of today and tomorrow, we must support food sovereignty of quality. That is what our fellow citizens expect from us, that is what we owe them. It is good for our economies and territory, it is good for our fellow citizens and it is a choice consistent with our long-term commitments. The fifth sovereignty we must defend is, of course, digital sovereignty. Here I would like to commend your work that has led to the elaboration of what appears today in all international debates as the reference legislation, the one that protects the personal data of our fellow citizens. Where others considered us to be those who, in a way, offered illegitimate protections, we are becoming the unique geographical space in the world where we promote innovation and breakthrough innovation — I will defend these choices in future debates — and at the same time we are building ourselves in the capacity to protect individual freedoms. Finally, this Europe of freedom and equality is based on a foundation of social values that we proclaimed together in Gothenburg. This social Europe is also the one of sovereignty, of this foundation in which we believe. There are differences, but we must not feed differences. The very meaning of the European adventure is that of increased convergence. That is why we have fought with many to regulate the seconded work in recent months. The European Parliament has made it possible to further improve the compromise reached in the Council and I am delighted that this reform will soon be successful, and I would like to welcome the work that has been carried out. This is precisely the image of a protective and effective Europe. We must continue to build these European sovereignties. They must be at the heart of a coherent project and must nurture the philosophy of the forthcoming multiannual financial framework, and I want to conclude my remarks on this point. This budget, which we are going to discuss, must to express a political project of coherence, efficiency and convergence. France is ready to increase its contribution, but to that end, it is a refoundation of the budget itself that must be envisaged by creating new own resources, I am in favour of it, on the digital and on certain energy resources, by removing the rebates that cannot survive Brexit, by dignified financing European action by defence and migration, modernizing current policies and defining conditionalities, I would say rather, criteria for fiscal and social convergence. We must not deny any ambition of existing policies, but we must add the new ambitions we carry. It is in this sense, in any case, that France will work in the coming months. (Applause) As you will have understood, ladies and gentlemen, the European Parliament is, in my view, the seat of European legitimacy, its responsibility and thus its vitality. It is here that part of the future of Europe is played, Europe as a gathering of our sovereignties, by and with an even greater sovereignty, the one that unites us, this Union in the service of peace and solidarity offering the world a unique space of stability and security. It is here that we must anchor the rebirth of a Europe driven by the very minds of its peoples. I hope that, in the coming months, we will succeed in overcoming the divides between North and South, East and West, small or large, and the decline in national selfishness. I belong to a generation that has not experienced war. I belong to a generation that is offering themselves the luxury of forgetting what our predecessors have experienced. There are many who today believe that we can continue to prefer the usual confrontations, the certainties of yesterday because we have become accustomed to them, the divisions well known and well concerted. But I also come from a land and a family that have experienced all the bloodings of our past history. So the choices are simple. I don't want to belong to a generation of sleepwalkers. I do not want to belong to a generation that has forgotten their own past or who will refuse to see the torments of their own present. Everyone, in times that open, will take responsibility, but I want to belong to a generation that has decided firmly to defend its democracy because it is not a word that no longer dirty or to which we have become accustomed to or to which we have been alanguished, it is a word that makes sense because it is the fruit of past battles. I want to belong to a generation that will defend this European sovereignty because we fought to have it, because it makes sense and because it is the condition that will allow future generations to choose their own future at that time. I will not give in to any fascination with authoritarian sovereignties, I will not give in to any ease of the present times, but I think that together, our responsibility in the coming months is to organise the real European debate, to have the real European deadlines which alone will allow our peoples to choose those who want a Europe that no longer proposes, those who want a Europe of withdrawal, those who want a Europe of habit or those who are ready to carry a Europe of ambition, of reinvented sovereignty, of a living democracy, the one in which we believe.

name: Le Président. –
text: Thank you very much, Mr President.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. — (FR) Mr President of Parliament, Mr President of the Republic, I strongly agree with what the President has just said. The President of the Republic and you, Mr President of Parliament, have hoped for a male and manly dialogue between the President of the Republic and the European Parliament. I therefore take the floor without abusing it. First of all, I wanted to say, as a Luxembourger who I am and European that I want to be, all my emotion and friendship to see the President of the Republic express himself in the way he expressed himself. Real France is back! (Strong applause) We, Luxembourgish, with the immodesty that characterizes us, we usually say that Luxembourg is the small France of abroad. I therefore welcome France's return to us and I would like to tell you that your election, Mr President, and your election campaign have given Europe new hopes. I hope that your ambition during the election campaign and in the aftermath of the presidential events will be crowned with success. You can count on the Commission to support you in your approach and I hope that, as is already the case today, a genuine complicity in ambitions between the President of the French Republic and the Commission will be established. As you have shown this on many occasions, you were among those who supported all the Commission's efforts to make social Europe, not a poem, not a dream, but a reality of today and tomorrow. Let others follow you in this ambition, which is also ours! You were alongside the Commission when it came to reviving investment Europe, the Juncker Plan — as it was called at the time — today's EFSI, led to the mobilization of €273 billion in the field of investment. of investments, 41 of which are in France. This joint joint approach, which was ours, is therefore producing results. I would like you to continue to co-lead the European struggle for commercial sovereignty. With regard to international trade policy, I do not want to see this sad spectacle of a Europe offered. I would like Europe to remain open but not a Europe offered. We have common interests to defend, particularly in the steel industry, among others. I would like to see together to ensure that this gap, which often divides Europe between East and West, is bridged by a renewed common ambition. I believe that the fate of Europe is not written by dividing and rising against each other. Europe is a whole. (Applause) I know the importance you attach to Franco-German friendship, and I am geographically and historically very much in favour of many rapprochements between these two countries and these two nations. However, let us not forget that Europe is not only Franco-German. We are 28, tomorrow 27: it is also necessary, for the engine to operate, the contribution of others. We are 27 and not only French or German. (Applause) I would like our radar of the future to continue to signal the plight of the peoples of the Balkans. I would like to recall the European perspective that we proposed to the countries of the Western Balkans in 2003 in Greece, in Thessaloniki, a city that I like, since I had the honour of being a Doctor Honoris Causa of the University of Thessaloniki. So I am deeply attached to this city, for reasons not only historical, but also personal. In 2003, we decided to give a credible European perspective to the countries of the Western Balkans. I am aware of all the difficulties on this subject which the Commission is going to discuss today, with Federica Mogherini and others. I am not naive, I am aware of the difficulties, the efforts that the countries of the Western Balkans must make, of the need to improve the performance of certain countries in the Western Balkans in some respects, but if we take away from these countries, in this extremely complicated region — I should say tragic — the European perspective, let us relive what we experienced in the 1990s. I don't want a return from the war in the Western Balkans! We will have to focus on this ambition. (Applause) Finally, I support the initiative of the President of the Republic to launch this citizens' dialogue. This is in fact an extension of a Commission initiative, which we call the Citizens' Dialogues. I have taken part in many of these dialogues, and we have conducted more than 500 of them in all the Member States of the European Union. I encourage the President of the Republic, the French Government and the Minister for European Affairs to make this a major event, not only in France but throughout Europe. Europe deserves a thorough democratic debate. Actually, tomorrow's story is written today. I wish we could write it together. (Vivid applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: I am now going to close the electronic recording system for catch-the-eye requests. The debate will take place as follows: now representatives will speak on behalf of the groups, then President Macron will have the opportunity to respond to the first speeches. Catch-the-eye interventions will then follow. I pray everyone to stick to the allotted time to give as many MPs as possible to intervene. I remind you that the votes will take place at 1 p.m.

name: Manfred Weber
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the European Parliament, this House, has waited a long time for a pro-European French President like Mr Macron. President Macron, my Group is glad to have you here. France is a proud country, but you know France can only be strong if Europe is strong. You spoke today about the values of Europe, about our common union of values. And you are right, secondly, to convince Europeans it is important that Europe must deliver – protect our borders, stabilise our euro, fight against terrorism, common defence, fair taxation – the list is long and you can rely on the PPE as a strong partner in this agenda. Concrete projects and values: this has always been the approach for convincing people about Europe over the last decades. So why, today, is Europe under so much pressure and even in crisis? My answer is: people do not feel involved. The reality is that they still see Europe as an external power and not as their own project. The key question for the future of Europe is: who has the power? The people in Europe, or some elite groups? To answer this question we do not have to invent anything new. We simply have to practise what is the essence of Europe, what has been fought for over generations with blood, sweat and tears; we must dare to practise parliamentary democracy in the future. You spoke about democracy. I want to be a little bit more precise. What makes parliamentary democracy such a strong force? It gives people a say and brings them together. When my voice matters, I care, I engage, I belong, and I am willing to work for a greater common good. And what if my voice does not count? Then it starts to feel like this is not my Europe. This is visible everywhere today: in newspaper headlines, in Facebook comments and in voting turnout.  When you lose people, you lose Europe. It is good to knock on the doors of Europeans and ask for their opinion on Europe, and many Members of this European Parliament are doing this on a daily basis; to speak, to convince, to discuss with Europeans. But it makes, in the end, a big difference, and you know this: to simply stand in front of people and ask them their opinion (afterwards you can care or not), or whether you stand in front of people and ask for their vote, because then the people have the power. That is why we need parliamentary democracy. And now to be more precise. True democracy does not work just during the meetings of the Heads of State or Government. Too often, they postpone their decisions, too often, they only look at who is the loser, who is the winner, and tomorrow’s headlines at home. True democracy does not mean decisions are taken behind closed doors. True democracy means more than just a meeting – and Jean-Claude Juncker has already said this – between Angela Merkel and Emmanuel Macron: the Franco—German axis is important but it is not Europe. Europe is much, much, much, much more. (Applause) True democracy does not mean denying responsibility. Leaders and national ministers cannot keep blaming and shaming Brussels for their own decisions, and true democracy does not mean dividing us into good and bad Europeans. I respect the will of the voters in every Member State, whether it pleases me or not.  So what is true democracy? President Macron, just take a look around here. The Chamber of the European Parliament is the right place to discuss this. Every citizen is given a voice here. You can find Communists, you can find Conservatives, Christian Democrats, Liberals, Greens, Social Democrats and even right-wing extremists. Some people call this old Europe: I call this democratic Europe, where people recognise themselves, with their concerns and needs, with their different views and with their representatives. The European Parliament is the political landscape of our continent and they can be proud of this.  There is no vote on a President of Europe, there is no European-wide referendum. There is simply only one event where all Europeans together are asked for their opinion on Europe. Political issues in Europe must be in the hands of the voters during the European elections, just as national interest issues are in the hands of voters during national elections. And for the same reason, the European Parliament is the only place to elect and to control the European executive bodies – the Commission, or, as I call it, the government of Europe.  This is why the people must be given the right to decide who will become the next President of the European Commission.
