Candidates must stand for election, must defend their programme, explain to people what they stand for and, finally, they have to look for the support of a majority of this Chamber of freely-elected Members of the European Parliament.  (Applause) This is how the German Bundestag works. This is how the Spanish Cortes works, this is how the Polish Sejm works. It is simply parliamentary democracy in practice, which gives the power to the people.  And let’s call a spade a spade. Not a college, but a government; not a Commissioner, but a Minister; not a regulation, but a law; it would make things understandable for people if we were to do so. And those who want to become a Commissioner next year should probably run in the European elections. Let the people decide who the government should send to the Commission next year.  Other elements are equally important. A true democracy can only survive if it has common basic convictions. There is no French, German or Croatian way of life, there is only a European way of life, and we can be proud of this fundament. It is unique in the world.  A true democracy in Europe also means believing in a vision. Politicians like Kohl, Delors and Mitterrand have made the impossible possible because they followed their European dream. But again, the key question for true democracy is: when this Parliament decides to freeze the negotiation process with Turkey, then the process has to be really frozen. When this Parliament is deciding about strengthening the external border, then Frontex officers have to be sent to the external border, and when this Parliament decides to introduce free interrail passes, then the project has to see the light of day. So the people of Europe must decide – and we are representatives of the people of Europe – about the future of the European project. If we ignore the European people, the people will ignore us, and that is what we are facing sometimes today.  So let us rebuild Europe as the most successful form of government ever invented by man: a parliamentary democracy. And I know this idea is not welcomed by everybody, but we have to overcome our trauma. Since 2005 we have been discussing more about red lines and not enough about ambitions. The French say no more Treaty change, the Germans say no more money, the Central Europeans say no more Brussels. I tell you, my main fear is not another Brexit; my main fear is a frightened Europe, and we will not be able to cope with the next crisis if we go on with this, so let’s start now.  Today we have the President of France with us. With his forward-looking approach for Europe we can achieve a lot. The PPE is ready to work for a democratic Europe with ambitious projects, but in the end the people are the owners of the European dream and the European future.  As a young student, I was very much marked by the history of the ‘Weisse Rose’. Young people, students in Munich – the youngest was Sophie Scholl, 22-years-old – were arrested by the Gestapo in February 1943. They had used flyers to call for resistance against the Nazis. I quote from one of their flyers: ‘The imperialist idea of power must be disarmed whatever side it comes from, for all time. [...] Only with generous cooperation between the peoples of Europe will it be possible to create the ground on which a new construction is possible. [...] Freedom of speech, freedom of confession, protection of individual citizens from the arbitrariness of violent criminal states, these are the foundations of a new Europe.’ In Munich 1943, four young people were executed for these ideas. This has always motivated me to carry on their dream, dear friends. (Applause) And I am sure they would be proud of what has been achieved during the last decades, a Europe of peace and freedom. And the task of my generation now is to build up a real democratic Europe, but the future is in the hands of the people of this continent, a true parliamentary democracy for Europe. Let us begin. (Loud applause)

name: Udo Bullmann
text: on behold of the S&D Group. — Mr President, I would like to welcome President Macron on behold of the Socialists and Democrats. In these days where the enemies of Europe, those who would like to fight the European project, shout out their hate, and in these days where fake news is going whole countries, we need to certify and to reconfirm that we need this united Europe and we need a strong Europe. Somebody like you, President Macron, having dedicated his own faith to his commitment on Europe, is very warmly welcomed in this House. Thank you for your courage. Thank you for your pro-European stance. We need that and we would like to see more leaders doing the same. Just look at the slaughtering in Syria and what happened over the weekend. but, please, this is a real case for a unified Europe. This is a real case for strengthening the European institutions. This is a real case for strengthening Federica Mogherini, the High Representative, the United Nations and António Guterres. So please work in that direction. More is Needed Than the Action of Member States. Look at the Facebook scandal. Look at the situation in Europe and world-wide. Data protection is at the top of the agenda today. but, just as we need European institutions to strengthen our foreign policy, we need European legislation. Facebook needs European legislation. Facebook urgently needs the community method and our group, the Socialists and Democrats, proudly lead on e—privacy and on general data protection. Please support us in the Council. And now, forgive me, when I start to talk about the relationship between Paris and Berlin, I feel tempted to switch to my native tongue. Mr. President, who do you want to work with? Who is your partner? It is true that we sing the Beethoven anthem — the European anthem. But it's not enough to step off red carpets and sing the anthem. We have to make our dream come true, and incidentally, when we talk about history in Germany talk: Friedrich Schiller, who wrote the text on this magnificent European anthem, did it against German small-state affairs, against the Napoleonic Wars and at a time when the liberals were just about to discover that their idea of human freedom is only in a society of the same, only in a society of the same brotherhood and sisterity can become a reality. If we ask ourselves today, “Where is the situation in Europe? “, let's go back to the roots. If this European idea of universal freedom saddles people because it does not create a world of brotherhood and sisterity, then the axe is placed on the European project, and that is why we have difficulties today, and we must remember this in order to overcome it. So again the question: who do you want to work with? You have difficult days ahead of you. “Madame No” in Berlin has already shown how difficult it will be to reform the Economic and Monetary Union, and the many small mini-Schäubles that are already positioning themselves in the German Bundestag on the occasion of the debates today in the German Bundestag will not make business easier for you. (Interjections and applause.) What story do we learn? It's not internationality. No, you need a strong European Commission. You need a strong European Commission, supported by a strong European Parliament. This is the only way will economic and monetary union progress, and that is what the European Socialists and Democrats stand for. If you are looking for an intergovernmental project with Berlin, I have a suggestion: go to Angela Merkel and tell her: “Look, Angela, you are drastically reducing the use of coal and I drastically reduce the use of nuclear power.” sustainable development could serve the European Union. (Applause) You have chosen the right slogan: Europe is about protecting our people. Europe must protect its people. But why, then, do you block the work-life balance package in the Council? We fought for this package, and we want the mother to be able to come back after the baby break and decide for herself when she is in the family and when she is in the workplace. This is an important thing that we can move forward together. Why are we blocking the financial transaction tax when it comes to justice? (Applause) Why can we no longer make up for a European corporation tax if we want to tax large corporations? And last but not least: Europe's dignity decides when dealing with refugees. Are you sure that what is being done in France at the moment is in line with the size of the nation and the European dignity? I have question marks. Social Democrats have been fighting for more than 150 years — for more than 150 years! — for a united Europe and for a Europe of solidarity. This is not always the Europe of red carpets, but this is certainly the Europe of schools and universities, workshops and marketplaces. I believe, Mr President, that you have to decide: if you want to be with the people, you will find friends in my group. But that must then become a reality in our common concrete policy. We wish you luck, but we also wish you to make the right choice! (Applause)

name: Syed Kamall
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would like to welcome President Macron. The European Conservatives and Reformists (ECR) Group welcomes a leader with a bold vision and a desire to shake things up, for too many national politicians praise the idea of ever-closer union when in Brussels or in Strasbourg, but when they return home their support for the European project of further political integration becomes a barely audible whisper.  Monsieur le Président, what you say in Paris is what you have said here in Strasbourg, and that is to be respected, but when it comes to your desire to reform the European Union, the ECR Group agrees with the objective but I am afraid the devil is in the detail.  Whilst we share your commitment to strong transatlantic relations, cutting red tape to help businesses create jobs, and the need for closer security cooperation, your vision of a European Union with a bigger budget, harmonised corporate taxes, unified social policy, a common asylum system and a European Minister for Finance may be the right vision for France, but the ECR Group feels it is not the right vision for all Member States.  While there will be many in this Chamber who see you as a saviour of the European project of political integration, many outside this Chamber do not want to see an EU dominated by just one or two large Member States. They want national leaders to find common solutions which are agreeable to all Member States, but what you propose, Monsieur le Président, is revolutionary. But rather than sleepwalking – to use your phrase – towards your goal, it should be presented to voters across the EU, with an honest disclaimer, in large letters, bold and underlined, that Member States will become less and less sovereign as the EU becomes more and more sovereign, as you wish to see.  All politicians need to be careful. You talk about temporary taxes but I am reminded of Ronald Reagan’s line that there is nothing more permanent than a temporary government programme. The growing dissatisfaction amongst voters has not been because the EU has too little power, but because it has too much. Despite this power, it has failed to secure the greater stability and prosperity that was promised. Countries signed up for cooperation in key areas of mutual interest with their EU neighbours, not to see more and more decisions made in one city on the other side of the continent.  Mr Macron, we understand why you are seeking to regain the initiative. My Group agrees that the European Union has drifted for far too long, but by returning to the 1950s agenda of political integration you may be in danger of ignoring those who want the EU to face the challenges of the 2050s, not the 1950s. That is why the ECR Group believes that the EU should facilitate nations to cooperate where necessary, but return powers to Member States and local communities in areas such as immigration and social policy. But when countries do agree that an EU solution is the best solution, all countries should stick to the rules and not pick and choose, as we saw with the Stability and Growth Pact or with the Dublin Regulation on asylum.  The ECR Group believes that common sense and proportionate regulation, rather than more political integration, will allow businesses, farmers, fishermen and entrepreneurs to compete in global markets, but we also ask for more honesty. We ask that richer eurozone governments be honest with their voters that their taxes will be transferred to the budgets of poorer eurozone countries, possibly forever, for that is the way that currency and sustainable currency unions work. Like your movement, Mr Macron, the ECR was established to offer an alternative to the longstanding and stale political establishment in the EU. We have appreciated your honesty about your ambitions here today. While I may be one of a number of MEPs who will not return to this Chamber after the 2019 elections, the ECR Group will continue to fight for a vision of a reformed European Union. We will continue to oppose calls for ever more political integration, but where there is common ground the ECR Group hopes to work with you to shape a reformed European Union which respects all Member States and their citizens. Let me just end on a more personal note. As our two nations, the UK and France, work together with the US in Syria, supported by our European and international partners, can I thank you for your cooperation and hope that our countries will continue to act as partners where it is in our interests to face global challenges together.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (FR) Mr President, Mr President of the Republic, ladies and gentlemen, I want to start where Mr Kamall has finished his speech and I would like to repeat in your presence what I said yesterday in this very Chamber of the European Parliament, namely that we fully support the military action that has been carried out in Syria by France and other allies. It must be said, ladies and gentlemen, because a regime that uses chemical weapons against its own population is a genocidal and illegitimate regime. That is the reality that must be acknowledged. (Applause) But it must also be said, Mr President, that this intervention demonstrates our weakness because it is France that intervenes, it is the United Kingdom that comes in and launches missiles, it is not the European Union. Sixty-five years after the National Assembly torpedoed the European Defence Community — we tend to forget — the European army still does not exist. It must also be said, ladies and gentlemen, that our foreign policy is also occasionally an illusion because of our lack of unity, because of this unanimity rule that still exists to date for the Union's foreign policy, which is an aberration and which must be put to an end. This weakness, let us admit, is not only about our external action. You used the word “paralysis” in your intervention. A paralysis is declared at the internal level, let's say it. When a country like the United Kingdom leaves the European Union, it is difficult to say: “Ah, what a success!”. Moreover, there are, of course, authoritarian drifts in Poland and, above all, in Hungary. Ladies and gentlemen, in a recent report on the Hungarian elections, the OSCE speaks of “intimidating and xenophobic rhetoric”, “media bias” and “opaque electoral financing”. These are almost the same terms, word for word, that in the comments made by the OSCE during the election of Putin. It must be clear: in my opinion, there is no place and there will never be room for illiberal states in our Union. Freedom of expression, the rule of law, legality before the law are not only liberal principles derived from the Enlightenment, but also and above all European values. Something needs to be done in this regard. At the moment, we do nothing strictly. I was touched, Manfred Weber, by the words you used, by this pamphlet written by these young people in 1943, murdered by the Gestapo. You have gone to the heart of the existence of the European Union and it is, in any case, better than sending telegrams of congratulations to Mr Orbán. That is the reality. (Applause) I think, Mr President, that it is this refusal to tackle aberrations in Hungary, this inability to act in the major conflicts in our neighbourhood, this inability to respond to migratory flows — let us say it, because that is the reality of today! — which also affects our economy. The Americans, during the 2008 financial crisis, responded in nine months with a plan to clean up the banks, with investments of $2,500 billion — in nine months and with two different administrations, one Democrat and the other, Republican! What about us after nine years? After nine years, we have not yet cleaned all our banks, we do not yet have our banking union, we have not yet created the new governance of the euro area. I am therefore strongly afraid — I will say this very openly here — that Europe is not ready for the moment if tomorrow — hopefully this will not happen, of course — a new financial crisis is triggered. We must ask ourselves in this debate, Mr President, why? What is not working in the Union? Why, in the European Union, is it always too late, too soft, too weak? It must be said and acknowledged: it is the intergovernmental system with, at its core, this foundation of unanimity that is doomed to failure and inertia in this world which is constantly moving faster and faster. It must be added — we have already talked about this during the debate — the binary political system that governs the Union and which, from the beginning, is gone. It is not only about the two major traditional parties in this chamber — I will not say any harm to them, they are our colleagues — but also, we have already talked about it, about the Franco-German axis. It must still be said: he is not in good shape at the moment. Make no mistake: I am in favour of having a very good relationship with Mrs Merkel, but of course, the future and the next Europe cannot depend solely on the 'random agreement' between two Heads of State. We need a lot more! Let us face it, the Eurosceptics — there are a number of them here and you will hear them after our speeches, because at the moment you listen to the good part of the speeches — are not always wrong, naturally, let us admit it. It must be recognised that a large majority of our fellow citizens — as you said — are exasperated by the inertia of the Union at the moment. As you said, the problem of citizens is not the European Union, but the way we manage the European Union. You saw right in your speech at the Sorbonne. The solution to break this inertia is not to break Europe, but it is to reinvent it, to redesign it, I would say. You said — and you have said here today — that true sovereignty is European. I must say that it is very courageous of you in a country that has always thought “long live Europe, as long as it is French!” — which was still a bit of the feeling in France. What is important in this debate, Mr. President, is that you have broken up with what i call a platitude, you did something incredible: you convinced the french during the election that a nation is not sovereign when it withdraws on itself, but when society and its citizens regain power over their own lives, over their own destiny. You convinced the French — and certainly this chamber — that for this we need a new European project, a transnational project with a pan-European impetus. I encourage you to persevere because the conservative forces in Europe are still powerful. Too many say “Let's stay on the status quo, nothing should be done! Keeping power is actually more important than exercising it!” Between us, I sometimes feel that compared to conservatives in Europe, even SNCF is a stronghold of reformers. Do not hesitate, do not abdicate: after 2019, you will find another European Parliament, with many more people who will support you, a “Europe” generation that demands boldness! When I talk about boldness, I always end, Mr President, with Danton, who said: 'Boldness, boldness, still bolding'... and Europe will be saved! (Vivid applause)

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (FR) Mr President, it is good that France is back. Its European headquarters had been physically occupied but politically empty for too long. Certainly, Europe cannot be neither French nor German, but it cannot build anything in the long term unless it can count on the resolute commitment of Germany and France. A France that could, if it really wanted, embody within its borders the European motto of unity in diversity. Mr President, your ambition for Europe overlaps in many respects with the long-standing struggles that we regionalists and ecologists have been leading. We are convinced, like you, that Europeans must act together if they are to meet the challenges of this century. This is where the key to our true sovereignty lies. We share your willingness to build a political union that gives back the voice to the citizens, who must be at the heart of the European project, not on the margins. Like you, we want to give a future to our common currency, which requires, in fact, a robust investment budget, a common guarantee of bank deposits, but also an end to tax competition and social dumping. Finally, we are with you to say: “Make our planet great again”. As we know, and you know, Europe must be at the forefront of the ecological transition, starting with its budget, which must be the instrument of it. Ecology is the key to our prosperity. Mr President, what you want for Europe, you say that France must start doing so itself today. Yet, your action in France tells a whole different story, a story that underlines your country's motto: freedom, equality, brotherhood. Where is freedom when your citizens can be under arrest, house arrest and searches on mere police suspicions? Where is freedom, when armed police arrive in the early morning to arrest a group of young people whose only harm would be to have peacefully occupied a construction site? My daughter was part of that group. She was taken in front of her two-year-old son, far from home, to undergo an interrogation for a whole day. In your France, the rule of law, guarantor of our freedoms, is moving away day after day. Freedom, equality. Where is equality when you impose more precariousness on workers while at the same time, you make tax gifts to the richest, the ones you like to call the first of rope? Your faith in them is unshakable. But, you see, what defines the rope, Mr. Macron, is the rope. It is it that allows to adapt the speed of the first rope to the needs of the group. It is also the one that prevents the last rope from falling into the ravine. But in our societies, Mr President, this rope no longer exists: the rich are getting rich, the middle classes stagnate and become precarious, and the most fragile ones are abandoned to their fate. Freedom, equality, fraternity. Is it in the name of brotherhood that you sell weapons to regimes that return them against their own population or against their neighbours? Where is this fraternity, when your police lacks tents and sleeping bags of migrants? Expeditious procedures, non-suspensive remedies, administrative detentions are the ingredients of your Asylum and Immigration Bill. Contain and repress rather than welcoming human beings in forced exodus. Freedom, equality, fraternity. In the country of the climate agreement, I will add a fourth term, namely “sustainability”. You say you want the carbon tax, the end of glyphosate, the end of diesel cars, bravo! But at the same time, you remain an ardent promoter of the current free trade treaties and, worse, nuclear power. You have allowed, unlike your predecessor, the adoption by the European Union of a completely lax definition of endocrine disruptors. Certainly, you had the courage to put an end to this senseless airport project in Notre-Dame-des-Landes, but it is to crush in violence the projects of those who have invented for years a different way of life. Mr President, a book tells you a philosopher. He says that none of your words is the result of chance. A few months ago, you talked about “successful people” and “people who are nothing.” You did not say “people who do nothing” or “people who have nothing,” you talked about “people who are nothing”. You see, for us, the European project is precisely to ensure that never again, in any part of this continent, no woman or man can be considered “nothing” or think of themselves as “nothing”, because to consider human beings as “nothing” means allowing them to suffer anything, and that we will never accept it. (Applause) Mr President, you have become a habit of giving a gift to your distinguished guests. Allow me to do the same. I offer you this climbing rope, symbol of the rope you seem to hold on. I tell you this: whenever you advance the cause of freedom, equality and fraternity in Europe, whenever you act for a more just, more sustainable and democratic Europe, we will be at your side. Otherwise, you will find us on your way. (Applause)

name: Patrick Le Hyaric
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Mr President of the Republic, welcome. It is difficult to understand your concept of sovereign Europe at the very moment when you made the decision to bomb sites in Syria, outside the framework of European discussions, without a UN mandate and with Mr Trump and Mrs. May as the sole alliance. No matter how unbearable, condemnable and abject the use of chemical weapons by the dictatorial regime in Damascus may be, you cannot be free from the framework of international law. Even the September 2013 resolution against Syria obliges it under Chapter VII of its Charter, which expressly mentions that the decision falls within the purview of the Security Council. What is serious and worrying here is twofold. If our country produces acts that in fact violate international law, then we are paving the way for the law of the world jungle. On the other hand, why double standards? On the one hand, the readiness to bomb in Syria without waiting for the conclusions of the expert mission when Israel, with impunity, kills in Gaza, when Turkey grabbed Afrin and when Yemen is shelled in total silence. We would grow to work on a project for a peace and co-development conference between Europe and the Near and Middle East, including recognition of the State of Palestine. If your citizens' consultation project was intended only to oppose those who would be for a European integration and those who would be against them, I believe we would be in a mortiferous trap. There is another far more productive path, that of a progressive, social, democratic and ecological transformation of the European project, that is, the modern and new way of a union of nations and associated peoples, free and sovereign. The word “refounding” should not hide the forward, ultraliberal, austeritary and ademocratic flight, the very one that causes in all Europe a huge anger, which you talked about. In France, the bustling of employees, pensioners, job deprived of employment, those whose lives are precarious or even crushed comes from more than a decade of austerity, while large companies generate profits and tax evasion is breaking records. For Europe to protect them, we must end this old dogma of competition, which allows social and fiscal dumping, promotes relocations, lowers levels of remuneration for work and destroys public services. It is solidarity Europe that we should invent. Let us carry out an innovative act for all European citizens, that of social security at work combined with the necessary training to ensure a higher harmonization of wages and the right to housing for all. Europe does not protect when it goes ahead of these free trade treaties that destroy our social, health and environmental standards. Let us invent equal exchange and cooperation instead of this economic war, a new agricultural and food policy that secures our peasants and food quality, a mercy fight against tax evasion and tax havens, and the taxation of financial transactions. A Europe that protects would be one that would no longer let refugees sink into the sea and stumble on walls but would reach out for asylum, as proposed by a report by this Parliament which could also be used by your Minister of the Interior. To protect workers and peoples, for sovereignty, it is necessary to have the courage to emancipate oneselF from the dominance of financial markets and to invent new mechanisms to cancel illegitimate debts, renegotiate others and to give ourselves the means to effectively mobilize the enormous sums of money created by the Central Bank for the economy of the future: public services, environmental and digital transition through the creation of a fund for human, social and environmental development. Such a fund would also be a very good tool to undo our SNCF debt, to carry out a common project for freight in Europe at the service of the climate, it could also be a tremendous lever for launching a large European digital company to emerge from North American domination. In fact, Mr President of the Republic, the time has probably come to ask the question of revolutionizing the construction of Europe with and for the peoples.

name: Florian Philippot
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (FR) Mr President, Mr President of the Republic, I have far too much respect for your role to welcome the exercise you are taking before this House which plays in Parliament — because it is not a Parliament and there is no single European people to represent — and which is which was largely acquired in Brussels, where we dislike when we talk about peoples and where one likes when communicated in the European religion. You have come to please: to please the powerful, as you always knew how to do; please the richest, who can now, in your own words, fend themselves on their own, exonerating themselves from their duty of solidarity with the nation; to please the givers of professional lessons, to those who have long confiscated power and have turned the back to the peoples. Your jury is here, in the ranks of the European Commission, and it is he who assesses you every day and it is he who, today, will put you a note. Rest assured, your rating will be excellent because your speech has unsurprisingly resumed all the canons of European catechism. Your jury gives you a good point when you talk about European sovereignty, a way of undermining national sovereignty, the only one that is worth democracy. Your jury gives you its encouragement when you endorse its agenda: liberalization, destruction of public services, total opening of borders in defiance of senseless migratory risks and terrorist risk, ideological condemnation of any form of commercial protection. Today, it is true, you have little missed the congratulations of the jury, because you have spoken for once in French, while, more and more often, in your public expression, you are abandoning the language of Molière and the Francophonie to the benefit of Anglo-American. But, rest assured, you stay darling of the Commission. You are so good pupil, so well applied to the policy of the Commission and the lobbies that you have already joined Tony Blair and Matteo Renzi as the Brussels whooping cough. And, like them, you are doomed to promise to reform the European Union, but you are already disappointing because it is irreformable by construction. Mr President of the Republic, you have already failed on the seconded work and on glyphosate. That's why I'm sad. Leading an old nation like France is too noble a function for it to spoil in this Star Academy of fading stars of the European flag where everyone scrolls like a vulgar pupil. Mr President of the Republic, do not wade in the croupy waters of technocrats and lobbies. The world here is already the old world. The world of tomorrow is the world of people who raise their heads. Be connected to this dynamic of history. Under the leadership of Nigel Farage, followed by so many others, the British people have already broken their chains. Yes, the British people, whether you like it or not, voted sovereignly for their freedom and independence. Freedom is the future, the European Union is already the past. Mr President of the Republic, therefore, talk about France and, therefore, talk to the world, as France knows how to do when it is free and as President Chirac knew how to do in 2003, when he knew how to refuse American wars. You said that yourself in a recent interview with the BBC channel, if a referendum on Frexit were held in France, Frexit would prevail. So be a Democrat, so make this referendum in France, offer young people pride, the elders dignity and all freedom. France is much better than a long exhausting head-to-head with Brussels and Berlin. France is a country on all continents and oceans. Our nations are good civilizations brighter than any European treaties will ever be. Let's get out of the European Union and go back to the world. And if, by adventure, Mr President of the Republic, this prospect did not seduce you, then you could reconvert to the European Commission or directly get recruited from Goldman Sachs. You will have only grilled one step. Long live Frexit, long live the freedom of our nations, long live free France!

name: Nicolas Bay
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, if you have succeeded — it must be said — without great difficulty in not making us regret your predecessor, François Hollande, your recent decision to follow the United States in unilateral military intervention in Syria will perhaps make us regret Jacques Chirac, who at least had the merit, to say no to the american war-going. Have you, therefore, taken nothing from Iraq or Libya from these interventions that their authors justified at the time by moral considerations, but which led to war, create chaos and allow jihadists to prosper? Are you not aware that in France and Syria it was also the worst of Islamists who applauded your strikes? In international matters as in many others, you are finally far away from the new world you claim to embody. You coalize around you, in a reflex of a besieged citadel, all the beneficiaries of this old world, of a breathtaking model, all those who have an interest in what it perpetuates, all those who still dream of the global village. Your plan to escape forward appears above all as the pale synthesis of Jacques Delors and Édith Cresson, that of an ever more bureaucratic and less democratic construction, that of an amnesian Europe, without borders and without identity. Under the looks of a certain modernity and not without some communication skills that you must recognize, you are finally against the current world. For human and cultural reasons, for economic and ecological imperatives, this century will be the one of the return of the very notion of boundary, that is to say, of border, does not deprive the zealots of the unimpeded free movement of goods and people, which has become free movement and weapons and terrorists. Sunday night you have said that France should be “a more flexible and mobile country”. Mobility and flexibility are words, slogans, advertising, com, so far away from real politics and its demands. What we need to guarantee is a sustainable France and sustainable nations in Europe. People have started to speak, Mr President. Listen to what the United Kingdom, Austria, Italy, Poland and Hungary have said, in turn, but also many Frenchmen. These peoples want their economies, businesses and jobs to be protected from unfair competition. They do not want posted workers or free trade treaties, which a small minority benefit to the detriment of the real economy and the people who suffer from it. They want to put an end to unstoppable and endless immigration. They want to regain their sovereignty, that is, simply, their freedom. Yes, people want to be able to decide for themselves. In the past it was called democracy. People express their rejection of this European Union, which intends to decide on everything but is unable to meet the challenges where it is really expected. A paradoxical mixture of deregulation and overregulation, absent and powerless in technological innovation, food safety, artificial intelligence or personal data protection, the European Union is pervasive when it comes to undermining the freedom of nations. You want to accelerate by leaving aside those nations that would not share your choices and who, according to your expression, would not want to “move forward”. But what, Mr President? Moving forward towards more European integration, less economic regulation, more immigration and communitarianism? With you — and you will probably have Mr Verhofstadt's support — it would therefore be Europe without Hungary but with the Turkey. “It seems impossible to imagine a renaissance for Europe that does not take into account the demands of rooting,” said Albert Camus, speaking of the work of Simone Weil, the philosopher. The rebirth of Europe, its refounding, must be rooted in our nations, in our common civilization. This is the challenge of identity that we must meet together. The identity of nations is not a weight, on the contrary, it is a weapon and a shield in globalization, it can be a formidable factor for success and outreach. A Europe of nations, cooperation and protections: this is the future that people are writing and it is before them that we will meet you in a year.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI).
text: — Mr President, Mr President of the Republic, I address you with the esteem in which I hold the man who restores dignity to the presidential office in France and who is undertaking courageous reforms in my country. You want, like me, to give a future to France and Europe, which is going through a deep crisis of legitimacy and disasusing peoples. But Europe, this civilization of freedom, will be nothing tomorrow if it is erased by demographic realities. On Sunday night, you quoted essayist Stephen Smith about Africa. I will therefore repeat his figures: today there are 510 million Europeans in the Union and 1.3 billion Africans in the neighbouring continent. In 30 years, the proportion will be 450 million Europeans for 2.5 billion Africans, or five times more. And by 2100, three out of four people who will come into the world will be born south of the Sahara. Your Minister of the Interior, Mr Collomb, himself spoke of “migratory submersion”. Immigration is not the cure for Europe's ageing. Immigration brings more dependents than assets. It destabilizes our societies and helps to tear apart our national units, fragile legacies of centuries of struggle. What we need is to make living gains made productive, to encourage labour mobility within the Union, to revive our European birth, to digitize our economies by focusing on robotics and artificial intelligence. Mr President of the Republic, our freedoms are primarily the product of our civilization. It is this evidence reminded us of Budapest, Prague, Warsaw and Vienna. To neglect or treat with arrogance this signal from the peoples and governments of the East would, in my view, be a serious mistake for the future of Europe. It is now up to you, Mr. President of the Republic, since you have talent and courage, to add to your fight for the economic modernisation of France the essential fight for the future of European civilization. The French and many Europeans are waiting for you on this subject.

name: Le Président. –
text: Mr President, you have about ten minutes if you want to answer the first questions asked by the groups. If you want, you can speak right away.

name: Emmanuel Macron
text: President of the French Republic. — (FR) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for allowing me to relive what the French Constitution no longer allows me, that is, a debate with Parliament. I was a former minister and I particularly liked this exercise. I will not necessarily repeat in chronological order but try to answer the main points that have been raised. Firstly, however, when we talk about sovereignty and national or European peoples, I would like to make two or three clarifications to Florian Philippot. I am surprised that you can say what you said about this assembly, in which you are. You were elected there by the French people. You have a strange respect for the French people to treat the function they have entrusted to you like that. (Applause) If you didn't like this assembly, you shouldn't come to it, that's all! (Applause) You had to go to other elections, you had to submit to them. As for the project that would be the real French project, but finally, the French chose it last May. Both of you were defending a project that lost. And he lost because the French people decided so. (Applause) Nevertheless, you are expressing anger. I have already said this on several occasions: we must hear it, and I hear it. As I have always said, I have always had respectful debates, including in the campaign with Mrs Le Pen, and that is why I will not find myself in the ease of the comments that have been judging from here what should be done in a country by telling about all the nonsense to which I answered at length last Sunday. It is precisely because I am here with the legitimacy of the French people, but with all the demands of the French people, that I cannot accept what you have said about what is happening in my country. First I want to tell you that it there is a Constitution in my country, which has not waited to incorporate fundamental freedoms, a declaration of human rights, a preamble of 1946 and all these values, and that there is a Constitutional Council to judge and determine whether laws respect freedom, equality and fraternity. The laws you referred to, the Constitutional Council has judged them, either by referral to parliamentarians or by question for a preliminary ruling on the law on internal security and the fight against terrorism. So you can make remarks of platform that can fit you, sir, because you have the comfort of this living room, but I don't have the comfort of this place and I have the cohesion. I had the courtesy to listen to you, I ask you the same courtesy. I have had this courtesy which is democratic; you are a representative, I am another representative. The Internal Security and Combating Terrorism Act makes it possible to fight Islamist terrorists in our country. It is in this capacity that it allows home visits, it is in fact that it allows the protection of public spaces. I fully assume that because I am today the president of a country that has been repeatedly attacked by terrorists. Therefore, I cannot explain to my people that we are disarming in the face of this risk because people like you allow themselves to utter untruths in the name of the principles that are rooted in our Republic, defended by the Constitutional Council and which a whole parliament carries. In the name of the respect I have for the majority in Parliament, as for the Council, I cannot let you say the nonsense, forgive me the term, which you have said so. In the same way, you mentioned Notre-Dame-des-Landes's project and, given the time allotted to me, I will not expand further. We have made courageous decisions that have never been made since 20 years to stop a project that was not in line with our objectives. But, the people who were demonstrating against this project, is it legitimate to let them protest and attack the law enforcement forces when there is no more origin to their demonstrations? Agricultural projects, including the most innovative ones, are still on site, carried by people who comply with the rules, but freedom, equality and fraternity also require respect for the republican order, and no project can be built if we do not respect the rules of the Republic. (Applause) (We hear Mr. Coburn shouting “Long live free France”) Long live France and long live Europe. I don't know what you're putting behind free France. If you put the same thing as I do, we have all our place in this inquiry. Many of you have talked about migratory issues. This subject, and you are right to recall Mr Smith's figures, is a much deeper root topic and which we will not settle through any policy today's national policy. That is why I believe that tackling the cause is to help stabilize Africa in terms of security and the fight against terrorism, what we are doing at the United Nations and in the framework of the French intervention Barkhane alongside the Sahel States; it is to have an ambitious development policy that alone will enable development and the emancipation of everyone in his country, and that is what Europe has repeatedly supported through the idea of this Marshall Plan; that is what we support and what we do through the alliance for the Sahel and our policy; and this is the decision I have assumed to increase our official development assistance to achieve a new 0.55% of gross national income by 2020; it is then a policy of external and internal solidarity in Europe and it is the key to having an integrated response to migratory risk. You have heard me speak earlier on these issues that will occupy the Council and Parliament in the coming months, but I believe very deeply that we need European solidarity at our borders to protect ourselves, as well as solidarity within our borders. As such, I made a proposal, but there are many others to be able to share the burden. France must now welcome cooperation with several Member States in this area. I am thinking in particular of Germany and Italy, whom I wish to welcome, and I believe in particular that, together with Italy, we have shown, during the last year, our ability to work together precisely. Just like the one I mentioned earlier, that of cohesion, I am assuming reforms underway which aim, on the one hand, to give an effectiveness to the right of asylum which I have always defended and which I defend vigorously, but which consist in stopping a system where it takes 14 months before obtaining asylum, which is the case in France, when it is six months in Germany, for example. So the whole meaning of the reform which is thus carried by France is to bring our system together with another system, especially that of the Germans or our neighbours, in terms of deadlines and organisation. The French system, today, is not up to the migration challenge that is ours. It is extremely long, it does not distinguish, strictly speaking, asylum seekers from other migrants, and it does not allow us to receive a reception that is equal to what we owe to women and men who arrive either on visas or to apply for asylum and be protected. I fully assume that and, you know, when I speak of the sovereignty of an effective Europe, it is because I refuse the unacceptable plan of nationalist narrowing, because from where I am, I have beaten it, and I also refuse a form of of guilty irenism that would be draped behind principles, forgetting that we must always maintain the cohesion of our peoples at the same time and that there is a reality to embrace. Chesterton had a nice formula, he said, “True idealists are pragmatics.” Look at Robinson Crusoe, he did not leave with great travel ideas but with hams and cheeses and an organization to be able to hold. I invite you to take inspiration from Robinson Crusoe. Secondly, many of you talked about issues that are essential for the functioning of our Europe. I will try to get back in time. On the subject, first, dear President, of the Balkans. I would like to see two lines that seem to me to be a matter of our interests and pragmatism. As for the first, I agree with your desire to tie the Balkans to Europe. Our geopolitical risk is to see the Western Balkans drifting to Turkey or Russia — that is a risk — or collapse into their own divisions. Therefore, giving them a perspective and linking them to a project and this European ambition is essential, but, for my part, I would only defend enlargement when there is first a deepening and reform of our Europe, and I would like us to be able to keep that ambition in these two lines. So I do not want Balkans who would turn to Turkey or Russia, but I do not want a Europe which, working hard at 28 and tomorrow at 27, would decide that we can continue to run and be tomorrow 30 or 32 with the same rules, that is not true. In speaking of these rules, I am convinced that we must have more pragmatic rules. First, if we want to move forward, let's accept it. Many of you have talked about the Franco-German couple, but you never heard me in my speech about the Franco-German couple. I have so was grasped by your reaction that is inspired or educated by history. I am committed to the relationship with Germany, but I never considered it to exhaust the European subject. I simply know, educated in history, that if there are not a minimum of agreements between France and Germany, we are wasting a lot of time moving forward and pretending to make Europe and pursue. But I always wanted, sometimes breaking the front lines that had settled, consider that one could move forward with a form of hard core that we would have predefined. In recent months, I have seen several European leaders with real ambition, who were from countries that some say small or east, or this or that. There are only Member States of the European Union and that is a project logic. But let's try to move forward with a rule that the one who does not want to move forward cannot block others. I also hope that we can make the reforms ahead and move forward with this rule that has been proposed by others in the past, and that we have this degree of ambition. I am therefore in favour of more qualified majority so as not to systematically move towards a logic of blocking, I think this is fundamental. Then you talked about more institutional issues of Parliament, President, and parliamentary democracy. I am deeply attached to it and that is why I wanted these participation exercises too. I am also committed to the separation of powers which goes hand in hand with a Constitution. Constitutions and Treaties are therefore responsible for Parliament and others with the Commission or the Council. If we want to change it, we must ask the peoples to do so, and I am therefore not in favour of deciding to arbitrate this or that competence and, at once, pass it on one side or the other. Besides, I believe so much in democracy parliamentary and the vitality of the expression of peoples that I proposed these transnational lists, because, if we believe in the vitality of peoples and democracy, we must not believe them simply when we organize with parties in elections that remain national projections and with the turnout that is ours today . Let's go to the end of logic! We believe in parliamentary democracy, we want it to be a great parliament, there must be the maximum participation in the elections, so the debates must be truly European and we must therefore dare to go towards a part of transnational lists, the leaders of which could legitimately be the famous Spitzenkandidaten. However, I find it odd, as such, to stop somehow in the middle of the ford and to believe in parliamentary democracy if it remains a democracy of existing, structured parties whose logic is still mainly national, it must be said. I see the time running and I know the rules that the President told me. Nevertheless, I would have liked to come back to several other topics. Let me just finish this with two points: one is Syria, the other is the European budget and the ambitions that we must carry. I do not believe that a higher budget is a problem for our fellow citizens if we know how to organise ourselves, and I do not believe that this European ambition — to clarify this point that many of you have raised — namely a stronger European budget to bring our new ambitions, to bring the ambition of our historic policies , this European sovereignty of which I am talking about, competes with national budgets or national sovereignty. I do not believe so because when I look at the big challenges, that is, energy transition, digital technology, trade, major migration, we need a European response. And we see it on all these issues, the national response is being debated, but it is insufficient, and as such, you have given a great example: the general data protection regulation. It made no sense to do so at the national level, none. We would not have protected anything, there would have been bypass policies, the operators would have gone to Belgium, the Netherlands or Germany if I had done so. You have done this only at the level where it was relevant to do so and at a level where we can stand up to major economic players but where you can create an organisation, and I therefore assume the fact of carrying these two sovereignties because they are complementary. Finally, with regard to Syria, I would like to say first that this intervention by France, the United Kingdom and the United States of America has nothing to do with Iraq or Libya, for a very simple reason: we have not declared war on anyone and we did not intervene in declaring war on anyone. But it's a little always the same principle, basically, what I'm telling you. If we believe in multilateralism, in the strength of law, we must be able, at some point, to decide not to give in to the cynicism of those who want to “powerless” multilateralism, that is what it is about. So, very precisely because this subject, like others, does not suffer approximation: we are engaged in many in an international diplomatic and military coalition that fights against whom? This is the only war that is being waged in Syria, against ISIS, against the Islamist terrorist groups that have attacked us and killed hundreds of people in our countries. This war is legitimate, it has a framework and we are fully involved. This is the only war we are waging today in Syria. But there is a parallel war, the one that Bashar Al-Assad has waged against the Syrian people and their opponents for seven years now. We did not declare the war in Bashar al-Assad, I have said repeatedly, and the interventions of a few days ago did not change anything in that regard. However, we have done constant diplomatic and humanitarian work to do our duty and defend our values, and I fully assume that. United Nations resolutions, in particular resolution 2118 of September 2013, provided for the use of coercion that President Putin used when he visited Paris a little less than a year ago, when I had already presented this red line of chemical weapons use. Indeed, there are international texts condemning the use of chemical weapons, including resolution 2118, with a commitment by all the permanent members of the Security Council and a commitment, at that time, by the regime of Bashar al-Assad. This commitment has been repeatedly violated. On several occasions, several members of the international community have organized themselves to “blame” the United Nations and the International Organization for Combating Chemical Weapons since November 2017, by de-structuring the OPCW attribution mechanism and then opposing all resolutions that allowed further progress. So, I ask you, to the same people who, every time, are indignant at the images we have seen, of children and women who died of chlorine attacks, let us sit down, defend rights by saying that rights are for us, the principles are for us, but that reality is for others. No! (Applause) So, in a context that is very specific, and I would like to recall, where we are fighting on terrorists, where Bashar al-Assad waged war on his people, three countries have intervened, and I say this with great frankness, for the honor of the international community, for, precisely, in a legitimate multilateral framework and in a manner that is so targeted, without any human victims, destroying three chemical weapons production and processing sites. So let's face our principles, indeed, look at international law in front and ask where we want to go. These strikes do not solve anything, but they simply end a system that we had become accustomed to, which is that somehow the law camp would have become the camp of the weak, and I do not solve it. Then we will continue the essential diplomatic work in the Security Council to build the framework for the fight and prohibition of chemical weapons. It started again with always the same Russian vetos. At the United Nations, we will continue to fight for humanitarian access and evacuation in Ghouta, as unfortunately tomorrow in Idlib. We will continue humanitarian work on the ground, and I announced yesterday with France, which will invest €50 million for projects carried by non-governmental organizations on the ground, and I invite all countries to join in this humanitarian effort. Finally, we will continue to work towards an inclusive political solution by speaking to all parties, Russia, Turkey, Iran and the regime and, above all, all opposition forces, to build tomorrow's Syria and repair this country, because that is the main thing. But we will not build tomorrow's Syria if we look away and leave it to Bashar al-Assad's regime and its allies, once they finish the dirty work they are doing. I'm telling you frankly.

name: Adina-Ioana Vălean (PPE).
text: — Mr President, I represent a country that the French love a lot: Romania. The Europe of the future, Mr President, is a Europe in which no one is left behind. This is why the discussion of a multi-speed Europe creates confusion and weakens citizens' confidence in the European project. Beyond the theoretical debate about the future, we live in the present and we need to act now. We need to provide a multiannual budget focused on growth and investment, and I congratulate you, Mr President, on committing France to contribute more. We need to take the implementation of the legislation we have seriously, respect our commitments and each solve their internal problems before engaging in resolving the shortcomings of others. Each Member State is a pillar of resistance of the European Union, and you cannot have a strong structure with clay feet, because - is it not so, Mr President? - the future of Europe does not solve the present of either of us.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D).
text: — Mr President, Mr President of the Republic, you are speaking as a convinced European, a European in augmented reality, and that has been enough for some of my colleagues. However, on at least two occasions, you have retained only the virtual side of these European references. In February 2018, the French government voted on the proper application of the common asylum system, but its title is misleading and the intention was to use the European screen to justify particularly criticable provisions, such as the detention of any person affected by the Dublin Regulation, including children. The same is the same thing this week with the Asylum and Migration Act which, to summarize it, destabilizes or destroys what is not a problem and does not solve what is causing it. The question of delays, perhaps we will come back to it, is not the problem, at least not as you think. Meanwhile, the reform of the Dublin Regulation is in danger because Member States are blocking negotiations, and France is particularly rigid in this regard. This is not what I call a European orientation, and I deeply regret that.

name: Geoffrey Van Orden (ECR).
text: – Mr President, President Macron, good morning and thank you for your very interesting address. In terms of defence and security, France and the United Kingdom have been the closest and longest-standing of allies for over a hundred years. Do you not think that in the economic and other fields it would be helpful if France could more strongly signal its support for the EU to have as close a partnership with the UK as possible post-Brexit, recognising that this will require novel arrangements?

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL).
text: — Mr President, Mr President of the Republic, our world has entered a process of ensauvement and decivilisation. Calling Europe as it has become to the helm of our conscience is indefensible. Indefensible because it accommodates the rise of far-right movements and the questioning of fundamental rights. Indefensible because Europe of defence actually prepares the path of war. Fortunately, however, it is not close to emerge when we see the isolation of France in its warlike adventure in Syria. It is also indefensible because Europe, which was intended to be the one of the peoples, has become that of the rich. What we propose is another path far from the Ordnungspolitik thought in Berlin is a Europe which, without defeating France, is done with the peoples. I believe that the European sovereignty to which you mentioned is an impossibility even by nature, because sovereignty, as you know, lies in the people.

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD).
text: - Mr President! Thank you, President Macron! Your primary asset is that you a good speaker. You are a good rhetorician. I still fascinated by the electoral movement where you effectively promised everything to everyone. You promised to unite the left with the right, you effectively promised 'follow me into the light, where it is warm and beautiful'. Then you were confronted with reality after you got elected and have now lost big in your support in France. You have a vision — so have I. But my vision is not for Brussels and the EU to take power over my homeland. My vision is not for us to sit here and decide over specific conditions that we better solve in my home country. But that I believe in my own country is not because I don't believe in Europe. I believe in a Europe where we are friends with our neighbours, where we have intergovernmental trade agreements, a different system than we have today. That does not make me a worse person, Mr Macron, than you are.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Mr President of the French Republic, I too welcome you to the European Parliament. In one of your recent televised interviews, you said that you persuaded President Trump not to withdraw American troops from Syria. You also instructed the air forces of your country to take part in Hollywood filmmaking intervention in Syria. I would like to ask you whether you have succeeded, by participating in this - from all points of view and above all military - failed intervention, what you wanted to achieve, or have you provoked the anger of the Arabs so that they would attack the French troops in Chad more fury. and Mali? And finally, why are you continuing the talks with Turkey? It is not about exclusion, it is about enabling Turkey to be consistent with its European obligations.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D).
text: Mr President, we are in a debate on the future of Europe, and I would like to ask you about your opinion on the regions that want to become new states in Europe. We are talking about Europe's sovereignty and I fully share that the challenges of the future are precisely the challenges of greater sovereignty for Europe, of a stronger Europe. My question is about the outbreak of nationalist sovereign nationalism that exists throughout Europe and I ask your opinion on the possibility of a future of Europe so that it can be built on the different regions that want to be new states that are broken off from the Member States. What is your opinion on the future of Europe, taking into account that demand?

name: Franck Proust (PPE).
text: — Mr President, Mr President of the Republic, on behalf of the French delegation of the EPP Group, welcome and thank you for being here. Thank you also for launching your election campaign here, because this afternoon, in Épinal — beautiful image — you will start citizens' consultations and so you will equip your political family with a tremendous administrative machine. The question in the coming months is not whether we are for or against Europe. The real question is what Europe do we want? What our fellow citizens want is more proximity. Here is my question, Mr President: how are you going to strengthen this proximity knowing that in France you have jumped back 20 years by abolishing regional constituencies, that you have tried to impose transnational lists here, that you have also attempted to impose transnational lists here, that you have also attempted to impose on the Council the appointment of the President of the Commission in outside of any democratic process? I understand that you are trying here to have a European anchor, but I really have the impression that you are walking a little alone and, unlike your majority in France, European democracy is done here for and by consensus. Therefore, Mr President, if you persist this way, I am afraid that the name of your new formation here in Parliament is not 'On March' but 'On March': on the sidelines of decisions and, above all, on the sidelines of the results to which we try here to contribute on a daily basis for our fellow citizens.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D).
text: — Mr President, I welcome the President of France and I will speak Greek in a European Parliament in which we are not only French and German but also Greeks, Italians and Spaniards, from countries on the borders of Europe who pay the bill for the decisions of military interventions that are not only French and German. taken without a European project and consultation. Mr Macron, we welcome your efforts for a stronger Europe, but do you have any concrete suggestions for economic governance? After ten years of imposing tough and government solutions, it's a big responsibility in your hands for the future. Would you support a role for the European Parliament in a European Monetary Fund? Would you support a European defence in which the South is not just a good client of the North and a good payer? Mr Macron, in Greece we have a government cooperation without ideological barriers - which is also the case in other countries, of course, what do you think should be the ideological antidote to this? What do you think, what is the political family in your opinion that we can begin to move forward together, with principles and values that are truly progressive?

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: - Mr President! Mr. President! Welcome warmly. You mentioned the European University. I have a proposal, let's set up a European University here in this building, in the seat of the European Parliament. We will have a fulfilled request, one seat of the European Parliament in Brussels, and an additional one in Luxembourg. Second note, the Lord spoke of European sovereignty. Is it known to Emanuel Macron from the point of delegated workers, that is the manifestation of European sovereignty or is that simply the interests and advantage of richer states over less rich countries? Our community has both rich states and less rich ones. I fear that this is not a manifestation of European sovereignty.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Macron, I believe that, alongside all the issues that have been dealt with, there is one that I consider central, prevalent and that is what concerns businesses Europeans, the development, economy and work of European enterprise, in a context where the trade duty war between the United States and China is prevailing against any other logic. I would like to know what your view is with regard to the strategy that Europe should implement, because I think that at this moment we should be in a position to relaunch, as far as the trade agreements, a perspective that looks at our “made in Europe”, as it looks at the protection of European products, through those rules of anti-dumping for steel and aluminium, that is to say to all those situations that realize the condition of making it clear that there is not only populism and there is not only an evanescent representation of situations. We have the responsibility and the duty, as a united Europe, to protect our business, especially the small one, especially the one that suffers, especially the one that cannot even get to the international process. So it is clear that in this type of situation it would be important to know from you whether sovereignism should prevail in this area or not.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D).
text: Mr President, in this House, of course in my group, no one has any doubt about the need to stop the use of chemical weapons by the Assad regime, for that you have our full support. Now, has it been effective enough? Did you count that attack, that response, with the European — Europeanist — endorsement that you defend, with the sovereignty of Europeans? Will this attack be used to change the course of the war, or rather, Mr President, we have to take forceful diplomatic action in order to get everyone at a table, on a path of reconstruction and peace in Syria? Would it not be more useful to seek European endorsement for that decisive and definitive diplomatic action that avoids pain and suffering in Syria?

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE).
text: – Mr President, five years ago, President Macron, the Irish President, Michael D. Higgins, said the following: ‘Europe is a legacy that cannot be taken for granted. Citizens yearn for the language of solidarity, commitment to cohesion, for inclusive rhetoric that is appropriate for an evolving political union.’ I think you echoed those words. But we evolved through disagreement, and we will be judged by how we solve our disagreements. You heard this House; there are many voices.  I might take a different view to you on taxation – I am from Ireland – but I don’t want to talk about detail, I want to talk about the middle-men between citizens and the European Parliament, and that is national parliamentarians. They are not always the friend of Europe. Some of my own colleagues do not speak about Europe in a positive way. We have a job of work to do, those of us who are pro-European, to persuade our elected representatives in national parliaments that there is not a fight between the European Parliament and national parliaments; there is not a power struggle; that together we can be stronger. Will you join us in that fight?

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: — Mr President, Mr President of the Republic, welcome to the European Parliament. Whether you are a Macronist or Socialist, we need members of the European Council to advance the European question. The president of my group, Udo Bullmann, offered you a deal. Certainly it is Franco-German, but I still believe that it is a cheap Franco-German market: nuclear power against coal. You did not answer him, so I offer you an opportunity to do so. On the question of economic and monetary union, I believe that all ideas are on the table. We share a lot but the obstacles rise day after day, including during the weekend. If you want to move forward, you need those in this European Parliament who know that it is with the Community method and not with national selfishness that we can do so. What place do you intend to give to the Community method and this European Parliament as a parliament of the euro area?

name: Daniel Caspary (PPE).
text: Mr President! Congrats on winning your choice with the European theme! People are indeed dissatisfied with the European Union. Some want Europe to keep its way out of things, but others also want more Europe. When Mr Bullmann addresses the social issues, just 25% of people in my own country want Europe to take more care of the communitarisation of social policy. But 75% of the people in my country want more European migration and asylum policy. They want a common right of asylum, a common asylum procedure and uniform benefits. Let's move forward, please! Three quarters of the people in my country want a better European foreign and defence policy. PESCO has now agreed to develop a fighter jet together by 2040. That's ridiculous! Ain't we gonna make something faster and more intense? And three quarters want more European external border management. Also in the budget: 10 000 Frontex soldiers would cost us just EUR 600 million a year. That is just over one euro per citizen, and we would really answer a key issue where people have expectations of the European Union. I would be very, very grateful if we could not only talk here, but above all deliver in the months leading up to the election.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Macron, you certainly have the merit of having rekindled the European dream by going against the current when it blows strongly and still blows the wind anti-European, we've heard some amazing nods. This is a great merit but it is above all a great responsibility and now every choice of his, every act of his is measured in terms of consistency and effectiveness. It is true that the divisions are first and foremost between pro-Europeans and anti-Europeans and sovereignists, but this is not the only division, Mr Macron, I would like to know if you agree. In order to achieve that Europe that protects, which you mentioned in Amiens, to the workers, but which serves us all, it is not enough to be pro-European, we also need other choices: on the subsidy for a European guarantee for unemployment, on the fight against blind austerity, against relocation, on immigration — and I leave out the events of Bardonecchia — for the defence of the rule of law, we in the S&D Group are in front row, for years, in this House and we will continue to be. But here there are still many differences between conservatives, progressives and many other choices. So then, President Macron, how will you choose with whom to realize, in fact, that dream that we have?

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE).
text: — Mr President, Mr President of the Republic, the French delegation of the ALDE Group joins me in telling you that it was important that you remember here both values and sovereignty, or sovereignty. You have been the only candidate in Europe in recent years to bring these values forward, at the time of the risk of an election campaign, in a speech of legitimacy to the people. So you are credible to carry them now again in front of us. I would also like to tell you that, despite a few mistakes in this House — some would like to raise the heads of the people while waiting for them to lift their arms, perhaps — a majority in this House is in your opinion and wants more Europe. I would nevertheless like to point out that, while Parliament is usually an integrative tool, the Council is gladly, beyond the engine, the brake of the machine and, often, is not the easiest body to move forward on our issues. Therefore, we expect you to use the same enthusiasm to convince your colleagues in the Council to follow Parliament's integrative minds. In any case, thank you once again for reminding us of what was precisely important to the peoples, that is, Europe.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: — Mr President, Mr Macron, you have presented yourself here as President of France but in reality you seem to think you are a little Napoleon. Because you came to make a declaration of love for democracy, you even said that democracy is not a hollow word, and I ask you: what democracy? The democracy that you decided to execute less than a week ago when, unilaterally, with Trump and May, advanced to the attack on Syria without strictly consulting anyone? Does your concept of democracy have no citizens? Don't you have parliaments? You have not even seen the French assembly, ridiculed the European institutions, is that your conception of democracy? Mr President, your concept of democracy is not hollow, it is nonexistent. His conception of democracy is Napoleonic and we want a complete democracy. If you want peace in the Middle East, you have a good remedy: stop selling weapons, you are in a great position to do so.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: — Mr President, Mr President of the Republic, I welcome your speech and your European policy, but we have differences. I must say that transnational lists increase the distance between voters and elected officials. Moreover, there is no federalist experience with transnational lists. This does not exist in the United States, neither in Switzerland nor in the Federal Republic of Germany. To have good integration, we do not need transnational lists. I also invite you to support a proposal contained in the report on national parliaments which will be discussed tomorrow. The aim is to create a European Week which would take place simultaneously in the 27 parliaments as well as in the European Parliament, with exchanges of views between Commissioners, Members of all nationalities and national MEPs. That would be the “European Week”. I invite you to support this proposal, which we will approve next Thursday.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, President Macron, I thank you very much for speaking about the need for new internal solidarity between the Member States of the European Union. However, I would like to remind you of what has been going on, for many months now, at the French-Italian border of Ventimiglia-Menton, as well as Bardonecchia, Claviers and Montgenèvre, where the French police have attitudes that are very much bordering on legality and also humanity, rejecting asylum seekers and minor refugees, pregnant women, getting them off trains, and holders of normal transit bonds. I would like to know if you are aware of this fact and whether this is the internal solidarity you intend. Finally, a suggestion and an invitation for your political position, which is very much talked about in Europe. The suggestion is not to create new families: there is no need, those that are there are enough. The invitation is to come to the next meeting of the European Socialist Party: you will see that it will find many affinities in our programmes.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President! Mr President of the Republic, the subject of Nord Stream 2 is part of the European solidarity you have mentioned in the field of energy policy. Nord Stream 2 would increase Europe's gas dependency on Russia, at a time when, as you said earlier, it is important that Europe has a clear common position vis-à-vis Russia. This Parliament rejects Nord Stream 2 by a majority. How will you help us prevent this wrong project?

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, Mr Macron, the Greek people listened with interest to your speech at the beginning of September 2017 on the hill of Pnyx in Athens on the future of Europe. Mr Macron, Turkey intensifies its aggression against Greece every day, violates the territorial waters of my homeland, violates Greek airspace; Erdoğan demands a change to the Lausanne Treaty, threatens Greece with war, keeps two Greeks illegally in their prisons military. I would therefore like to ask you, Mr Macron, whether the French Republic intends to conclude with Greece a defence cooperation agreement, a military assistance agreement to Greece in the event of an attack by Turkey on Greece, a pact of French commitment to provide assistance and for the protection of Greek borders, which is also European borders, and all this is here and now, because the Turkish threats against Greece are intensifying every day.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: — Mr President, Mr President of the Republic, I wish the best for the European Union, a united and strong Union, a Union that is a democratic world power with global interests.
