However, Mr President, allow me not to agree with your two-tier Europe. That would be quite dangerous for Central and Eastern Europe. We cannot, once again, have any differences in development between Western and Central and Eastern Europe. Mr President, we need a united and supportive Europe.

name: Esther de Lange (PPE).
text: – Monsieur le Président, Monsieur le Président de la République, je vous remercie d’être venu. Nous sommes nombreux à être à vos côtés. especially when it comes to fighting the nationalistic and romantic – but often dangerous – visions of the 19th century of those who believe that they can go it alone. I believe that cross-border challenges ask for cross-border and European solutions. You have spoken very little about Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) and the Banking Union. I believe it is very important to reassure those constituents, especially in my Member State but also in others, who say that, of course, France also has some homework to do when it comes to reforms. You have been one of the few presidents who have actually said out loud that France needs to reform before we can take steps at a European level. I thank you for that; I think it is refreshing. But can you reassure my constituents that you will be taking those reforms at home to an end before we take steps at a European level? I look forward to your answer.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, thank you, President Macron, for having brought back hope for the future, hope for the Union, to citizens all over our Member States. In the last Eurobarometer, last year, citizens pointed out that they want Europe to deliver on climate change, on combating terrorism, and on migration. We are delivering on everything except asylum at this moment. Now we need to change that. I am the rapporteur for the reform of the Dublin Regulation, and I count on your support on moving from the Dublin Regulation as we know it to an instrument worthy of the European Union in the 21st century, based on fair sharing between Member States, based on solidarity and based on a modern mechanism that is up and running in days of low influx and high influx – an automaticity that is necessary. If we deliver on this, we can meet citizens in the upcoming elections in 2019 and be strong together. I still believe that it is possible – and I count on you, Mr President – because I still believe that we, in this Union, have our greatest victories ahead of us, and not behind us. But we need you for that. You will be crucial in that development.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: — Mr President, Mr President Macron, I am really disappointed that I did not hear in your speech or in your replies a single word about equality between men and women in Europe. Equality between men and women in Europe today faces serious difficulties, whether in Hungary or Poland, but also in general, whether it be representation in employment, in wage discrimination, or in violence. Not a word about this discrimination. I therefore give you a third chance, Mr President, to be able to say, in your reply, what France's position will be with regard to the European Commission's initiative on the balance between private and working life, on parental leave which will finally enable these fathers and mothers to assume their lives professional but also their family life and thus give all possible development to European children.

name: Ivo Belet (PPE).
text: — Monsieur le Président, Monsieur le Président de la République, j'aimerais vous poser une question en néerlandais. Vous avez parlé de la protection des citoyens et nous sommes totalement d'accord avec vous. Mr President, one of the fundamental priorities here - and you have referred to it - is the development of a European defence. The Belgian government is thinking and in the coming weeks wants to replace its F-16s with only American fighters in the coming months. What initiatives do you intend to take to persuade not only the Belgian Government but as many partners as possible in the European Union to join? To tempt these partners to participate in this fascinating European project of a common European defence and to invest in it jointly and to convince them in the short term?

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: — President Macron, you are pro-European. I am also pro-European. Here, behind you, I am. I am also pro-European and I congratulate you for what you have said here, but you contradicted yourself in one respect and I would like you to answer me, maybe clarify. I agree with you that we must not have an authoritarian democracy, but have the authority of democracy. This is very important. But don't you think that your statements that France and Germany must be the hard core and lead this arrogance of being a power over other states lead to Euroscepticism? How can we convince the citizens of my country, in Romania, that they are equal at the negotiating table, if you declared that you want a two-speed Europe, that you want two states that are “more” than the others? How can we reform Europe, which you spoke of, if you want this discrepancy between Member States?

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE).
text: — Mr President, Mr Macron, I would like to thank you for your speech and also for the activity, passion and energy you have brought to the European debate. It is also appreciated in my country, Finland. You spoke very much about European sovereignty. It is, of course, an important point, but only to the limit that it must not mean protectionism or turning inwards. On the contrary, in these times of difficult times internationally, it is important for Europe to take a stronger role as a global leader, promote peace and stability, be active in trade agreements and promote international cooperation based on commitments and agreements, including in the fight against climate change. I particularly liked the fact that you emphasised the importance of European democratic values and the need for all Member States to engage with these values. My question is, how do you intend to act in the European Council to ensure that all the Member States of the European Union adhere to and commit to European values, at this time and also in the future?

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: Mr President, President Macron, many of us liked the energy you have put into your response time, as we liked the praise you made for the nobility and complexity of democracy — what is a message against populism — and the vindication of the authority of democracy — which is a message against illiberal democracy. But President Juncker replied that tomorrow's story is written today, and the time is already running against us, because the 2019 elections are a test, an exam for European leadership essentially on two points. The first is the balance between freedom and security. Fight against terrorism? Yes — I tell you in Spanish... that we have suffered so much the scourge of terrorism and we owe so much to France — but, at the same time, the preservation of the free movement of people, the most precious for Europeans. Secondly, those prime ministers who pledge to increase the resources to the Union budget, to ensure that in the next budget there are own resources, a rate of financial transactions, which we have so much demanded and is not yet in force at European level. And, of course, also a relentless fight against tax havens and tax fraud.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: — Mr President, Mr President of the Republic, I would like to begin by paying tribute to France, which plays an essential role in the fight against terrorism and trafficking in human beings in the Sahel. I'm coming back from Niger, I witness it. Thank you to France who protects us. I also recognize the key role played by France for peace in Europe. We must continue to respect it, but we must be on our side the citizens, who find it difficult to understand why reconciliation between France and Germany cannot, nowadays, be celebrated in a cheaper way, closer to them. Mr President, I am not expecting an answer today, but simply an openness, listening to the voices rising from all over Europe and asking us why so much waste and not a more efficient, more coherent Europe that preserves our planet, faithful to the Paris Agreements. We, the representatives of Europeans, vote regularly and consistently by a large majority, beyond political groups and nationalities, for a single seat of the European Parliament. We are confident that a brave leader like you will not close the doors to dialogue, so let's engage him without taboo, unreservedly. Let us not let Europeans turn against us, let us not leave them on the roadside while together we build their future.

name: Presidente. –
text: So many other MPs would have liked to take the floor. I apologise if I could not give it to all those who wanted it, but the debate has continued far beyond predictions. There will be other opportunities to intervene. I truly apologize to all the Members who have waited so that they could put their question to the President of the French Republic.

name: Emmanuel Macron
text: President of the French Republic. — (FR) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I will try to summarize the answers to all the questions that have been raised. There have been a series of questions about migration policy. First, I would like to say that everything that happens between France and Italy is not at the initiative of one or the other, but in perfect coordination. I said so by stressing the perfect understanding that we have between our two countries to manage migration flows and situations — you are right to recall — which are always extremely difficult and worrying human situations and which call first of all the greatest humanity but also for coordination. I therefore welcome the exemplary relationship between France and Italy, which will continue. France adopted a reform earlier this year, on the initiative of parliamentarians, to allow the application of the Dublin Regulation, which is currently unsatisfactory — and I agree with you on this point — but no longer applying it at all was unsustainable for a country like France, which today counts thousands of people whose situation is still unsatisfactory. allows them to be in refugee camps, even though they have been refused, for example, in Germany. 50 to 60% of the people who are refugees in France, especially in the Paris region, are called — I do not like this formula, but it is often taken up — “dublined” from neighbouring countries. So if we do not make the current system work, with all its imperfections, it is unsustainable, especially for a country like France. Therefore, on this point, I assume the realism we have shown, which has allowed us to resume what has been done for several years and which will be pursued. Now the question is how to reform this system, because I do not satisfy it and I consider that it does not allow to respond today to the migration challenge as we know it. First, moving towards harmonization of rules. That is what we want to do, especially with Germany and Italy. Harmonising our rules means that we can manage in a much more coordinated way the reception — we should draw heavily on our German neighbours — the deadlines and rules on asylum and the treatment of irregular situations — in this regard, I invite you to look at the rules in force in Germany which are even more drastic than those proposed today by France — but with, behind, an investment in integrating populations and those who obtain titles, which is also our wish. It is to this co-ordination that we will go in the short term through the law. Finally, more broadly, there is the European stage which, as I said earlier, is the most effective stage. On this point, I want here, in response to several of you, to defend, on the one hand, greater solidarity outside the borders. Indeed, we need to assume a European investment to protect European borders and not leave the burden on the countries of entry. This is an indispensable reform without which we cannot support today the migration we have to face and which will continue. On the other hand, we must move towards a common asylum system. I am in favour of it; that is the best answer. Today we are trying to coordinate things. I am in favour of a common asylum system where all Member States would adopt the same rules. Finally, we need to build the rules of internal solidarity and, on this point, several reflections are under way. We have seen all the difficulties of a relocation policy — which was urgently needed. If we want to build the regulations and the laws that will allow us to deal with this challenge tomorrow, i am in favour of assuming solidarity policy funding. That is why, together with others, I am pushing the idea of having an agency that can fund the communities that will be candidates to welcome and integrate refugees. We see all the difficulty of some national debates, we also see cities that are ready to go in this direction. Simply, European solidarity is essential to finance reception and integration policy. On this point, as you have understood, I am in favour of much more convergence, internal and external solidarity, and the same common rules. In the French debate, we often misestimate the fact that the problem we have been having for decades in France is that we do not welcome everyone, that we keep everyone waiting, that we have some of the highest deadlines in Europe for granting asylum and that, at the same time, we do not know how to accompany those who have been able to accompany them. those who are not eligible for asylum and who have no title. Therefore, we are in a situation where everyone is badly welcomed, we do not integrate almost anyone and we do not bring home any of the people who do not have the right to receive a residence permit. So I want to defend such a system, but I can tell you one thing: it is neither fair nor effective. Therefore, I assume this passage which is unsatisfactory for everyone. Some say it is unfair, because indeed we are harder with those who remain in an irregular situation. We are harder to be able to better accommodate those who will be in a regular situation, those who are entitled to asylum. Then you asked me about Brexit. I have a very direct answer on France's position vis-à-vis the United Kingdom and the post-Brexit situation. I am in support of the most integrated relationship possible, the closest one, and there is a solution: we know it well, it is the EU Membership. It is the one that allows good access to the single market, which allows access to freedoms and very good integration. I know we can't promise something to your people and then want to give them the opposite. So there will be negotiations. They are led by Michel Barnier within the framework of a mandate given by the Council. I am very interested in friendship with Britain and we have bilateral relations with regard to the defence and management of common borders, but there is no cherry-picking in the single market. It is a simple principle. I believe in Europe and, therefore, believe in what we have done. Consequently, freedoms in Europe are united and full access requires recognition of all these freedoms, European jurisdiction and contribution to the budget. Afterwards, we know the formulas, but we have to be consistent in the choices we make. This is also democracy, it is explaining the What if scenario to the end. There are many people who propose — to make a nod to your country — what if scenarios, but they don't explain it the next day: the day after is necessarily the moment when you have to embrace the principle of reality. As far as the regions in Europe are concerned, I believe in one thing. I am sensitive to all cultural expressions. They have their place and Europe has always recognised them, but I also believe in the constitutional framework in which they speak. You are MEPs elected in different countries: France, Spain or others, where sovereignty is expressed at the level of a state. So it is within this framework that my answer can be made. I am in favour of accompanying cultural specificities, the richness of our diversity, but to do so in a a framework that is a democratic framework. And this democratic framework requires respect for the constitutions that our peoples have chosen. It may or may not please, but these constitutions do not cut apart and sovereignty does not fall apart unless the people decide to do so. Then, on the link with the European elections, I received all the political formations in France before making this choice. First, had the regional constituencies reconciled France with Europe and allowed much greater participation? No. All political parties believed that they had a national constituency — all but yours, I recognize your consistency in defending it here, but honesty simply requires me to remind you that you were the only ones. All the others were for a national constituency, in view of the fact that the constituencies previously selected by France did not correspond to any political, administrative or even local identity reality. As you know very well, they were relatively artificial splitting of regions whose only coherence was the telephone directory of some thirty years ago. I believe that this does not correspond, from a political point of view, to the reality of France, neither yesterday, nor of today or of tomorrow. I think that this reform, which was wanted by almost all French political groups, was therefore the right one, and I believe in the Spitzenkandidat system. I think he's very good. So, on this point, rest assured. I do not belong to any political family that is represented among you today. This is my freedom, it is quite consistent with the spirit of the French Constitution and this freedom gives me the right not to, in any way, enter into the deliberations that are yours and which will be those of Parliament and the political families whom I eminently respect but which I respect, are neither those of the European Council nor those of the President of the French Republic. Therefore, I consider that it is indeed a step forward that the existing political families propose a Spitzenkandidat. I consider that it was even more democratic to go to the end of this logic and that there is a form of European emanation and a start of European demos that can be made. If we had been coherent to the end, this president, this Spitzenkandidat would have been the top of the list of European parties. I am not opposed to it at all; I am simply not a member of a political family of your Parliament. Therefore, it seems to me that it is extremely coherent. I would just like to say to the Hon. Member that almost all the states you have cited are federal states, so their lists are federal lists. You are right to say which are not transnational, but because they are already federal. If we want to have a start of federal reflection, we have to go towards lists which are transnational, which are at the bottom of truly European lists and which are no longer national lists reflecting European beliefs. I just wanted to make this distinction that seems to me to show reality, because you could have led to other interpretations. Secondly, several of you told me precisely about the Europe that protects. I want to tell you that, in assuming my responsibilities, that is the principle I wanted to bring to the European Commission. Some of them followed me in this formula. I believe in a Europe that protects. This is the basis of sovereignty. Sovereignty is both protection and the ability to carry one's voice in the concert of nations and internationally. It is the very pact that makes our citizens trust us. So yes, I believe in a Europe that protects in all forms. I defended this formula in all my speeches and in my action. It is also under this Europe that protects that I wanted — I did so in my speech and welcomed your commitment on this point — to bring about a more ambitious and faster reform of seconded work because I think it is very concrete. It speaks to our fellow citizens, and you know, it speaks much more to them than all the stories of voter lists or size. What speaks to our fellow citizens are not our political subjects but the topics we debate and the answers we bring to their daily lives. For our fellow citizens, it is not the setting or setting of our action that prevails, it is the bottom. Therefore, the Europe that protects is how to deal with the issue of social dumping in our Europe. I am going to be very direct with you: when we defend a reform of the seconded labour directive, for a Europe that protects, we are precisely in line with the European interest and we do not go into any kind of drift or betrayal of European history, dear Member, which now consists of advancing Europe through tax dumping and social. I believe that, if we believe in the European project, we must take note of the fact that we have ambitious agricultural or cohesion policies — and I defend them. Look at the philosophical and political fundamentals that led us to decide on these policies. It was to make all countries converge towards a kind of European standard. For years, we had accepted that these policies would be used to finance alternative models in some cases and, therefore, tax and social dumping. Therefore, cohesion funds are used to lower your tax or create tax niches to attract companies against other European states. Or, to maintain social models that are unsustainable, we pay less well for the workers and sometimes decide to pay them even less well for attracting companies within Europe. I fully believe in the need to move towards a stronger European competitiveness and I am pursuing these reform policies in my country. But I think it is impossible to pursue such policies if, at the same time, we do not have a genuine desire for cohesion at European level and, therefore, convergence and if we do not use both our directives, our law and the money we invest in our budget to allow these convergences. Therefore, I believe in a Europe that protects, I believe in a Europe from convergence, particularly in fiscal and social terms, and therefore in strengthening the fight against optimization, fiscal and social policies and non-cooperative policies between our countries. You then asked me about trade policies. On this point, you have stressed all the tensions that exist, and I find myself perfectly in what the President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, said earlier. I believe in the trade policy we have built multilaterally. It has set rules for itself, it is the WTO that defends them. I am not in order to retreat nationally, because this trade policy creates rules of the game and these are opportunities for growth. Now I'm not in support of a naive trade policy. That is why I have defended the strategic sectors that are precisely to be defended, and I think we cannot buy everything or invest in all sectors innocently in our countries. In fact, I invite you to look at how other countries organize themselves, including when they join the WTO. They have always defended their own strategic interests, and we have sometimes suffered too much naivety on this point. Finally, I am in favour of ensuring that our trade policy is fully consistent with our other objectives. Free Trade Treaty with Canada had been negotiated — moreover, if the jurisdiction as it is normally defined is followed to the end, it is a Community jurisdiction, which could therefore have been exercised to the end. It was decided to refer the file back to national parliaments. A great deal of work has been done at the level of the French Parliament to follow this text, improve it and ensure that before it is ratified and throughout its implementation, it will comply with our requirements, especially in terms of climate. The Canadian Prime Minister will address the French Parliament this afternoon, where he will have the opportunity to recall his commitment to these principles. But, for my part, I hope that with regard to the upcoming trade policy that is ours, we will have a minimum of coherence, that is, that our environmental, social and health commitments will always be reflected in our trade negotiations. We cannot negotiate new treaties where one agrees to open trade lines with geographical areas or countries which, in a claimed way, either do not want the Paris Agreement or decide that their social model is based on claimed dumping or on a particular optimization mechanism, because at that time it is explained that we will trade, but at the expense of those who have rules in our space. Our trade policy must therefore be consistent with our environmental, social and health commitments. You have repeatedly come back to the issue of Syria. Let me begin by telling you that today, no European taxpayer finances the targeted interventions made by France, it is the French taxpayer. So, on this subject, let there be no misunderstanding between us. Secondly, I want to say again, because democracy has rules, that it can not only be rules that we Arrange. The President of the French Republic is the head of the armies, it is the French Constitution, voted by the French people, that decided so and which makes the President of the Republic responsible and can take certain decisions. The Constitution provides that the president is then obliged to inform the national representation, which has been done, and we have even decided that there should be a debate. Each country, by its Constitution, has its rules, but you cannot give me lessons in democracy by explaining that you do not like French rules. They were decided by the sovereign French people and voted by them when they had to decide on their Constitution. This is so and will continue to be so with regard to the competence of the French President. If it is a European intervention, a European policy, it is European rules that prevail, but loving democracy and sovereignty, that does not mean wanting to mix all the rules or anything that binds us. Finally, I would like to recall — and I will not be longer on Syria, since I have already detailed our position at length earlier — the heart of France's action, for months now, it has been diplomatic and humanitarian action and the preparation of the follow-up, which has enabled us, on several occasions, in the Security Council to take a resolution for the ceasefire and humanitarian access that was not respected, but Russia had agreed to sign, because we had activated ourselves. It was resolution 2901 a few weeks ago. We resumed this diplomatic initiative the next day, and we are on the ground on the humanitarian front with our NGOs and the support announced yesterday. On the other hand, we have consistently promoted a policy of preparation for the next — as I said in the UN General Assembly — and we have taken the initiative of what has been called the small group, together with several countries in the region, also to prepare for tomorrow's Syria, with the participation, in particular, of countries where millions of Syrian refugees today live. I am thinking of Jordan, Lebanon and Turkey. So that is what I think is the essence of what is happening today in Syria and which I wanted to recall. Secondly, I would like to say two words about energy policy. First, I fully understand your concerns about Nord Stream 2, and I must tell you that Chancellor Angela Merkel expressed them herself a few days ago, recognizing that this was an extremely delicate matter because it involves our collective sovereignty, our energy sovereignty over the Russia. In my view, the energy policy we must have fits in these lines and that will allow me to respond to your Franco-German energy proposal. We must have an energy policy that is consistent with our commitments to reduce CO2 emissions and ensures Europe's energy sovereignty, because if we give it anything, it will not be possible. The French strategy was to keep these two lines. Some people don't like nuclear power, I can hear it. Nuclear, however, does not emit CO2 and it emits much less than coal. However, it is not good to rely too much on nuclear power and, in this regard, my predecessor had committed France to a transition strategy that is quite desirable and which has been strengthened. But France will have a very clear line on this point. Our desire is to develop much more and continue to do so, renewable energies to improve the mix, to do so in conjunction with all the European countries to improve the interconnections that make it possible to use these energies better. But our wish is not to yield anything to our energy sovereignty, nor to the sovereignty of the countries around it. You can shake all fears. What I am simply saying is that we have the Safety Authority, which is the most demanding and, look at what has happened, I have not seen in recent years, even during the incidents that may have occurred far from home, victims to deplore as for other energies. So I simply note that there is a security requirement and we have, and that there is also a requirement to reduce the dependency on energy production that must continue. The share of nuclear power must be reduced, but it must be done at a rate that will allow for the maintenance of that sovereignty. If the shutdown of plants leads to the reopening of coal-fired power plants, which has been the case in Germany unfortunately, you are degrading your CO2 balance, which is exactly contrary to the Paris Agreements, and if the acceleration of this pace, without preserving your energy sovereignty, leads to increasing your dependence on a particular Non-European sovereign power, especially Russia, to import energy, this is not a good decision. I therefore fully assume that we have an energy strategy that has a top priority: reducing emissions. That is why I decided to shut down all coal-fired and thermal power plants in this five-year period. The law has been passed, it is not a petition in principle, they will all be closed, so there will be no more. In terms of mobility, there is a need to move much further, with rising fuel prices and diesel-petrol convergence, which is also essential, and with a renewable energy investment policy which is absolutely essential to go much further and which will reduce the cost of fuel costs. over time, at the pace that has been recalled by the Minister of State, Nicolas Hulot, a few months ago, the share of nuclear power. It is this strategy that we have decided to retain because it allows us to keep these two lines: lower emissions and energy sovereignty. I therefore hope that together with Germany we would keep these two lines, and I will not give in to policies that would lead us to increase, even in the short term, CO2 emissions, or to those that would collectively lead us to dependence on other powers so that we can now operate our economies. Secondly, in terms of union and economic and monetary integration, I must tell you, there is already a multi-speed Europe. We must not be mistaken: there is Europe of the euro, there is the Europe of Schengen, so there are already several speeds in our Europe. For me, our moral duty is not to declare these clubs as closed and not to declare that we decide ab initio with whom we are going to work or not, but to take note that in order to move forward in Europe, it is necessary that the most ambitious and voluntary be able to move forward, and that is how Europe has Always advanced. If Europe had always waited for the entire club, but — sorry to tell you — you wouldn't be there. Europe was born from the ambition of some who have sometimes taken crazy risks and pursued these crazy dreams, which must therefore be pursued. In this context, I hope that we will have more ambition for Economic and Monetary Union. First, in the short term — I will be very clear — we must complete the commitments made on banking union and go to the end of what was decided several years ago in this legislature. Clearly, at country level, we must carry out reforms that bring us in line with, in particular, the European Semester and our commitments, because that is the responsibility of States. This is what I decided for France and presented to the French people during my election. We must also move towards greater solidarity within this Union because today, what is dysfunctional, in particular, in the euro area is that we have put ourselves with instruments of responsibility, but we have not taken decisions on solidarity and there is no monetary space in the world that works with the the constraints of a common currency, with reforms that are totally legitimate at the domestic level and without fiscal capacity that allows investment, convergence and stabilization in the event of a crisis. (Applause) So it is this project that I am defending, the one I want to work on with Chancellor Angela Merkel and with all the partners in the euro area as well as outside, because it is a discussion with the ultimate objective that all countries that wish to be able to join it. It is therefore essential that there be regular discussions not only within the euro area but also in a broader manner. I therefore agree with you on this point: we must move towards a political form that cannot be merely intergovernmental. So there is a part of intergovernmental, there are intergovernmental instruments that exist and this will involve the decision of States and governments, but there must also be community-type structures that can be established at this level. That is why I welcomed the proposals. I think we must try to go further than what the President of the Commission did, because there was this reflection that there would be a Eurozone line. I think we simply need to have, here too, a democratic principle and democratic governance at the euro area level. We undoubtedly needs to have, at the euro area level, a representation of the parliamentarians gathered here, on certain subjects, at least a more consolidated circle because there will be extremely important questions which will involve democratic control before a Parliament which will have to know about them, because it will require a form of executive which will be competent and who will have a mandate. Since this cannot simply remain at the intergovernmental level, we must find a path to move, in any case, towards a much more integrated institutional and democratic form at the level of the euro area or of all those in the euro area who want to integrate such a project. I believe that if we do not, in the coming years, and if we do not decide in the coming months this organisational and institutional breakthrough, which allows for greater stability and greater capacity to invest, we will not be able to move forward in Europe. You asked me about a lot of other subjects, but I think I have far exceeded the time. I still wanted to seize the opportunity you gave me to talk about gender equality. It is a subject that I have constantly defended, which we defended during the campaign and for which I made the great cause of the quinquennium. We are defending this right now by a law which is being examined in France. So, on this subject, rest assured, my commitment is full. With regard to the proposals that are being made and the draft directive, I fully agree with the principle, but paid parental leave at the level of the daily sickness benefit is a nice idea which can be very expensive and end up being unsustainable. In France, we are going to reform leave, especially parental leave, for the spouse who today cannot benefit or benefits much less from it. I think we have to have an egalitarian ambition and go much further, but we do not can't make it pay through systems, sometimes unbalanced. We have to work on the proposal, I agree with the principles, but the modalities described in this way, as analyzed on the French system, have a potentially explosive cost. France will itself make a proposal in this direction; in any case, I believe in this equality, and the reform of parental leave that we will carry will go in this direction. Finally, with regard to the strategic defence of our Europe and defence policy, I said: France believes in this defence policy. President Verhofstadt just now paid tribute to the French National Assembly, which a few decades ago put a stop to well-known projects. I think we can be grateful, collectively, for having made a great deal of progress in recent months because a compromise has been reached, because the Commission has pushed out an ambitious project and because you yourself are pursuing this by working on the European Defence Fund. I hope that we will achieve this ambition as much as possible. But it is also about our sovereignty and, in the meantime, I want to make it very clear that France will stand at every moment alongside any Member State when its sovereignty is attacked. That is the position we took firmly from day one alongside Britain when the Skripal affair broke out. It is also the position that we are constantly standing alongside Greece when it is threatened in the Eastern Mediterranean. A few days ago, I discussed this with Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras. We will constantly have this position from where we are because the heart of our common sovereignty is to have this solidarity between us. So, ladies and gentlemen, I have probably not answered all the questions, but I tried to be as exhaustive as possible, and I was very happy to do it here in Strasbourg. In Strasbourg, a European university will also be opened, Mr Hon. Member, as in many other places because it is a nice idea. I believe that this Europe of Strasbourg, we are proud of it. In any case, for my part, I am proud of this and thank you for honouring this beautiful European city with your presence. (The Assembly, standing, applauds the speaker)

name: Le Président. –
text: Mr President, thank you. Once again, Parliament was at the heart of the democratic debate on the future of Europe. Thank you very much for accepting a real debate with MEPs. The debate is closed. Written declarations (article 162)

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. — Thank you President Macron for this opportunity which allows us a direct confrontation on the state of the European Union. Your election, President, has awakened the hopes of all the convinced pro-Europeans, of all those who identify, in his own person, a chance to overcome the impasse in which the European Union is precipitated with the economic crisis. We have delicate dossiers on the table awaiting answers: reform of the Dublin Treaty, eurozone governance, banking union, public finance rules, EU budget post 2020, the management of security and external borders. You need to speed up. The rule also applies to the European project that the stalemate must have a limited time because what is not progressing regresses. And it is important to give answers long breath and respecting everyone: I refer, for example, to the unpleasant episode of Bardonecchia. I don't think this is what Europe has in mind. And also for Syria another solution must be found, a solution other than the use of weapons which, although used for extreme evils, can only lead us to an escalation of violence that may not have end.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: in writing. — I share Macron's view that the European Parliament has a major role to play in shaping the future of the EU. We are the institution that is directly elected by the citizens. We are the link between citizens' needs and policymaking. Accordingly, I hope that Parliament's position will be taken more into account in future.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR)
text: in writing. — I highly appreciate France's role and contribution to maintaining international security and peace. I support the intervention of the coalition of the United States, the United Kingdom and France to prevent another use of chemical weapons by the regime of Bashar al-Assad. I would also like to refer to Polish threads. According to a global report by the World Economic Forum, my country achieved its highest competitiveness rate since the beginning of the transition. Entrepreneurs, both in Poland and France, appreciate this fact. Our economic relationships are deeply embedded in a long-standing tradition. The best case scenario for Europe would be to take these experiences to a multilateral level, with the inclusion of the UK after Brexit. Economic relations must be beneficial to all parties, devoid of barriers and prejudices, based on mutual respect, not — as President Macron rightly pointed out — on lectures and lectures.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: in writing. - I think it is particularly important that we take time and again to discuss the future of Europe, as the Union obviously has a number of unresolved problems. I am honored that the President of the French Republic has also visited us and shared with us his ideas on how to solve these problems. Although there is a discrepancy between us at the level of concrete responses to the challenges, I see that the solutions are based on the same factors: to save and renew Europe, we cannot rely on national and cultural diversity in the Union; the right and we cannot find or make changes without the wider involvement of citizens. In order to resurrect Europe, strength must not be sought in some external power, but rather in its fundamental core, the diversity of nations. A strong Europe is unthinkable without strong nations. Representative democracy loses its legitimacy when citizens' views are excluded from decision-making. It is unacceptable for us MEPs to represent vague ideologies instead of the citizens who elected us, but this is only possible if we open up to the people and ask for their opinion. I believe that the Union can learn a lot from the experience of Hungarian national consultations, where millions of voters were free to express their views on the current challenges.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR)
text: I would like to take this exceptional opportunity to express deep concern about the state of fundamental rights in your State. As the format of the debate does not allow the list of examples, I will mention only one, which is nevertheless particularly emblematic. This is the invention of the crime of obstruction of abortion, which provides for imprisonment for online statements, is an open attempt to intimidate non-governmental organizations defending the lives of the weakest, as well as an attack on freedom of expression. Such liberticidal regulations cannot be justified in any way; they must simply be repealed as soon as possible.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: in writing. — In the context of the debate on the future of Europe, I pay particular attention to the issue of modernising education in the Union and increasing the role of education at European level, which is essential for achieving Europe's economic and social objectives and building its future. I welcome President Macron's approach to strengthening EU education cooperation. Educating future generations, so that they are able to address the challenges of the modern world, should be a goal that unites us all, regardless of policy options. Europe's demographic and social challenges, labour market requirements, new technologies and personal educational preferences and needs determine the lines of change in education. It is essential that education systems, taking into account the above factors, offer not only quality knowledge, but also an appropriate resource of competence, including the key competence of the 21st century, which is the ability to effectively learn throughout life.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: in writing. — The vast majority of MEPs agree with much that has been said in the speech, particularly for more cohesive and solidarity Europe that defends European sovereignty in practice rather than theoretically, for a Europe that protects the environment, promotes quality of life and industrial relations and of course will apply the fundamental freedoms and rights of democracy and the rule of law of the EU in practice. These are the principles and values that cover all EU citizens without exception, in all 27 Member States. However, European sovereignty is mutilated by the Turkish troops occupying the northern part of Cyprus. It is a sovereign territory of the EU but under Turkish occupation. In addition, Erdoğan's Turkey is blocking with its fleet the EU's sovereign rights and plans in the EEZ of the Republic of Cyprus and threatening war against Greece in the Aegean. A European leader differs from a politician because the leader has a place for the difficult, not just the easy ones. Today, we need European leaders and not just politicians. A European leader defends by all means the European sovereignty violated by Turkey in Cyprus and elsewhere.

name: Artis Pabriks (PPE)
text: in writing. — As President Macron of France said, we, the European Union, are an example of liberal democracy in many parts of the world. It is liberal democracy, the need of which is currently questioned by many, is a key part of our European identity. It is necessary to stop ignoring the lessons given by the past. We need to be proactive, listen to citizens' concerns and respond to them. The president touched on the topic of the EU budget after Britain's withdrawal in a speech. We heard that France is ready to increase its contribution to the EU budget, which is positive, but it should be understood that the President's goal is to link the budget with his new proposals and France's priorities, but it is important to remember that the EU is other member states and the future of the EU is possible by balancing everything the interests of States on behalf of a common objective. The proposal for better EU cooperation on security and defence is welcome, which is a top priority for Europe today. I also agree with the suggestion of the introduction of taxes on the giants of technology companies, even though they pay a fair share of the profits made in Europe. On the other hand, the proposal to create a joint EU fund for the reception of refugees is doubtful, as this is a nationally important issue that cannot be decided centrally without respecting the reception and integration capacity of each country. Europe needs enterprising and decisive leaders today. The French president is perhaps the only real EU leader for the time being with a clear vision for the future of the EU, even if not all the ideas he voiced are acceptable to us.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: in writing. — (FR) Mr President, welcome to the debate on Europe. I would like to discuss with you two points. First, security. As far as the Dublin Regulation is concerned, I ask you to reach a consensus, so as to allow a unanimous vote on this key issue and not to place the citizens of Eastern countries in a minority situation. We all wish peace in Syria. The attack may have been necessary but, believing in the common foreign and security policy, I would have expected joint coordination. However, the intervention took place without the consultation of the European partners. Secondly, the free market. Since 2016, your name has been linked to the Macron Act, the law that angry foreign drivers and their employers. Your name is related to protectionism. This policy limits and diminishes, in my opinion, the competitiveness of firms in the internal market. Mr President, do you think that we can be competitive with China if we build internal barriers to business development? In order for Europe not to experience new outflows from states, new “exits”, we need to regain a sense of mutual trust. I wish you good luck and thank you in advance for your answers.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. – President Macron has expressed his opinion that Brexit should result in enhanced cooperation between the Member States. I fully agree with that. Particularly suitable are areas which bring benefit to our citizens such as digitalisation, energy sector or completion of internal market. Furthermore, we must focus our attention on stabilizing the euro currency by creating a functional bank union. On the other hand, I cannot accept the idea of harmonizing tax and social rules. The state budgets could be exposed to enormous pressure and the functioning of the small and medium-sized enterprises could be placed in jeopardy. Unification of the tax rates could considerably weaken the competitiveness of certain Member States.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – Your campaign, Mr President Macron, l’Europe en marche! reminds us that indeed, we Europeans are all in march confronting several battles, which we better win if we want our Union to last for the generations to come. The greatest battle of all is the one with the enormous disparities, the ever rising inequality and the poverty. For millions of Europeans life in dignity is out of reach simply because they are desperately poor! Masses to be manipulated by populists and anti-Europeans. Mr President Macron, we will not win this war with a new Finance Minister for Europe! Neither by creating a special Eurozone Parliament! Nor will Europe win in a two-speed format! The EU will win the battle against poverty by enforcing solidarity between all its willing members, by enhancing Cohesion Policies and by better financing its common policies!

name: Maria Gabriela Zoană (S&D)
text: in writing. — I represent an important country: Romania. I'm a law teacher and a lawyer. This makes me look at things from the point of view of compliance with the letter of law and partnership agreements between Member States. We are at the point where the European Union is deeply affected by the dynamics of global economic, social and political change. It is a point where, as you yourself have pointed out, we must arm ourselves with force and move forward strong and united. The essence of the European Union is the unity and acceptance of the diversity of values as the state you successfully represent does. In such a context, President Macron, we are talking about the ability of all of us to accept the national policies of each state and to agree that any form of intrusion into domestic policy is not timely. We're partners. This is why I ask you: do you think that the future development of the European Union at the accelerated pace that you are talking about will create a segregation based on the democratic policies and values of each state?

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF).
text: Mr President, very briefly on the order of business: I just wanted to announce that a three-gesith Mass will be held at Parliament in Brussels on 26 April in Brussels in remembrance and memory of the French hero, but that we all feel our own, Arnaud Beltrame, who proved the extreme sacrifice: that of his own person. That is the real solidarity. Our homeland is courage and then we all feel unworthy patriots with him. I honour the memory of this great French officer and I deprecate that this morning, in his long speeches, President Macron did not find a second to remember him.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I understand that everyone concerned has written down the date, place and that anyone will be able to participate as far as possible.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item of the agenda is voting. (Results and other voting details: see meeting minutes)

name: President. –
text: (off micro comment from Mr Verhofstadt) Mr Verhofstadt, if you had spoken for a shorter time, you would have saved two minutes. It is the privilege of the rapporteur to take two minutes. (Applause)

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, at previous meetings we adopted the most important Euro-Mediterranean initiative so far in the field of research and innovation, focusing on agri-food systems and water disposal and management, in the involving nineteen states. Having already approved the Scientific and Technological Cooperation Agreements with Algeria, Egypt and Jordan, at the plenary session on 30 November 2017, I welcome the European Commission's proposal for the corresponding agreement with Lebanon and invite you to give your consent to allow participation in PRIMA as soon as possible.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Mr President, I would like to ask, on behalf of the EFDD Group, to vote on the amendments tabled to the next report to vote, namely the Bressen-Wieland report, as provided for in Article 59 (3) of the Regulation.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: Since this is a formal proposal, I am putting Mr Castaldo's motion to a vote. (Parliament rejected the proposal)

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I hereby close the vote.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: Another point of the day's order is explanations for voting.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: — Mr President, we agree with the need for the European Union to diversify its crops and combat its structural protein deficit. Now it is also necessary to clarify that this dependence, these massive soybean imports, which grow exponentially, have an origin and that origin is our intensive production model that is highly dependent on soybean and compound foods, and therefore a sustainable strategy that seeks to combat this issue must of course take into account the need to revise this model. In short, I would say that the intention on the one hand to create a sustainable strategy that will combat our protein dependence and at the same time pursue a free trade policy with third countries is hypocrisy, because it places our producers in a condition of inequality which naturally impels them to that consumption untenable of imported protein.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: — Mr President, protein crops must find their place in European agriculture because dependence on imports is not useful in terms of food and food safety. I am worried to hear Bulgarian producers that the imported produce is actually genetically modified and that although they take all care of proper cultivation, the risk of contamination from GMO feed is actually serious. My country Bulgaria has excellent opportunities for the production of protein crops. Peanuts, as such a culture, produced in the Sadovo region, have excellent qualities, and unlike others, imported, Sadovo peanuts do not form aflatoxins. That needs to be encouraged. European production creates and maintains not only livelihoods but also quality and safe food, and this must be known and protected. In the new common agricultural policy, all protein crops must be supported by concrete measures and stable resources, so provision should be made for a mechanism for these crops to remain and be used in the agriculture sector in the European Union and not exported to third countries without the added value from the European subsidy.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the most extraordinary story of my lifetime has been the conquest of famine. I grew up, like almost everyone in this House, regularly watching news images of disasters caused by lack of food. Now famines are exceptional and when caused almost invariably the result of human activity: of war or corruption rather than of failures of food. Why is this? Partly because food supplies have become more global, more diverse, there is always a surplus somewhere – we are less dependent on avoiding localised shortages – and partly because human ingenuity is unlimited. And there have been advances in genetic modification that have allowed us to get extraordinary yield out of the same amount of land. I worry though, when I look at the European Union, that both of those things are being resisted here. There is still an ideological preference for local production of food, what’s called ‘food security’, but actually the most insecure thing is to make yourselves dependent on one area, and a reluctance to embrace the latest technology. We have to ask why this country, this continent which was for so long the fulcrum of innovation is now turning its back on that past.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: — Mr President, I supported this report by Mr Denanot. I consider it very important that the EU finally begins to address this issue because — as the report rightly mentions — sufficient protein stocks are indeed a necessity for the Union's self-sufficiency; and Member States precisely on the issue of food security. It is not entirely happy for the EU to be dependent on any raw material, let alone food or protein, on another partner country. So for it to be self-sufficient, that is really important. Being dependent on a country like China is very unsighted going forward. So I want to fire for the EU to address this issue and for example to look for very reliable partners and allies, such as Ukraine, because this country is supposed to have our support, and I think it is in this area of protein security that we can find new areas of cooperation and support another co-operation for the next period.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I am pleased to support the report and the work of the negotiating team on the 2030 non-ETS targets. It is absolutely crucial that our actions to combat climate change go hand-in-hand with maintaining the competitiveness of our key sectors in Europe. Thankfully, this text finds the balance that will ensure our transition to a low-carbon economy is done in a fair and just way. From an Irish perspective, this legislation is important, as it gives the needed flexibilities that are crucial for countries with a high share of agricultural emissions. Ireland will be allowed to cancel allowances that are earmarked for emissions from power plants and heavy industry. We can therefore choose to have less emissions in the power sector, deploy more renewable electricity instead, and then shift these emissions to the effort-sharing sectors. This will allow Ireland the flexibility to ensure that emission reductions are made where it is cost-effective to do so. Additionally, this text properly recognises afforestation as a mitigating strategy. Ireland can now incentivise our farmers to increase their forest cover, and this will help us to meet our 2030 targets. The agricultural sector is crucial to Ireland. It cannot be treated in the same way as energy and transport. This report ensures that.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL).
text: — (start of intervention outside the microphone)... Commitments are always welcome, but of course, those commitments must be more ambitious. This was decided in the Paris Agreement and we are already very late. Member States must commit to radically reducing greenhouse gas emissions and it is the duty of this Parliament to urge them to do so, because otherwise it will happen that corrupt governments, such as the Spanish Government, will continue to implement policies that go against the planet and people's health. Spain is the third country in Europe that has issued the most broadcasts of the so-called “Kyoto basket” in 2015, surpassed only by Cyprus and Turkey. Climate change is a political challenge, and it involves making important decisions and political decisions; it implies a change in the way we understand life and, of course, be clear that it is not solved with emissions marketing, that's just a make-up.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, the institutions of the Council and the Commission, after the appearance of dialogue, have not bothered to maintain the proposals which this Parliament had adopted. After a hard debate to include more ambitious targets that would bring Europe closer to meeting the Paris Agreement on reducing greenhouse gas emissions, the triologues have returned a document that slows down the fight against climate change and the sustainability of the planet. After a few years of timid progress, negotiators have not wanted to talk about setting a binding final goal, which is essential if we really want to take the goals signed at the Paris Climate Summit as a compromise. They left this statement on wet paper. On the contrary, they have introduced into the text more flexibility in exchange, that is, the purchase of allowances, and relativize wetland and forest protections. The European Union seems to believe that the dramatic point at which the planet is located is not enough to get to work, and it does not seem to have any plan but to continue with the escalation of destruction of the planet.

name: Christofer Fjellner (PPE).
text: - Mr President! The vote on burden-sharing for EU climate policy is one of the most important climate votes of this term, but it is also perhaps the biggest and clearest example of the capital failure of the Swedish government in both Europe and climate policy. In this decision, Sweden is forced to take by far the greatest responsibility for reducing carbon emissions. But because this is a zero-sum game, it means that Poland almost does not have to cut emissions at all and Bulgaria will not have it altogether. Sweden should have high ambitions in the field of climate, and we should be happy to be an example. But it must never be that our high commitments lead to others getting away — and that's exactly what this decision leads to. That's where Sweden's government has miserably failed. Not only does it hit Sweden, it affects the climate above all. Climate change is so passport serious and it's such a rush that we can't afford to do anything other than what's most cost-effective — and that's not letting those who already do much do even more, but to ensure that those who have barely done anything at all do much more.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: — Mr President, I ultimately supported the report, I must say that I regret that some of the amendments of our parliamentary faction have not been approved, but the report as such in my opinion will stand even without this approval. They weren't key points for us. Anyway, for me, it is very important that the rapporteur has identified the areas in which Europe and its Member States fail to meet the environmental objectives. To me it is very important that she mentioned the problem of suburbanization in adjacent urban areas, because this is indeed a problem very serious. There, people are faced with very significant disorders on health, on the environment — it is related to unbalanced zoning, with infrastructure — that have unconscious economic, social and environmental impacts. And it should be pointed out that by 2020 almost 80% of the European population is projected to live in cities and adjacent areas. Therefore, it is important to pay attention to them, and therefore I am pleased that the rapporteur has mentioned this matter.

name: Rory Palmer (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I was very pleased to support this report today because perhaps, more than at any other point in my lifetime, we need a strong, independent and free media. And one of the key elements of that, in my view, is a media sector that itself is tackling some of the problems and challenges it rightly helps one cover in wider society. So, where the media doesn’t just talk and cover and comment on the need to smash glass ceilings, but is able to demonstrate it has smashed its own glass ceilings for women. We must also work to secure a society both online and offline where journalists can go about their work free from the fear of abuse, discrimination, harassment and violence. Sadly and outrageously, it is female journalists and women who suffer the most gratuitous, disgustingly violent and sexualised abuse. So it is right that we approve this report today, not just for the sake of democratic debate in today’s need for a strong and free media, but also for the sake of women working in the media today and in the future. And that’s why this report today was so important.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, according to media monitoring projects for 2015, women are the focus of only 10% of news stories and comprise just 20% of experts or spokespeople interviewed. And 4% of news stories are deemed to challenge gender stereotypes. The problem with this sad statistic is that what we see on screen is a reflection of what is off screen. Since I have a wife and a daughter, I will not stop stressing this and repeating what we have said too many times, namely that we need to improve this situation. I will not stop saying that until my wife and my daughter have the same legitimate right to be represented in the media as myself and my son.

name: Urszula Krupa (ECR).
text: - Mr President! The report on equality between women and men in the media contains a number of proposals that are difficult to consent to, which is why I voted against. Media has a huge influence on a society where women have been in the same professions for years and hold the same positions as men, also particularly responsible and stressful positions, such as managerial, where they are represented as much as 40%, although they should not do so by virtue of disparate psychophysical characteristics. It is the liberal media, while promoting the necessity of eternal youth and attractiveness, that contributes to breaking up family life and giving up motherhood, which for many women is a primary vocation. Excess responsibilities, by contrast, leads to a strain on women, which triggers aggression and various illnesses; as does forcing paternity leave and sending women to work. Therefore, the priority action should be to protect women who can be helped by taking maternity leave to work time or by paying pensions or equivalents when they decide to raise children, as recently proposed by the Polish government's family and women appreciative.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR).
text: — Mr President, the report raises important points about the role of women in the media sector. It also acknowledges the role of the media as a shaper of public opinion. The media not only portrays the world, but also shapes it. Children face gender inequality from a very young age, for example through images taken from television, games and commercials. Media should give voice to a wide range of women and produce a diverse range of role models in order to break down old-faced gender stereotypes. There were also a few problematic points in the report, such as the proposal to introduce gender quotas, which I do not support. Despite some of the weaknesses in the text, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL).
text: — Fewer than one in five experts, gatherers or presenters are women. Our media is full of male-led programs that contribute to stereotyping and invisibilizing women. The media is today the most important mechanism of socialization; they not only describe realities, they also build them and can also change them. I voted in favour of this report because, among others, it recommends that greater emphasis be given to gender equality plans in media organizations, in order to promote positive representation of women in advertising, news, reports, production and broadcasting. The creation of regulatory bodies and incentives, such as quotas, for equal gender representation in decision-making and management positions are measures in the right direction, as well as the mainstreaming of content and ensuring a safe environment for women workers. Today I would also like to thank the journalists and presenters who joined the strike on 8 March in Spain for making the fight for women's equality visible. His role was fundamental.

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI).
text: - Mr President! I voted against the report on gender equality in the media sector not because we freedoms have anything against it, against equality or equality even. We don't mind women earning as much or more than men. By contrast, this resolution goes towards forcefully forcing such solutions. It is an individual matter between two people, how much who wants to pay, not a member of the European Parliament to lecture others on this topic. This resolution is disgraceful because it appeals to the use of coercion in a field where there is no place for it, in the area of contractual relations. The authors confuse equality with equality. Equality is a good thing, but equality leads to inequality as a result of many different factors, including differences and abilities and predispositions of different people. Equality can only be enforced with violence and the authors refer to it.

name: Urszula Krupa (ECR).
text: - Mr President! I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the empowerment of women and men in the digital sector, as digitisation offers new opportunities and perspectives. Most jobs in the near future will require digital skills, many job openings may be in this sector. The resolution highlights the continuing gap in employment between women and men, in basic and advanced skills to access digital technology and services, and women's participation in digitized jobs. For me, the results of studies can also be very interesting, just to be consistent with reality, aimed at identifying the systematic causes of increasing gender inequality in digital skills, which can be simply due to different brain building in both sexes, which is formed already in the initial periods of life, weeks of life, being reinforced in personal development, which many modern ideologues do not perceive trying to force parity.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: - Mr President! This is an important point, although perhaps the report itself does not convey this, because the debt of many developing countries is very high, to this level high that it even threatens the liquidity of these countries, therefore the matter is important and for those countries, for their citizens, but also for institutions financial, international, also of the European Union. We should all work towards the recovery process, perhaps also to create a new framework and rules for lending to the States. What is very important — in the report, as if a point of gravity is shifted to the responsibility of the debtor, so it is not that institution or country that provides aid, grants loans, loans to the debtor, i.e. governments of developing countries, which are often not fair, in which often we are dealing with crime, embezzlement of money, corruption. Such a shift in the point of gravity cannot be accepted, which is why I voted against.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the resolution on debt restructuring in developing countries is important because it sets out certain principles. Firstly, it supports the audit of debt and, secondly, it does not recognise debt that has been formed without the approval of the Parliament of the Member States and developing countries. It also supports the establishment of an International Debt Restructuring Tribunal. This means that these basic principles must be applied to the debt restructuring of developing countries. However, the same must be done for the public debt within the euro area, especially for Greece's debt, a debt which is shameful, an odious debt, a debt which did not serve the needs of the Greek people, since, on the contrary, as Mr Dijsselbloem confessed in a question I submitted to him, Greece was overcharged with all the memorandum and loan agreements in order to rescue foreign creditors, to rescue foreign banks.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: — Mr President, we follow the principles underlying social and territorial cohesion. Now the facts show that the European Union has diverged, the gap between rich and poor widens, social and economic inequality is growing between regions and countries. This is because the Structural Funds tend to decline. The current Community framework has fewer structural funds compared to the previous framework and, in the framework that is to come, everything is likely to indicate that the funds devoted to cohesion will also be reduced. This is much more serious because in the next framework there is also the need to link the application of these funds to structural reforms, to the European Semester, and this naturally represents the death of what was the only instrument that allowed Member States to cope with austerity policies.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, social and economic cohesion is a key process to support the regions of the European Union. This means concrete measures and there can be no such support when the Troika and the Commission, as a member of the Troika, impose an increased value added tax on the Aegean islands, a tax that will reach 24%. Specific action is therefore needed in favour of remote regions, coastal regions and islands. At the same time, however, Greece, which has been dissolved by the memorandum, should be able to obtain a special status within the European Union, a special relationship, with regulations and exceptions for a certain period of time, in certain sectors such as energy, shipbuilding. industry, tourism, the primary sector and transport, so that the Greek economy can recover under this special scheme.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Joulaud report is of fundamental importance, as it photographs the state of the art of implementation, current programming and debate on the next multiannual financial framework, just a few weeks before the presentation of the latter and the various post-2020 cohesion policy regulations. The European Parliament today expressed concern about the cuts in the various Commission scenarios and highlights the indispensability of an ambitious budget, commensurate with the many economic and social challenges of the different territories and also functional to the coverage of all European regions. Parliament also reiterates to the European Commission the importance of multilevel governance, a shared management model, which really makes regional and local authorities protagonists and which try to also involve economic and social actors in a more systematic way. It expresses the need to promote alternative indicators to GDP, which take into account environmental, social and demographic parameters. It expresses the hope that within the next framework of cohesion policy, the structural investment funds can be used more effectively to achieve the objectives of COP 21, in particular reference to renewable energy and energy efficiency. I must point out, however, that the report contains no mention of the Commission's worrying proposals on the hijacking of as much as 21 billion... (The President interrupts the speaker...)... to be devoted to structural reforms. That is why our decision was to abstain, for us, adherence to the Stability Pact and structural reforms is a red line.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: Mr President, there are many European regions that are affected by the demographic decline. The demographic decline also affects my country, Spain, and among other regions Galicia, where I come from. Both the Galician Government and the Central Government are taking steps to address this serious challenge, but I think it is necessary that European cohesion policy should also contribute to this. I therefore supported with my vote the Joulaud report on strengthening cohesion. I stress that paragraph 13 of this report indicates that cohesion policy should prioritize attention to regions suffering from demographic decline. In addition, paragraph 22 calls for the European Structural and Investment Funds to also be used to address the demographic challenges facing several regions of Europe. I also agree that, along with the per capita income criterion as the main indicator for the allocation of European funds, other complementary criteria are taken into account, as claimed in paragraph 26 and, among them, the demographic criterion. I would therefore like — and I conclude — for the European Commission in its proposal for the multiannual financial framework to take into account the demographic criterion in the system of allocation of funds.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: No Stanisław Polčák? So I suspend the meeting until 3 p.m. Thank you very much to all the people who persisted to the end.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice—President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on progress on UN Global compacts on safe, orderly and regulation migration and on refugees.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. Mr President, I welcome this opportunity to join you today to discuss again the UN global compacts. In our globalised world, human mobility can only be addressed effectively by the international community as a whole. It is – and we all recognise it – a global phenomenon that requires global solutions. No country can manage this alone, but together we can set up a humane, dignified and secure mechanism for governing human mobility. Over the past years, the European Union has built a comprehensive approach to addressing migration and forced displacement. In the face of the worst refugee crisis since the Second World War, we are the world’s first responder, granting asylum to persons in need of protection and offering safe and legal pathways through resettlement. In the year 2016, Member States granted asylum to over 720 000 persons, and in the year 2017, 382 000. In the context of our partnership with Africa and with the help of the International Organisation for Migration (IOM), we are funding five transit countries where migrants receive assistance, medical care and psychological support. In Libya, over 33 000 people have benefited from our support in detention centres at disembarkation points or in their host communities. Through the new Joint Task Force that the European Union has set up with the African Union and the United Nations, an additional 15 000 migrants stranded in Libya have been assisted in the voluntary returning to their homes, where they receive re-integration support. 1300 persons in need of international protection have been evacuated from Libya in view of future resettlement. The Commission has also launched a new resettlement scheme with at least 50 000 additional places for refugees from Africa, the Middle East and Turkey by the end of 2019, and set aside 500 million to support Member States’ resettlement efforts. All this was possible thanks to our common work inside the European Union, and to strong cooperation with our partners in our region and worldwide. Our approach is based on solidarity, shared responsibility, multilateralism and engagement, and we would like these four principles to be reflected in the global compacts on refugees and migrants. The crucial point for the global compact on migrants is to strike a balance in addressing regular and irregular migration. A person should never risk their life when seeking a better future abroad. Dangerous and irregular travellers must be differentiated, whilst also opening regular channels for human mobility. As you are aware, we are working very closely with our Member States to develop targeted pilot projects on legal migration with certain third countries, the priority currently being African countries. At the same time, the global compact should promote effective return policies. In this respect, we have managed to engage with a few countries of origin in Asia and Africa. As for the compact on refugees, it is an opportunity to modernise refugee responses by going beyond traditional humanitarian intervention and focusing on development.
