This is in line with the European Union’s approach to forced displacement, and it also meets the expectations of host countries and eases the pressure on them. I believe that the global compacts present a unique opportunity to share the lessons we have learned and the partnerships we have built, as well as to listen to the needs and priorities of others. Comme l’a rappelé le Président de la République française, Emmanuel Macron, ce matin, nous avons besoin de plus de solidarité interne et externe pour affronter les défis migratoires. Le pacte mondial pour des migrations sûres, ordonnées et régulières doit permettre de renforcer la solidarité entre l’Union européenne et les pays tiers pour une gestion responsable des flux migratoires. Ce pacte permettra de parvenir à une compréhension commune des défis migratoires auxquels est confronté chaque pays dans le monde et fournira une boîte à outils commune pour y répondre. The two global compacts together present international cooperation frameworks that will guide our work over the next decades. They will serve as a toolbox to address the various situations which may arise in the future. They will serve as a platform to build new partnerships and to forge new alliances. So it is clearly in the European interest to negotiate two strong and ambitious compacts, and to do it together as a Union. The future compacts are first and foremost about people, and they must be shaped not only by our interests but by our values. They must be shaped by a vision grounded on human rights, responsibility and mutual solidarity. A vision where the most vulnerable ones, are protected. A vision in which there is no place for traffickers, smugglers and criminal organisations. A vision where irregular migration is reduced, and instead we have the courage to invest in more regular and safe channels for migrants. We have now reached a defining moment in the process. We are half-way through the negotiations and formal consultations on both compacts. Thanks to the European Union’s leadership and strong engagement, the current revised drafts of both compacts largely reflect EU legislation and policies. We see a good chance to develop a common understanding on how to humanely and efficiently manage human mobility. The next months are crunch time to find the middle ground between the diverging views, different national migration realities and priorities. We will continue our engagement toward reaching an agreement on the Global Compact on Migration, to be politically endorsed at the intergovernmental conference in Morocco in December as well as on the Global Compact on Refugees to be adopted under the auspices of the United Nations General Assembly later this year. With the withdrawal of the United States from the Global Compact on Migration back in December 2017, the compacts need more than ever a strong and united Europe that speaks with one voice during these negotiations. In that light, I regret that one of our Member States has taken the position on the Global Compact on Migration that is not in line with the position of the 27 other Member States. Here, our common work and your contribution as the European Parliament will be essential. This is a test of humanity. But let me add that we should also be very pragmatic in how we approach this discussion. Two good global compacts will help us manage human mobility in a much more orderly and effective way. Let’s not turn this into an ideological debate. Let us shape these two compacts together as a Union and for all Europeans.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I welcome the UN Global Compact on migration and refugees. Global challenges need global solutions and the EU as a global actor must do more to address the root causes of migration, from conflict to poverty and climate change. It is time to have a global governance of flows, sharing responsibility for orderly and safe migration. The EU must take the lead to move from illegal to legal migration, combat smuggling of migrants, implementing resettlement and voluntary returns, and supporting countries of origin. It is also time to put humanity back at the centre of our debates on migration and change the narrative. For many people, migration means slavery. I am just back from Niger and Agadez, the trafficking hub to Europe via the Mediterranean. We met women, children and young men coming back from Libya. Their stories are heart—breaking. Trafficking in human beings goes hand-in-hand with trafficking of drugs and weapons. People die in the desert in their thousands of hunger and heat, abandoned by traffickers. Libya is hell on earth. Migrants suffer ransom, forced labour, sexual abuse, torture. We have a responsibility to help people trapped in detention camps get out of there back via Niger. The EU operation in Niger is effective, but more resources are urgently needed for resettlement with UNHCR and repatriation of returnees from Libya by OIM to home countries in Africa, and for reintegration projects in their local communities. Key are the projects for reconversion of traffickers into legal work, like handwork and building work. It is happening. Let’s do more: fewer traffickers in Agadez, Niger, means fewer irregular migrants to Europe, but also fewer deaths in the Mediterranean, in the desert and less labouring in Libya and I finish by saying that the Global Compact should also focus on children and promote gender equality in the world, with zero tolerance for violence against women and children. With the PPE, we call on the Member States to be united in negotiations on the Global Compact and focus on common solutions.

name: Elena Valenciano
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Mr President, today in this House we are going to address issues that are important for the future of the Union and I think to a large extent for the world. The response to the human drama of the shelter tests the strength of our values and our identity and, at the moment, we are going wrong. Migration is a key element for our future, for our economic, demographic, social, political and ethical continuity, but in both cases only a global response based on cooperation and shared responsibility can be effective, fair and humane. That is why the Socialist Group has promoted this debate and the accompanying resolution. Because we believe it imperative to support the action of a European Union that is ambitious in both global pacts, and which exercises the leadership that is due to us. For that, it was very important to reach a broad consensus in this House, which we have done around a common text that defends the dignity of the human rights of all persons — whether refugees or migrants — that addresses the situation of the most vulnerable, which calls for more legal and safe avenues for refugees and migrants and which calls for explicitly that humanitarian assistance is not criminalized, as is currently being done in the Mediterranean with the NGO Open Arms. It is true that the global covenants will not be binding and, although they have great potential, they are fragile; that is why we must seize this unique opportunity. Only by getting a more optimistic, more positive account about migration, would we have already achieved great success. We cannot finally lose the battle against those who sow a hate speech; that battle must be won, starting by winning it at the European Council. Mr Avramopoulos, Mrs Mogherini, you have all my support.

name: Helga Stevens
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — (NL) Mr President, asylum and migration are important issues. Our citizens are concerned about the continuing influx of migrants. They are concerned about our porous external borders and the socio-economic challenges and security risks associated with them. I still believe that we must move in the Union towards a system whereby recognised refugees can only be transferred through resettlement, so that we know who comes in and can impose a maximum limit, but also so that families would not risk their lives in rickety boats. because they know that an illegal entry is no longer rewarded with legal residence. Dialogue is also being established at international level. I am delighted that agreements on such a resettlement policy are made to Europe, but also worldwide. I would like to call on the negotiators to show the necessary ambition and realism and also to give sufficient attention to the return of illegal economic migrants, so as to increase public support. Make clear the distinction between vulnerable refugees who did not find a safe haven abroad and lucky seekers on the other. I think it is questionable that Parliament is calling for the decriminalisation of humanitarian aid, a pointer to Italy, which confiscated an NGO boat on suspicion of aid to smugglers. Despite orders from the Italian Rescue and Coordination Centre and from the EU-trained Libyan Coast Guard, the NGO brought migrants to a European hotspot. After all, humanitarian organisations are not above the law or the agreements made.

name: Hilde Vautmans
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (NL) Mr President, we at ALDE are actually very pleased that we are finally going to have the global pacts by the end of this year. Although it is not a binding framework, it is certainly a framework in which we are going to encourage international cooperation to tackle this phenomenon. We are about to start the debate here and everyone is talking about the negative effects of migration. I would like to say briefly that fortunately migration is positive in many cases. People who have the freedom to live, work and live and move within the world. But here today we are talking specifically about the migration that worries people, about illegal migration, about refugees and migrants. And I would like to make a plea here for one specific group, namely the children in migration. May I ask you, for 30 seconds, or let us say 10, because I do not have that much speaking time, to close your eyes and think back to your own childhood? Fortunately, we can think back to happy childhood, to playing in freedom. Kids on the run, they can't. Children fleeing from chemical weapons, bombing, are put on a rickety boat by smugglers at the risk of drowning. Commissioner, I would like to make a plea here today to focus on children in migration. Europol has also said that 10 000 unaccompanied minor asylum seekers are missing in Europe. Let's make a real action plan. Let us ensure that the global pacts focus on children. No more child detention. Bets on registration, bets on family reunion, bets on humane reception of the most vulnerable. A child in migration is primarily a child and deserves our protection.

name: Judith Sargentini
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (NL) Mr President, how does the European Commission's efforts towards this global pact actually relate to internal European laws on the reception of refugees and migrants? Let's be honest. Paper here is very patient again. The Pact recognises that migration is a phenomenon of all times and states that every effort must be made to enable legal migration. But there is still no idea of a proposal from the European Commission for a law to give migrants in Europe access, including lower paid and lower skilled jobs. We have to wait well after the European elections for such a proposal. While we know that in southern Europe the harvest is being taken off by immigrants with no papers and exploitation is the order of the day, the global pact and also our parliamentary resolution rejects the imprisonment of children. That makes sense, because children are not supposed to be in prison, but - even here in this Parliament we are afraid to say it out loud - European countries are locking children away. Refugee children who are waiting for asylum or are evicted are systematically imprisoned. Or helping migrants, giving someone something to eat, offering someone a ride, saving someone from the sea, they're all normal, human, humane actions. You can't make that punishable, that's what our resolution says. But there are European Member States that have sued and prosecuted their own citizens who gave refugees a lift. There's a Spanish rescue ship in Italy in chains because it saved people from the sea from drowning. These are three examples that show that European Member States in New York may speak very humane language, but at home simply go on with business as usual, keeping migrants at all costs. In order to be politically and administratively responsible, we must do what we say.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (FR) Mr President, we can only welcome the work undertaken by the United Nations on migration. It is certainly an international policy issue and it is time for Europeans and our governments to have a less historically centered and ethnocentric view of these issues. It is a fact that international migration is increasing and, as the Secretary-General of the United Nations says so well, the majority of them are regular. But the West is no longer the center of it. Migration has become globalized, regionalized. South-South migration now exceeds South-South migration. Of the 258 million international migrants, 60 million come from Europe, which is, proportionally to its population, the continent whose inhabitants migrate the most and most mobile. This is normal because Europeans are very largely those who enjoy a real right to mobility, unlike the rest of the planet. And only half of their migration is intra-European. Therefore, who better than Europeans can show that migration is an opportunity and a wealth? We are the first to benefit from the right to migrate. Let us therefore realize that those who are in an irregular situation on our continent, those who risk their lives in the Mediterranean Sea, are first of all those who are deprived of this right to mobility, do not have a regular migration route and flee inhumane situations whose causes are difficult to unravel. We must welcome them with dignity rather than make scapegoats. The European Union would grow if it were to fight for the universal right to migration and mobility. We all have the right to dream.

name: Kristina Winberg
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — Mr President, 65 million people are on the run in the world. Could I, so would help them all, but I realize it's not possible. Me and my country feel a willingness to help as many people as possible who are truly on the run. At the same time, it must be noted that our resources too are limited. We must recognise that we cannot open our door on at the gable and allow the country to be filled by an overwhelming proportion of economic migrants who want to enjoy our welfare at a high economic and, above all, social cost. There is a shortage of housing and jobs and the consequences will be a failed assimilation where new areas of alienation are emerging. It is more reasonable, for example, to help one million refugees on site instead of ten thousand in Sweden at about the same cost. The UNHCR is in dire need of assistance to deal with the situation in the refugee camps they are looking after. It is about being able to provide these refugees with clean water, food and a pregnant residence, arranging school for the children and creating a belief of the future and a hope of returning to their home countries. It is here that I think we should put our resources and help as many people as possible. I support an intergovernmental approach in which the sovereign nations agree voluntarily with the UN to help refugees without EU involvement.

name: Auke Zijlstra
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (NL) Mr President, this report mixes two things, refugees and migrants. The right of asylum for a relatively small number of refugees is confused with the desire for migration of many millions of people. This report trivializes the problems arising from this. It brings together internal mobility in the EU with the depopulation of Syria and suggests that the Member States of the European Union allow too few migrants. There is no suggestion in the report that there are limits to the growth in the number of migrants. That this is untenable must be clear, right? Even now, Western countries are hardly able to cope with mass migration. We read in this report that, because of this migration, there is still a great deal of extra need to be done in every EU country in the areas of health, education, child protection, housing, social inclusion, justice, employment and social protection, but these are issues that exist in the Member States of the Union is already under pressure. With ongoing mass migration, these things will disappear rather than improve. The United States takes in one million migrants a year. That's more than any country. However, the United States has stepped out of these negotiations. That's got to tell us something, right?

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to Commissioner Avramopoulos that he speaks about Hungary as if we were some sort of deviant. Let me tell you that we are not the deviants; we represent the majority of the citizens, the population of Europe.  The majority are fed up with mass migration. They do not want any more migrants and they want to send back those who are now here. We are on one side and, on the other side, there is the whole corrupt political elite. The thing is that the majority of the citizens of Europe cannot really speak up because they are punished, they are oppressed, there are all these hate speech laws that silence people. It is really strange that we are the ones who are accused by the European Union of not being democratic and of not having freedom of speech. We do have freedom of speech and we speak up for the majority of the citizens of Europe, but they should also speak up and they should support Hungary in our efforts.

name: President. –
text: Ms Morvai, I do not think there is any reason to enter into polemics separating you and your political party from all the rest, portrayed as corrupt politicians. I hope that was just a misunderstanding on my part.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE).
text: — Dear Vice-President of Parliament, Honourable Commissioner, in the context of the New York Declaration as the first intergovernmental agreement on refugees and migration for the first time encompasses the overall dimension of international migration. The United Nations Global Agreement on Safe, Orderly and Lawful Migration and Refugees as followers of the New York Declaration helps improve governance as well as solve challenges associated with global migration. Responsibility, i.e. protecting the lives, freedoms and human rights of refugees within the framework of global commitments, I underline this because this is not just about European problems but about global obligations, it is one of the key elements of this proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament and the Member States of the European Union. like other global actors, they should be more actively engaged in their fulfillment. Fulfilling global obligations would also include measures to support developing countries that have already received large numbers of refugees in terms of their integration into society as well as their economic independence in recipient countries. In conclusion, what I consider important is strengthening the resilience of societies and economies in crisis-affected countries, as well as the adoption of measures to combat poverty and strengthen the inclusivity of economic growth and development as one of the key solutions for global migration, which is also specified in the text of the resolution of which I co-authored.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: – Mr President, in the last couple of years the world has witnessed an unprecedented volume of international migration. Both migrants and refugees leave their countries due to economic or social hardships, persecution, conflict, poverty or even climate change. If we have learned anything over this time, it is that human mobility cannot be stopped or forcefully prevented, but it has to be managed globally. Therefore, the UN global compact is crucial. No country can face these phenomena alone. The EU has to speak with one voice and has to take a leading role, especially after the US has decided to leave the negotiations. Managing migration requires major investment in comprehensive global development policy, especially in human rights, social inclusion, education, justice, health and employment, with a special focus on vulnerable groups and children. At the same time, we need to work in our countries on our perception of migration. The dangerous spread of misinformation and fake news poses a threat to our policies and provides fertile ground for xenophobia and racism. Legal and safely managed migration can be beneficial and can be an engine for economic growth and innovation. And it will lead to fewer deaths, less abuse of irregular migrants by smugglers and less exploitation by employers. This is a process we can win if, as the EU, we work together as one.

name: Jussi Halla-aho (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the global compact unfortunately keeps repeating old mistakes. It stresses the management of immigration, for example by distributing migrants more evenly or by creating new legal avenues for migrants in the hope that this would discourage illegal entry. The real problem however, is the sheer number of people who are coming, or who want to come, from the third world. Europe cannot integrate them, regardless of whether they are legal or illegal. Therefore, the numbers should be brought down with a stricter asylum legislation and a more efficient return policy. It is true that Europe is ageing and that the funding of welfare states presents a challenge. It should be understood, however, that immigration of this kind does not alleviate the problem, but makes it worse. In addition, it creates new problems.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I am more pessimistic than Commissioner Avramopoulos or Mrs... the people who have preceded me; perhaps because I am the daughter of a girl who was a war refugee and I see that the vast majority of them are not going to have a future, they will not have the future that my mother could finally meet. The problem with this resolution is that evaluation is not entirely real: there is no political will that can make this beautiful resolution a reality. We are covering with words the mountains of mud and misery of children who have no future, women enslaved in Libya, the sick. We call in the proposal that humanitarian aid should not be criminalized, but we have done nothing else, since the agreement with Turkey, but to remove NGOs from the middle. Authorities say things but, little by little, they remove uncomfortable witnesses. Proactive Open Arms, for example, does what we are not able to do and has gone from receiving prizes in 2016 to suffering discredit campaigns or to the Libyan warlords — who we pay — take it out of the way. At least 14,500 deaths in the central Mediterranean since 2015, three years of humanitarian crisis and many children with no future.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President! I would like to lift some absolutely necessary starting points and principles for the EU's stance in the negotiations around these global compacts. First of all, I would like to say that Europe needs to take responsibility for the negotiations being more equal. The South, the global South, must have a stronger role. Indeed, these are the countries that are most affected. We also need to lift the greater perspective. That means migration cannot be seen as a problem, let alone discussed in terms of security threats or other completely irresponsible that we often hear here. Migration has always existed. It's something fundamentally positive and it's something we should cherish. We also need to make sure to create policies that preserve and reinforce people's right to mobility globally. What is a problem is the exploitation of migrants. In the job market, sexually and in other ways. Furthermore, I must also say something about the economic and foreign policy of the European Union, as well as the trade of arms from certain Member States, which are actually responsible for creating many of the situations we see and driving people fleeing and migrating. It is naive and perhaps also irresponsible — or, perhaps some would say, hypocritical — to think that you should continue with that policy while saying want to reduce migration. No, we need debt cancellation, we need development, we need economic partnerships that are equal and we need to stop the militarization of Africa and the Middle East in particular. Further, if we are going to have a positive change here then we have to do right at home level. We need a humane refugee policy and we need to ensure that we stand up for those who stand up in solidarity with refugees. We need a new policy in the EU. (The speaker agreed to answer a question (“blue card”) in accordance with Article 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question under the 'blue card' procedure. — Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleague, you said, among other things, that we should not fear migration and you are right, we must not fear other people. The issue I want to ask now: do you think that, now, when we are discussing the issue of migration, the European Union has a coherent plan to ensure, on the one hand, the security of migrants, on the other hand, a correct selection of those who migrate economically or from the perspective of War? Do you think we have the right security and the right selection? And do we have a plan to return migrants?

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: answer (“blue card”). — No, I don't think we have a worked system. As I said: I don't think we have either a good migration policy or a sufficiently humane refugee policy. Europe can take a far greater responsibility in terms of the refugee situation in the world and we need to arrange and direct our refugee reception for it. But we also need to make sure to develop global policies that do not, as today, increase gaps between countries and between different parts of the world. It is also our responsibility. That means a different trade policy, a different economic policy, it means that poverty alleviation has to be on the list and it also means that we need to stop exporting guns.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the migration flows of recent years to the European Union have made awareness of the complexity of this phenomenon and the need to provide a global response in terms of international cooperation and shared responsibility. If, from this point of view, the European management of migration flows has proved to be quite bankrupt, the world one, which is intended to involve the entire international community in the face of the bleak Current framework, it is foretold rather problematic. The United States has long declared its withdrawal from the Global compact, deeming it incompatible with its government policy line. The wars, political destabilization and economic exploitation affecting geographical areas around Europe and to which the actions of the US government and other Western powers are not alien are only one of several obstacles to an effective international pact for refugees and for safe, orderly and regular migration. If we analyse the European situation we find ourselves coming to terms with those states which, preferring walls and crosslinks to cooperation and demonising and exploiting the migration phenomenon, making it a source of intolerance, they create divisions over the compact negotiations and hinder obtaining a common position. If this agreement is intended to give a global response to human movements caused by conflict, persecution, violence, poverty and the desire to seek a place where to have a better life, as for all international agreements, the most challenging challenge will be to move from statements of principle to the facts and commitments of the responsibilities of individual states.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF).
text: — Thank you Mr President, the United Nations Immigration Pacts are dripping good feelings to justify the intensification of migration flows and make illegal immigration legal, which you refuse to prevent, for ideological or low economic reasons, to the detriment of identities, security, and even the sustainability of European peoples. Arrogant, the globalist elites no longer hide their suicidal goal, such as UN Secretary-General Guterres, stating that migration must be convinced that migration is inevitable and that the multi-ethnic, multicultural and multi-religious societies that are building themselves are a wealth, or you, Mr. Avramopoulos, who have said last December, “we must all be prepared to accept immigration and diversity as a new norm, this is an imperative for our continent”. But this imperative is criminal. The United States has made it clear that immigration policies should only be taken by the Americans. Our duty is to think of Europeans first. That is why we must denounce these pacts and not applaud them.

name: Steven Woolfe (NI).
text: – Mr President, too often immigration is considered good or bad. I take a different view. I see the benefits of immigration, but only if it is managed, controlled and legal. But I also see the negatives of immigration on communities if we continue the chaotic, uncontrolled mass migration policies that we see from many in this Chamber and the global elites who support it. The problem with this UN Global Compact is that it assumes all migration is exactly the same, and it also ignores illegal migration. It also says, more importantly, that international bodies should have power over the nation states to determine the setting of immigration policies across the globe. The frustration of the people in Europe and the world to deal with the economic problems of mass migration is real. It should be the voters who elect parties to deal with this that have the power, not the unelected global elites or their lackeys.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: — Mr President, Commissioner Avramopoulos, ladies and gentlemen, the importance of a global refugee pact is revealed in three simple facts: firstly, we are experiencing the biggest refugee crisis since the Second World War; secondly, 50% of displaced persons in the world are on the African continent; third, about eight million refugees are only in five countries. Let us be clear: we have an unprecedented crisis whose effects are mainly felt on developing countries and for which the international community was not and is not prepared for! We must be at the forefront in defending a more coherent and fair system, based on more solidarity and sharing of responsibility, which protects the most vulnerable, such as children. This has already been emphasised, among others, by Mrs Bildt. Mr President, this global pact, proposed within the United Nations, can correct the mistakes of the past, can improve the present of millions and anticipate a future in which those who flee from hunger and persecution are not surrendered to their fate but are supported by the world. And the European Union cannot escape its leading role.

name: Birgit Sippel (S&D).
text: Mr President! What is the United Nations Global Migration Compact? Flight and migration are global challenges, and most refugees are outside the European Union in regions that are much poorer and often more unstable than our continent. However, all states must make a contribution, including with the reception and integration of refugees. And the fact that the US of all countries, whose citizens were almost all originally migrants, evade this challenge is a staircase joke in history. The EU has a good position in the negotiations — with one exception: Orbán is fuking fears with lies in his country about the causes of flight and migration, and he also wants to prevent global migration. In our resolution we also call for the fight against racism and false news. I find it almost unbearable what I need to hear here today, and we should start combating false reports here in the House too. There is no mass migration in Europe. If, in 2015, if we had the arriving refugees evenly distributed across all countries in terms of population, for example, exactly 30 000 would have arrived in Hungary, and exactly 240 000 would have arrived in Germany instead of 880 000. I find it outrageous, as you say here, that the majority of European citizens do not want migration... ( Interruptions) (The President withdrew the speaker) (The speaker refused to answer a question by Mr Woolfe in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure laid down in Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: President. –
text: Ms Sippel, you are off the microphone. I think that you should show sufficient courtesy to your colleagues by respecting in the same way the time slot that you have received. The moment the President asks you to cease further comments, I would appreciate it if you would do so.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR).
text: Mr President! This discussion shows very clearly what is lackening in the migration crisis in particular: there is far too much ideology in this topic inside. And I think it is precisely inhumane for some here to pretend to have the philosopher's stone that says: we just have to open up more, we need to get more to the migrants, we need to get more to the migrants, we have to get them a safe crossing, and so on. This all sounds beautiful, but that's an illusion! We can see that, of course, we have mass migration in Europe — especially in some countries, including Germany — and we need to keep an eye on the feasibility of this. This feasibility has not only been achieved, it has also been exceeded in individual municipalities in Germany. Mrs Sippel, you are well aware that some mayors in Germany write incendiary and say, “We are no longer in control of the situation.” As you can say: “It's all theoretically solvable.” — I'm sorry, I don't understand that at all. (The speaker agreed to answer a question under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: question asked by raising the blue card. — Mr. colleague, I would like to ask you: How would you deal with the migration crisis in this case? What specific solution do you propose? Have you ever been to Africa? Have you ever been to a discussion with African statesmen? Do you know that in Africa a number of states profit from their workers working in Europe or other advanced states? What kind of solution would you suggest?

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Answer to a question about the 'blue card' procedure. — Thank you, Mr President, for this question. I was in Africa. I also spoke to the relevant parliamentarians there, and one thing is evident there time and again: if, for example, in Germany we have to spend EUR 20 000 a year on a refugee to take care of him, then we could help fifty or even a hundred people in North Africa with the same amount. That alone should make us think of whether we are going to be at the right point here at all.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the UN Global Compact for Migration and Refugees will be the first intergovernmentally negotiated agreement prepared under the auspices of the United Nations to cover all dimensions of international migration in a holistic and comprehensive manner. The global compact is a significant opportunity to improve governance on migration, to address the challenges associated with today’s migration, and to strengthen the contribution of migrants and migration to sustainable development. The UN has a leading role in defending and advancing the negotiations and EU Member States must unite behind a single EU position in order to promote a common European vision on migration, a vision which will be people-centred and human-rights based, and should provide for long-term sustainable and comprehensive measures for the benefit of all parties involved, building on the principle of a partnership strengthening cooperation among transit and destination countries in the region.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, migration is a complex phenomenon that is not going to end, no matter how many fences we build or barriers we place. I believe that building legal avenues and stepping up pledging efforts to resettle those in need is a key aspect in order to tackle the problem. I welcome the Compact on migration, and I appreciate its focus on people and the safeguard of their fundamental basic rights. This is of the utmost importance and should be the driver of any action taken. A safe, orderly and regular migration offers a wide range of opportunities to migrants, their countries of origin and the countries that host them. For instance, remittance has proved to be a tool that boosts development up to three times the total of the official development aid by contributing to the economy of the country of origin. In 2017, indeed, while migration was seriously challenging the global humanitarian aid system on the one hand, on the other hand an estimated USD 450 billion were transferred in remittances to developing countries.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the UN says that we must welcome all the emigrants in the world and that Italy must continue with the open door policy for all. We're madness. In five years, 700 000 immigrants have landed in Italy, false refugees. In 80% of the cases they are illegal immigrants, who do not run away from any war and potential terrorists are hiding among them, as Europol denounced. In these years Brussels and Italy's leftist governments have committed the folly of favoring illegal immigration. Over the past four years the Italian state has spent EUR 14 billion — our own money, money from Italians — to keep these illegals in hotels with breakfast, lunch and dinner. Not to mention the huge social costs this kind of immigration has brought to our cities: degradation, theft, violence. Enough now! Italians no longer want to take in illegal immigrants who have no right to stay in our country. We need few rules, clear and iron: border defense, fight against human traffickers, expulsion of all illegals. There is no other solution.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. Before Mrs Merkel's visit to Parliament, Vice-President Timmermans said: thank you, Mrs Merkel, now it is possible for the 100 to 140 million blacks from Africa to come to Europe. Mr Avramopoulos, you say that the first state in Europe is residing and does not want to take part in this global pact. The US has dropped out. Yeah, why is that? Why don't you even hold a referendum in Europe and have the people vote on what the population really wants? I say that Europe cannot integrate this mass rush, nor does Europe want to integrate these masses. Ask the people who want to live with the alienation in the cities, in the areas, in the suburbs. They had to introduce special laws in all the European states, so that hardly any citizen dares to say today: I am full of my mouth. We need to change something in this policy.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: — Mr President, this document, in which Parliament invokes all international commitments and repeatedly emphasises in the document the protection of human rights in relation to migration, is certainly need. But it nonetheless contains a number of vague phrases: where it is necessary to unite states in the fight against migration, the issue of resources and shared responsibility. The document only notes status, but offers no solutions. Ladies and gentlemen, we know that migration is a global problem, that it is necessary to stand up to this EU as an international actor and have a dialogue with the UN. But we need to look for a rational solution. We need to speak directly to African states and say how we will deal with the migration crisis. And we have to really tell ourselves who really is a migrant and who is a refugee. We also have to say to ourselves that we're not going to circumvent the rules in the future, that there aren't people going to walk across the European Union and tell each other which states they're going to and won't live in. If someone is at risk, they should accept the offer of the first member state and go through the procedure in that state. And the rest of us states should help manage this procedure as quickly as possible. Only if we ask ourselves a clear question can we look for the right answer. And that, unfortunately, was not laid in this document.

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. I believe that we are on a very right path with our resolution. We need to show our citizens that we want and can manage migration sustainably. We are concerned with lasting solutions, that is to say, resettlement of refugees, local integration and also return and, above all, the fight against the causes of flight on the ground. What we need for this is better international coordination, common binding objectives, solidarity and partnership between the countries of origin, transit countries and host countries. This is the key to better handling migration. The so-called Migration Pact and the Refugee Pact are important steps in this direction. They help to improve the implementation of existing principles and commitments. We European Socialists and Democrats are clearly and united behind the work of the United Nations. Because we need to create perspectives and address the root causes of global injustice — through an equal and fair partnership with Africa, for example. This includes fair trade, which we also need to talk about here. On this basis, we can work together on more effective development cooperation, conflict resolution and sustainable economic growth. That's our priority. It's not about charity. It's about justice and solidarity.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, the United Nations wants an international compact on migration to cover what it calls ‘all dimensions of international migration in a holistic and comprehensive manner’. This is supposed to be a non-legally binding document, but the danger is that if enough nations sign up to it, it may become what is known as customary international law.  So let’s be clear what the compact is all about: it is an illegal migrants charter. Its purpose is to make illegal migration legal and to facilitate it in greater numbers. The United Nations includes many countries that are deeply corrupt, politically and financially. They cannot provide their citizens with anything resembling democratic and prosperous societies protected by the rule of law, impartially implied. But the one thing that they can produce is more people, millions of whom want to flee their homelands, and who can blame them? The global compact is part of the intention of a global political elite to flood Europe and Western nations with never—ending millions of migrants from Africa, the Middle East and beyond. It is their intention to change the continent of Europe into something else in terms of its existing populations, culture and civilisation.  Immigration is of itself neither good nor bad. It depends entirely on the context. Every democratic nation state should have the right and freedom to decide its own immigration policy. What we are seeing in Europe now can only be described as invasion and settlement: it has nothing to do with immigration policy, but is an unprecedented exercise in social engineering in pursuit of an ideological goal. If European nations need a global compact on migration, it is one for international cooperation to protect our borders and control immigration, not one to make the current situation worse.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. The UN Pact on Migration and Refugees mingled two things: on the one hand, migration for economic reasons, and on the other hand, the refugees and asylum seekers, who should only seek and receive temporary protection, which is actually no migration. It has been quite rightly mentioned: we have millions of migrants, and only a fraction of them are coming to Europe. Nonetheless, we are already arguing here about whether it is mass immigration to Europe. However, we are only helping in fractions, while the same money on the ground allows us to provide real assistance to many, many millions more refugees. The aim of this UN Pact is now to increase incentives and opportunities for migration, thereby exacerbating the problems in the target countries. There is a very bitter aftertaste, Mrs Sippel — you can follow the debate further — if you cite here as an example the most disastrous example of migration, namely the United States.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE).
text: Mr President, the New York Declaration commits us to the adoption of a global compact on refugees in 2018 and a global compact for safe, regular and orderly migration, to be signed in Morocco in December. Forced migration is a human phenomenon, a reality as a result of armed conflict, terrorism or climate change. According to UNHCR, it is already known that, with 2015 data, about 65 million people were living in situations of forced displacement. The Emergency Trust Fund to Combat the Causes of Migration in Africa or the Union's Migration and Asylum Legislative Package are two key instruments to help manage this situation. Member States must join the commitment to the High Representative and promote the agreements contained in the New York Declaration. Only together on a global scale can these challenges be addressed. Developing countries hosting refugees must be assisted, and sustainably assisted. Coordination between humanitarian aid and development policies was essential to improve effectiveness, efficiency and aid to refugees. Cooperation between countries and regions is obliged. We need the global approach as a global response, and that essentially combines three areas: diplomacy, security and development cooperation.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, perhaps the most important thing to mention is that both UN global compacts are not binding. The quality and the importance of these compacts depend on what goes into them. It depends on the value of the compacts and that is why the first point I want to make is that the European Parliament should be closely involved, as Mr Díaz de Mera said, in the final Morocco conference. The Parliament should be there. We should be at the table. Why should we be at the table? We should be at the table because whether you are in denial about migration or whether you’re talking about managed migration, whether you don’t want it or whether you understand, as we did, as Ms Corazza Bildt will say, because we were in Niger and we saw the suffering and the push-backs. The Commissioner was there. We were in Agadez seeing what migration means – millions of people in West Africa outnumbering all of the refugees in the European Union. When you see that and you see the demographic needs in the European Union, if you want to deny it, deny it. But if we have no plan and we’re still depending on the Geneva Convention from just after the war and we have no plan, then say we don’t want it. But if we want to have a good-quality plan then we participate in the compact. I want Parliament to be at the table. Let’s be at the table. Let’s be at the final Morocco conference. Let’s participate. It is not binding, but the quality of this depends on us. Let’s be at the table, let’s negotiate. I say to the Commissioner, we want to be in Morocco, with my colleagues and let’s make it a holistic approach and let’s talk the talk and let’s ensure that Parliament makes a significant contribution.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF).
text: Mr President, I would like to point out a further persistent confusion in relation to migration. The idea of respecting the human rights of migrants on European territory has shifted to an idea that was not intended at all, namely that migration is a human right. One who has understood this very well is the Hungarian Government, which, in a barely two-page document, the 'Proposals by Hungary to the UN's Global Compact on migration', states in paragraph 3: 'Migration is not a basic human right'. And it is. That is why we, as the ENF, defend the idea that the Geneva Convention should be revised as soon as possible. She dates back to a completely different time. She was meant for quite different things. And it hinders a normal and modern view of migration, adapted to what the population of Europe today thinks of the migration that has happened to it.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: Mr President, we are witnessing a large increase in the phenomenon of mobility, not only for economic reasons but also for political persecution, crisis or conflict. No region in the world is more or less alien to these population flows, and international coordination should therefore be strengthened for the better management of these flows and, at the same time, ensuring the rights of migrants and refugees. Dialogue between recipient, origin and transit countries is essential. Europeans must play a leading role in the United Nations in drafting the global pacts as we enter the so-called intergovernmental phase of negotiation: we can provide our experiences and our vision of this problem. For me, there is a need for an analysis and also a realistic debate on migration, which takes into account its positive potential, but we cannot ignore the security concerns of transit or origin States, nor the limits of their capacity for economic and social integration. Europeans have known migratory phenomena and their tragic problems in recent years. We have experienced the so-called refugee crisis, which affected the eastern Mediterranean and also the central Mediterranean. Still today, the Mediterranean continues to be the scene of daily news about irregular migration attempts or flows. We need to continue to intensify dialogue and cooperation with countries of origin and transit. I would like to stress the importance of the Valletta Plan of Action and the agreements reached with some countries of the Sahel. On migration, in short, we Europeans must give priority attention to our relations with Africa and to attack the deep roots of migratory phenomena. Underdevelopment, crises and conflicts account for many of these flows. And I'm done. I think it is also necessary to intensify — and I end with this consideration — the fight against the mafias that traffic with the lives and dreams of so many human beings.

name: Norbert Neuser (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. What some of the contributions came from the ENF and the non-attached Members is disgraceful because we do not see any political will to solve the problems, but only the intention to capitalise on this difficult situation in which we are. In their view, Fidesz and Jobbik did an excellent job in the elections — unfortunately. Unfortunately, many of their fellow citizens have gone on their glue in this situation. I think the global pact is a good chance. We are united in the EU — with the exception of one country, namely Hungary. Viktor Orbán is the one who makes us implausible as the EU. He and Hungary must stand by what is common ground: we stand for human rights, and this includes the right to provide sensible care for refugees who come to us. We need to take care of what happens to the children and women, and we need to find solutions. All that I heard is the opposite of what is needed. We need — as previous speakers have said — a strengthening of development cooperation. We were too late. But if we tackle the causes of flight, we're on the right track.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF).
text: — Mr President, the UN's plan to establish a global compact on refugees is very worrying. It is based on the idea that mass migration is inevitable and that more migrants must be accommodated, whether they are real political refugees or mere economic migrants. None of the reasons put forward to justify this forced immigrationism is convincing. Europe's demographic decline must be combated by natalist policies, not immigration. The alleged richness that cultural diversity would bring is only a mirage designed to conceal the sinister reality of communitarianism. As for the argument based on respect for human rights, he cannot conceal this truth that the primary duty of a State was to ensure the security and preservation of the national identity of its people. It is not a global pact to promote immigration that the world needs, but international cooperation that allows every State to ensure a decent life for its nationals within its borders.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I recall President Juncker declaring, at the beginning of this parliamentary term, when Italy was under a very strong migratory pressure, that “the migratory phenomenon and these dramatic events cannot be an Italian problem, but it is a European problem”. Here we go further: it becomes a problem to be addressed internationally; that is why we have to support these pacts. Of course, it must be said, the United States has defilated and it must be said that at this moment we are seeing an increase in migration pressure from minors, children, women, who suffer violence unenarrable, who are not schooled in their countries of origin and are not even when they come to Europe. So what is missing within these resolutions is implementing EU foreign policy, implementing European defence policy, not least because there has been an increase in conflict — the bombing in Syria — and the European Union heard about it afterwards, as if it had been a broadcast in deferred and this is very serious. It has to go hand in hand.

name: Kati Piri (S&D).
text: Mr President, it is good that a serious attempt is being made within the United Nations to reach mutual agreements in order to make the issue of migration more manageable and, at the same time, to ensure that people who have to flee are safely taken care of. The EU must take the lead in this, despite the fact that a small number of European Heads of Government such as Viktor Orban are obstructing. It is therefore very important that our European governments do not leave it just fine words, but actually take action. More than 1 million vulnerable refugees worldwide are eligible for resettlement. But the EU countries together have made no progress in two years than providing this safe and legal route to 25000 people. This political failure still leads to refugees dying on their way to a safe place. Those governments that do want to think solution-oriented must ensure that the UN process leads to substantially more places offered for this group of vulnerable refugees.

name: László Tőkés (PPE).
text: - Mr President, As a whole, the UN draft migration document considers global mass migration, which it intends to encourage and organise, as a positive phenomenon. On the other hand, Hungary considers migration to be a bad and dangerous process, which must be restricted and stopped. For the security of Europe and because of the threat of terrorism, the migration crisis is not a temporary crisis, but a long-lasting challenge for all of us, Manfred Weber warns. With these in mind, while not denying the importance of global cooperation, I call on the European Parliament not to provide opportunistic support to the UN draft Migration Pact. I also consider it unacceptable for the Union to stigmatise and punish Hungary and its allies for its anti-migration position. We cannot allow migration to be free. Migration cannot be regarded as a fundamental human right. The right of self-determination and the sovereignty of Member States, guaranteed by the UN Charter, must be respected.

name: Boris Zala (S&D).
text: – Mr President, migration is a big link in global governance. The two UN agreements rightly focus on easing the human suffering and safeguarding the rights of millions of refugees and migrants, but migration has now become a geopolitical challenge too. Governments cynically use refugees as a strategic bargaining chip, for example Turkey. But some countries of origin in Africa are doing the same. In the destination countries, the issue is abused by extremist forces. It has driven a wedge into the heart of European politics. The use of migration as a geopolitical weapon is an extremely dangerous phenomenon and will cause more instability unless there is a strong multilateral regime to govern migration flows. The European Union must be at the forefront of this effort.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE).
text: — President Macron said very rightly this morning that a large number of European citizens are angry. But they are not angry about the fact that the European Union is too strong, but on the contrary, that the European Union is slow and inefficient and is slowly adapting to the changing world around us. Paradoxically, those same people who criticise the European Union are not ready to give the European Union instruments for us to be quick and effective and to adapt to the changes around us. European citizens are asking us to ensure their physical and social security. The fears of European citizens are being exploited by various political players trying to get dividends from this. While economic problems can be dealt with by ourselves to a large extent, the issues of terrorism and migration require a global response. In order to find a lasting solution to the migration problem, apart from the global migration management policy, the focus must be maintained on tackling the various primary sources of irregular migration and forced investigations: conflict, persecution, ethnic cleansing, violence and others factors such as extreme poverty or natural disasters. Last but not least, in order to tackle this problem, we need to work to protect the external borders, for common defence, for general intelligence, exchange of information on the fight against terrorism, to limit migration into the European Union. We must ensure very swift return of those migrants from the territory of the European Union, who are subject to return and have no right to remain here. Here, too, I would like to call on giving the High Representative, Mrs Mogherini, much more opportunities for a common European policy on security and migration.

name: Soraya Post (S&D).
text: - Mr President! Large parts of the resolution show a direction that the EU must take. In particular, the wording that we must secure the right of fleeing and migrant people to their human rights and that the exposure that arises from the circumstances of the country of origin when you migrate and how you are received is a result of political choices. After all, there are no weak people, but weak structures. We see it in terms of migration, both within Europe and except Europe. So we need to open the borders of the EU. We need to increase the number of quota refugees. We need to remove barriers to family reunification. We also need to provide amnesty for asylum seekers who have been waiting for a long time and we must secure the rights and security of undocumented people. EU migration policy must be firmly in the rule of law and in respect for human rights, and this will never be negotiable.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner Mogherini, there is rarely a coincidence in politics between what is urgent and important, but this is the case, because if there is something urgent and important it is to change the European Union's negative gaze on immigration, which is not a crisis or a threat, but a constant in history that is here to stay. And the European Union has a duty to deal with it in an orderly and secure manner with all the parties involved, and to do so in accordance with European law, which establishes not only the moral duty to assist those fleeing despair, but also the legal obligation to do so in accordance with international law and European law, in particular. Now is the time to meet the United Nations objective: a global compact, a global pact for immigration, that orders the issue and faces the enemies of that global commitment; outside the European Union, the Trump presidency, and within the European Union, the xenophobic discourse of some countries, such as that of the Orbán government. But it is time to do so, moreover, in line with the common European asylum system and finally imposing a legal and safe avenue for regular immigration into the European Union: humanitarian visas.

name: Elly Schlein (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, if 86% of displaced people from around the world are housed in developing countries, it is clear that the issue of greater sharing of responsibility for welcome is not only European but global. And now that great powers are paraded, it is necessary for the EU to lead itself in this process, finding a single and strong voice in this negotiation. But we would be more credible in calling for solidarity with other global players if we were able to demonstrate it within ourselves, by approving the courageous reform of Dublin, proposed by this Parliament, than ensures that each state does its part. What we do not want to see in the compact is the tendency towards outsourcing the borders of European governments, just as we do not want to see the tendency to condition aid development to greater control of African borders. Here, we do not miss the opportunity with the global compact to reiterate that we are talking about people with their fundamental rights, to create legal and safe avenues for access to refugees and migrants as the only way to counter traffickers and to contribute, with development, to create real opportunities for young Africans.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: — Mr President, I agree that the migration wave is simply a challenge that both the UN and the EU must respond to in a coordinated approach. In particular, we should take into account the plight of children and women. However, I have fundamental reservations about the draft UN pact and the European Parliament resolution. Above all, the UN global pact sees migration as a big and positive opportunity. I simply don't identify with that kind of vision, because I see migration to Europe in that migration wave like that we are experiencing as a problem. Secondly, resettlement programmes would have to remain voluntary and the EU cannot seek their commitment. Finally, third, legal routes for refugees must not act as a motivational pull factor for massive migration. I think the EU's priority should be peace and respect for the human rights of citizens in their original countries.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I am proud that the Socialists and Democrats Group took the lead on supporting Ms Mogherini in her efforts to strengthen the international framework for migration. Free movement is a human right, Article 13 of the Universal Declaration. It should be protected at all levels and we must support the international rules that ensure all migrants are treated in a way that respects their dignity. It is also important to recognise and support the work of community groups who defend migrants’ dignity. In my north—west England constituency, RAPAR has been working alongside migrants for decades. Today, they are extremely worried about the UK’s hostile environment, which pressures migrants to voluntarily return to their home countries. RAPAR is exceptionally concerned that the Home Office is now infiltrating community groups and setting up voluntary returns clinics with the clear aim of pushing vulnerable people to leave the UK. Migrants in all European countries deserve to live in safe communities, supported by neutral organisations, without the pressure to return.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: — Mr President, the UN draft pact to manage migratory and refugee movements makes sense. The question is whether the European Union will really make a difference, will open up legal and safe, controlled, and therefore, through the revision of the Dublin regime, so that immigrants and refugees do not have to keep putting their lives in danger in the hands of drug mafias to get to a safe country. Because European governments have effectively contributed to feeding these mafias, not opening up legal and safe channels. It is essential that the European Union does not continue to externalise responsibilities as it has done with Turkey and Libya and effectively be careful in the use of taxpayers' money, notably in development policies that serve regimes, governments that actually want to give rise to the conditions of development, democracy and progress for their peoples, rather than suppressing them and thus making them refugees and migrants. Salih Mahmoud Osman, the 2007 Sakharov Prize, before being arrested again in his country in Sudan, came here to warn us precisely against these alleged development policies, which count on criminals such as Omar al-Bashir, as if he were our friend and cooperating with serious policy in this area.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the situation in the Aegean islands is getting worse. There are now increased refugee and migratory flows. Compared to last year, the situation is worse and of course we have a great many who are illegal immigrants. The Aegean islands cannot afford other refugees and illegal immigrants. At the same time, we see a migration flow from the side of Evros, on the land borders of Greece and Turkey. I therefore think that we need to see the need to reinstate the relocation process, because the previous programme was only one-third in relation to Greece, Germany had to take 17,209 people with relocation and took only 4,447 people. So you understand that, with such a policy, it is impossible to cope with the huge refugee and migratory flows towards Europe and especially towards Greece.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, the European Union is at the forefront of the UN's global pacts and claims to defend and demand security, immigration, solidarity with refugees and states, and a human-centered approach to refugee refugees. At the same time, it pays Turkey to keep refugees stranded and finances it to buy tanks to prevent them from reaching Europe, knowingly violating the Geneva Convention on Refugees and the European Treaties. It tolerates Member States closing borders, not accepting refugees and blocking the necessary revision of the Dublin Regulation and not only does it not condemn, but also stands with France and Britain, which bombed Syria the day before yesterday, in contempt for these UN institutions too; at the risk of creating new waves of refugees. Tell me, Commissioners, with what moral authority will you defend in the United Nations treaties and values which are scorned by Member States of the European Union and are trampled by the very institution you represent? What is the common European position on the refugee situation? That's all I want you to tell me.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: — Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, 15 907 migrants have died in the Mediterranean since 2014. Those who manage to overcome the walls of Fortress Europe and reach the territory of the EU await us the increasing limitations on the right of asylum and integration, persecution, violence, discrimination await us, the shameful and inhuman conditions of detention centres, authentic concentration camps of the today awaits them either forced repulsion, or brutal labour exploitation and, worse, sexual exploitation. Those who cannot despair and are exploited in the camps of Turkey or feed slave labor in Libya's camps, realities financed by the European Union. It is the consequences of criminal, xenophobic and racist migratory policies that the EU imposes and promotes, violating international law, human rights and human dignity. The absence of EU contributions to the construction of the compacts will be the greatest contribution to ensuring the rights and protection of migrants in fact.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL).
text: — Mr President, I think there is no doubt that we need a Global Pact to address the migration issue. But I dare say, at least in relation to the European dimension of the immigration issue, and I stress that I say 'issue' rather than 'problem' or much more 'risk', that the United Nations was absent from its European dimension and that the European Union was left alone to deal with the issue of a few million refugees from Syria. There are no sanctions against states that do not assume their responsibilities against migratory flows, such as Hungary. I shall conclude with a reference to Turkey to say that, in my view, there is an exaggerated fear that Turkey will use immigrants in the country as a lever, because I think that when the border from Greece to Europe is closed, there is no strong will to do so. part of the refugees started to come to the Greek islands and have the fate of immigrants in these places, a fate much worse than the situation in the country they are in.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: Mr President, while the United States of America, together with France and M. Britain, bombing Syria, with the full support of the European Union and NATO, the European Union, and with the prepared UN Accords, is posing as the protector of the rights of refugees uprooted by the bombing, its people and its allies. You invoke principles. Your principles are the bombings, the entrapment on the Greek islands, the lives in appalling conditions of thousands of refugees, quota competitions, fast-track deportations, thousands of family reunions pending. Immediate migration for you is to open and close the faucet and, for those migrants who are left and who are not directly needed as fuel for European monopolies, consider them illegal. We demand human reception and hospitality areas, we demand their evacuation from the Greek islands and the mainland and we demand that they be able to travel to their final destination countries. We must strengthen the solidarity and the common struggle of the peoples against the rotten capitalist system of exploiting the wars of refugees!

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I listened carefully to this debate and I thank this House for its support for the difficult work we are trying to do in the UN system on the global compacts on migration and refugees, in a global environment that, it is quite clear to all of us, is a challenging one and in particular on issues like this. We are well aware of our responsibilities in this respect, I would say on two different levels, both of them extremely important. One is the investment in the UN system and in multilateral approaches, as such. We know very well that this is challenged from different sides in the world of today. And we know very well that the world looks at the European Union to create, consolidate and strengthen alliances globally to work in a multilateral manner. This could be true for issues related to different things, from trade to human rights and crisis management, but also on migration and refugees. So we know that the UN system counts on us. We know that the partners around the world count on us to make sure that the multilateral approach and the multilateral method are the ones followed when tackling a global issue. I would never – never – say ‘problem’, because we’re not talking about a problem, if not for those fleeing countries at war or facing forced movements. As for the specifics of our responsibilities, we know that we have a responsibility to uphold a certain approach to the migration issues and also on refugees. On refuges, this is clearly full respect of values and, in particular, full respect of international principles and regulations. And it is also a matter of the basic moral compass that for us as the European Union is a must, and this entails full respect of human rights and the consideration that every single person that is a refugee or migrant is first and foremost a human being and, as such, has individual human rights that are impossible to be considered as subject to discussions or negotiations. We also know that we have a responsibility to build consensus globally on a certain way of managing migration. I say ‘managing migration’. I don’t say ‘stopping a problem’. I say managing migration, which is the partnership approach. The European Union has not always been on this line. The European Union has, in the past, several times either turned its eyes away from this issue, leaving the front-line Member States alone. Or some other times – I still sometimes see this temptation here and there – it has taken the security approach, as if it were a border management issue. Migration movements are massive global phenomena that need to be managed together with partnerships that involve countries of origin, countries of transit, and countries of destination. Some of these countries are at the same time the three and the international agencies of the United Nations system. I will give you an example of how this partnership approach is bringing results, because this is the basis on which we are going to work. And we are already working in the UN system to try to build a global alliance around this model. Take the dramatic situation in the detention camps in Libya. We have discussed this in this chamber several times. And several times I have told you we are working to close these camps. Last December we established a joint task force between the European Union, the African Union, United Nations with UNHCR and the IOM, and we set the target of emptying the detention camps and, as an intermediate target, to save 15 000 of the people that were in the detention camps in Libya in the coming two months. We have managed to save more than 16 000 of them in less than two months and have assisted them in returning voluntarily to their own local communities and supported them with reintegration projects and economic start-up activities. And we are about to completely empty the detention centres in Libya. The news was shocking and striking when we saw the images and the stories from the detention camps. I would also like us to tell the stories of those whom we managed to save as we empty the detention camps. Because this helps us pass on the message inside Europe and outside of Europe, that this is not the policy we’ve chosen purely out of values and good feelings. This is also the policy that is bringing results. It’s cooperation and partnership, and not walls, that is bringing results in migration policies, and we are starting to see good results. We will continue to take this approach, hoping for a united position between the Member States of the European Union But let me tell you we will exercise our responsibilities and duties in the UN context on migration and refugees. We will, I imagine, continue to discuss this issue in this chamber in the coming months as we go towards the summit and then the finalisation of this work towards the end of the year. I count on this Parliament to follow this work very closely on a day-to-day basis to help us to build this way of working, both internally within the European Union and outside it. I will not refer here to the issues related to Dublin or to other decisions related to solidarity internally that still, I believe, should be tackled. But today in this building I speak of a global compact both on migration and on refugees based on the principles of human rights and respectful partnership across the globe.

name: Πρόεδρος.
text: I have received two motions for resolutions pursuant to Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure. Discussion is over. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 18 April 2018.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D)
text: in writing. — (NL) If we want to reverse the growing reluctance of parts of our societies towards migrants, we must show citizens that migration policy can be different. We must offer European citizens and migrants an alternative to the images of rickety boats in the Mediterranean, the jungle of Calais or the abuses in crowded asylum centres and refugee camps. That is why the Global Compacts are an important opportunity that we have to fill in ambitiously. I am proud that the European Parliament is able to present a strong text today. In much of the world, migration is both a challenge for society and an opportunity for the economy. In order not to fall under the challenge and reap the benefits of this opportunity, we need to work together. This means financial solidarity for vulnerable regions and common organisation of legal migration channels. A good migration policy strengthens people instead of making them more vulnerable. That is why I am pleased that the text also focuses on children, who already, but much more in the coming years, represent a significant proportion of the number of migrants. Parliament reaffirmed today that human rights are the key, not the obstacle, to sound policy.

name: Πρόεδρος.
text: — The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Syria (2018/2673 (RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, 10 days ago chemical weapons were used yet again in Syria, on the outskirts of Damascus this time. We have said very clearly time and again that, even when the war in Syria disappears from the headlines, we always have to remember that the war in Syria is not over yet and, in particular, that the use of chemical weapons is a pattern which we have seen developing from the regime side over the years. The entire international community, we believe, considers the regime’s use of chemical weapons entirely unacceptable, but for Europeans, it most certainly is. Our response as the European Union was very clear, united, and immediate. The use of chemical weapons is unacceptable to us, and those responsible must be held accountable. Accountability is also a key element when it comes to building a new future for Syria, as I think President Macron very rightly mentioned here this morning in the Chamber. We, as the European Union, have always worked in all the different contexts that we could, and we continue to do so, in order to re-establish an independent mechanism for investigating the use of chemical weapons in Syria. Today we are working to enable the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons to investigate and report on the most recent attack.  You have all followed the targeted strikes carried out by France, the United States and the United Kingdom on chemical facilities in Syria with one objective: to prevent the regime from using chemical weapons again. You will also have seen the reactions, including the declaration I issued a few hours later on behalf of the 28 Member States, and the Council conclusions which we adopted yesterday and cover not only the issue of the use of chemical weapons, but also, more generally, our common position on the conflict in Syria.
