The main point here is this: now more than ever, it is clear that the only sustainable, the only pragmatic, the only possible solution, to the war in Syria is a political solution. After seven years, there is certainly no doubt: there is no military solution to the war. The only way to end this conflict is through the intra-Syrian talks in Geneva, between the Syrian parties, under the leadership of the United Nations. Now more than ever, it is time to invest all our work, all our convening power, all our political capital, to push the Syrian parties towards the negotiating table and finally start meaningful negotiations; not just talks for the sake of talks, but meaningful negotiations.  This was the message that I delivered just the day before yesterday in Saudi Arabia, where I had the honour to open the Annual Summit of the Arab League and where I also had the opportunity to meet the UN Special Envoy, Staffan de Mistura, with whom I spoke at length about the current situation and how to relaunch the political process. I also had the chance there to discuss and share with all the leaders of the region not only our analysis, but also the need for a renewed regional effort in order to try to put an end to the war in Syria through a political process.  Next week, exactly one week from now, all the relevant international and regional players will gather for the second Brussels Conference on the future of Syria and the region, which I will have the honour and the responsibility to chair, together with the United Nations. This Brussels Conference was planned long ago. We had a ministerial preparatory meeting as far back as September at the margins of the UN General Assembly. It will be even more relevant today in the current circumstances because it is the first huge international event that gathers different players that are, let’s say, on different sides in this war, and the EU-UN co-chairmanship is obviously an excellent opportunity to try to build a path towards a political solution. We will make full use of the conference to do just that: to shift the focus now to diplomacy and peace-making. With no meaningful UN-led political talks, it is only a matter of time before the next military escalation comes. The risk of splitting the country into zones of influence is increasing by the day. The Geneva talks represent the only path that can lead towards a peaceful, united, independent and truly democratic Syria, in all its diversity. At the Brussels Conference we will have over 80 delegations around the table, as I said, with very different positions among themselves. I see this as an opportunity to collectively and consistently commit to stopping the violence and supporting the Geneva process. We want to bring together – it will not be easy, but nor will it be impossible – those who have leverage not just on the Syrian parties, as we always mention – in part because on the Syrian opposition we have the leverage ourselves and we have been working with them and we continue to work with them day by day –, but mainly those who have leverage on the Syrian regime, which so far has not committed seriously to the political talks in Geneva. It has not entered into the mechanism and the dynamic of negotiation. Those who have leverage will work together towards new and meaningful intra-Syrian talks under the auspices of the UN.  I am also proud of one thing that I believe this Parliament will understand very well. We will host at the conference hundreds of delegates from Syrian civil society groups – Syrians – women and men, most of them coming from inside Syria. I know that some may think that this is a marginal issue, that it is even something nice to say, something naive, that as war is going on it is a sort of distraction, but these are the real people on the ground who are experiencing the suffering of the war. They are also what I would call the everyday Syrian heroes. They are incredibly precious for the country and its future because Syria will not be taken out of the conflict or be reconstructed in the sense of building the country a democratic future if the international community, starting with the European Union, does not invest in those Syrians that want to build a democratic, peaceful and united country. The future of Syria lies – and this is a minor detail that the international community tends to forget –and has to lie only in the hands of the Syrian people and no one else. It is not a chessboard. It is a country with people and citizens, and we want to bring the voices, the faces, the hopes, the dreams, but also the ideas and the aspirations of the Syrian people to the stage. That is democracy. That is the way we intend it.  We believe it will have to be up to them to decide on the new institutions of the country, to make them inclusive, democratic, and, at the end of the day, make sure that every Syrian man, woman and child, beyond ethnicity, faith and political or social background, everyone will have the right to feel protected, safe, welcome, and at home in the Syria of the future.  Many people ask about preconditions – who has to step back or forwards, one step in or out. The real answer, which is borne of pragmatism, from our side, is this: we need a political process that guarantees that every single Syrian inside the country, including those that are currently outside of the country, can feel at home in the Syria of the future. That is it. That is what the political process in Geneva should guarantee. What we can do as Europe, as the international community, is to invest all our resources, to move from a context of never-ending escalation on the ground, which is repeating itself cyclically, to one of true political negotiations. It is not easy, otherwise it would probably have been successful long ago, it is not easy, but we will work on this in Brussels next week, on renewing our humanitarian pledges, which are essential and vital, on the resilience of the Syrian people, and on the only way to make our humanitarian work sustainable, which is to unlock the Geneva talks. This is what we are working on every single day with the United Nations, and this is what we will try to deliver in Brussels next week.

name: José Ignacio Salafranca Sánchez-Neyra
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (ES) Mr President, High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, I think this Parliament would be wrong if it focused its debate today on this 'surgical intervention ', as President Macron described it this morning, about its legitimacy or not. In any event, the use of the Syrian chemical weapons regime against its people is a proven fact. The real debate, apart from the horrible humanitarian crisis, is whether we are dealing with a new episode — as the Secretary-General of the United Nations said — of the Cold War. The withdrawal of the United States, what has happened in the electoral processes in France, Germany, the referendum in the United Kingdom, the support for separatist movements in Spain make it clear that we are facing a new scenario and a new configuration of threats: cyberterrorism, nuclear proliferation, increased race weapons, mass intoxication on social media. Mr President, Syria is the greatest failure of the international community, and that questions ourselves and our role in the world. It is important to know whether the Member States, Madam High Representative, have a strategy for this conflict in Syria apart, of course, from achieving the objective of supporting the efforts of the UN Secretary-General's special envoy. You, Madam High Representative, have made a great effort in launching the Union's defence policy. Today we will not be able to provide security to our citizens without laying the foundations of a defence policy. There is no time to waste, and we wish him luck in his purposes and at the Brussels Conference.

name: Victor Boştinaru
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the length and the horrors of the Syrian conflict are impossible to describe, and I believe they will be on our conscience in the long term. I was appalled by the cynical positioning of some, including in this House, on Monday evening who, since the last chemical attacks, were denying the obvious lightening up of the seriousness of the attacks and others before.  Do we really have to choose between fighting terrorism and promoting civilian and human rights? I don’t think so. I will make clear once again that Assad is engaging in what the UN has termed the ‘crime of extermination’. The vast majority of the Syrian victims were killed by the Syrian—Russian—Iranian alliance in deliberate, indiscriminate attacks. They have targeted hospitals and rescue workers, and they are impeding humanitarian aid to those in need. Several chemical attacks have been committed in this country. There is no doubt about that, and there is no doubt that these are unacceptable acts under international law in the Geneva Conventions. The targeted US, French and UK air strikes were a necessary response in order to prevent the future use of chemical weapons. Russia has vetoed 11 times – I repeat, 11 times – the UN Security Council resolutions on Syria, and undermines the ones adopted. I am firmly convinced that the only solution for ending the war in Syria is a negotiated political solution, where Europe should work in coordination with the UN in general and the UN Security Council. What remains to be done today? I will continue our calls for a ceasefire to implement the resolutions on the territory. It is necessary to reinvigorate the UN political process, and formally we have to support the work of the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW) and its findings on Syria. Finally, we urge the EU to rapidly re—establish an independent attribution mechanism to ensure accountability.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, it was Ghouta in 2013, Khan Shaykhun in 2017 and only 10 days ago Douma. These are the spots on the map which have become tragic names to all of us as the sights of atrocious chemical weapon attacks in Syria. There are some in this House that question the evidence and many more that doubt their attribution to the brutal Assad regime. There will be no cast-iron guaranteed independent sources, Assad will make sure of that. But the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons and the UN have each verified the use of chemical weapons banned since 1925. And the British, French, US and other Western governments, NATO and the European Union have all concluded that the Assad regime is culpable. The continued use of chemical weapons is wholly unacceptable, and allowing this to continue with impunity cannot be tolerated. Russia has repeatedly used its veto at the UN Security Council to stop chemical-weapons-related resolutions on six occasions since 2017 alone. Such use of the UNSC veto to protect tyrants and violations of international humanitarian law, or the use of prohibited types of weapons can provide, in my view, under the evolving ‘right to protect’ doctrine, legal justification for the use of military force to deter or prevent further humanitarian crises. Given the potential for unintended consequences and escalation, military intervention is a decision not to be taken lightly. The targeted and very limited air strikes carried out are specifically and solely aimed at impeding President Assad’s regime’s chemical weapon capabilities and must surely be seen for what they are, which is the West’s determination to deter future use of chemical weapons by tyrants everywhere across the globe.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, thank you. High Commissioner, colleagues, – or High Representative, excuse me – every time we discuss Syria we have to mourn more deaths, more who have forcibly disappeared or been raped or tortured, and recently – despite the alleged destruction of Syria’s chemical weapons, despite international law – hundreds, including children, choked to death because of the use of chemical weapons. Those children cannot possibly be terrorists, as President Assad claims with every citizen that he kills, and this cannot go unanswered. But even now – and we’ve heard it as the EU position over and over again – the mantra is that there is no military solution to the war in Syria.  The question that I want to ask is whether all this is happening because we have no decisive role in creating peace and contributing to peace in Syria. Clearly – and I really hate to say this – military brutality by the cynical coalition of Assad, Putin and Tehran-steered militants is creating facts on the ground, and the facts amount to war crimes. I’m convinced of that. So when we as the EU repeat that there is no military solution, what we must avoid is a situation in which this becomes the carte blanche for the status quo and for facts creeping ever further on the ground. We desperately need an EU strategy to end the war in Syria  if we want to be serious about ending the war. Seven years of bloodshed, several vetoes by our Member States, disruption in Syria and the Middle East – and an impact here in Europe, with people seeking shelter and asylum, which is also – unfortunately – feeding politics of fear seeking to exploit the situation. This impacts us globally and certainly in Europe. So I think that next week’s Syria conference is another opportunity for the EU to develop a strategy and I consider it welcome that accountability and justice are to be the key priority. That is an essential ingredient for peace, and so hopefully the EU as a whole can build on the Dutch, German and Swedish initiative to centralise accountability.  (Applause)

name: Barbara Lochbihler
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. Next week's Brussels donor conference on Syria should focus on the following areas: protection of civilians, humanitarian aid and assistance to refugees, prospects for peaceful Syria. During the military offensive in East Ghouta, which began in February, the Syrian army and its allies committed massive war crimes through heavy bombing of the besieged civilians with thousands of deaths and injuries. Ten days ago, the Syrian Army is said to have used chemical weapons against civilians in the city of Duma. It is important that these allegations are now being investigated by inspectors of the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons on the ground. The use of weapons of mass destruction must remain an absolute taboo. A longer-term presence of international inspectors in Syria is needed to guarantee the complete destruction of the chemical arsenal there. I strongly reject the military strikes by the United States, France and the UK last weekend. Without an international mandate and in combination with President Trump's war rhetoric, this military action posed a significant risk of wildfire. And it is important that the international community is committed to ensuring that all those responsible for war crimes committed in Syria are held accountable. I therefore welcome the fact that the EU Foreign Ministers have once again made very clear this this week. Finally, the Syria Conference must make it clear that only political negotiations can provide a perspective for peaceful Syria. There must be an immediate ceasefire for conflict resolution. For this it will be necessary to bring all parties back to the negotiating table. Coordinated European diplomacy must also contribute to this. The donor conference must guarantee humanitarian aid in the region in the long term. In addition, together with representatives of civil society, scope for further support measures should be explored.

name: Gabriele Zimmer
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative. I believe it was a good decision to focus your speech primarily on what needs to be done and how the EU intends to act in order to ultimately help to end the untenable, inhuman conditions and involvement of global nuclear powers in this conflict and to lead to a stable long-term solution. come. The main problem, however, is that some of the Heads of Government, who are responsible — including within the EU — are now pretending that what happened last weekend is more or less a symbolic act, a kind of sandbox game. But I don't think we're sitting in a sandbox, and everyone — at least that was my impression — was happy at the end of the day that there was no further escalation. How can it be, however, that we are talking, on the one hand, about the fact that we want diplomatic, political solutions to talk about the untenable conditions within the UN Security Council through the veto policy of some states — particularly Russia — and, on the other hand, tremble that Russia will hopefully not take adequate measures to take on what the US, France and the UK reacted? It has been a fatal mistake that Russia broke off the joint UN investigation mechanism last year after it proved that chemical weapons were used by the Assad regime a year ago. And it is all to be done to give us joint mechanisms of investigation again so that it finally comes to the day, and those responsible for this must be punished. That's indisputable here in the house. What is controversial, however, is to what extent one's own launch, without having prior evidence, really serves to open the political and diplomatic doors and bring all those involved to the table. This is just not the case! What happened has been counterproductive, and you have to say that clearly! Our job is to really get everyone involved involved in preventing some wild believers that sandbox games can satisfy their own ego, but ultimately endanger the lives of hundreds of thousands of people. And one thing I have to say about this: if the aim was to destroy production deposits of chemical warfare agents, then this is just as dangerous as, for example, to say: you want to punish the breach of international law by responding to the breach of international law. The destruction of ordnance production facilities ensures the release of warfare agents. This endangers people, which threatens the future and people's lives and health. And I would like to know if there is information on the extent to which warfare agents have lephemerged and to what extent there have been changes there. This needs to be investigated in the same way as any previous allegations.

name: Gerard Batten
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, Ms Mogherini said that there is no military solution to the war in Syria, but of course the cold, hard, unpalatable fact is that Assad and the Russians were actually close to defeating ISIS. I and my party, the UK Independence Party, have no sympathy whatsoever for President Assad: he is a tyrant who is quite capable of killing his own people, I have no doubt. But ISIS is much worse.  There is no proof that Assad’s regime was actually responsible for the chemical attack, and let me quote, if I may, a higher authority on this – the former First Sea Lord, Admiral West: ‘I think we need unequivocal proof that this chemical attack was done by Assad’s forces. [...] as a military man, if I’d been advising Assad, I’d have said ‘you’re about to take over that bit of territory, you’ve clearly got the whole of that area now under your control. Why on earth would you do something that would bring the international forces in?” If I’d been advising the opposition, I’d have said “get a barrel of chlorine gas here, at some stage there will be bombs dropped on you – when that happens blow it up and we can blame them, because what we really want is the allies coming in’.”’ Yesterday, in this Chamber, we had MEPs who would normally condemn President Trump out of hand warmly supporting him because he is dropping bombs on the Assad regime. All they were doing was virtue signalling to the rest of the world that they oppose chemical attacks on civilians. Well, who doesn’t?  But who actually did it? What this Parliament should have been doing yesterday was actually asking questions: ‘What proof is there that Assad did it?’, ‘Who benefits from this attack?’, instead of making statements that they can’t substantiate, and Mr Tajani said that this House was overwhelmingly supportive of the bombings. Well, it wasn’t. There were three groups that actually spoke against it, and if we are sensible about this we should not just be knee-jerk reacting to these terrible attacks, but actually asking questions on a very serious matter: who ultimately benefits? (Applause)

name: Mario Borghezio
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, High Representative, is our colleague Batten right: whose prodest? If we were to see the consequences, consult Bloomberg, note the fact of the leap forward in the oil price and reflect on, about the “whose prodest.” And on the subject of statements, there is a new one made today, in this House, by the High Representative, that this situation demonstrates — I quote — the ever-increasing influence of Europe. You think that only, the High Representative, because everyone else thinks, according to what is read in the international press, exactly the opposite, that is that this situation has seen Europe totally absent. Others are our concerns: while Russia, Iran and even Israel show that they have a precise strategy, it is the Americans, that is the authors of the blitz together with other countries, who show that they do not having one, unless you have to reflect on what James Mattis writes, that terrorism is no longer the US fight target, has been abandoned. Then we understand why those who helped defeat the Islamic State are attacked. There are many doubts and there is also the troubling question posed by the Russian Foreign Minister, that there would be a possibility that, as the situation on Israel's borders worsened, one could determining a great exodus — because of the Syrian crisis — of refugees, one aspect that Europe should reflect on, given that it is seasoned with human rights but then, in fact, it tells only fairy tales ... (The President interrupts the speaker...)... and no one had the courage, in front of Macron, to say he waged a war... (The President interrupts the speaker...)

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: — Mr President, your speech, Mrs Mogherini, raises more questions than she answers. First question: why were we hidden, especially last month, that the eastern Ghouta sector was in fact in the hands of the Islamic radical groups Jaish al-Islam, Failaq al-Rahmane, Ahrar al-Sham, that they were the ones who held the civilian population hostage and that they regularly sent rockets to central Damascus, including on the Christian quarter of Bab Touma? Second question: the video footage that moved the whole world and which aroused, still earlier, the fervor of the French President, is it only known when it was taken, where it was taken, by whom it was transmitted and how? By the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, entirely in the hands of the Muslim Brotherhood? Third question: how is it that immediately afterwards President Trump concluded that the use of gases was materialized when the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, present there, did not distinguish any trace of it in his statement of 14 April and, even assuming that, as the previous speaker said, what would have been 'the interest of President Al-Assad to use it, when he was the winner on the ground and already a corridor to evacuate his opponents had been organized? There are many other questions you would like to ask about this.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Mr President, strikes against the use of chemical weapons were justified and necessary, but the crisis is continuing. I agree with my colleague, Mr Salafranca Sánchez-Neyra, that Syria has been the biggest failure of the international community for years. However, the primary killer of the civilian population is not chemical weapons; it is indiscriminate, systematic aerial bombing. Assad’s goal is clear: to bomb and gas all opposition to total surrender, leaving no space for substantial negotiations or compromises. Russia and Iran, by siding with Assad and backing him in full, have defined themselves as co—responsible for all atrocities and crimes.  By the way, five years ago, Russia managed to prevent President Obama from reacting by force to the use of chemical weapons by offering itself as guarantor that this would not happen again, taking responsibility for removing chemical weapons from Syria. Today, Russia has lost any credibility in this role. We need to make sure that peace cannot be achieved without justice, and the EU has a substantial role to play here.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D).
text: Mr President, there are still many doubts. It's true, but there are also some certainties. For example, we are completely sure that if someone is losing the war it is the Syrian people, that's for sure. And it is also certain that if anyone has the possibility of rebuilding Syria and reconciling Syria among the Syrians it is the Syrian people. That's two certainties. Here I see many colleagues with great capacity for spying and intelligence. But in any case our thing, the European Union, is politics. It's not the military. It is not the exercise of military force. We are in politics; we are from the beginning, it is true that with many difficulties; but we are politics. And the measured response given by the United States, Great Britain and France, with all their doubts — has been explained here today by President Macron — does not seem to change the course of war, of course. So it's up to us again politics, diplomacy, the exercise of the power we have, if we act in a coordinated manner, to talk to the Russians and to settle the parties, because there will be no other way for peace in Syria than that. And in the meantime, of course we have to mark the red lines, as we have done with the attack on Al-Assad. But it is also true that we should agree on how the red lines are curbed and that probably has not been done well. I think we need to spend the energy, the budget, the strength of our competition when we are united to open a path, not of dialogue — as the senior representative said — but for concrete and direct negotiation. That is what is the strength presented here today by President Macron and also the force that the European Union can develop in a coordinated manner behind the efforts which I, as always, greet and congratulate the High Representative, Mrs Mogherini.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR).
text: – Mr President, there is a legal obligation to stop crimes against humanity. This obligation was executed recently on behalf of all of us by the US, France and the United Kingdom. We are grateful that both NATO and the EU show unanimous support for these actions. The precision strikes allow us to expose what was so difficult to detect in the very long, complicated war in Syria, with elements of hybrid – our allies and our opponents, if not enemies.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE).
text: Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, Assad is doing it again. We are here again today, after another attack in Syria. 73 times already chemical attacks have been launched on the population there in Syria by Assad. More than half a million deaths to this day. This figure, those images, it defies any imagination. Can we still sleep when we see the images, when we see the foam from the mouths of the children and the women? What are we supposed to do with that? That is why, I believe, there is also broad support and understanding for the counter-attacks launched by France, Britain and the United States, targeted attacks. But, Mrs Mogherini, it must be clear that the military escalation has only one effect for me, and that is, at the moment, it is impossible for all women and children and men there to live. In fact, we should dare to say that with the escalation that is taking place, we must consider how humane it is to allow the Syrians to live on the ground. Hence my call. We heard fine statements at the European Council. But actually, I read them too much. I wish we could move towards a genuine European strategy, and I know it is not so easy to solve. It's a complex problem. Nevertheless, we must continue to focus on a truly comprehensive approach. Speak to the allies, speak to Turkey, speak to Iran, speak to Russia. That's the only way to ever end that conflict there. In addition, I would like to make an appeal here. Let us continue to speak on diplomatic terms, but let us ensure, above all, that the people there are not starving, because that too is a crime. For me, this is the first priority at the moment: to provide people with the necessary humanitarian aid.

name: Michel Reimon (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. Assad has been massacting his people for seven years, and Putin has been protecting and supporting him in the United Nations for seven years. It is not possible to take action against this in accordance with international law. This is not a current development, it will remain so. There will be no military solution compliant with international law, and we should not aim to do so. We are the European Parliament and not NATO, we must strive for a political solution. If Putin holds his hand over Assad, we need to increase and strengthen political and economic pressure on him. That is the solution we should seek. We in the European Parliament, we as the European Union, have been failing to put sufficient pressure on Putin for seven years, we are failing to put pressure on Assad, and we are failing in other wars in this region too. In Yemen, there is exactly the same problem as in Syria. There it is Saudi Arabia's Western ally who commits the war crimes. We must stand on the side of the democrats in this region, with really massive political pressure. That is the solution to this question.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, I believe that we want and must say in every word that the attack by the United States, the United Kingdom and France in no way contributes to peace in Syria or to a political solution in any way. And the European Union cannot whitewash this attack, otherwise it will fall even more ridiculous than it has already fallen. Three weakened leaders in their countries alone decided to follow up this attack as if it were their main purpose. They have not consulted anyone, not even their respective parliaments. They did not inform anyone and have made the United Nations and its Secretary-General ridiculous images, the same ridiculous images that they have made of the European Union, the European Commission, the European Parliament, which have not been consulted at any time and, interestingly, what the Commission and Parliament do is say that we have to speak with one voice. There were two European leaders who spoke alone, yes, spoke with one voice, but did not consult, did not inform the European Union at any time. The tragedy of Syria is that no one cares about the Syrian people, that is the biggest tragedy and we cannot agree with a military escalation and we cannot launder this attack.

name: Jörg Meuthen (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. Fortunately, I believe we all agree that the use of chemical weapons cannot be justified. This is a disgusting crime against humanity that we all want to condemn and fight against. We should also agree that we should only intervene militarily once it has been proven who that was. Mrs Lochbihler of the Greens has just said: 'This needs to be investigated and then we can react. 'What has happened is the opposite of this, and Mr Weber defended this verbatim here yesterday when the subject already arose. So you wonder when you say that the time has come for negotiations now: now? Does that mean shoot first, then negotiate? That really can't be that way around now. Shouldn't one first explain who used the chemical weapons in Syria? To my knowledge, we have no clear evidence that this was the Assad government. Don't you have to check this carefully before? And then can't you consider what steps to take? And isn't the last of all the steps to take the military? In this respect, we cannot agree with the reaction that has taken place without clearly examining what is the real situation here. Emotionality, as presented here, is the worst advisor on such a difficult question.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF).
text: — Mr President, the French, British and American governments hit Syria last Saturday. This costly masquerade with almost zero results is another demonstration of the madness of Western Chanceries, unable to recognize that their policies add chaos to the chaos they themselves have created. Where is the credibility of the United States, which denounces a violation of the Chemical Weapons Convention, when it has not ratified the Oslo and Ottawa Conventions on Cluster Munitions and Anti-Personnel Mines? Where is that of France, which intervenes in violation of international law in the name of alleged moral values, but which turned a blind eye to the bombing in Yemen, causing thousands of civilian casualties? So where is the famous evidence that, according to Mr. Macron, is overwhelming the Syrian army? Madam High Representative, you are talking about a humanitarian emergency, but the European Union maintains its economic sanctions against Syria. This unjust aggression encourages terrorist organizations to continue their despicable abuses. It is not me who says it, but the venerable patriarchs of Antioch. You should listen to them.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: Mr President, we join our voice with the peoples who condemn the bombing of the United States, France and Britain. With the blood and uprooting of peoples, the imperialists are drawing new borders; the European Union and its supposedly reformer Macron, with their allies, are bombarding, while the European Parliament, with the same multiplayer tape of the pretext about chemical weapons, is lying as has been shown in Iraq, Libya. No matter how much you hide it, the cause is the competition to control energy and markets by monopolies, which is exacerbated despite your diplomacy and timed surgeries at the expense of the peoples. The Syriza-ANEL government, an active participant with bases such as Souda, an apologetic for imperialism about chemical weapons! How ironic! She suppresses fierce mobilizations, having a crown on her head the statue in Athens of the butcher of Hiroshima and Nagasaki Truman. One truth, the real superpower is the peoples, and their most decisive struggle is that against the rotten exploitative system, aimed at releasing the European Union and NATO.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: — Dear Chairman, the fact is that the situation in Syria is one of the major failures of the international community. For seven years, the Syrian people have been suffering, 73 times chemical weapons have been used, 300,000 dead — all of which speaks in favour of this united reaction from the United Kingdom, France and America. So the use of chemical weapons in the Damascus suburbs this time is unacceptable and it is obvious that the war has not stopped. Therefore, one should not lose sight that Russia has vetoed 11 times in the Security Council and that the only solution remains a political solution. So a military solution clearly cannot be sought in Syria and I agree that the entire political capital should be used in that direction. But Ms Mogherini asked one question she did not give an answer to, and she said: “Who has to give in?” So from the conference in Brussels next week, but also from the resumption of the negotiations in Geneva, we expect them to accelerate and give concrete and tangible solutions. Otherwise, the Syrian people will continue to suffer, and we will not have a solution.

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. A few days ago, the US, France and the UK decided to use missiles to show the Assad regime that there are borders. International law prohibits the use of chemical weapons. Anyone who uses them nonetheless has to reckon with our unequivocal resistance. It may be that the time for such action was necessary. I would have been more comfortable, firstly, waiting for the results of the OPCW study and, secondly, if it had been embedded in a real strategy. I cannot see a strategy for Syria — not the EU, not the West, certainly not the US. The desire to eliminate Assad is very understandable after his crimes against his own people. That's up to the Syrians themselves. This is not a strategy on its own. I sincerely hope that the governments of the Member States will provide the High Representative with a clear mandate and authority to bring together the parties in Geneva, clearly and offensively, on behalf of all of them, under the umbrella of the UN, in order to negotiate to ensure that the people of Syria free from war, be able to decide their future free of fear. The conference in Brussels can be a first step towards this. Mrs Mogherini said earlier that she wants to act more than in the past. There's nothing to add.

name: Bas Belder (ECR).
text: Mr President, all European humanitarian efforts to alleviate the immense war sway of the Syrian civilian population deserve our praise and support. But - and I hear so little about this and I have not seen it in the Council's conclusions - the geopolitical and military reality also requires acknowledgement that all these efforts do not bring a lasting political solution to the national and, above all, regional focal point of view. is currently the Syrian territory. In particular, an acute danger, the expanding Iranian military presence on Syrian territory should therefore not only be the exclusive security risk to 70-year-old Israel. It is precisely Tehran's destabilising and regional advance that requires an urgent and joint Western response. I do not hear anything about that in yesterday's Council conclusions, nor in today's debate. It's about to happen. Escalation by Iranian military presence at the northern border of Israel combined with Hezbollah. We close our eyes and leave Israel alone. It's really not just sad, it's a shame!

name: Patricia Lalonde (ALDE).
text: — Mr President, High Representative, today we are witnessing the agony of the Westphalian order in favour of the law of the strongest. On what grounds should the moral obligation to prevent the use of chemical weapons must be met? This is very commendable. On the principle, we agree, but it is not enough for a fact to conclude the identity of the author. This requires an independent and impartial investigation. Furthermore, we must not underestimate the capabilities of jihadists and different groups — I am thinking of Al-Nusra, Jaich Al-Islam, Ahrar Al-Sham — in terms of chemical weapons. There are also several reports, including UN, on ISIS's use of chemical weapons, at least twice in Iraq and once in Syria. On the other hand, manufacturing a chemical weapon does not require advanced technology, unlike nuclear weapons. This military intervention has taken place outside international legality and is likely to undermine diplomatic efforts aimed at de-escalating violence. We must focus on dialogue and the search for an inclusive political solution by also integrating Kurds and Syrian civil society. We hope that this will be the case and that we will be able to move forward at the Brussels conference. (She agreed to answer a question “blue card” (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: blue card question. — (FR) Mr President, I will be very brief, that is not really a question. I wanted to agree with Mrs Lalonde and say that I had the original of such a report. This is the original of the latest report of the International Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons.

name: Patricia Lalonde (ALDE)
text: answer 'blue card'. — — It is great, Mr Gollnisch, if you have the entire report. I read it myself, so I can say that this is reality.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, on 14 April the world witnessed a military aggression against a sovereign country, a unilateral attack outside international legality. There was no authorization by the Security Council or self-defence; that is, under international law, we are dealing with a criminal act defined as a crime against peace, and illegal under domestic law, since parliaments were not consulted. What did the European Union do, which, according to its Treaties, must promote peace, observe strict respect for international law and the United Nations Charter? Otherwise, that's what he did. She was sympathetic to this aggression; she was complacent with the action of this new “quartet of the Azores”: the pathetic trio, trio of thugs who have acted as accusers, judges and executioners. The European Union — without waiting for evidence, without waiting for the OPCW's investigative work — gave credit to the propaganda of supposedly humanitarian organizations that coexist with terrorists who kill in Syria, but also in Madrid, Paris, Barcelona and Brussels. Sad and unworthy behavior.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF).
text: Mr. Chairman! “Mission accomplished” was fully and naively tweeted by Donald Trump after the rocket attacks. Fulfilled or achieved, ladies and gentlemen, however, is nothing at all. The war continues with its 4 000 unfortunate victims. Assad remains in power. Russia remains a driving force in the region and not the US. France is once again playing pseudo-world power and bombing it in violation of international law. The business giant Germany, with a materially and ideally trimmed Bundeswehr, like in a Muppet show, gives its well-meaning commentary on this. God's Union, unfortunately — and you have to say this — does not have a script. She has no discernible strategy. This needs to change and change quickly. I am an optimist and perhaps it will be possible to make a diplomatic leap forward under the next Austrian Presidency. Ladies and gentlemen, Vienna has always been and still is a good neutral ground for getting the parties to the negotiating table.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE).
text: — Mr President, one of the Communist Members of this plenary of the European Parliament commented on the intervention of the United States, Britain and France in Syria a few hours ago. She said, “I dislike the American concept of democracy exported on major rifles and rockets.” It's not the only case. Communist parties of a number of European countries openly collaborate with the Assad regime and Kremlin Russia. In a situation where Russia is waging a hybrid war against the EU, its support is a dangerous collaboration. Do you realize, Madam High Representative, that European Communists have declared a new sharpened stage in the Leninist class struggle in Europe? All proposals to restore the Joint Investigation Mechanism against Chemical Weapons, all eleven Security Council resolutions under enthusiastic approval of the Communists were blocked by the Russian Federation. What evidence that communism is criminal do you still need?

name: President. –
text: Mr Štětina, you have a blue card from Mr Hadjigeorgiou. Do you accept it?

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE).
text: – Mr President, from whom do I have a blue card?

name: President. –
text: From Mr Hadjigeorgiou.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I just wanted to ask if whoever calls on me is a member of the Communist Party, because I do not discuss with members of the Communist Party publicly. In case it's not, I'll be happy to hear the question.

name: Πρόεδρος.
text: — Mr Štětina, I chair, I set the rules. I think you have an obligation to answer. Anyone who asks you here is an elected citizen's representative. If you are a democrat, as you claim, you must respond. Do you agree to answer the question of an elected MEP like you? Yes or no?

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE).
text: - No, I will not accept the question. (The speaker rejected the question he wanted by raising a blue card to ask Takis Hadjigeorgiou.)

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: Nice. You have the right not to accept the question, but it also shows how much you accept that your arguments can withstand criticism.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have read the conclusions of the Foreign Affairs Council, the lines drawn and the dutiful condemnation expressed of the use of chemical weapons. However, it is hard to escape the sense perceived by the European public that on the Syrian conflict, which has lasted for more than seven years now, Europe appears divided and weak. Yet Europe should be much more interested than the US in solving the Syrian crisis, especially if we think about the terrorist threat and the refugee problem. I am not surprised by the protagonism of France and the United Kingdom, although the fact that they colonised the countries of that area up to a hundred years ago does not justify their unilateral action, as if we were still in the days of the Sykes-Picot deal. I think our goal, in this framework, is to prepare for peace, starting with the complicated Geneva negotiations. That is why I hope and hope that the conference on Syria, held for next week under the auspices of the European Union and the UN, will not limit itself to photographing the situation but will be able to put in place a strategic plan adhering to the reality changed in recent years and all commitments, starting from the European countries, to this objective. We must not be deflated by the goal of peace.

name: Anders Primdahl Vistisen (ECR).
text: - Mr President! The conflict in Syria, now under way in the seventh year, demonstrates with all the clear that there are also moral consequences to a laissez-faire stance, by a non-intervention. It shows to the very highest extent how, in Europe, with our rhetoric around American activist foreign policy, we are made equally complicit in genocide by being passive and - if you see it from a Syrian perspective - show indifference to the horrific incidents that going on in Syria now in seventh year. I think it's fine that the international community exemplified by the US, France and Britain have now put down a red line when it comes to the use of chemical weapons. But let's face it that the chemical attacks are, after all, only the minimum of the many civilian casualties that happen in Syria every single day. If we really meant anything by it, then we would have laid out a much better strategy where Europe had supported the Americans in an intervention in Syria. Then we could have stopped these human rights violations instead of just talking from a moral high ground and then, moreover, allowing the disaster to continue.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the devastating impact that chemical weapons have had in the past, and their recent use not only by states at war but in civil conflicts and by non-state actors, provide the imperative for the international community to work towards complete global elimination of chemical weapons. This attack is a strict violation of international law and a crime against humanity, and is also another try by Assad to preserve power. It is the moral duty of the international community to prevent further use of chemical weapons by the Syrian regime against its own people.  I welcome the fact that the EU is supportive of all diplomatic efforts aimed at the resolving of the conflict, but the Syrian war enters its eight year and the situation remains critical. Therefore, I call on the EU to mobilise all its diplomatic leverage in the upcoming second Brussels Conference on Syria in order to find a long-term solution to the violence and human tragedy inside and outside Syria.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: — Dear Chairman, Honored Commissioner, is the eighth year of conflict, and the solution is not looming. Syria is a political training ground for world powers of opposing interests, while its authorities do the exact opposite instead of protecting its citizens. In doing so, they use the most brutal means that apparently and repeatedly involve chemical weapons. These methods are absolutely inadmissible for every conviction. 13 million people need help, 6 million have been displaced within the country, 3 million are in areas that are difficult or impossible to access even when it comes to the delivery of medical assistance, and 5.5 million people have escaped to neighboring countries. The European Union has a Strategy for Syria. It needs to be the basis of a common European approach. Everything else only further distances us from a peaceful solution. I support the conference to be held next week under the auspices of the United Nations and the European Union. The topic will be the current state of affairs, but also the future of Syria, which only allows for political dialogue and agreement within the United Nations.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - Mr President! In this terrible war that has been going on for seven years, we are being guided by often uncertain reports, and we don't want to listen to certain information or opinions that we should consider. All the Christian authorities of the region have recently called on the head with Cardinal Raïem not to escalate the conflict and to investigate the reports fairly, but, more than that, any of us who will take an interest in what is really going on in Syria, who will talk to the missionaries, with the activists humanitarian organizations, he will know that this is not the way Mr. Verhofstadt told us here a year and a half ago about the moderate forces in Aleppo. Christians just want calm and, for example, the cessation of hostilities in Aleppo took away as liberation. The same is happening today. Let's start really looking at the facts, this war has to end in everyone's interest. Europe, if it is to be Europe, cannot be deaf to the voices of Christians that flow from there. It's time to end this tragedy.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE).
text: — Nothing new happened in Syria when three presidents of Western countries, members of the United Nations Security Council, without the consultations of their parliaments, decided to intervene military in Syria. In this way, we add new players to the interventions in this country, and the suffering of Syrians continues. In an outraged conflict of various geostrategic interests, fanatical religious and terrorist movements lasting seven years, Syria is becoming a model example of future venues of military clashes and endangering world peace. In the Communication published yesterday on the meeting of the foreign ministers of the European Union, the only phrase that there is no military solution to the conflict in Syria deserves special attention. So whether the operations are carried out by Russia, Turkey, hired terrorists or the Western troika. Syria needs effective assistance from the European Union because of people who would still like to live in our homeland and because of our own intetres. Syria needs peace, not thundering military drums.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: — Mr President, the use of chemical weapons cannot be tolerated wherever it may be. But, as we have seen before, single bombing of Assad's arsenal, however surgical they may be, make no strategic difference in ending the war in Syria, or to punish criminals, or to prevent further chemical attacks. We need the European Union to act with political determination, strategic autonomy and military muscle to enforce the ban on chemical weapons and, above all, to exercise responsibility for protecting the Syrian people, the remaining people in Syria. Before we pay for reconstruction in Syria and encourage the return of refugees, we need a political solution to the conflict, yes. But no illusions, it will not be found, we will not help find it, unless we stop Russians, Iranians, Saudis, Turks, Americans, Israelis, Assad and terrorist groups from Daesh to al-Qaeda from continuing to use Syrian land for cross wars at the expense of the Syrian people. The Member States of the European Union have forces that can mobilise within the framework of a Europe of Security and Defence to impose no-fly zones in Syria, to open and defend humanitarian corridors, and to bring Assad and other criminals in Syria to the International Criminal Court. This is what Mrs Mogherini should propose to the Member States. This is what they must be confronted with. Enough tolerance to impunity, enough of the lack of Europe.

name: Николай Бареков (ECR).
text: - Do we have a plan for Syria? No. The actions of the United States, Britain and France do not engage either the European Union, nor NATO, nor their parliaments. I doubt the West won any new friends in Syria the night before, despite the destroyed chemical plants. Our leaders are trying to solve their domestic problems through Syria. But the war in Syria has caused Europe's biggest migrant wave in a century. Only a common goal of peace and democracy, a strategy of the European Union, can make the Syrian people our ally. This strategy must be the case only and solely of the European Parliament and all its MEPs. The European Commission to implement. We are Parliament, the most important body in the European Union. Europe in Syria, with a common purpose and programme, is a much more decisive force than a hundred or a thousand bombs thrown accidentally. Syria must be our mandatory foreign policy priority.

name: Wajid Khan (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the reports from Douma point to an attack carried out with chemical weapons in full contravention of international humanitarian law. The evidence of the deaths and suffering inflicted by the gas attack, including young children, is horrific. In retaliation we have seen the response from the US, UK and France. It is regrettable that these countries have launched further military action in Syria, which could lead to an uncontrollable escalation that puts more civilians in even more acute danger. It is also deplorable that the British Government’s decision to take part in the air strikes was not brought to Parliament for approval.  Rather than further military intervention, what is urgently needed is a coordinated international initiative to achieve a ceasefire, de—escalation and a negotiated political settlement. The Syrian—led constitutional committee under UN auspices should be implemented now, as a priority. It is high time that all parties in this conflict put their agenda aside and the interests of the Syrian people first. Over 400 000 Syrians are estimated to have died in this conflict. The UN estimates that 13.5 million Syrians are in need of humanitarian assistance. Their world has been destroyed. We should all work together to give them a dignified future.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D).
text: — L-użu ta' scar kimii huwa wieed mill-akbar theddidiet gall-umanità. Att orribbli. Ima l-atck min-nathe tal-Istat Uniti, flimkien Mar-renju Unit u Franza, jistgЂu jwasslu gЂall-eskalazzjoni perikoluża ta' dan il-kunflitt. Dawn l-atattaattack gandhom il-potenzjal li jkomplu jtawlu l-kunflitt fis-sirja flok itemmuh. Hemm ir-riskju li jistgЂu jkomplu jagmlu l-affarijiet agShoar giheall-familji u t-tfal li gadhom hemmhekk. Giheadni s'issa ma rajtx sforz kollettiv biex jito u protetti kif suppost i-ittadini Sirjani, u lanqas giheadni ma rajt bis-serjetà offensiva diplomatika li taqbel ma' dik militari bl-gthe li tinstab soluzzjon gthe all-kunflitt Sirjan. L-Unjon Ewropea trid tkun magthe quda u trid tkun fuq quddiem nett biex timbotta 'l quddiem strateija internazzjonali favur il-paЂi, u nemmen li gЂandha wkoll id-dover tinnegozja pjan fit-tul biex twaqqqaf l-użu ta' scar kimi' scar. S'issa ataki bl-ajru ma wasslu gall-ebda soluzzjoni fis-sirja u gЂ‹adni m'iniex konvinta sal-urnata tal-lum li se jkunu s-soluzzjoni minn issa 'l quddiem.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Mr President! The war in Syria is an unbelievable tragedy for the people of the country, for the displaced and refugees, for the neighbouring regions and for Europe. Above all, however, it is a sign of poverty for European foreign policy that does not exist. Many things would not have happened and many things would have changed if there had been a common approach. We have to learn the lessons from this, but that does not help the affected people. They will only be helped by an immediate end to the war, which must be accompanied by a stable post-war order based on democracy and the rule of law. And this can only be done through diplomatic channels. It is all the more paradoxical that a few weeks ago in Afrin we allowed Turkey to intervene under international law, using weapons sold by individual Member States to the aggressor. We are all paying the bill now: tens of thousands of people who had found shelter in Afrin again became refugees. It is high time to end this short-sighted policy geared to the particular interests of individual Member States.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D).
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, beyond the legitimate strikes by France, the United Kingdom and the United States against these barbaric acts of the Assad regime against his children and his own population, the situation in Syria must also lead us to a double European reflection. First, the reform of multilateralism. The Security Council is blocked by the relentless Russian vetos, as is the field missions of the International Chemical Weapons Agency. Pushing for reform of the functioning of the Security Council is essential to move forward when international law is objectively flouted on the ground. Secondly, our ability to act together. Can we talk about strategic autonomy when only one out of five missile fired in Syria is European? Here we see the challenge that remains before us to build a Europe of defence. These, Commissioner, are challenges in addition to the necessary resumption of international negotiations on Syria.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D).
text: Mr President, what have the interests turned Syria into? In a vast ring, where the various players give hits, but in the middle remains the Syrian people. Eleven million refugees, 6.5 million refugees in their own country, 5.5 million refugees abroad. We forgot the role of Turkey, which invaded Afrin, and we also forgot the Kurds, who were the first to resist Daesh. I welcome the Brussels Conference. But Europe must move forward to solving the problem and I propose that a permanent international conference on the solution of the Syrian problem be held in my country, Cyprus, the European Union's closest country to Syria, so that we can finally give a signal that the Europe to solve problems.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D).
text: Mr President, the Syrian tragedy is probably the greatest expression of the chaotic situation affecting the international system today. As someone has already said, it is in fact the biggest failure of the international community in recent years. Eight years of a terrible war, without a glimpse of any possibility of a solution. This military intervention is justified in view of the chemical weapons attack by the Syrian Government against its own people. But, in fact, it has changed neither the military situation nor the political situation in Syria at all. And these can only be changed by means of a major diplomatic solution. The European Union has this responsibility to lead this diplomatic process. In this respect, the Brussels Conference can and must play an absolutely decisive role. As someone has already said here, Europe is missing in this process. Europe must have more active participation, it must reveal a strategy, it must have another commitment from the perspective of political and diplomatic resolution of the conflict, because there is no other way to resolve it than through politics and diplomacy.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the military intervention of the United States, France and the United Kingdom has only confirmed once again that it is not with a sequence of attacks — even when targeted and free of human victims and destined to target chemical weapons depots — that it is possible to solve the complicated Syrian skein: we must avoid escalation at all costs and stop unilateral actions. Europe has a duty and right to act together, giving full support to the intense diplomatic action that High Representative Mogherini is carrying out and which will culminate in the Brussels conference next week, a crucial moment to reiterate our commitment alongside the United Nations, to confirm humanitarian commitment, to continue working on a political solution to the conflict and to recall Russia, Turkey and Iran to a constructive role as far as possible. We are at a point of no return: everyone must stop and think about the consequences of continuing the conflict. The international community cannot afford it but even less can afford the Syrian people, true martyr of years of suffering because of the game of the great powers and the bloody Assad regime. Europe must return to acting in the Syrian theatre with authority and encouraging a sustainable peace process.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: — Dear Chairman, Dear Commissioner, I believe that we can agree that the greatest evil that happens in the world is the suffering of innocent people. Immediately behind this comes the lack of peaceful action of those who are able to help. I emphasize peaceful action, versus actions that will further deepen the conflict. The factor that makes it difficult to decide when it comes to Syria is the lack of access to facts. As we read about alleged chemical weapons attacks we can't help but wonder: how is it so hard to come by the facts? Why are we inclined to respond to various announcements and even take military action before an objective factual state is established? Extremist forces bombing civilian positions in Damascus were housed in Eastern Ghouta, with Christian churches being shelled as well. Why didn't the West react then and the conflicts wouldn't escalate? Why didn't the West react 8 years ago so there would not be a genocide against Christians in Syria nor would millions of Syrians be left without their homes? Syria needs peace, not war.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the attack on Douma, in which chemical weapons would have been used against the civilian population, represents only the last shame, in temporal order, of this war, which is the last shame of this war. counts nearly half a million deaths since the conflict began. The issue is very complex but the solution cannot be military, which can only aggravate the instability of the area. We cannot respond to the war with another war: and in fact, after the attacks of the United States, the United Kingdom and France, the situation remains serious and, at the same time, even more complex as a result of overlapping of tensions. The solution can only be political and diplomatic and the High Representative, Federica Mogherini, who has already expressed himself in this regard, will have to continue working, starting with the next conference of Brussels, to put in place an effective strategy for peace in the area. Instantaneous and overbearing solutions ill-fit an area where imposing economic interests and thirst for power overlap with social, ethnic and religious problems.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, in Syria, the intervention of foreign forces, the terrorist activity of ISIS and the civil war have literally torn apart the country. They have led to thousands of deaths and millions of refugees. They destroyed Syria's economy and society. They gave the opportunity to third Arab countries, such as Iran and Saudi Arabia, to resolve their religious and other differences there. At the same time, the United States, Britain, France, Russia and Turkey are competing to divide the prey to Syria, grabbing every resource in the country. The political problem in Syria must be resolved diplomatically, peacefully, away from the use of force. The recent missile attacks from the West, due to the alleged use of chemical weapons, will not solve the problem. The same applies to the crocodile anti-war tears of SYRIZA, while the SYRIZA-ANEL government provides facilities for the US to conduct missile attacks in Syria.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, the bombing against Syria is a flagrant violation of international legitimacy, the UN Charter, the territorial integrity of Syria, the human rights of the civilian population, but also of peace in the wider region. The reason for the use of chemical weapons makes no sense, it is not based on any evidence, but it reminds us of the lie used to intervene against Iraq. In fact, the United States, the United Kingdom and France have carried out missile attacks following the imperialist intervention which has been taking place in recent years against Syria with the aim of changing the regime, redrawing the border in the Middle East and controlling the energy sources and roads. Britain even used the bases in Cyprus for this missile attack, with all the risks that this entails for the people of Cyprus. As for the European Union, it identifies itself with the United States and adopts the strategy of imperialist interventions and further militarisation through and strengthening investment in the war industry, on the altar of serving European monopolies and broader their geostrategic interests.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: — Madam President, in all things, we must set an example. We cannot act against international law, we cannot act against our peoples and against peoples. This has already been done in Iraq and Libya, why should Syria be added? Especially since, as far as gas is concerned, there is a 1993 convention which requires, according to international law, an investigation by the United Nations, which arrived just after our bombing. Did we have evidence to hide? We are facing a situation that cannot continue. We must indeed be part of the UN process, not only the Geneva process but the Astana process, because it will not be possible to find solutions without Russia, Iran and Turkey.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: Madam President, I am concerned and concerned about the situation in the neighbourhood of my home country of Greece, in the Eastern Mediterranean, because these events usually create chain reactions. After the end of the world wars, the forceful forces proceeded to create the UN, NATO and then the European Union, under the pretext of “never more war”, “never again misery and refugee children” and much more. However, the tragic results in Iraq, Libya and Afghanistan have demonstrated that in the countries where the great powers installed puppets leaders who served their interests, when they stood up, they were faced with war, destruction, anguish and rivers of blood. However, the attempt to apply the same recipe in Syria as ISIS was implicable in Russia and Assad. The raw interventions in Syria created hundreds of dead people of all ages, homeless people, refugees, incalculable destruction to ancient monuments and left the country in ruins. So any debate at European Union level is vanity because it does not involve sincerity, because it is aimed at ignorant people and because only a naive person can believe you.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, as speakers have said, the situation in Syria is truly catastrophic – eight years of conflict, half a million people dead, millions of refugees, and more millions, as the United Nations has said, in need of humanitarian aid – and no end in sight to the conflict.  Some people blame the European Union. The European Union has given more in humanitarian development aid than anyone else – at least EUR five billion – and we take in refugees, as President Macron said this morning. Indeed, I am looking forward to the conference which Commissioner Mogherini is going to have in Brussels next week: I think that the European Union is the only body that can actually help to bring about a resolution here. It did so with the Iranian nuclear accord, and we have an obligation to ensure that we give every leadership we can to try and bring about an end to this unfortunately deadly conflict – and the sooner the better.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Madam President, we cannot turn a blind eye to the use of chemical weapons. In that respect, the targeted strikes by the US, the UK and France, staking out chemical facilities, sent an important signal. But this is not a mission accomplished. We do need a larger strategy and we need to implement it. So my question to the External Action Service is how we will use the momentum to deliver this at both EU and UN level, ensuring that next week’s conference on Syria is not just a funding exercise, but underpinned by a strong diplomatic initiative. What will we do to revive responsibility to protect the doctrine at the UN and bring credible pressure to bear on Russia to engage in this process? Yesterday’s Foreign Ministers’ Council’s conclusions deplored Assad’s social engineering, closing off the path to a credible transition. What measures are we taking at UN level to ensure that aid and reconstruction reform is not dictated by Assad, one possible approach being to implement recommendations offered by the Martin Griffiths report?

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – Madam President, just last week I hosted a conference in the European Parliament on the future of democracy in Syria. Yes, there is such a thing! The speakers and participants were not academics, nor were they analysts or politicians per se. These were the brave men and women of Syria who rejected the idea of becoming a victim of a violent state and started to defend their families and rebuild their homeland. I am speaking of the Democratic Federation of Northern Syria, so far the most successful story of a democratic model for Syria. This is a corporation of Christians, Kurds, Arabs and Yazidis based on European values of religious equality, gender equality and human dignity. These people are operating on 30% of Syria’s territory and I think we need to take them very seriously. I ask High Representative Mrs Mogherini, as I always do when she is in the Chamber, to consider the Northern Federation, start a dialogue and acknowledge their existence. These are major actors in a project that is hardly recognised by Europe. The EU has a unique opportunity to make a difference. Please invite them to a Brussels conference.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, thank you above all for giving me the floor following the incident in which a colleague, when I asked to ask him a blue card question, said that he did not accept questions from Members of this House from Communist parties. In other words, he used this democratic step to break every democratic rule, and I think that this thing should be looked at, not because it violates anyone's right not to accept an answer to a question, but because his argument is being circumvented — I repeat — every democratic meaning. So he did what he denounces. As I do not have too much time anymore, I will only say that I personally am not convinced that chemicals have not been used in Syria, nor am I convinced that they have been used. This House should have in front of it some experts who would give us evidence and with satisfaction to accept their correctness so that we would have the right reason to speak.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI).
text: Madam President, today's speech by the reformer of the European Union French President Macron on Syria was a monument of provocative cynicism. “We bomb whoever and whenever we want, without anyone's approval, “he said, in response to those who, naively or intentionally, claim that UN or parliament decisions legalise imperialist crimes with thousands of dead refugees, sparking generalized ignition for their interests. The credibility of intervention is exactly the same as that of Iraq's nuclear weapons that were never found. Congratulations from NATO, the European Union, the majority of the European Parliament, from all governments, such as that of SYRIZA-ANEL, and the other civil parties who, as NATO flag bearers, entrust the protection of Greece from Turkish aggression to such massacers who Erdoğan congratulates them for their intervention in Syria. Dirty alternating alliances against the peoples! In the face of the barbarity of war, of popular poverty, there is no more time left. All the peoples of Europe on the road against governments, the European Union, imperialism and capitalism!

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: These were the participants in the spontaneous speech procedure now. Unfortunately, I can't give the floor to everyone else now. This is also due to the fact that many, many of the Members are simply spending their time. Then we just won't have time to give everyone the word. (End of spontaneous speeches)

name: Christos Stylianides
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, Ms Mogherini has had to leave to catch her flight due to her mission in the Western Balkan region. I followed your interventions. I share the same concerns as all of you about the escalation of violence in Syria, in particular during the last months and especially the current situation. As Ms Mogherini has already emphasised, we need urgently to return to the political process. The UN Secretary—General, and of course the UN Special Envoy, warned of the risk to the entire Middle East and Europe if the conflict in Syria continues and expands.  We need to use all our means to request an immediate ceasefire followed by unconditional humanitarian access, leading to a return to the political talks. The European Union remains committed to supporting the Geneva process, providing assistance to the Syrian opposition to be able to remain engaged and committed to the political talks, and to assisting Syrian civil society. As the European Union, we will continue to invest to support the capacity of Syria for constructive social and political change, now and in the future.  At the same time, the Brussels conference in the next week is an initiative which will definitely also include humanitarian perspectives, as well as diplomatic efforts in order to reach this ceasefire. I would also like to say that the European Union has remained the biggest humanitarian donor in the Syrian crisis since the beginning of this crisis.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Jaromír Kohlíček (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The Syrian conflict is slowly but surely reaching a new phase. Al Qaeda and other radical components have been driven out of most enclaves on the densely populated western part of the state. Islamic State apparently controls only some rural areas somewhere in Syria's southeast and the adjacent territory of Iraq, with most fighters already moving to other locations. The United States now possesses some 2,000 troops in Syria, particularly in the northern part of the country controlled by Kurdish forces. It is likely that Turkey's efforts to weaken Kurdish troops will continue soon, while at the same time the highly likely onset of the Syrian army against Idlib can be expected. Almost confidently, one can assume a number of heart-warming shots that will show us the cruel advance of the Syrian army. We may be able to see another charge of chemical weapons attack, and we can also expect the charges to be brokered by White Hells' staff from the UK. It is high time the EU changed its stance and launched real aid to a war-subverted country. The lurid White Helmet allegations reproduced by Minister Johnson and other leading EU politicians will seek to prevent adequate decisions being made. This is precisely why it is necessary to reconsider the position on Bashar al-Assad's regime and adopt an adequate programme of assistance in reconstruction of the war-torn country and thereby allow refugees to return back to their homeland.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. – The war in Syria is one of the worst humanitarian crises that the world has faced since World War II. The seven-year conflict continues despite several international efforts to achieve a ceasefire and lay the basis for a negotiated solution. The recent toxic gas attack on Douma was part of a sustained and ultimately successful regime assault on one of the last rebel-held areas in Syria, killing around 80 people and injuring hundreds. The humanitarian situation in the country remains devastating, where 13 million people, including 6 million children, are in need of humanitarian aid. It is a matter of the utmost urgency to allow access for our partners to deliver the long—awaited humanitarian assistance. The European Union needs to act collectively through its High Representative and take the lead in the international efforts to find a diplomatic solution, calling for an immediate ceasefire, access to people in need and particularly the most vulnerable populations, humanitarian deliveries and the protection of civilians, civilian infrastructures such as schools and hospitals, relief aid workers and facilities. This is of the utmost importance!

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — Who is finally shaping and what is the common position of the European Union on Syria? Two leaders of Member States, without even any preconceptive legitimacy and circumventing every concept of international law, decide and bomb Syria. You too hasten to justify them and present it as a common European position. Global nuclear powers are exchanging threats via Twitter, the tragic effects of global cheating on Iraq's chemicals are fresh even instead of the European Union playing the role of peacemaker, it is influenced and carried by the micropolitical and geopolitical interests of some Member States. Today Mr Macron has invoked the need to destroy Syria's chemical weapons. I will answer him straight: with the same intensity as it is condemned, the use of chemicals by anyone, with the same and greater intensity, his own uncharacterisable decision which directly jeopardises the safety of European citizens. I tell you: Not in our name, not in the name of the European Peoples!

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — (PT) We clearly condemn the attacks on Syria. These attacks violate international legality. In this field they confirm the recurrence of the United States and the main powers of the European Union in the use of false pretenses to justify their warmongering adventures which aim nothing more than imperial rule over the Middle East and its oil reserves. This barbaric aggression occurs in response to the alleged use of chemical weapons by the Syrian government. There is currently no evidence of this or of the other alleged attacks, despite international investigations carried out and approved by the Syrian government. It is, moreover, symptomatic that the missiles were launched on the day the inspectors' mission was to begin work. While further condemning this escalation in the conflict, we reaffirm our solidarity with the Syrian people fighting the Western-funded terrorist forces who have been trying since 2011 to repeat the scenario experienced in Libya or Iraq. We are convinced that peace will speak louder and that the people will soon be able to regain their sovereignty.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
