text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Russia (2018/2669 (RSP).

name: Christos Stylianides
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, yesterday the Foreign Affairs Council discussed the challenges that we are facing in our relations with Russia. The Foreign Ministers shared a common assessment of the challenges for the European Union’s relations with Russia. We have seen an evolving pattern of challenging Russian behaviour in many different fields. Central to these challenges is, of course, the situation in Ukraine, where Russia’s illegal annexation of the Crimean Peninsula and at the same time the destabilisation of eastern Ukraine continue to this day. Other areas of challenging Russian behaviour obviously include the Russian posture in Syria, which you discussed earlier today, just an hour ago, and also the issue of disinformation and interference, hybrid threats, malicious cyber activities, and military posturing. The space for independent political voices and civil society in Russia is shrinking, and respect for human rights and the rule of law is waning. At the same time, Russia is our neighbour and an international actor that we must deal with and talk to, not least as a permanent member of the UN Security Council.  Yesterday, the Foreign Affairs Council reaffirmed that the five guiding principles agreed two years ago continue to be the most balanced, dynamic and effective framework for managing our relations with Russia in the current circumstances.  Firstly, the full implementation of the Minsk agreements remains a key element for any substantial change in EU-Russia relations. We will continue to support the work of the Normandy format. Yesterday the Foreign Affairs Council looked at ways in which the European Union can help more to work for the full implementation of the Minsk agreements. This includes action at the political level, as well as concrete humanitarian action on demining and the preparations for reconstruction in Donbass, all within the UN framework when the time comes. Secondly, we will continue to strengthen relations with our eastern partners, especially after the very successful Eastern Partnership Summit that we had in November 2017, and also with our Central Asian partners, in anticipation of our new Central Asia Strategy, which I discussed with you in plenary last month. We will purse a policy of transparency towards Russia on our cooperation with our eastern partners, exploring cooperation in areas of mutual interest. Our Eastern Partnership is not an alliance against anyone; it is not about spheres of influence or confronting partners with binary choices. It is a positive partnership that is delivering on our citizens’ needs and aspirations, both within the European Union and among our eastern partners. Thirdly, the Salisbury attack has made it painfully clear that we need to reinforce our own resilience within the European Union. The EU gave a strong and united response to this attack. In its conclusions on 22 March the European Council condemned the attack in the strongest possible terms and expressed unqualified solidarity with the United Kingdom in the face of this grave challenge to our shared security. Ms Mogherini, the High Representative, recalled the Head of the EU Delegation to Moscow for consultations, following which most Member States took coordinated bilateral measures. A strong signal has been sent. At yesterday’s Foreign Affairs Council we also discussed how the EU and its Member States will take forward the European Council’s decision to strengthen resilience to chemical-, biological-, radiological- and nuclear—related risks, as well as to bolster capabilities to address hybrid threats, including in the areas of cyber-based strategic communication and counter-intelligence. All institutions have a critical role to play in these efforts. Fourthly, as you know, we have a policy of selective engagement with the Russian Federation in areas in which we believe this to be clearly in the European Union’s interest. Yesterday Member States agreed that this is still a very valid principle. We must continue to apply it, primarily in the areas of foreign and security policy: from the nuclear deal with Iran to the Middle East peace process, from Afghanistan to the situation in the Korean Peninsula, or to other global issues such as climate change, the environment, migration, counterterrorism, or cooperation in the Arctic or certain regional issues. All of these are strategically important for Europe and our citizens. Last – but certainly not least – we discussed ways to provide even more effective support for civil society and human rights in Russia, as well as for people-to-people contacts, with a focus on youth, the most important hope for any society. We are looking into a significant increase in EU funding for civil society and human rights in Russia, but will also engage in other ways to send the clear message that the EU is open and supportive to the Russian people. So, once again, the Foreign Affairs Council has confirmed the unity of the European Union in our overall approach towards Russia. It is both a principled and a pragmatic approach that takes into consideration both our interests and our values. As we look ahead, we call upon the European Parliament to continue to support all the strands of EU action towards Russia. Unity among Member States and EU institutions is a very strong signal to Russia. But it is also a strong signal to our citizens that the European Union is there to protect our beliefs and our interests. Thank you for your attention and I look forward to our discussion.

name: Sandra Kalniete
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, the European Parliament has repeatedly called for a realistic and responsible strategy for the EU’s relations with Russia that must be based on the principle of credible deterrence. The recent use of chemical weapons on European soil and in Syria, the continuous war against Ukraine and attacks in cyberspace have once again reaffirmed the need to deter further aggressive actions by Russia. While I welcome the readiness for new sanctions on Syrians linked to the 7 April gas attack, it would only be logical to extend similar measures to their Russian patrons. I believe that it is necessary to make the Kremlin pay a higher price for its actions by designing and implementing comprehensive measures in the areas of finances, technology and energy. We also have to target further those individuals who are responsible for the breaches of international law and also those billionaires from Putin’s inner circle who participate, finance or manage the regime’s dirty interventions abroad. As we are witnessing the space for independent political voices shrinking, and decreasing respect for human rights in Russia, a Magnitsky List at EU level must be an appropriate response to the continuous human rights violations.

name: Knut Fleckenstein
text: Mr President, on behalf of the S&D Group. I do not know if I can speak on behalf of my group at all. We have wondered until now what we really want to discuss. The situation in Russia did not tell us much. And I want to tell you a secret why more than 720 Members have not come here to discuss it at all, not the Council at all, and in the Commission only those who are otherwise likely to be punished if they do not come: it is simply a matter of repeating the same thing here. We have a long list of things that we do not like, that are contrary to international law, which may even be “highly likely” — that's the new choice of words of some — and then we see where we need to be a little tighter. And then that was it. But I think politics is only just starting. This includes sanctions on the one hand, but this includes many more confidence-building measures. This is very difficult. It's also very difficult for me to imagine how something like this is going to work. But if we do not overcome our speechlessness, if we are content to always list what the others do evil, and that maybe you can still find a sanction, then it won't work, and I'm getting scared. The START agreement will expire in two years' time. What about the INF contracts? We have to find a way together to get back into conversation. I would ask the Commission, the High Representative, to think more in this direction than has been possible so far. Secondly, and lastly, we in Parliament need to get back to talks with our colleagues, which means that the work of the Cooperation Committee must finally start again. If we have nothing to say to each other, we do not need to talk about each other either, because nothing will get better.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, our partnership with Russia is far from being positive. On the contrary, Russia’s posture against the West, including the EU, is more and more aggressive. Also, the modalities of our so-called ‘selective engagement’ with Russia are not so clear. Allow me to give one example: just a few days ago, the investigative journalist Maxim Borodin died in very suspicious and unclear circumstances. Some time earlier, he had exposed the role of the so-called Wagner group of private mercenaries: Putin’s army fighting first in eastern Ukraine and then in Syria. How would you describe this selective engagement, being negative in the Ukraine and positive in Syria in respect of the same people, who have a very bad record of war crimes?

name: Petras Auštrevičius
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, in March 1946 George Orwell, who coined the term ‘cold war’, spoke about it for the second time ever when he wrote in The Observer. I quote: ‘After the Moscow conference last December, Russia began to make a cold war on Britain and the British Empire’. History is repeating itself isn’t it? Over these days, and in particular after the Salisbury attack, the term ‘cold war’ is now on our lips and in our minds once again. The cold war was the environment that Putin was raised in. It formed his mindset, it made his KGB career. It was his comfort zone, which he wants to get back into. All his arsenal is set ready – propaganda, spy games, regional and civil conflicts. So we are facing the 21st century cold war, different from the previous one: undeclared, more hybrid and less ideological. Colleagues, to deter Russian aggression, our response must be based on sanctions and unity of our action. I strongly believe that additional sanctions must be imposed this time to target specifically those Russian tycoons and oligarchs, true enablers of Putin, who fund operations worth billions, such as propaganda campaigns or sending mercenaries to Syria and Ukraine. The EU must join the United States without delay in supporting action to counter these adversaries, in the shape of the recently adopted Sanctions Act. Only by taking these steps together, as a truly united transatlantic community, can we contain Russia and avoid further escalating this new cold war, which we don’t like at all.

name: Rebecca Harms
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. I have to admit, I was also somewhat perplexed when thinking about today's debate, but not because I thought we would only have to debate if we already have a new Russia strategy in mind. Mr Fleckenstein has unfortunately left now — like the 720 colleagues he has just mentioned here. I do not think we have made any progress with what we have done so far. There are two warehouses in the European Union. Some say: 'All this has been too much and wrong in tone, and we need to be milder again in our dealings with Russia. 'And the others say, 'This is all not consistent enough, and we have to put it on top.' I believe that this can continue for a while and that this very indecisiveness of the European Union is one of our great citizens. problems and rather a guarantee of failure. The European Union has never declared itself an enemy to Russia or the Kremlin. Ever since I noticed the confrontation — quite clearly, at least with the occupation of Crimea and the beginning of the war in Donbass, but also around events such as Syria bombardment, for example Aleppo, or the poison gas attack in Britain — I have seen that it is clear: Russia is sending a signal that it will show the West wants it to be strong and somehow to defend itself against what has developed in the West. How to deal with this, for example, after the reaction of this airstrike to chemical plants in Syria, we now have a new moment to talk about it. I found what President Macron said today in the debate right. I believe that we have to explore again and again all the possibilities of change in the Kremlin. But when it gets as difficult as in Donbass, with a ceasefire in Syria — and recently Russia has done everything it can to make new escalations They supported the Turks in Afrin, they put Iran in position in its new position of power in Syria — if we fail, then the instruments we have given ourselves with sanctions is one that we need to develop. The EU must be ready to contribute its economic strength to such disputes... (The President withdraws the speaker from the speaker)

name: Helmut Scholz
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (DE) Madam President, Commissioner. Yes — our debate in the European Parliament on the situation in Russia has long been pretending to be “fair to unjust” or “rules-based against irregular”. Above all, however, it is a question of a conflict between different interests and the question of who will prevail globally and thus also nationally. For us, too, we are talking about an exact inventory — I am with my colleagues here. For years, the rulers in Russia have pursued the same policy approaches as the EU: privatization, tax avoidance, corruption, liberalization or withdrawal of the state from social services — keywords of this policy. The same policy, however, also produces similar results: real wage cuts, increasing impoverishment and thus also the fear of the future, or the desire for a little “stability” on the one hand and in the waterless growing wealth of the few dollar billionaires and millionaires on the other. The recent elections have confirmed that the foreign policy of the “Putin system” is also well accepted into the libertarial urban milieus. One does not get enough of national pride, and his policy eats up important resources. That's why the partners have to join together again today... (The President withdrew the speaker)

name: James Carver
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, listening to today’s speeches, which revolve around the usual platitudes, a thought has struck me.  Under the tenure of the High Representative, relations between the European Union and Russia have steadily worsened to the point where we hear comments that the situation is far worse than existed during the cold war. Is this not a damning indictment of her diplomatic skills? Whatever the provocations, I believe the High Representative’s first duty is to ensure the security of European Union citizens. That she is manifestly unable to do so simply reinforces my country’s wise decision to Brexit and accordingly secure control of our own foreign and defence policy. Our approach to Russia needs to be multi-layered and must take account of Russian national interests. Through your neo-colonialist desire for European Union expansion, as well as the militarisation of your capabilities, you have put yourselves on an unnecessary collision course with Russia that can only end in tears. (Applause in some quarters)

name: Janice Atkinson
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – Madam President, is this place determined to have an economic war with Russia? Your sabre-rattling grandstanding drives more geopolitical alliances. Russia, Iran and Syria are fast becoming firm allies and an economic force as well. You condemn Russia for their human rights and lack of democracy and rule of law; you are trying to punish EU States for electing governments. Yet you court China, a country that has no elections, restricts social media and murders and tortures its own citizens, such as the Falun Gong. You have double standards and a dangerous and warped sense of what is right.  This morning, the socialists call for Ms Mogherini to have more powers. That is like putting a child in charge of air traffic control, resulting in lethal chaos. (The speaker agreed to take a blue—card question from Mr Coburn under Rule 162(8))  Yes, at least I won’t get some nonsense from him.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – How kind of you; you haven’t heard the question yet! I just wonder if you agree with me that Great Britain getting out of the European Union is something that might add something to Europe – that we can have a counter—view from Britain every time Europe makes mad decisions under Ms Mogherini and her crew. I wonder if you think that might be something that is going to be an advantage to the European Union, as well as other places – that we can bounce Europe and the United States with some sensible views?

name: Janice Atkinson (ENF)
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, I absolutely agree, but what we have to remember is that this place is not Europe: this place is a European Union which is actually crumbling before us with the populace. Macron talked about democracy this morning, but my Group was not allowed to respond to catch-the-eye. Across Europe, you’ve got Poland, Hungary, Italy; my country Brexiting; in Germany, you haven’t got a government yet – it is still in abeyance; in Italy you haven’t got it. So absolutely, the European Union will fall. Europe will reform, and we will become a Europe of [...] (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: We have just witnessed the British-British debate. That's what we need again and again. I now come to the other speakers. I tell you quite clearly: after 5 seconds of overdraft, I will withdraw the word because we are already in a very long delay.

name: David McAllister (PPE).
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. We have already heard today that the list of Russian aggression is long: from Crimea to eastern Ukraine, through the ongoing attempts to destabilise countries such as Georgia or Moldova, to the events in Salisbury, to cyberattacks, disinformation campaigns and support for the barbaric Assad regime in Syria. I think the vast majority in Parliament very much regrets that this unacceptable policy of Moscow represents a significant step backwards in our relations, a step backwards for which Moscow is responsible. Russia is, of course, our largest neighbour, with whom we want to guarantee peace in Europe, the integrity of national borders and the sovereignty of all states on the basis of the OSCE principles. Ladies and gentlemen, one is the policy of the Russian President and his cliques in Moscow, but there are more beyond that, and I think it's good that our German Federal President Frank—Walter Steinmeier has said these days: “We must not Russia overall, declare the country and its people as an enemy. A relationship with Russia, based on mutual trust and peaceful reconciliation of interests, remains our goal. “Unfortunately, we are a long way from this. In order to achieve this objective, we should also strengthen civil society cooperation with Russia. It is about direct personal contacts, especially with regard to young people, and the Erasmus+ programme can also make a valuable contribution to this.

name: Eugen Freund (S&D).
text: Madam President! How to deal with Russia? If I were still a journalist, “highlight likely” would not be enough for me — just as Britain formulated as a perpetrator in the poisoning attack on father and daughter Skripal with regard to the Kremlin — even if so many clues point in a very specific direction. At least there is a repeat offender in the use of chemical weapons in Syria, and that is called Bashar al-Assad. This also does not approve of Russia's behaviour in Syria. Moscow supports a regime that has hundreds of thousands of victims on its conscience, if it has a conscience at all. I am convinced that all this would not have happened if the European Union had intervened at the beginning of this conflict with a robust common, strong foreign policy — back when there was no ISIS or Islamist fighters, and Russia had not yet been involved in this war. Back then, peace could still have been made. Now it's high time to talk to everyone involved, including Russia.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: — Madam President, a month ago, President Putin was re-elected until 2024. Since Stalin, no president has stayed in the Kremlin for more than two decades. The Cold War returned to take revenge, as António Guterres said. Another six years with Putin means support for the use of chemical weapons, support for dictatorships, the division of European states, the attempt to destroy democracies in various European states and across the Atlantic, and it means creating and maintaining conflicts intentionally to give The Kremlin and Putin's an iron hand to say “I intervene and resolve”; means, of course, also the maintenance of old conflicts. I would like to repeat once again: the Cold War has returned... (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE).
text: Mr President, we have heard a lot here today: relations with Russia are on a low burner. We are actually making fewer agreements with Russia, we are talking less with Russia than in the Cold War time. Surely that is something that absolutely needs to wake us up. Since the illegal annexation of Crimea, we have, as it were, fallen into a negative spiral of sanctions and countersanctions. We must break this spiral, because our farmers in Europe feel the boycott of Russia, but in Russia too, a whole generation of young Russians is growing up with anti-European feelings. That is why we are putting forward all these proposals to develop a real new Russia strategy, such as the Helsinki Process, a conditional commitment, step by step. I see you nodding. Well, then I hope, Commissioner, that we will simply really apply that new strategy of conditional engagement.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: — Madam President! After the results of such elections in Russia and because of the deteriorating situation, it is likely that V. Putin's anti-Western policy and orientation will only intensify. New incidents can also be expected. At present, the Western response to Russia's aggressiveness has intensified — US sanctions, some countries' response on Syria — only somehow inaudible strong and principled voice of the European Union. And not only the voice, but the desire and action. Here is Gazpromo's Nord Stream 2 project, which breaks down Europe and is geopolitically very dangerous, unfortunately, but without saying all the events, it is successful. We need a strong leadership and a position of the European Commission that is in line with the current realities. (The speaker agreed to answer the Blue Card question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question under the 'blue card' procedure. — Madam President, dear colleague, of course, has been debated here, Russia is a matter of democratic behaviour, but I am talking about what you said. Consider that we need to have additional sanctions. Earlier, another colleague proposed to see how we find solutions, because there is suffering for farmers when importing, exporting between Russia and Europeans. What are you proposing? What additional sanctions have you thought of? Because I hope you're not thinking about a conflict, but about a diplomatic relationship. What are the sanctions you see?

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: the answer to the question raised by the Blue Card. — I have not spoken about sanctions, but I believe that sanctions are actually affecting, and now, perhaps, the most important thing is that the Commission of the European Union must say its clear, constant and permanent position on Russia's actions, which, Let's say, performed. Only if the position mentioned by the Commissioner on the implementation of the Minsk Treaty and other matters is not respected.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: - Madam President! Let's face it: The Russian Federation has in recent years become a threat to peace and security in Europe and the world. The policy of the Russian Federation under President Putin's leadership is a policy that breaks international law, a policy that is aggressive towards its own neighbors. This is the politics of a country that supports President Assad's criminal regime in Syria. This is the country that bears responsibility for the deaths of tens of thousands of people killed by barbaric airstrikes on Syria. This is a country that bears full responsibility for the deaths of independent journalists. This is a country that interferes with democratic election procedures in Europe and in the United States. This is a country that has become an opponent of Europe. Someone here said this is all about difference of interest. Please, this is about the fundamental conflict of values between Europe and the Russian Federation. I believe that we have given very much time and diplomacy, and opportunities for dialogue with the Russian Federation. Unfortunately nothing comes of this. I am surprised by the naivety of some colleagues who have been taking the floor in this discussion and who say all the time: you have to find ways of talking to the Russian Federation. We talk, but in addition to that we should be tough and united, we should speak with one voice. And I share the view of colleagues who talked about sanctions... (The Chair has voted back)

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Madam President, President Putin’s re-election is not just remiss for democracy in Russia, given the lack of space for credible opposition, but also for the global rules-based order. The list we have already heard is long: last month’s chemical attacks in Salisbury, Russia’s support for the Assad regime – which has turned on its own people, the series of cyber-attacks – the US and the UK yesterday issued alerts, continued interference in Ukraine, and meddling in elections policies across the globe, including Brexit. Yet the EU’s response so far has been marked by weakness through divisions and thanks to populist governments rejoicing in these grave breaches of sovereignty and international law, as demonstrated by the failure to adopt sanctions yesterday. Commissioner, I would like you to pass on our thanks to the High Representative and to the Council for standing with the British citizens following the Salisbury attacks in my colleague Clare Moody’s constituency. We appreciate that, but my question to you is, how would you build ... ? (inaudible)

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE).
text: — Madam President, There are enough speakers in this Parliament who, in discussions on the relations of the European Union with the Russian Federation, use a language that some older and more experienced people know from the times of the Cold War. I myself do not fall into this circle, but I wish that Russia would not slide in the direction of an authoritarian regime, where it already is, in order not to violate human rights, not to restrict freedom of expression, so as to assert its geostrategic priorities, not to use military potential and try to strike a balance that was lost by the collapse of the Soviet empire. Russia does not need to be seen as a natural enemy of Western Europe, it can not be equated to its political and economic oligarchs. It is still time that instead of a geostrategic confrontation in Russia, we see a potential partner, a country in which people who have created a rich cultural heritage who want freedom and democracy and are willing to fight for it alone and also with our help. (The Speaker agrees to answer the question raised by raising the blue card (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Rebecca Harms (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – You said you would not like Russia to develop into an authoritarian system. What kind of system do you think President Putin and others have established in Russia?

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: The answer to the question raised by raising the blue card. — Dear colleague, you probably overlooked that I said they were already there, that they already have an authoritarian system. I did explicitly say this in my performance.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: That must have been a misunderstanding. But it's always good if something like this can be cleared out.

name: Yannick Jadot (Verts/ALE).
text: — Madam President, it is always surprising to see that the Kremlin Amicale has more and more people in this House, in European governments and on the European political scene and that she makes us believe that, finally, it is Europe that assaults Russia in this matter. It is still a country that organizes war on the borders of the European Union and validates every bombing in Syria. We know that journalists and political opponents die, and we know the difficulty of all those working on human rights in Russia. So, if we have to be independent of Russia or, in any case, with less complacency, let's stop Nord Stream. President Putin himself signed a paper that says that the threat to Russia's economic security is our energy savings and green technologies. So let's make a real energy transition, and we will not need Russian gas, and then we draw up a Magnitsky list prohibiting Russian accomplices in crimes in Syria and elsewhere from entering European territory, freeze their assets and do not go to the World Cup... (The President withdrew the floor)

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. We all feel it: we are powerless, but also from our own fault. And others are fleeing into the old theory of “an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth” — not only because it is about two different systems, different political self-conceptions, a different way of dealing with problems and strategies, but also because some believe that politics is a game, weapons are a toy, poison gas is a different way of dealing with problems and strategies. wonder weapon and infringements a cavalier offense. Therefore, I appeal to everyone to finally leave the sandbox, stop playing and return to the negotiating table. Responsible behaviour and action is different from what is happening in our world at the moment, from Syria to Russia and Ukraine. But it's also about us: let us not be provoked! Let's not split and play against each other! Let us speak and act together, united, not only in words, but also in deeds! There is no way around a common foreign, security and defence policy, an independent energy supply of the European Union, diplomatic solutions. Clearly in position and ready to talk... (The President withdrew the speaker)

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: - Madam President! I take note of the views expressed here by Commissioner Stylianides, and I take it that this is addressed to Russia's power. At the same time, let's look at what's going on. Here in this room are representatives of the states that support NordStream 2, here in this room are representatives of the states where President Putin is very warmly greeted. Here, in this room, there are representatives of states that import coal even more and more from Russia, that is, you can conclude that these economies are complementary regardless of government, which always passes, even as it is long-lasting, remains society. I would like us to realize that Russian society is a proud society, but often has negative stereotypes about Poland. I am with those who urge dialogue, to develop an offer for young Russians, even in the Erasmus system, to eliminate stereotypes. Let's be prepared for the fact that someday things will be better and normal.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, our relations with Russia have been difficult. Up until now, only little progress has been made to improve affairs. Unfortunately, the atmosphere in Russia has not changed after the last elections, and it has brought even more tensions to the international scene. Protracted conflict in Ukraine, Russia’s military backing of the Assad regime in Syria, and its constant interference in EU internal politics make it difficult to improve our relations.  I support the five principles underlining our relations with Russia. At the same time, our strategy and these principles could work only if we stand together: only if the whole EU is united in its actions, upholding the values and principles we share. This means standing firmly behind the implementation of the Minsk Agreement, being united in our approach to Eastern partners, reinforcing our joint resilience and last, but not least, re-engaging with civil society and youth in Russia. EU security is threatened on a daily basis from dependence on Russia’s energy, the destablising effects of propaganda, cyber-attacks and, lately, even suspicion of the use of nerve gas. My appeal is simple: in these extremely insecure times, we can guarantee the security and safety of our citizens only when we act together.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: — Madam President, this debate should be about the European Union vis-à-vis Putin's Russia — the one that kills Russian journalists such as Maksim Borodin, the one who invaded and occupy territories of Ukraine and Georgia, which prevents the Security Council from taking action in Syria, which funds the racist extreme right in Europe and the States United, which spreads fake news and cyber attacks and threatens with invincible nuclear weapons. We need to keep talking to Russia, yes. But, of course, with a strategic sense, with a European Magnitsky Act, with sanctions aimed at those responsible for the murders of Serguei, Anna, Boris, Maksim and so many others and the failed Skripal murders in Salisbury. Expel Russian diplomats is no policy at all. Putin retaliated and nothing has changed. How long are we going to let our governments aggravate European dependence on this Russia through projects like Nord Stream 2? And how long are we going to let Member States of the European Union, starting with the United Kingdom, continue to be laundries for Putin and his oligarchs to invest in Europe, capture governments and institutions and attack our democracies from within?

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I think there is nothing more important for European security than to understand the nature of the Russia of today. It is not the Russia of its citizens; it is the Russia of the Putin regime: always fearing its citizens and fearing democracy. That’s why it wants to undermine democracy and the rule of law wherever it exists, in neighbouring countries, in Europe and at home. And it has to demonstrate the brutal willingness to use force. That explains Salisbury, Syria, Georgia, Ukraine, the murder of Russian citizens abroad and in Russia and the ongoing warfare in Ukraine, disinformation and destabilisation. All these are signs of a regime that is afraid and needs to use covert operations, needs to use criminal activities. I think our response must be: ‘we know what you’re doing, we know who is doing it and we will punish criminal activities. We will sanction the policies that are undermining democracy, and we will highlight when you are acting against us. We are strong and you are weak’.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, it seems very clear that the European Union states do not have a common position towards Russia. This is our main problem: we don’t have a common foreign policy concerning Russia. Unfortunately, I have to agree with High Commissioner Mogherini: we are seeing an evolving pattern of challenging, negative Russian behaviour in various fields which include, of course, Syria. We cannot continue on this path. We have to talk with Russia only after they stop what they are doing in Syria. When are they going to withdraw their troops from eastern Ukraine and also from Crimea, when are they going to withdraw their troops from Transnistria, when are they going to stop challenging all the Eastern Partnership countries associated with the European Union, the Republic of Moldova, Ukraine, Georgia and so on....(The speaker was interrupted by the President.)

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE).
text: – Madam President, more than a month has passed since poisonous nerve agents were used against Sergei Skripal and his daughter in Salisbury in the UK. While many of us commend the clear line that Western governments have taken against Russia, it is important to keep up the political and diplomatic pressure. In order to make the Kremlin change its unacceptable behaviour we must look at ways of challenging the corrupt system that underpins the regime. There are tools. These include the possibility of strengthening sanctions and asset freezes for Russian officials that feed the regime with money. Europe could also ensure that oil and gas prices stay low by increasing financial support for fracking and climate-friendly energy. There is no reason for failing to act with resolve against Putin and his companions. By clamping down on the ongoing money laundering of Russian oligarchs, the foundation of the Putin apparatus will be affected. This would clearly show and convince the Kremlin that Europe has red lines that must not be challenged.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in Russia deserves all our attention. First of all, I would like to stress the lack of transparency in recent elections and funding to foreign parties, as well as the widespread homophobic sentiment in Russian society and politics, which are harmed the rule of law and respect for human rights. Normalization from relations between the European Union and Russia is a factor that we must consider crucial for stability, security and peace in the world. There also needs to be a strong, resilient and cohesive European response to the orientation of Russian activity in foreign policy, including allegations of direct involvement, though unproven, in cases of poisoning of Russian citizens in the UK and supporting the Syrian regime in using chemical weapons in Douma. Also relevant are cyberterrorism and destabilization charges in Ukraine. The invitation, therefore, is to undertake every possible effort to restore conditions of mutual trust and restore normal relations.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE).
text: — Madam President, in relation to Russia, the European Union reminds me of a bunny that stares precipitously into the eyes of a cobra. The EU's foreign policy towards Russia is cautious and fails to call relations with Russia by its real name. That's a dangerous game, Madam High Representative. Russia is waging an information war against us, the European Union. Its aim is the distribution of the European Union. Following the territorial robberies of Russia in Ukraine, Georgia, Moldavia, after provocations against the Baltics, after the intervention in Syria, after the placement of offensive Russian Iskander missiles in Kaliningrad region directed at EU Member States, it is time to clearly identify the Russian Federation as a security risk. Let's not be afraid of Russia, Mrs Mogherini. Let's worry about Russia, let's worry about its weakling democracy, let's worry about the Russian nation and the other nations of the Russian Federation.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Madam President, it is clear that the Kremlin’s strategic goal is to target us all: to weaken and demolish the very foundations of the Western rule of law system, to break international norms on conduct, and apply an indiscriminate policy of brutal force and lies. Some colleagues have spoken about respecting the national interests of Russia. What were the national interests of Hitler? This is not about the Russian national interests, but the interest of Mr Putin and his criminal associates.  No EU country today can cherish hopes that they will be exceptions and bargain better positions with Mr Putin. The immediate requirement is new tough sanctions targeting the responsible individuals among Russian elites. Russia is as strong as the EU is weak and hesitant. Putin can be successfully contained, but only from a position of strength.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: In the procedure for spontaneous speeches that follows, I will give the floor to one person per group for time constraints. Spontaneous Speaking

name: Clare Moody (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the solidarity that the EU has shown towards the UK regarding what happened to the Skripals in my home city of Salisbury was truly appreciated. The use of a nerve agent in a European country could not go unanswered, and the united European response was both a justified response and a preventative action. But the use of a nerve agent is not the only difficulty that we are facing emanating from the current Russian regime. We also know that we are facing state—sponsored cyber attacks, such as the NotPetya malware, and we have to face up to the Orwellian disinformation that is being used to try to undermine both our EU democracies and our eastern partner countries. Yes, we should do all we can to encourage people—to—people contact – our problem is with the Russian regime, not the Russian people, but we must be honest about the reality of the intentions and the actions of Putin and respond accordingly.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL).
text: — Madam President, I think we should use in this Parliament every tool we have in our hands to strengthen or defend democracy, both in the Member States and in the States beyond ourselves. And while we are all defending this, all or several of us are saying that there can be no development in this area without dialogue. For Russia in particular, I think that despite any disagreement there is no other way than cooperation, but interaction, and in any case, as long as the Member States do not have a common foreign policy, this will continue to fall short. However, I would like to conclude by saying that, despite any disagreement I may have with Russian politics, I think Putin's comparison with Hitler was a little exaggerated, not to say anything more.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Madam President, I could point out that the European Union's relations with Russia are the apotheosis of absurdity, liquidity and contradiction. As you have pointed out, on the one hand, Russia is regarded by the European Union as a strategic partner with which it should discuss, but not on all issues but on some as an option. The European Union supports NATO in its attempt to surround Russia strategically, but denies Russia the right to react accordingly. The European Union considers it a right to support civil society in Russia, but it denies Russia the same right in countries of the European Union. I could mention many of these examples but I will conclude by concluding that real confidence building and real cooperation exists when both interlocutors want to cooperate, they are honest, they want to solve the problems and, mainly, they want to manage to convince that it does not pose a threat to each other.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: — Madam President, we are commenting on the situation in Russia for the first time and very shortly after the election of the President. And I would like to say that I have been very paused over congratulating President Juncker of the Commission. He apparently neglected to take into account the fact that the Russian regime had suppressed the possibility of running for anti-candidates, strong anti-candidates. Boris Nemtsov was assassinated, Garri Kasparov is in emigration or was not admitted to the election by Alexei Navalny. I think European institutions should avoid similar congratulations and not give a semblance of legitimacy to Russian elections. The EU should not turn a blind eye to human rights violations in an undemocratic system. The second comment concerns support for Ukraine. Here I very much agree that the EU is united and sanctions should continue.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, this has been a very useful exchange. I would like to thank the Members for their speeches. From this debate, I conclude that we all share, more or less, a common interest in retaining above all a united, realistic and balanced approach towards Russia. We will continue to look at how best to use all the instruments available to us, first of all in strengthening our own resilience. Secondly in supporting our partners and continuing political dialogue, and in supporting Russian civil society. Thirdly, we must insist on human rights and democracy and people—to—people contact. I think this is our obligation and our moral duty in order to provide what the Russian people need inside Russia. Thank you very much again for this very fruitful discussion. I strongly believe that the role of this Parliament in keeping this important issue on the agenda remains very, very important.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place during the next partsession. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: in writing. — Situation in Russia, 17 April 2018 Solidarity between the Member States of the European Union is demonstrated by the unanimity of the leaders of all Member States in their support for the United Kingdom Government in the Salisbury assassination. The conclusions of the European Council show, in particular, that Heads of State or Government agree with the findings that the Russian Federation is likely to be responsible for the assassination and that there is no other realistic explanation. I think that the situation that has arisen also shows that there is a need for solidarity between EU members, because this is the only way we can act with the proper weight in world politics. It is also clear that the Member States, in such an extremely serious and serious case, have lined up without question, showing the strength and unity of the EU. This also highlights how damaging it can be when we put the concept of solidarity at the centre of political debates and forget about the issues on which agreement and joint action are really important.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – Taking into account Russia’s behaviour on the international arena, such as the attacks in Georgia, Crimea, Ukraine, and Syria, and more recently the use of military grade Novichok nerve agent on UK soil, it would be most inappropriate to reward Russia by letting it host the 2018 FIFA World Cup. To this end, I will promptly launch an initiative urging FIFA to reconsider the host country for the 2018 World Cup.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the prospects of peace for the Korean Peninsula in the light of current developments (2018/2643 (RSP)).

name: Monika Panayotova
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, recent developments in the Korean peninsula since the beginning of this year are encouraging. We were glad to hear that the Republic of Korea and the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea have agreed on a date – 27 April – for the inter-Korean Summit meeting on the southern side of the joint security area, and are actively preparing for it. The planned meeting between US President Trump and DPRK leader Kim Jong Un, is another historic opportunity to launch a process which may lead to denuclearisation and lasting peace on the Peninsula. We are looking forward to the outcomes of this summit and we are following the preparations closely. We firmly hope that they will foster trust and become building blocks for a process of negotiations leading to stability and development in both countries. Trust is essential. History has taught us that peace-making can be a long and fragile process. Once trust is broken, it takes a long time and serious efforts to rebuild. Many remain cautious about the prospects for peace on the Peninsula, despite recent encouraging signals. Indeed, North Korea must take concrete action to address international concerns with regard to its nuclear and missile programmes. To begin with, we expect that the DPRK will enter into a negotiation on denuclearisation and refrain from further tests on nuclear weapons or re-launching missiles. A peaceful environment will be crucial to create the necessary conditions towards the negotiated solution. The recent positive developments would have been impossible without the leadership and courage shown by President Moon and his government in reaching out towards the north. The European Union has always supported the leading role of the Republic of Korea in assuring the engagement of the DPRK in a meaningful dialogue, aimed at a complete verifiable and irreversible denuclearisation. The Korean Foreign Minister, Ms Kang, took part in the Foreign Affairs Council on March 19 to discuss the state of play and the way forward. This meeting provided an opportunity to pledge the EU’s continuous support to the work of the Republic of Korea. We reiterated our position in favour of a peaceful resolution on the crisis, and we also confirmed that the strict monitoring of DPRK commitment to de-nuclearisation will be necessary. Our support to furthering the diplomatic process, combined with sustained pressure through sanctions was reaffirmed by the Secretary-General of the European External Action Service at the end of March, on a visit to the Republic of Korea and Japan. Clearly, through our policy of critical engagement, we have been maximising pressure on the DPRK. The EU has transposed all UN Security Council resolutions in a swift and timely manner. Additionally, the European Union has adopted autonomous measures against DPRK. We can safely confirm that the EU sanctions regime vis-à-vis DPRK is currently our most restrictive towards any country. We approached a significant number of countries in Africa, in Asia last autumn, and will do so shortly again to encourage them to fully and strictly implement all UN Security Council resolutions. This time we will also include an offer of concrete support for capacity-building on sanctions enforcements where needed. It is of the utmost importance that the international community remains united and determined in its approach, and calls on the DPRK to completely abandon its nuclear and missile programmes. We would thus maintain the direct and indirect pressure on North Korea until it embarks on a credible path towards complete, verifiable and irreversible denuclearisation. Talks for the sake of talks are not an option. This has to be a meaningful process towards peace. At the same time, pressure and sanctions are not an end in themselves. They are always an instrument to encourage a political process. The European Union is strongly convinced that lasting peace and denuclearisation of the Korean peninsula must be achieved through peaceful means. This is why we have welcomed these new high-level initiatives which will give diplomacy a chance. And in parallel to our current strong focus on the critical track, we have always kept communication channels open. We also believe that the multilateral process will be necessary to address the DPRK nuclear issue in its entire complexity and achieve lasting peace and security on the Korean Peninsula. Once agreed, consistent monitoring and verification of the de-nuclearisation by respective international bodies such as the International Atomic Energy Agency will be needed to ensure that DPRK is be strictly and fully implementing its commitments. The European Union will be ready to support these processes, in close consultations with the key partners. The European Union has a huge expertise on nuclear non-proliferation, particularly thanks to the talks with Iran. We are now willing to support the Korean peace process in any possible way. Once again, we are on the side of non-proliferation and we are on the side of peace.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (FR) Madam President, we can only welcome positive news from the Korean peninsula with optimism. The two summits, the one between the two Korea and the one between President Trump and the North Korean leader, are steps in the right direction. The summit between the United States and North Korea is highly anticipated and highly commented as it will be unprecedented, but this is not the first attempt to persuade the North Korean regime to abandon its nuclear programme. I think we should focus less on the details of this meeting and focus more on the key points which are: what can we promise the North Korean leader and, above all, what will he ask for in return? Two elements seem meaningful to me. First, North Korea is seeking international recognition of its status as a nuclear power, and we must absolutely avoid granting that recognition. That is why we must categorically deny the lifting, even partial, of sanctions until we have long-term guarantees on the complete, irreversible and verifiable dismantling of nuclear installations. These safeguards are also in line with compliance with the obligations of the Non-Proliferation Treaty. Secondly, maintaining pressure on the diet is an absolute necessity. We should not reward Kim Jong-un for his consent to dialogue. The time for confidence will come when there is genuine openness and an improvement in the human rights situation and living conditions of North Koreans who, let us not forget, still suffer greatly from malnutrition, torture and slavery. So let's be optimistic, but let's remain lucid. North Korea is one of the most authoritarian and brutal regimes in the world that has put everything on its nuclear arsenal, and I am not convinced that Kim Jong-un gives here the wages of change.

name: Victor Boştinaru
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I will start by saying in Bulgarian: Благодаря, госпожа министър Панайотова – thank you very much, Ms Panayotova, for your remarks.  Now, please remember that, when we last discussed the situation in North Korea a few months ago, not many of us would have imagined that today we could discuss such developments, or even the wording ‘prospects of peace’. Let’s be cautiously optimistic: the Winter Olympics have contributed to the softening of tensions, but there is no doubt that we have to be thankful to the international community for being united in condemning North Korea’s ballistic missiles and nuclear programme and exercising strong pressure, and to President Moon Jae-in of South Korea for showing incredible leadership and commitment to peace.  The EU played an important role here. We imposed sanctions that went even beyond those adopted by the UN Security Council, and High Representative Mogherini used all the diplomatic tools at her disposal to mediate the contacts between the two sides. This is indeed a crucial moment. We have to be optimistic but realistic at the same time. It is an opportunity that should not be missed, but it is not all in our hands and we need to keep our guard up. The visit of Kim Jong-un to Beijing and the upcoming summit between the two Koreas’ leaders and between the North Korean leader and the US President are very encouraging steps towards a negotiated solution. Peace, security and stability in the Korean peninsula are key not only for the region, but for the entire world. I thank once again High Representative Mogherini for her not always visible but still effective work, and I trust the EU diplomatic efforts that will continue at this crucial moment.

name: Nirj Deva
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, a unique opportunity now exists to take the first steps towards lasting peace on the Korean Peninsula. President Trump’s decision to accept North Korean leader Kim Jong—un’s invitation to talks without preconditions is an unprecedented act of diplomacy. These talks are a stepping stone to further dialogue and are the beginning of a process, not its end. We are at a point where a 64-year-old armistice will finally be made into a peace treaty. The North Koreans want this and now so do the South Koreans. President Moon must be congratulated by this House. Having returned from Asia, I come to this Chamber with the perception that the North Koreans are at last willing to discuss denuclearisation, starting with a freeze. I also know that nuclear weapons are existential to the North Koreans. They do not consider nuclear weapons simply a deterrent; the weapons also underpin the very identity of the DPRK and reinforce the authority of Kim Jong-un. The fact that they are willing to discuss denuclearisation is a huge advance in the cause of peace, a peace that can disappear like a puff of smoke if we ask for too much too soon.  There is another legitimate view that a step—by—step dismantling of the nuclear programme may simply be a stalling tactic to remove crippling sanctions and that the DPRK regime has no intention of removing the nuclear weapons. The answer to this must surely be open and authenticated verifiability. If the North is truly sincere, it must agree to a verification system that is acceptable to the international community. The EU has a role to play here. Not only will verifiability confirm a freeze, but it will also lead to a step-by-step dismantling of the weapons according to a staged process, whereby North Korea becomes more engaged in global institutions and has access to the family of nations. Again, the EU has a role to play here.

name: Urmas Paet
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, North Korea has long been a country with a very poor human rights record but with great military ambitions. It has for decades been very aggressive and threatening towards its neighbours, South Korea and Japan. The size of the North Korean armed forces is ranked fourth in the world, and now the threat of nuclear weapons has been added. North Korean actions have been met with an international response in the form of sanctions, and it is good that China has finally also started to follow the sanctions policy. The meeting planned between the US President, Mr Trump, and the North Korean leader has been met with slight but careful optimism in North Korea’s neighbouring countries. However, it seems unlikely that as a result of just one meeting, both sides will be able to agree on something substantial. It is a fact that North Korea has only caught the attention of President Trump because it now has nuclear capabilities, and it will be very hard for North Korea to give up this privilege so easily. The United States, the European Union and other nations cannot withdraw sanctions before North Korea has significantly changed its behaviour, so we are probably going to continue in this limbo. What that the EU can do is make sure that the sanctions are kept in place and that they are followed by the Member States. We also need to make an effort to ensure China also keeps following the sanctions policy until North Korea gives up its nuclear weapons ambitions and stops violating human rights. This is the one thing that influences the behaviour of North Korea. It is not only the nuclear weapons that is the problem. It is also the grave violations of human rights in North Korea that needs to stop, and the aggressive policy of North Korea towards its neighbours, especially South Korea and Japan.

name: Klaus Buchner
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. There was still a threat of nuclear war in Korea recently. Fortunately, this situation has improved significantly now. We can even see at the moment that there is a will to cooperate between North Korea and South Korea. The meeting on 27 April has already been mentioned. Of course, we welcome this very positive impact. But this is far from no reason for optimism, because we need to see the situation throughout the area. And here I see at least a major problem with Japan, whose defence still has large gaps and which is obviously in the focus of Russia. The activities of the Russian Navy around Japan are significant. That is why the situation on the Korean Peninsula cannot be seen independently. And we still don't know what the North Korean president really wants. On the one hand, he achieved what he wanted to achieve for a long time, namely some international recognition. It has also alleviated the pressure exerted on him, especially by China. But whether all this will be enough to pacify the situation is questionable. That is why I urging the High Representative to take intensive action here once again and to seek a peaceful solution.

name: Stefan Eck
text: Mr President, on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. In mathematics, there is a rule: minus times minus gives pluses. Hopefully this can also be transferred to politics. A personal meeting of the crazy and unpredictable leader of North Korea with no less crazy and unpredictable mister “America First”. Maybe something good will come out. There is at least one positive aspect: as long as they talk to each other, they will not shoot at each other. But what can Donald Trump really offer the North Korean leader for the scrapping of nuclear weapons? The nuclear missiles are the best life insurance for Kim Jong—un. On the other hand, Donald Trump absolutely needs a foreign policy success to conceal the many domestic failures. As far as the negotiations are concerned, I will stick to the principle of hope by the German philosopher Ernst Bloch After that, the talks end peacefully and in absolute perfection or in an absolute disaster. Let's hope that Mr. Trump will make a great deal. Nowadays, the most incredible things are possible, especially in politics.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in recent months we have all welcomed with relief the small, timid signs of detente that we have seen appear on the horizon of the peninsula Korean. These messages are certainly encouraging to bring back a moment of normalcy to the peninsula, which actually experienced an intense 2017, in which there have been several very tense moments that are almost lead into an open confrontation. It should be noted, however, that according to the latest Human Right Watch report, the human rights situation in North Korea remains precarious and strongly critical. We must ensure that the albeit legitimate ambitions for stability in the peninsula do not affect the efforts and attention that this Parliament has also devoted to human rights, which is already the subject of discussion several times. If, on the one hand, the good of peace remains a crucial element in the peninsula of Korea, on the other hand, the protection of human rights, still trampled in the northern part of the peninsula, cannot be ignored. There can be no peace without justice and there can be no justice without respect for human rights.

name: David McAllister (PPE).
text: – Mr President, two weeks ago, following a visit to Japan, I had the honour of leading a Committee on Foreign Affairs delegation to South Korea. Some of our colleagues who were on this trip are present in the plenary. I see that Mr Czarnecki, Mr Brok, Ms Gill and Ms Šuica are here. During our political talks in Seoul, our delegation underlined that the EU and the European Parliament have been long—standing supporters of respect for international law, universal values and, in particular, of nuclear non—proliferation. We conveyed three main messages. Firstly, in the light of the latest promising developments on the Korean Peninsula, we supported the opening of a new high-level dialogue with North Korea. Secondly, we recalled that this dialogue should aim at a peaceful resolution and at the denuclearisation of the Korean Peninsula. Thirdly, we emphasised that pressure on North Korea must be maintained until the regime in Pyongyang delivers in a concrete manner. A final remark: regarding the prospects of the ultimate goal of reunification of the two Koreas, the case of my home country, Germany, has taught us that such a process can take a very long time, but it has also shown that all of a sudden things can move very quickly once the process has begun. Therefore, I sincerely wish the Korean people all the best.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, as the Chair of the Committee on Foreign Affairs said, I also had the privilege of being on this delegation and actually visiting the border between the two Koreas. Seeing with one’s own eye the most militarised frontier in the world brings home the intensity of tensions and the threat felt by the South Korean people, so I welcome the clear signs of a willingness to engage from both sides, although the main onus is obviously on DPRK, a helpful step that could be taken by South Korea would be not to overly insist – I believe – on reunification, especially given that we sense that the younger generation sees this as less important than peaceful coexistence. At the same time, I think it’s really important that we are not overly naive. It wouldn’t be the first time that countries open up to DPRK following positive signs, but that funding is quickly diverted to further development of nuclear weapons, as has happened to Japan in the past. The difficulty of monitoring underground networks, equally, makes it extremely difficult to ensure compliance with any future deal. So, talks between the US President Trump and King Yong Un scheduled for May need to be underpinned by a coherent strategy rather than motions or machismo. Involvement of regional actors is key. Both Koreans have talks later this month, but Japan, which has had two missiles over its territory in the past year, does not have a seat. I would urge that the US strategy is first and foremost informed by the concerns and interests of these countries, rather than the hawkish views held by some of the people who advise the President on the Hill.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR).
text: - Mr President! I was privileged to be a member of this delegation, like my honourable speakers. It was my fifth visit to Korea, and my fourth in recent years. South Korea against name is part of the West and should be supported by the European Union, by our states. This country deserves support, all the more because it has an aggressive communist neighbor. I think the fate of unification is in the hands of the Koreans themselves. They're the ones who should decide that, but we should obviously support them in that. Good thing the situation is interested in the United States. We hope that decisions on this will be joint decisions by the West. By contrast, there is no agreement on the aggressive policy of the authorities of communist North Korea, which does not respect any standards. We can't let that happen.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the latest developments on the Korean peninsula have once again catalysed the attention of the major world powers. As for importance and relevance, I believe that Kim Jong-un's visit to Beijing and the possible bilateral United States-North Korea meeting are commenting for itself. Once again the question of the stability of the peninsula demonstrates how much this region has a geopolitical value that goes far beyond its geographical and demographic dimension: avoiding military solutions from Unforeseeable consequences and encouraging dialogue between the parties, therefore, is the only possible solution today. Moving the shadows of a possible conflict away from this region must remain one of our highest priorities. It is vital that we step up cooperation with South Korea, our strategic partner. We must always keep in mind — and remind our American allies — that any kind of military escalation would have a devastating impact especially on its civilian population and that of our own Japanese allies, another key partner. For this reason, too, we must support and encourage intra-Korean dialogue initiatives, making efforts to ensure that the global and regional powers involved contribute positively to this process. As for North Korea, it is important to reiterate that abstaining from missile provocations and stopping the nuclear programme are essential conditions not only for keeping the dialogue open, but also and above all in order to reopen, if the commitments follow concrete and inoppulsible facts, possible prospects for humanitarian aid. As a third-party actor, neutral and lacking ambitions or second ends of which other actors can be cast, we can and should have the ambition to propose ourselves as an authoritative mediator: never as in this moment — and we also see it in theaters far closer to us — we need to reiterate the importance of dialogue rather than a rhetoric based on threats and evidence of force and escalation. That is and must remain our role. These are our principles and values, in a world where diplomacy and politics too often are wrongly shelved or rendered powerless.

name: Elmar Brok (PPE).
text: Mr President, President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen. Let me now move forward with two descriptions that we must not forget: South Korea is a democracy, and democracies must always be supported. North Korea is a gruesome dictatorship. This is a picture that you have to see as a prerequisite. We should, however, ensure that the talks between the two Koreas are supported. We should ensure that nuclear weapons are eliminated, for security in the region, but also to give the non-proliferation treaty as a whole more credibility. That is why we ask our American friends not to abandon the nuclear deal with Iran. Because if you give it up, North Korea has an alibi to close none at all. There is an inner context here that we need to see. I am pleased to have our information that the People's Republic of China has been fully addressing sanctions against North Korea for the first time since January — significant restrictions on oil supply and the like — in order to encourage North Korea to focus more on a peaceful solution. This is a very important step where we have to look — and America must be careful here — that China is increasingly presenting itself as a regulatory power in the region, which we have also seen in Japan on this trip to Mr McAllister. However, I believe that an attempt should be made to support the solutions there to support unity, even if it is difficult, but one thing is clear: we must not forget about freedom and peace for South Korea in this whole process.

name: Arne Lietz (S&D).
text: Mr President, honourable Presidency of the Council. I welcome the recent signs of an inner-Korean convergence process, which has been stepping up in recent weeks. It is imperative that this dialogue be maintained with international support. At the same time, however, this is not enough to achieve lasting and stable peace on the Korean Peninsula. That is why China and Russia must continue to use their influence on the leadership in Pyongyang to prevent the regime from further nuclear and missile tests that are contrary to international law. Likewise, US President Donald Trump should focus on diplomacy and prudence at the forthcoming meeting with Kim Jong—UN in May, and use the United Nations and EU-backed sanctions programme to the North Korean leadership as a means of exerting pressure. In the long term, Iran's nuclear agreement will serve as a reference for a possible deal with North Korea. This is one of the reasons why it is important for President Trump to abandon his plan to unilaterally terminate the Iran agreement. The European Union should play its role as mediator and diplomatic strength to advance the inter-Korean talks and international negotiations on North Korea's nuclear disarmament.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: — Dear Chairman, it should first be remembered and once again reiterated that North Korea is one of the most authoritative and brutal regimes that exist in the world. And I have had the opportunity and honor, as well as part of my colleagues who have previously spoken, to be on a mission to South Korea two weeks ago and convince myself live about both North and South Korea's desire to continue high-level dialogue. I also welcome the North Korean leader's visit to China, and we also expect with impatience a meeting between Trump and the North Korean leader. It's one of the precedents in world politics, but here, we need to see what's meant to talk about. In any case, without denuclearization, without, therefore, disarmament of the peninsula there is no talk of lifting sanctions. Therefore, sanctions should be taken as measures that are not of their own purpose, but at the same time they should be kept until human rights are improved, until the standard of living is improved in North Korea. And that's what the European Union must always keep in mind, too. In any case, I support the continuation of the conversation, I support a possible peaceful solution, support that after 64 years the ceasefire grows into a lasting peace. And that's what we all need here to support, and I hope that's going in that direction. However, we should always be on guard.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: — Mr President, Minister, I am pleased that you are optimistic. All afternoon, we've been discussing foreign policy. We talked about Syria, about Russia, and now about the Korea Peninsula. But I think we need to be hopeful, because on March 7, the President of South Korea said that it is too early to be optimistic about denuclearisation of the Korean Peninsula. He was also concerned and hoped for progress in the United States dialogue with North Korea and, of course, is important in this equation and China. But I believe very much that we, the European Commission, the Council, the European Union, need to think about how we can support South Korea. It is a country with democracy, a country with an economy in progress, it is an example for Asia. I have visited South Korea several times as a member of the delegation, and I think it is good to think about how we can support sanctions, because the President of South Korea said that he will not be able to support sanctions on his own in relation to North Korea. And I also believe that together, together not only we, the European Union, but together with the other institutions, must support peace in the Peninsula.

name: Paul Rübig (PPE).
text: Mr President! I would like to thank the Council because it is important for us to have this debate here in the House. Nirj Deva, our chairman of the Korea delegation, has already put it in a good point that we need to negotiate. Our contacts are, of course, first of all the ambassadors, and I would like to mention here the Ambassador of South Korea, who really supports us very well, who informs us, who gives us factual information, and I would also like to believe that the Ambassador or Ambassador of North Korea in future to work here on the same extent. Europe has a bridge function here. I believe that we are perfectly in a position to approach each other here and also to communicate. At the time, we also suggested in the delegation to attend the Olympic Games. The two countries have done this now. We have proposed cultural exchanges to them, and I believe that it would also make sense to provide incentives in the future — once Korea is a nuclear-free zone. I would mention the Sustainable Development Goals here by number two — safe food, sanitation, renewable energy — but first the negotiations must be a success, and then Europe can deliver. I would also ask Mrs Mogherini to take initiatives here.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D).
text: Mr President, the apparent distress in relations between the two Koreas and the prospect of a summit between the North Korean leader and the US President in May should be welcomed, but we must do so with great caution, as has also been said here. There is a problem of peace here, but there is also a human rights problem here. The problem of peace has to do with the relationship between the two Koreas and has to do with North Korea's need for long-term denuclearisation and the resolution of that old problem, which calls into question a democratic society, such as South Korean society. And then there's a serious human rights problem in North Korea. North Korea is one of the most tyrannical and most closed regimes of the present historical circumstances and therefore all pressure must continue to be exerted on North Korea so that this terrible political regime can show signs of openness towards a future development. completely different from what is still happening today. Let us be optimistic, but above all let us be very careful about the evolution of this situation.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: - Mr President! Of course, we have to be happy about the fact that the Korean states have re-established dialogue, the fact that the President of the United States will perhaps meet the North Korean leader, but we have to have a great distance to that issue. I hear voices of hope in most statements. I wouldn't want to quote a saying about the hope being the mother of the stupid, but there's something about the fact that we can't live on hope. We need to base our actions on facts. And the facts are that there is a ruthless regime in North Korea, and it is a regime based purely on strength and fear-mongering, a regime that so de facto has one only base, and that base is China. As such, it seems to me that the key to solving the problem — of course, taking into account the strength of the United States, the European Union, as well as Russia — is China. I would like to ask the Commissioner what the issue of talks between the European Union and China looks like. Without China, in my opinion, this problem will not be solved.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, prospects for peace between the two Koreas are unexpectedly encouraging. In our support for the talks, we must focus therefore on young people, who are essential to any lasting peace-building process. Young Koreans, on both sides of the border, have different perspectives from their elders and they should be given a voice in the peace talks. Women also have a crucial role to play when it comes to peace-building, so involving them in the process is a way to ensure that peace is more sustainable and more inclusive. I am aware that the process in the Korean Peninsula is still fragile. However, I believe that any step forward is good – even a baby step – as it is one step closer to peace and to nuclear de—escalation. In the current global context, it is hugely important for us to support disarmament campaigns. It is particularly important that the European Parliament supports all efforts at the United Nations level to make the use of nuclear weapons illegal for all states under any circumstances. Total elimination of nuclear weapons should be our objective, and we should put all our efforts towards achieving that goal.
