In that respect, I am very proud of the work of my office, working closely through Parliamentarians for Global Action to achieve our historic resolution in October 2016, which gives the High Representative a strong mandate in her dealings with all nuclear-armed states.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: — Mr President, I too would like to join my colleagues if they call for the right course of action in this peace process. I think the role of the EU should not be marginal, it is the right signal we would want to send. At the same time, I think it's important to condemn the brutality of that regime, which I think is one of the most brutal. What he performs for heinous crimes towards his people probably shouldn't be forgotten. On the other hand, here we are now addressing the question of disarmament, respectively, at least a kind of peaceful future. And here it is important to say that the EU should side with our allies. Unequivocally support this peace process and especially the role of the UN and undoubtedly our ally the US. If Kim Jong-un doesn't respect the process, it won't be stretched to an end. It is important to really target sanctions so that the regime collapses in its foundations as soon as possible.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, no one disputes that the possible meeting or meeting that has been decided between the leaders of the United States and North Korea is a positive development, regardless of what each of us has about the personality of these two men. It is a positive development, we welcome it and hope it will eventually mean a reduction in tension in the region. My second point is that the possible reunification of North and South Korea will also be a very positive development, but I agree with what has been said earlier, namely that it will be a slow and very difficult process which I hope the two states will be able to carry out. The last thing I have to say, and I think it is the most important thing, is that we should all bear in mind that the maximum objective is complete disarmament from nuclear weapons, because I fear that once we discovered the nuclear weapons, they will be used, either by mistake, or deliberately, and the destruction will be before us.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: — Mr President, the current developments on the Korean Peninsula give us hope for a peaceful solution. And as I hear it here, we all welcome North Korea's openness to further negotiations. Her willingness to communicate is the first step toward negotiating denuclearization and de-escalation of tensions. So we have great expectations of the negotiations ahead, especially from North Korea's leadership meeting with the United States. But if the North Korean leadership is really interested in finding a solution, then I strongly hope that it will show a willingness to multilateral diplomacy and negotiations as well. We still have very hopeful views in our memory of the common march under one flag at the Olympics, but that must not overshadow the fact of the 120,000 political prisoners undergoing inhuman treatment in labor camps. So negotiations on peace and the elimination of nuclear weapons need to be combined with human rights as well.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: — Mr President, I will take on what my colleagues have said here, especially on my colleague Shojdr. If we're talking about a political regime in North Korea, this is one of the largest totalitarians in the world, 120,000 prisoners in inhumane conditions, concentration camps. Why am I saying this? On the one hand, it is certainly a good thing if we support not to isolate this regime even more and to have some form of constructive dialogue on the part of the South Korean partner, so on the part of the United States of America. On the other hand, I say here that I am relatively skeptical that at this point the presidents of North and South Korea will embrace and the regime leaders in North Korea will disclose and change the rules the functioning of their state. Let's deal with them, but please keep in mind that this is one of the most criminal regimes in the world and that it will not just change.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Mr President, the admittedly good mood shown by the North Korean leader in the talks on his country's nuclear programme is encouraging, but it is confirmed that we will not be able to achieve a desired outcome soon and easily. It must not escape our attention that the growth rate of this programme has intensified because of two main fears felt by the North Korean leader. One is for himself and for his regime and the other is for the survival of his country, for which he considers to be in danger primarily by the United States and secondarily by China and the other neighbours of the Korean Peninsula. Based on this reality, it is utopia to believe that we will have a complete denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula. Kim Jong-un will not be persuaded to limit his nuclear activities if he is no longer certain that he or his country are in danger. It is on this basis that we must move in order to be able to reduce the problems that exist on this peninsula.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Mr. President! I have a shocking memory of living in Berlin when I was in school, and they lived on one side of the wall, and their family members lived on the other side of the wall, within sight. That's what comes to mind when I go to Korea as a member of the Korean delegation. We hear it from the personal stories there, and we know that it is a nation, a nation, living in two different worlds, separated from each other. There's a Ministry of Reunification in both Korea, so they're thinking about reunification in the long run. And what is very important is that after the war, only a temporary ceasefire agreement was concluded between them, and it is still in force. So our goal with the delegation, under the leadership of Mr Deva, was to persuade them to conclude at least one long-term peace treaty, with the need for completeness.

name: Monika Panayotova
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, this has been a very useful exchange and I would also like to thank the honourable Members for their interventions. Based on the intervention by the Chair of the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET), Mr McAllister, I would also like to highlight the importance of Parliament in its role as a diplomatic actor. The EP delegation to Korea was clear evidence, once again, of the relevance of parliamentary diplomacy alongside the traditional one. So you are also playing an important role in the process. For this debate, I would like to conclude that all we all share a common interest in achieving the goal of the complete, verifiable and irreversible de—nuclearisation of the Korean Peninsula through peaceful means. We will continue to support all diplomatic efforts to this end. We stand ready to work together with our key partners towards a negotiated solution and provide our support if requested, while keeping up the pressure on the DPRK to ensure that the country engages in a credible and meaningful dialogue. We look forward to the outcomes of the announced summit meetings.  May I close by signalling once again my appreciation of Parliament’s role in keeping this important issue on the international agenda.

name: Presidente. –
text: The discussion is closed.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the subject of infringement of rights Human and the rule of law in the case of two Greek servicemen arrested and detained in Turkey.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, the land border incidents and subsequent detention in Turkey of two Greek soldiers has received attention well beyond Greece and Turkey, including at the highest levels of the European Union. At the most recent European Council in March, our heads of state and government expressed their grave concern over the continued detention of EU citizens in Turkey, including the two Greek soldiers. The Council called for a swift and positive resolution of these issues, in cooperation with Member States, and the European Council is considering these matters. Shortly after, President Juncker and President Tusk discussed this issue directly and at length with Turkish President Erdoğan at the leaders’ meeting in Varna. The detention of the two Greek soldiers is a departure from the custom, usually followed by both sides, of resolving such incidents as swiftly as possible. No charges have been brought against these two soldiers and it remains unclear when the court will examine their cases. The two soldiers have been in pre-trial detention since the beginning of March. We trust that their case will swiftly be brought to trial, in line with international detention standards. Yet the situation creates unbearable uncertainty for the persons involved and for their families. On the political level, it increases strains between Turkey and the European Union. We still have serious concerns about the recent Turkish actions in the eastern Mediterranean and the Aegean Sea. The European Council condemned these actions in March, and detentions of EU citizens also create undesirable tensions with Member States. Turkey is a key partner for the European Union, as well as a candidate country. We do have serious disagreements with the Turkish government, particularly when it comes to the negative trend of the human rights situation in the country. Turkey has been moving away from the European Union, in particular in the areas of the rule of law and fundamental rights, and by weakening effective checks and balances in their political system. The Commission has repeatedly called on Turkey to reverse this negative trend as a matter of priority. And this is again our assessment in the country report on Turkey that we just adopted earlier today, after the college at noon. Yet, beyond our disagreements, our dialogue with Turkey is more important than ever. Just think about the situation in Syria. We need to engage with Turkey to address a difficult and tense regional situation, and Turkey needs to engage with us. In this context, good neighbourly relations would be extremely important. It is in our mutual interest to refrain from actions that only make our dialogue more difficult. This is why the European Union has urged Turkey to avoid any source of friction with our Member States, all the more so between two countries that are also neighbours and NATO allies. It is in the interest of all to avoid further irritants and instead strengthen dialogue and cooperation, as well as a peaceful resolution of any dispute that may arise. This is a message we convey to our Turkish interlocutors as part of our continuous dialogue. I assure you that the services of the European Union will continue to follow developments closely, and we count on the European Parliament to do the same, and to work together for a swift resolution of this situation, especially for the two soldiers, for their families and for the sake of dialogue in our troubled region.

name: Presidente. –
text: I inform you that at this stage we no longer accept “blue card” interventions because we are very late.

name: Μανώλης Κεφαλογιάννης
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Mr President, 48 days later, an ordinary border incident between Greece and Turkey has become a peculiar situation of political hostage, a hostage policy that eliminates all notions of the rule of law, democracy, justice and good relations. neighbourhood. Many foreign nationals, including the two Greek officers, such as the German journalist of Turkish origin, detained for over a year and a half, as the American pastor who is now on trial on heavy charges, remained in Turkish prisons. All of them remained incarcerated with no evidence, no trial, no apology, no indictment. 20 days ago I had the honour of visiting Ankara as chairman of the EU-Turkey Joint Parliamentary Committee, and there we raised the issue of the release of the two Greek officers at the highest level. I did not return optimistic, but with deep reflection. Forty-eight days later, the Turkish President demonstratively ignores Europe. But there is no à la carte accession path, no rule of law, no democracy, emergency status, arrest and prosecution. There is no path of accession with verbal challenges, aggressive actions, violations of airspace, violations of territorial waters, violations of the Exclusive Economic Zone of the Member States of the European Union, such as Greece and Cyprus. Forty-eight days later, Europe shows its total solidarity with Greece and the two Greek military detainees. It is time for the Turkish President to surprise us positively. It is time to proceed immediately to the release of the Greek officers. Ladies and gentlemen, we are not optimistic but we hope that Mr Erdoğan and Turkey will do their duty to the international community and to the law.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης
text: on behalf of the S& Group D. — Mr President, in discussing immigration we have referred to the need for better safeguarding of European borders. These two Greek soldiers were arrested by doing just that, guarding the European borders. Until today, however, they are still being detained in Turkish prisons, without even being charged. Let's not kid ourselves. It is not a bilateral issue but a conduct that affects Euro-Turkish relations as a whole. We know very well what Mr Erdoğan is pursuing. The case of the German journalist Deniz Yücel is very recent, as recent are the constant violations of Greek airspace by Turkish fighter planes, as of course recent is the obstruction of drilling in the Cyprus EEZ. I was elected by the Greek people to the European Parliament to convey their anguish. I therefore feel obliged to tell you what is being discussed everywhere in Greece: what is the European Union prepared to do to safeguard our sovereign rights? What is the European Union prepared to do to stop the illegal detention of the two Greek soldiers and finally to stop the unjust adventure they are experiencing?

name: Νότης Μαριάς
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President, for the second time we are debating here in the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg the overwhelmed demand of the Greek people for the immediate release of the two Greek soldiers who have been illegally detained for forty-eight days in Turkish prisons for forty-eight days. of the highest security of Edirne. On 12 March, after speaking here in plenary, the President of this House, Mr Tajani expressed our support for the two military and took a concrete initiative to release them. Yet, despite the decision of the European Council on 23 March and the pressure of the European Union on Erdoğan at the Varna meeting, our two military officers remain in Turkish prisons without even being charged, in violation of the European Union's Convention on Human Rights. Erdoğan and the Turkish leadership must be brought to their responsibilities, they must receive the message that they must release the two Greek soldiers immediately or they will be subjected to economic and other sanctions. At the same time, Turkey must respect international law, the principles of good neighbourliness and stop threats against Greece. Emmanuel Macron's statement of support for Greece against the Turkish threats, in response to my intervention this morning, here in the plenary of the European Parliament, sends a decisive signal to Erdoğan that Turkey is now walking dangerous paths.

name: Nadja Hirsch
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the ALDE Group. On 1 March, two Greek soldiers entered a military exclusion zone on Turkish territory — obviously without intent, that is, by mistake. They were arrested by the Turkish military and have been in custody ever since. We know that these two soldiers were on patrol in an area where there are many illegal border crossings. So they have protected the EU's external border. Everything, but also everything, indicates that it was an accidental crossing of the border in bad weather. This does not prevent the Turkish side from truly accusing the two soldiers of NATO partner Greece of military espionage and invasion of a restricted military zone — but without a real charge, as would be customary in a constitutional state. That is unacceptable! And it is obvious that Erdoğan wants to use the detained soldiers as a stake to force Greece to extradite suspected Turkish putschists. This approach is also unacceptable. That is why we here in the European Parliament today are calling by a large majority for the rapid end of the legal procedure and for the release of detainees. Unfortunately, this incident also paints a very clear picture of the fundamental situation in Turkey. This picture was reiterated when the Commission report was published today. It comes to a crushing verdict: Turkey is moving more and more away from the EU. Continuous grinding of human rights and the rule of law and disproportionate action in Afrin are just a few examples. Despite small progress in the area of the market economy and migration policy, the EU must not negotiate new deals with Turkey and with this regime. I said in the last debate on Turkey: It is up to the Turkish Government itself, and it must ask itself whether it wants to be part of our community of values or increasingly become an illiberal autocracy. The latter has no place in the EU.

name: Bodil Valero
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — Mr President, We are again discussing the theme of Turkey, and I do not know for what time in the order. I cannot recall having done it once during the term of office because something positive has happened. For the most part, we have talked about human rights abatements and just today about the capture of two Greek soldiers who have accidentally entered Turkish territory. It's not the first time it's happened. In the forested area near Kastanies on the Turkey-Greece border, the border has been crossed accidentally on several occasions before. But the difference this time is that in the past when it was crossed, one resolved the issue directly at the local level. Therefore, it is incomprehensible why Turkey today is holding the two Greek soldiers and why they refuse to send them home, as requested by Greece. What's the difference this time? I assume that it is partly about the long-standing state of emergency that prevails in the country, which put all previous formal and informal rules out of play — and which it is difficult for us outsiders to accept so long after the coup attempt that they are allowed to continue — and that it is the question of a form of show of force in the increasingly tough dialogue between the EU and Turkey and Turkey and Greece. In the case of the two prisoners, there are a number of issues to highlight. It is not just about the risk of degrading treatment, which many Turkish prisoners face in prisons in Turkey. It is also about the rights of prisoners, which under international law must always be respected. It also applies to their right to be notified of the crimes they are accused of. But we must also strive to avoid similar situations in the future. Since both countries are Nato countries, it would not be entirely wrong if NATO's secretary-general was asked to mediate between Greece and Turkey, partly to facilitate the rapid release of the two Greek soldiers, partly to promote the frosty relationship between the two neighbouring countries. Last but not least, we also ask the Turkish authorities to release the prisoners urgently and allow them to return to Greece.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (EL) Mr President, in order to simplify the picture completely and to make the citizens understand what we are talking about, it is like you, Mr President, going home one night in rainy weather, accidentally entering the neighbor's yard and he arrested you. and keep you two months in the basement. That is the situation, and it seems funny as I say it, but this issue has become such a difficult confrontation between two allied states that it should have been resolved in a matter of minutes. But the unfortunate thing is that this image is burdened and dramatized if you look at what else, even worse, Turkey does in the region, how much tension it causes every day in the Aegean Sea and how much tension it caused to the Exclusive Economic Zone of the Republic of Cyprus. We ask for one thing, together with all of you, together with the whole Parliament, for a firm, clear message of a total majority to be sent to the President of Turkey for the immediate release of these two Greek officers.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation of the two Greek servicemen detained in Turkey is very clear. The problems of minimal border crossings for years have not been a major problem: direct contacts and informal procedures, well below the political level, have often solved this kind of happenings. Today we are seeing a different dynamic. The case was politicized on one hand, preferring a media overexposure to the far simpler resolution of the case. Meanwhile the two Greek servicemen are being held in Turkey, without there being any precise charges against them. In fact, the initial espionage charge was scrapped. It is completely unacceptable to politicize this unjust detention of the two soldiers for purposes other than what is the case itself, namely a simple trespassing that occurred by mistake. This issue, of course, concerns the two governments directly, but we, as the European Parliament, must make our closeness and uniquely support felt for the government, the Greek people and its soldiers. Turkey must find before it a united and compact Union in defending the rights of the two arrested servicemen, two European citizens who are victims of an artificially fuelled accident, which must be released. We cannot and should not remain silent in the face of these provocations.

name: Jacques Colombier
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — Mr President, Turkey continues to provocate against Greece and the Republic of Cyprus. For this reason, she knows that she can benefit from cowardice and even complicity— one might say — on the part of the Brussels authorities. We note that your so-called European solidarity is only a vain word, especially when it comes to lying down in front of Erdoğan's outrances and provocations. The time is no longer for pious vows. Do you want to make a gesture with respect to these two Greek officers? Then suspend any relationship with Turkey until they are released, which is not negotiable. For my part, I urge the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to demand their release without delay or to postpone her immediate resignation, because it is the policy of Mrs Mogherini, yesterday activist of communism, today of globalization, which gives the Turkish Government full latitude to act on the way that we know and see.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: — Mr President, the continued detention of the two Greek soldiers by Turkey shows that Turkey is in violation of international law and good neighbourliness rules. According to the official announcement, the two military officers, due to limited visibility, accidentally entered a few metres into Turkish territory and were arrested and still detained there without charges. It should be noted that, at the time of their arrest, they carried their uniform and clearly the coat of arms and the insignia of their grade. Turkey had to, since we have a peaceful period, not only not arrest them but, as has been the case so far on both sides in similar cases, return them immediately to Greece in a brief process. Even if we had a time of war, they'd just be arrested as prisoners but they wouldn't be tried. But Turkey is using the practice of arresting foreign nationals, using them as hostages and thus blackmailing their countries. It is a sad and despotic process, a remnant of the Ottoman Empire. This situation also affects the European Union, which must demand the immediate release of the two Greek military troops and cease all communication with Turkey. It must compel it to behave like a civilized state.

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ-Βρυωνίδη (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, at its meeting last month the European People's Party was briefed in every detail on the issue of the detention of the two Greek military officers by the President of New Democracy Kyriakos Mitsotakis. Subsequently, the European Council strongly condemned Turkey's illegal actions and called on Turkey to respect good neighbourly relations and human rights, with explicit reference to our military officers. In this context, the European People's Party has accepted my proposal and I would like to thank my Greek colleagues from all the political groups who have helped bring this matter to the plenary session of this House. The continued detention of the Greek military is part of a conscious and deliberate escalation of Turkey's aggressive policy against my country, with a violation of international law, the Lausanne Treaty and with a direct question of Greek sovereignty over the Aegean islands. This situation cannot continue. The Greek military are European citizens and Greece is a member state of the European family. In my country, today more than ever, there is a need to demonstrate the support of solidarity and practical solidarity of the European Union and all the Member States. We now ask, here and now, immediately, that Turkey be forced to grant the two Greek soldiers their freedom, which it has illegally denied for 48 days, keeping them in maximum security prisons without being charged.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D).
text: Mr President, a series of tragic events highlight the disproportionate burden that Greece carries on the European border against the undisguised Turkish aggression. Continued escalation on land, with the abduction of Greeks at sea, with the constant questioning of islands, in the air, with constant air violations that endanger the lives of our heroic pilots every day. We are trying, despite our poor financial position, to bear the burden we bear at the borders of Europe, including the proper maintenance of our aircraft and ships. I call on you first to send out strong and clear signals as to what is and what is not tolerated by the European Union at our borders. Secondly, an assessment of the operational needs and the strategic situation in the Mediterranean must be made, but proposals are also needed to respond in the event of a hot incident. Thirdly, legal and political support is needed in similar cases to that of our military, as there are other prisoners from other countries and, fourthly, a proposal is needed for preventive measures, diplomatic or economic, and gradual sanctions against the Turkey.

name: Ελένη Θεοχάρους (ECR).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Turkey's behaviour is not consistent with the conduct of a modern democratic state which is a candidate for membership of the European Union. It refers to a terrorist organisation that acts criminally, invades foreign countries such as Cyprus, Syria and Iraq, uses chemical weapons against civilians, exterminates peoples and brutally oppresses every Turkish democrat citizen. It threatens to occupy Greek islands in the Aegean Sea, forces Greece to continually costly and costly combat readiness to cope with its attacks, and organizes abductions in foreign countries. Today we are discussing the kidnapping of two Greek officers who either lost their orientation and entered Turkish territory or, worse still, were trapped by transfer of the border and kidnapped by the Turkish gendarmerie. These officers are being detained without any charge. The European Union cannot allow Turkey to behave as a terrorist state. We demand the immediate release of the two military and call on the President of the European Parliament to intervene with the Turkish authorities for their immediate and unconditional release.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE).
text: - Mr President! The two Greek soldiers captured after they inadvertently crossed the border with Turkey are still sitting after a month of detention in Turkey, which is completely unacceptable. Similar cases of accidental border transgressions similar to these two soldiers, who were simply out in bad weather, have in the past been able to be easily resolved. The fact that Turkey has now chosen to imprison these two soldiers without informing them on what grounds they have been arrested is yet another example of Turkey's authoritarian anti-democratic development, which allows us to remove them immediately from the list of candidate countries for the EU. Immediately this must happen, for this a provocation and very worrying. The principles of the rule of law and human rights have been challenged. Ultimately, it shows with all clarity that one no longer qualifies as a candidate country. There are enough provocations, both against our Member States, Greece, and with the provocations against Cyprus. Now is the time the EU put its foot down and says enough is enough and now Turkey needs to take its sanity captive.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (GUE/NGL).
text: — Mr President, the European Parliament is today sending a strong, clear and unanimous message to Erdogan's leadership: 'Complete the judicial process immediately, release the two Greek military service'! This is not just a requirement of Greece, it is a requirement of the whole European Union: and of the European Parliament, and of the Commission, and of the Council. I welcome the cooperation of all the political groups which led to a joint resolution that we will adopt on Thursday with an overwhelming majority, sending out a strong signal. We want peace, we want good neighbourliness, but this requires respect for rules and international law and the rule of law and cannot be founded on oriental bargaining and blackmail, in absentia of the rule of law and international law. I pledge that we will not stop our struggle until the two Greek officers return free to our homeland, to the Greek army and to their families. And I expect both the Commission and the Council to coordinate their forum with Parliament by exerting all the necessary pressure and taking all the necessary measures.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI).
text: — Mr President, the prolonged forty-seven days unacceptable detention of the two Greek soldiers by the Turkish authorities is part of movements that mark an escalation of the aggression of the Turkish bourgeoisie against Greece's sovereign rights, questioning borders and international conditions that enshrine them. Aggression involving urban class competitions for their own interests, directed against the peoples, is part of broader competitions that are escalating, as demonstrated by the war attack on Syria the day before yesterday by the United States, France, Britain supported by NATO and the European Union, which, with war interventions, change borders, bloodshed peoples. The position of the Syriza-ANEL government and the other civil parties that entrust the protection of Greece to NATO, which is washing his hands for the situation in the Aegean Sea and for the fate of the two military, and in the European Union, which also encourages the challenges of Turkish bourgeoisie bargaining with her. Immediately and without conditions, the two Greek soldiers should be released and repatriated.

name: Γιώργος Γραμματικάκης (S&D).
text: Mr President, because the European Parliament echoes the voice of its peoples, it is necessary that this voice be heard as loud as possible, as rigorous as possible in the case of the two Greek soldiers. Their story seems incredible: for almost two months, they have been detained without any specific charge, without any indication of their future in maximum security prisons in Turkey. It seems that this country believes it can intervene and conquer foreign territories, such as Cyprus or Syria, but it reacts harshly because two people were misled and penetrated a few metres into its own territory. But in reality it is not just these young people who have been unnecessarily imprisoned. With them, the ideas of justice and law, democracy and dialogue that should dominate the relations of states have been imprisoned. The very values of Europe that we in this House have a duty to defend have been imprisoned. However, it is a good thing, and it shows a way for the future, that leaders of the European Commission and the Council have added their voice to the actions of the Greek Government. At least in this case, the invocation of a great Greek poet “of justice, the mind sun and myrsine you glorious do not please forget my country!” Let the voice of the European Parliament also sound loud and uncompromising.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: — Mr President, honourable, it is high time we realised that dictator Erdogan's neo-Ottoman Turkey is not our ally and is not our friend. It is high time we realised that this country, a neo-Ottoman in its nature, poses a threat to the territorial integrity and security of its neighbours. Neo-Ottoman Turkey of dictator Erdogan interferes inadmissible in the internal affairs of Cyprus, inadmissible interferes in the internal affairs of the Hellenic Republic, inadmissible interferes in the internal affairs of the Republic of Bulgaria. These two soldiers have not been arrested. A person who has committed any wrongdoing or crime is arrested. These soldiers have been kidnapped and are being held hostage by Erdogan's regime. Therefore, honourable, it is high time in this Chamber, in the Council, in the Commission that we have to do the following few things: we must immediately terminate the negotiations on Turkey's membership of the European Union, because it is not a European country; we must stop creating funds, with tax and customs relief; we must make it clear to Erdogan that this path he has undertaken is not the path that will lead him to the European Union.

name: Νικόλαος Χουντής (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, the incident that took place on the Greek-Turkish border at the beginning of March with the arrest of the two Greek military officers by the Turkish authorities and the decision of the Turkish Justice to be detained, without even having been charged today, demonstrates the a strategy of tension adopted by Turkey towards Greece, negatively affecting good neighbourly relations. Turkey, as a candidate country, must respect the rules of international law and good neighbourly relations. It is noteworthy that a portion of the Turkish press hastened to prescribe the guilt of the two military on charges of illegal entry into a restricted zone and espionage. Given that, firstly, Turkey has been recorded continuous convictions for the gross violation of human rights against Turkish and foreign nationals by the European Court of Human Rights, and secondly, that by extending the state of emergency As a result of the continuation of mass arrests and persecution, it turns out that there is no rule of law but a constant drift into authoritarian and totalitarian practices, we demand the contribution of the institutions of the European Union to the immediate release of the two Greek military European citizens; without further delay, procedural pretexts and inexpensive diplomatic statements.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D).
text: Mr President, on 1 March, more than a month ago, two Greek soldiers accidentally crossed the border with neighbouring Turkey. They were immediately detained by the Turkish authorities and are still in this situation today. In other circumstances, situations of this nature were quickly resolved by recourse to dialogue between the two countries. Greece and the European Union have already called on the Turkish authorities to release the Greek soldiers and return them to their country. Turkey has responded to this in a negative way. Faced with such a scandalous situation, this European Parliament cannot take any other action than to express its deep solidarity with these two Greek citizens, and as such Europeans, and urge the Turkish authorities to proceed with their immediate release. The current Turkish regime has been moving away from a democratic model. In recent years we have witnessed a genuine process of subversion of Turkish democracy carried out by the authorities of that country themselves. The European Union must firmly condemn this drift from Turkey, but above all, in this particular case, we must express without hesitation our solidarity with the Greek people and with these two Greek soldiers in particular.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I am sorry that Mrs Mogherini is not here to listen to us today, but I will not repeat the facts, we all know them very well now. Nor will I mention Turkey's transgressiveness over time; it took the European Union decades to dare talk about Turkey's illegal behaviour, 'illegal', as if it had violated a red traffic light. Nor have you dared to speak of a brutal violation of national European borders and the revisionism of international treaties. The accident is that the government of my country has already celebrated this lukewarm statement. Do you have any concrete action you intend to take to force, force, blackmail Turkey in the end, as it is blackmailing Turkey? And don't be frightened by the word, and if you don't know how it's done, ask your colleagues: for years, without inhibitions, they have been blackmailing entire peoples for more bank profits. Now that we're talking about human lives, about families, about dignity, do you intend to do something specific and similar intensity, or not? Otherwise, we have an expression in Greece that I imagine you are familiar with, for this performance: “tea and sympathy”.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D).
text: — Mr President, the events with the two Greek soldiers are simple: they were kidnapped on 1 March 2018 and Erdogan's regime seeks to use them as hostages to blackmail. A month and a half later, they haven't even been charged with specific charges. This is how their own are set up in Turkey, so the judiciary functions as a tool in a neo-sultanic-style regime. Turkey, which oppresses the peoples in its own country, continues the occupation of Cyprus, intervenes in the Exclusive Economic Zone of Cyprus, threatens Greece, cooperates with the “Islamic State” and the Cihaji to this day, invades Afrin and threatens us to” flooded “again with refugees. Commissioner, with all due respect, I would not call such a statute a strategic partner, nor even a key partner. So please tell us how you are going to give practical help to release, at least, the two Greek soldiers.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL).
text: — Mr President, the abduction on 1 March 2018 of two Greek military troops by a Turkish force at the border of Evros and their continued hostage since then are not an isolated incident. This is another proof of Turkey's ever-increasing aggression towards Member States of the European Union, such as Greece and Cyprus. The Union must respond to Turkish challenges and demonstrate its solidarity with its endangered members. Since the Erdogan regime does not understand the language of diplomacy, it will understand the language of sanctions. We cannot continue to pay massive financial pre-accession aid from the Union to a state which does not even elementary meet its obligations as a candidate for membership. And it is clear that Turkey is neither responding nor willing to meet these obligations.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE).
text: — Mr President, Turkey continues to provoke unscrupulously and criminally criminally, in contempt for European and international law and violating the sovereign rights of countries of the European Union, such as Greece and Cyprus. Turkey continues to occupy European territory for 44 years, the territory of occupied Cyprus and essentially denies, with its intransigent attitude and behaviour, the continuation of talks, despite the intense efforts and the stated will of the President of the Republic of Cyprus. At the culmination of all these challenges, Turkey is proceeding with the very provocative and illegal captivity and hostage of the two Greek soldiers who guarded the European border with Turkey. On this occasion, I have asked the European Union on a number of occasions to stop showing tolerance and indifference to Turkey's provocative behaviour and, at last, to take measures. This tolerance and indifference is pushing Turkey down. I think it is time for the European Union to show real will and determination and to put the strong message clearly: either Turkey releases the Greek officers, or we take concrete measures. Because I believe that no one can tolerate the continuation of funding in Turkey when Turkey violates all these principles and values of the European Union, and I do not believe that there is a European citizen who wants money from European funds to Turkey.

name: Γεώργιος Κύρτσος (PPE).
text: Mr President, the two Greek officers detained arbitrarily in Turkey are added to dozens of European citizens who are in the same situation. But their case is different because we not only have a violation of democratic and human rights, which is typical of the Erdogan regime, but also a message from Turkey that it could question the sovereign rights of Greece, a Member State of the European Union. Consequently, the European institutions and governments must run to prevent any negative developments because the basis of European unification is post-war reconciliation and peace. When Turkey questions Greece's sovereign rights, it challenges the very foundations of the European Union because, without guaranteeing sovereign rights and peace in Greece and in all Member States, the European Union will go into a dead end.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: — Mr President, I want to support the views of my colleagues here. It is clear that this cause, this incident of two detained soldiers, shows how the relationship between the EU and Turkey is deteriorating and how Turkey is ceasing to approach the EU with its values. Today it's no longer a democratic country, it's an authoritative country where the president rules with his authoritative style of government. Justice serves the interests of the state, it is not independent and we have to act on this and I join colleagues here saying that the EU response must be unequivocal, we must not turn a blind eye to that. I want to state that the Czech Republic also has a specific problem with justice in Turkey. Two Czech citizens, Markéta Vvelichová and Miroslav Farkas, were also detained for political reasons and were convicted in principle for political reasons by Turkish justice. So it is a problem not of one member country, but of the entire European Union.

name: Maria Spyraki (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to speak in English because I think that today we have to send a strong and clear message to Turkey, as an institution reflecting the will of the European citizens. It is important that the various parties in this House have already co-signed the text of this resolution in order to express solidarity with Greece and call for the immediate release of the two Greek soldiers. I would like to underline the contribution of the PPE Group, based on the initiative of the Nea Demokratia party leader, Mr Kyriakos Mitsotakis, who first raised this issue in the EPP summit last March. But also, Turkey is obliged to respect human rights under international law, including the Geneva Convention. Turkey is, however, fully responsible for the escalation of tensions in the Aegean Sea. So today we have also to explain to Turkish leaders that there is no à la carte accession procedure. We are the European Parliament. It is our duty to safeguard our core values. It is our duty to protect our citizens and, above all, we have to protect our soldiers.

name: Κωνσταντίνα Κούνεβα (GUE/NGL).
text: — Mr President, Angelos Materitotis and Dimitris Kouklatzis — to say their names — are not just two soldiers, they are young people with families living in agony. You are, as far as I know, a father too, Mr. Stylianides, and you know what it means to be anxious for your child and for the simplest things. Much less if it's a prison wrongfully, illegally and irrationally. The European Parliament is today sending a strong signal to Turkey to put an end to this agony and to stop playing the game of tension, and here we are the most united. We all call for the immediate release of the two military. What will the Commission and the Council do? Mr Juncker expressed a wish three weeks ago to end the matter before Orthodox Easter. Easter is over. What's he gonna do from now on?

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, we are concerned about the two officers but we are not afraid. They are Greek officers, and they will withstand the hostage. On the contrary, they have achieved something, which is rare in the European Parliament. They have managed to bring together all the political groups! And this is a strong signal to be given to Turkey: that all together here, one of the rare times, are calling for their release, and we will succeed!

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: — Mr President, countless times in this area, the majority of MEPs have condemned Turkey and Erdogan for violations of international law against Greece and Cyprus, the massacres of Kurds, the violation of human rights and the political on the refugee. Turkey has committed another serious illegality: the two Greek soldiers have been kidnapped! They were, of course, performing an ordered service and did not take any offensive action. If they have entered illegally then, in accordance with international law, the Protocols and the Brussels and The Hague conferences, it is not the persons who have committed a quasi-illegality but the State they represent. So they enjoy extraterritorial proceedings. Simply put, they cannot be referred to regular justice. On the other hand, they are imprisoned in maximum security prisons and experience the appropriate conditions of detention that apply to criminals of serious criminal offences. Erdogan, gentlemen, does not understand the European Parliament's condemnation resolutions, nor does he respect the UN decisions on Cyprus. The only language he will understand is to impose harsh sanctions, to stop all funding from the Union and not to join the Union.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: Mr President, forty-seven days have passed since the two Greek soldiers were kidnapped by Turkey. Forty-seven days when the criminal regime in Ankara is left free to violate any concept of international law. But our so-called allies in the European Union not only have not supported Greece, but continue to have impeccable relations with Turkey by confining themselves to cheap and meaningless statements, while continuing the various kinds of 'business' with Ankara. Thirty-one contracts for the supply of military equipment were signed by Germany with Turkey only in the two months of December-January, and this equipment is also being used against Greece. So we are not asking, but we are demanding that the countries of Europe choose a camp: it is either with Greece or with the defiant Erdogan. Any relationship between a European country and Turkey is interpreted by the Greek people, and quite rightly so, as hostile action. The immediate release of the two military is a prerequisite before any further discussion on Turkey and, until that happens, we demand an immediate break in diplomatic relations with Turkey and the imposition of an economic embargo.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE).
text: Mr President, I will not repeat the facts. Colleagues have already analysed them in depth. However, I will insist on the daily challenges facing Greece in Thrace and the Aegean. For years we have been talking about Turkey which does not comply, which does not follow European policy. Finally, many colleagues have come to our words. Today Turkey continues its hostile attitude towards Greece. It constantly challenges Greek sovereignty and violates international law. For a month and a half, two young children, two soldiers patrolling the Kastanies of Evros, Europe's natural border with Turkey, have been held captive in Turkish prisons. Dear friends, just the day before yesterday we said goodbye to a hero pilot of our Air Force, whose aircraft crashed into the sea on his way back to its base after a call for the interception of Turkish fighters that violated Greek airspace. This is the everyday life in the Aegean Sea. The European Union must finally take action. Dimitris and Angelos, we think of you and support you! We are proud of you and do not forget you!

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to express, as Secretary-General of the European People's Party and as a Spanish MEP, my full solidarity with my colleagues and with the people of Greece, and also Cyprus, who are not free these days from these kinds of interventions which we are unfortunately discussing today in this debate. And, of course, the fate of these two Greek soldiers is the fate of any European soldier. They are European soldiers in that task of defending our borders, and it goes beyond our solidarity: without doubt, if they are not released in time and in form, action must be taken against the Ankara regime. A few words for my Cypriot friends. President Nicos Anastasiades is conducting negotiations, yet the closure and, once again, the impediments on the part of Ankara are preventing that solution. I believe that Europeans — and I as a Spanien — should express that solidarity with our Greek and Cypriot friends.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, this has been a very useful exchange and I thank the honourable Members for their interventions. From this debate, I personally conclude that we all share a common wish, but also a common duty to secure a swift and positive outcome for the two detained soldiers. At the same time, allow me to speak in my mother tongue in order to inform our compatriots, my compatriots, about our humanitarian assistance towards refugees in Turkey. Κανένα σεντ, κανένα ευρώ από την ανθρωπιστική βοήθεια που δίνεται στους πρόσφυγες στην Τουρκία δεν πάει στον τουρκικό κράτος! Αυτό το δηλώνω κατηγορηματικά ως Επίτροπος για την ανθρωπιστική βοήθεια. Οτιδήποτε άλλο είναι εκτός πραγματικότητας!

name: La Présidente. –
text: I have received two motions for resolutions pursuant to Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, April 19, 2018.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Marietje Schaake, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the implementation of the Union's external financing instruments: mid-term review in 2017 and future architecture after 2020 (2017/2280 (INI)) (A8-0112/2018).

name: Marietje Schaake
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, in less than two weeks the Commission will publish its proposal for the Multiannual Financial Framework, and a lot of attention will go to the EU budget after Brexit. But we should not forget about the future of the EU’s foreign policy spending, with almost EUR 100 million budgeted for external relations already, a lot is at stake, and we must use this upcoming budget as an opportunity to reflect and reform in order to make the EU a stronger global player. It is undeniable that the current foreign policy spending structure needs improvement. Evaluations, independent ones, have found that a strategic and overarching vision is lacking, while management by different services within both the Commission and the European External Action Service are inefficient and incoherent. Information sharing with us here in Parliament has been anything but forthcoming and, similarly, legal barriers have prevented the EU from swiftly responding to new and emerging challenges. We cannot make opaque trust funds the new model for foreign policy spending and certainly not with the main goal of managing migration, and that is exactly what risks happening. The European External Action Service is rumoured to seek the creation of one single instrument for EU External Action with ‘a strong focus on migration’. You heard it right: the goal is to pool all the money together, and as we understand, Commissioner Hahn is trying to ensure the funding intended for candidate Member States and the European neighbourhood remain separate. What’s most concerning to me and many of my colleagues is not that there is an appetite for ambitious reforms – in fact that should be embraced – but that no governance model has been set up for such a single instrument. So how can we in the European Parliament be asked to agree with the new vehicle if we do not know how it is going to be steered? I am afraid that the lack of clarity here uncovers a bigger problem. During a recent Committee on Foreign Affairs hearing and during the many foreign instruments working groups that I have chaired, it has become clear that Members of the European Parliament are not in the mood to give the External Action Service or the Commission carte blanche. They feel sidelined already as strategic dialogues are often neither strategic nor dialogues. Information is shared reluctantly and late. Parliament is keen to ensure it can do its job and steer policies, spending and apply the necessary and required parliamentary scrutiny. MEPs also want to build in more flexibility to ensure adequate responses to new crises, as well as the preservation of European values. We do, as Europe faces unprecedented challenges at the moment: bloodshed continues in Yemen and Syria, and Presidents Erdoğan and el-Sisi have further consolidated their authoritarian grip on power in Turkey and Egypt. At the same time, governments in Russia, China and Iran are at odds with the values and interests we hold dear in Europe. In practice, the values-based goals and objectives of EU foreign policy have too often become subordinate to short-term and national interests such as migration management or countering terrorism. The deal concluded with President Erdoğan to stop Syrian refugees from reaching us in Europe is a case in point. The future of the EU’s foreign policy budget can benefit from reforms, but cannot only be designed to deal with today’s crises. Who knows what could be at the top of the agenda in 2025? And in the absence of an altogether more flexible budget, which is what we should be focusing on with the MFF, we need at least to build in flexibility while we have multiannual spending plans. But certainly the instrumentalising of all foreign policy funds and managing migration as the key goal is not the right direction. So before the European External Action Service and the Commission propose a new architecture, they should think about governance and, where needed, be reminded that we in Parliament play an equal role here. I therefore encourage colleagues in this House to focus on the principles of parliamentary scrutiny, oversight, policy-steered spending, evaluations and accountability. Let us not get bogged down in long lists of our favourite instruments to save from the reforms.

name: Neven Mimica
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, honourable Members, let me thank the Chair of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Mr McAllister, and the rapporteur, Ms Schaake, for this important report and good collaboration over the past months. Let me first share a few reflections on the mid-term review and the instruments covered by the report. I fully concur with the report’s findings that our instruments are generally fit for purpose, but have been stretched to their limits in the past years. In particular, the European Neighbourhood Instrument has been a pivotal tool to force reforms in our neighbourhood. At the same time, as the report notes, the challenges that we have faced in the neighbourhood have shown the need for greater financial resources and more flexibility. The Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance is unique in addressing the objective of preparing candidate countries and potential candidates for EU membership. The next instrument for pre-accession should be clearly positioned in the context of the new Western Balkan strategy. The mid-term review concluded that our Instrument contributing to Stability and Peace was relevant, effective, and efficient and had a unique added value, and we fully agree. The European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights promotes some of our core values in a challenging global context. We have witnessed increased pressure on human rights defenders and closing spaces for civil society in many countries. We intend to enhance our support to human rights defenders even more in the coming years and continue our work on EU election observations. Finally, the Partnership Instrument is a young instrument that has helped us invest in the European Union’s soft power, where and when we needed it the most. In the next three years we want to focus it on some priorities, such as economic diplomacy, climate, health, peace and security, and digital issues including cybersecurity. Let me come to the future architecture. I would like to reflect on the lessons from the mid-term review that guide our thinking for the proposal we will soon publish. First, the volume of external action funding needs to match our political ambitions. To deliver on our ambitions we need adequate financial resources. Second, too often we have had to adapt our policies to our instruments. It is time that we adapt our instruments to our political priorities. This is why we have proposed merging our development and foreign policy instruments into one broad instrument covering neighbourhood as well as development and international cooperation. Third, one broad instrument does not mean one single policy. It does not mean less funding for certain regions or themes. There will be clear funding dedicated to each policy area in order to reflect our political priorities. Fourth, we need more flexibility and more responsiveness. Our aim is also to set aside a significant share of unallocated funds. This will allow us to react to changing circumstances without diverting funds from other policies. We want – and we agree with the report on this – to make the EU budget more accountable, more transparent and understandable to the public. That includes, as announced yesterday, bringing the European Development Fund inside the budget, as this would significantly enhance parliamentary scrutiny. Finally, it should be easier to work for the security of our citizens and partners. For this reason, the High Representative has proposed setting up a European peace facility to finance missions and capacity building as an off-budget funding mechanism. Let me conclude by saying that our debates on budgets should finally focus on our citizens’ priorities, instead of focusing simply on instruments. We would like our conversation to be driven by the great issues of our times, from migration to the situation in Syria, from security to Africa’s development.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Madam President, as shadow rapporteur for the EPP Group I had the opportunity to coordinate my group's vision in a vital dossier for the European Union's foreign policy. I would like to thank and acknowledge the work done by my colleague Marietje Schaake which certainly helped to get the text we voted for tomorrow in this house. The effectiveness of the European Union's external financing instruments is essential if we can ensure that the European Union has the necessary tools to implement its overall, neighbourhood and enlargement policy. What we are discussing today is not only the mid-term review of these instruments, but also the recommendation for the new architecture from 2020: what needs to be changed or optimized in those instruments so that they continue to do the important work they do in our foreign policy. In this regard, I would like to highlight three points. The current external relations budget is only 6% of the multiannual financial framework. However, with that amount the European Union has achieved considerable successes in our external relations, from a successful agreement with Turkey to curb migration flows to the Minsk agreements to achieve stability and peace in Ukraine. Secondly, we must point out the importance of having specific instruments for specific aspects of our international agenda. Specific funding for our neighbourhood policy instruments must be ensured. The European Neighbourhood Instrument is the most effective way to influence emigration, security, economic development and better governance of our strategic partners who are geographically closer to us. I don't have time left.

name: Andi Cristea
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, many thanks to the rapporteur and to colleagues for the solid text we have before us today. It is clear that we need to enhance the effectiveness of our external financing instruments. We need an architecture that is able to match the unprecedented challenges we are confronted with. In the context of the preparation of the Commission’s proposal for the next MFF, the Commission and the European External Action Service are discussing the structure of the external financing instruments to simplify the architecture and enhance flexibility. We must ensure that appropriate safeguards in terms of parliamentary scrutiny are put in place. A simplified architecture of the instruments achieved through their consolidation would have to be accompanied by a new oversight model of governance and parliamentary scrutiny, ensuring full accountability. In addition, a consolidation of instruments would have very political implications, even more so in the context of Brexit and budget pressure. Current priorities this House has fought hard for – human rights, development, enlargement and neighbourhood policy, to name just a few – must remain at the heart of our external action.

name: Anders Primdahl Vistisen
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Madam President First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the work laid out in the report. It is incredibly significant that we have looked at how we get our funds spent in the right way and in the most flexible way. That is why the ECR Group is also pleased that we will have increased flexibility with the proposals contained here in the report. When we cannot vote in favour of the overall result anyway, it is primarily because we do not believe that we can propose increases for the EU's budgetary areas until we have addressed funding. Since we do not believe that the EU budget as a result of Brexit must necessarily be higher, then we also believe we have a responsibility to address how the funds should be raised before we propose to use them. The other thing that pains us in the ECR Group is that we have repeated the unilateral criticism that has been in relation to the devastation in Gaza and the West Bank of demanding EU funds for buildings back from the Israelis without thinking that the Palestinians have very much added up to them devastation that has occurred, including by deliberately using soft civilian targets as launch ramps and hiding place for terrorist attacks against Israel. What we are pleased, on the other hand, that has been included in the report, is a criticism of the candidate country funds that have gone to Turkey. It is absolutely clear to the ECR Group that we need to take a showdown with the rather uncritical approach that has been in terms of funding for Turkey in previous years.

name: Jordi Solé
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I welcome Ms Schaake’s report, especially when it comes to reviewing the current external financing instruments, underlining the need to align them with the Sustainable Development Goals and proposing some improvements. When it comes to making proposals on the post—2020 architecture, we are not so enthusiastic. We know – and we have just heard once again – that Ms Mogherini and the Commission are working on a major overhaul of this architecture, merging the existing financing instruments, including the Development Cooperation Instrument, the Human Rights and Democracy Instrument and the Instrument Contributing to Stability and Peace into a unified single instrument. Until today, we have not heard – beyond the rather empty argument of simplification – of any good reason why all these important thematic tools of the Union should disappear and be merged. On the contrary, the recent mid—term review conducted by the Commission has just confirmed that these instruments are fit for purpose and, in the case of the Instrument for Stability and Peace, ‘a key tool for the EU to underpin its diplomacy and tailor—made projects’. This mid—term review also stresses in its conclusions that this capacity ‘must be further strengthened in any future architecture’. We acknowledge that the new structure should be more rational and more flexible. We even acknowledge that there is room for merging some external-action and some development-cooperation instruments, but we stress the importance of maintaining separate instruments for enlargement, neighbourhood policy, development, human rights and democracy, civilian conflict prevention and civilian crisis response.

name: Sabine Lösing
text: Mr President, on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. The involvement of Parliament in the form of the so-called strategic dialogue between Parliament, EEAS and the Commission has so far been nothing more than occupational therapy for MEPs, where the EEAS and the Commission have dragged with public places through 90-minute meetings. This had nothing to do with information or even cooperation or parliamentary control. The now enumed merging of all financial instruments into a single one will aggravate this state of parliamentary non-participation. We refuse that. This is also against the background of the increasing misuse of the financial resources of the respective instruments. Once thought of as civilian instruments for improving socio-economic development and peace-building, they are now subordinate to the EU's security and economic interests. The Turkey-EU refugee defence deal was co-financed by the pre-accession instrument. The Instrument for Stability and Peace, conceived as a purely civilian instrument for development, disarmament, reintegration, conflict prevention, peaceful conflict resolution, has also been used since last autumn to train, maintain and equip armies in third countries. This is the complete subordination of civil and development policies to military and security policy. Using development aid for the military is a declaration of bankruptcy of peace policy. That is why we abstain from the report, but we support all proposals for democratic participation.

name: David Coburn
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, it seems strange to me that the European Union should have these so-called ‘financial instruments’ which are designed to support foreign and domestic policy objectives in the neighbourhood – North Africa, the Middle East, Eastern Europe, the Caucasus, etc. – and to support candidate member countries to meet the standards of the acquis and join the EU, whether their populations want to or not. In relation to Brexit, it calls for the ratio of spending to be increased. How is the EU going to be able to fund if one of its most important contributors, the UK, is leaving? Where is the money coming from? The purpose of this money seems to be to increase EU interference and disrupt neighbouring states. I would hate to think that this money will be used in the future to interfere and destabilise an independent Britain by subsidising disruptive remainer groups. We do not want the domestic and economic (inaudible) potentially booming UK economy undermined by our own money through these (inaudible) external financial instruments which seem more like some sort of Machiavellian slush fund. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Madam President, let’s just go back to some basics, please, which is that essentially the EU external financing programme is designed to buy friends and buy influence. It is actually a classic display of what is called ‘soft power’. The report all but admits that it has been a failure in its purpose to promote EU values, and let me quote from the report: ‘[The EFI is] inconsistent [with] implementation of EU values and partnership principles’, ‘[... the absence of] evaluation mechanisms’; ‘the lack of flexibility’. The report is concerned that the EU and its instruments face significant challenges, including political trade-offs between the promotion of values and rights and short-term security interests, numerous violent global conflicts and a decline in transatlantic consensus. Hardly a glowing report.  If the report recognises and cites this sort of shortcomings, what level of confidence can MEPs have in its continuation? Finally, may I finish by reminding the Chamber of the EUR 50 billion cost of these instruments? (The speaker agreed to take a blue—card question under Rule 162(8))

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Ms James, do you agree with me that this money does not seem to be accounted for, and that no one seems to know where it goes or what it is used for? Would you like to elaborate on that? What do you think?

name: Diane James (NI)
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Coburn, as a colleague, thank you very much, but we have seen this all too often with other areas of expenditure. It is interesting, isn’t it, that in terms of transparency and scrutiny far too many of the financial expenditure reports this Chamber looks at are equally as critical and equally lacking on the detail that would give us as MEPs confidence to sign off.

name: José Ignacio Salafranca Sánchez-Neyra (PPE).
text: Madam President, I thought I had a minute and a half. In any event, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Schaake, for her work on a subject that is of great importance. The European Union, as has been pointed out here, is mobilising EUR 52 billion under the financial perspectives, a very important part of which is assumed by so-called foreign policy instruments. Commissioner, you have just reminded us that they do not depart substantially from the fundamental axes of the 2030 Agenda, the Addis Ababa action programme, the Paris Conference objectives, but it is clear — and the rapporteur has told us — that these funds need adjustment. I take advantage of your presence here, Commissioner, to be interested in the Development Cooperation Instrument (DCI), the instrument you manage, and the problems that arise for the countries already graduated. In any event, if I had to underline one fundamental element of the report presented to us by Mrs Schaake, I would refer to flexibility. Clearly, we must be vigilant to take into account new threats and the new configuration of our relations and try to have more agile, more flexible and, above all, more effective instruments in the service of the interests and values of the European Union.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, financial instruments for external action are a fundamental component of European foreign policy for promoting our values through concrete actions in the world. Over the years, however, Parliament has repeatedly highlighted problems of inconsistency, inefficiencies and duplications which limit their effectiveness while international scenarios, particularly in regions close to us, are constantly evolving. In view of the forthcoming multiannual financial framework, the financial commitment must not be reduced but strengthened, despite Brexit and the growing reticences of some Member States, while instruments must become more flexible and transparent; it must be ensured even more serious Parliament's control over their use. From this point of view, our lighthouse must remain the principle of conditionality. The EU's resources cannot support those who take backward steps on human rights and the rule of law. When this happens it must become a well-established practice of our action and direct support for the civil society of the country involved, diverting the funds allocated to it, as is taking place for Turkey, after a strong pressure from this Parliament.

name: Bodil Valero (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President! Through my Green colleagues Alexander Langer and Green Party founder Per Gahrton, the Greens were driving for the EU to engage in civil conflict resolution. It also became part of European foreign policy. Peace promotion efforts have so far financed through a special instrument for peace and stability, an instrument that we green have actively contributed to the content of, but now many in this House want to dispense with the money pot after 2020. During the year, the money for the peace instrument has expanded to include some military purposes after both the Conservatives and the Social Democrats pushed through allowing it to be used for military capacity-building in third countries. Not only is it politically unwise, it is, moreover, not in accordance with the rules. We all know that the treaty does not allow the EU budget to be used for military expenditure. We also know that the legal basis for the instrument of peace does not allow it to be used to fund military projects. I would therefore strongly urge Parliament to restore the peace instrument in the next long term budget to what it is intended for: civil conflict resolution and peace-building.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would first like to pass on my congratulations to Ms Schaake for the good report. External financial instruments are like the muscles of our external policy: they can lift up the positive changes in third countries. To flex the muscles, however, we need a solid backbone – in other words, clear political guidance, direction and strategic vision. Once these are put together, we can talk about the ambition to become a global player.  Although the current instruments seem to be fit for purpose, they lack strategic overreaching vision. In many cases, we experience a lack of flexibility, for example the crisis in Ukraine, the migration crisis or the situation in Syria, Libya or Egypt. In the new Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), therefore, we need instruments fully in line with the vision and policy priorities. They need to be flexible enough and work in synergy with each other. Reform of the current instruments is required in order to provide more accountability, transparency and oversight. As the rapporteur to the Neighbourhood Instrument, I was often disappointed at the limited insight and role that Parliament had a chance to play after adoption of the instruments. We need more scrutiny, but also general political guidance coming from the European Parliament. The governance of the instrument should be more efficient and responsive to the needs of political priorities.

name: Clare Moody (S&D).
text: – Madam President, this is inevitably a technical report but, as the rapporteur has said, there is a fundamental principle at stake. Parliament plays a vital role in the effectiveness of European action. Part of that role is holding the Commission to account. The Commissioner’s statement said much on needing to be flexible and needing to make the funding more flexible in order to fit evolving priorities, on the face of it a very reasonable proposition. But what was not explained was how, or who, would set those priorities or the means of delivering them. Presuming a mechanism is put in place to determine that prioritising process, then that is when we should discuss in detail the best use of the funding. However, today it is important to be clear that the Parliament has a red line: parliamentary scrutiny. The Commission must come up with a clear proposal that meets that red line.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank my colleague, Ms Schaake, for this clear and common—sense approach to the vital topic. We actually call for a policy—driven and principle—based use of the external financial instruments that should operate within, and in harmony with, the EU’s strategic policies. The central idea for me is to develop a maximum of synergies and coherence between all the instruments in question. At the same time, regarding the idea floated by the Commission and the External Action Service to pool all instruments into one, I remain sceptical and agree with Ms Schaake that we cannot provide a ‘carte blanche’ for this idea. At the same time, I do believe that the EU has to apply stricter conditionality as for the beneficiaries. It would actually be useful to strengthen the ownership of the beneficiaries, having them fully on board from step one. There is also the need to make sure that the EU rules and procedures for funding are fully understood from the beginning. The monitoring and evaluating of the process is a must. In situations of serious political backsliding, funds need to be suspended faster to make the beneficiary comply with the EU rules and principles. Lastly, I think the EU has a task to have maximum visibility for its external instruments and their impact.

name: Arne Lietz (S&D).
text: Madam President, Mr Mimica. First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her report and would like to add two more things. Firstly, funds earmarked for development cooperation must under no circumstances be spent on financing the military in partner countries. Parliament has already successfully denied this to the Member States and the Commission last year, and I see no reason why we should fall behind it now. The Instrument for Stability and Peace should therefore be given particular attention when planning the Multiannual Financial Framework from 2020. We are waiting here for the Commission's proposal, which I hope will take this into consideration. Secondly, the EU and most Member States have failed to fulfil their obligations to allocate 0.7% of gross national income to official development cooperation. Against this background, its financing needs to be expanded as part of the future design of external financing instruments for the period after 2020.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would first of all like to congratulate Mrs Schaake on her comprehensive report. In this globalised, complex and interdependent world, we need robust external action on the part of the European Union: it is not possible to retreat, but we need to project ourselves outside the Union's borders.
