This external projection requires funding. The Union must be a provider of peace, development, democratic reforms, stability and integration, particularly in its immediate vicinity. In the forthcoming revision of regulations, our Neighbourhood Instrument needs to be reformed precisely. We require a realistic and ambitious neighbourhood policy that meets the needs of our partners and their ambitions without prejudice to our principles, values and interests. I therefore welcome the rapporteur's position in favour of maintaining that specific neighbourhood instrument in architecture from 2020: we must make it clear that we remain interested in promoting that neighbourhood policy as provided for in Article 8 of the Treaty on Union. I also support maintaining the current balance in the allocation of funds between the south and eastern neighbourhood, as the report we will adopt tomorrow. On the other hand, I will not reiterate the importance of the security dimension and also the migration issue. In dialogue and cooperation with our neighbours, these issues must be very high on the agenda. I'm done. The European Union has to be efficient; we must demonstrate that it is also a security provider and able to contribute effectively to the management of migration flows. We are experiencing these years, in Europe, the rise of populist and Eurosceptic forces: an effective European Union will take away arguments from them.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: “Kelam and Kukan colleagues have spurned me: I can sign under what my colleagues in the PPE group said earlier. Whereas I will only add two elements that, from my point of view, are relevant. First, just as colleague Kukan said, we are distracting ourselves. We need to take care of discipline, we need to be better organised and we should have better formulated strategic objectives. I add to this, that we should also take care of internal transfers here in Europe, so that the External Action Services remember that these allies for a particular policy are primarily citizens of the European Union. And finally, I'll add one more element. Well, 52 billion euros is not small money. If they are divided into such numerous tasks, we too often move away from the first and foremost neighbours, pursue scattered objectives in very remote geographical areas and thus lose what is most important — the value system of strategic goals to achieve.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE).
text: — Dear Chair, Honored Vice-President and Honored Commissioner Mimica, I would like to congratulate my colleague Marietje Schaaka on a well-prepared report that aims to contribute to creating a clear vision of the structure and priorities within the European Union instruments for external financing in the next multi-year financial period. In order to strengthen European Union values and interests of the European Union in the world, EU external financing instruments for the period after 2020 must be more efficient, flexible and transparent, and in order to achieve that, we need to reconsider the current situation within the current situation multiannual financial framework. In accordance with the above, it is necessary to detect flaws in its implementation and to detect overlaps that affect the aid effect in recipient countries. We must strengthen the ownership of recipient states in determining reform priorities in order to encourage the desire to implement the necessary reforms as quickly as possible. Requirements for implementation of key economic reforms as well as democratic political institutional consolidation in partner countries must be accompanied by appropriate financial resources in the next financial period. I consider this particularly important for the IPA II Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance, especially in the context of today's encouraging Report on Enlargement to the Western Balkans and the recently published European Union Enlargement Strategy, which provides support to candidate countries and potential candidates in implementation of reforms aimed at achieving stability and security in the immediate neighbourhood of the European Union.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I congratulate the rapporteur, Ms Schaake, and the team of shadow rapporteurs on the very good report. We have nine financial instruments which are working well, but for the next period, after 2020, we could improve the efficiency of many of these instruments. In the light of the wars and conflicts and rising tensions outside EU borders, I stress the importance of further strengthening, post-2020, the architecture of the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights, which could bring massive EU added value, as it cooperates directly with human rights defenders and local civil society organisations around the world, without the need for the approval of national authorities. The instrument needs clearer and more strategic objectives which are totally independent of other instruments in order to bring more feasible solutions on, critically, human rights violations in countries like Syria and Turkey, which were intensely debated last time in our plenary. Secondly, I would like to welcome the news that the Instrument Contributing to Stability and Peace, in addition to the support for security initiatives and peace-building activities, will now provide funds for training measures and equipment supplies to third countries working towards the Sustainable Development Goals. Nevertheless, we need the establishment of solid and transparent monitoring and evaluation systems that are consistent for all instruments.

name: Julia Pitera (PPE).
text: - Madam President! Of course, I see the merits of combining the financial instruments of the European Union, among other things, creating more flexible and simple financing procedures. At the same time, I believe that the European Neighbourhood Instrument should remain a separate financial instrument. I remind you: the midterm review showed that this instrument works great. Why should we change anything then? Depriving the neighbourhood policy of its own financial instrument will lower the political rank of the Eastern Partnership. We would lose a special approach to the immediate vicinity of the Union. Certain goals and qualities will also vanish, such as differentiation and the principle of more for more, and thus the incentive for structural reform. Neighbourhood policy is focused on political engagement instead of development aid, it is a more comprehensive policy, more ambitious and therefore needs special attention. In addition, there would be a risk of reducing funding for the Eastern Partnership by transferring funds more easily between different priorities and regions. I don't agree to this, and therefore I think that neighbourhood policy cannot be stripped of its own financial instrument.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: — Dear Chairman, I welcome Commissioner Mimica and congratulate the rapporteur on the excellent report. This report shows that we achieve results through changes in the public sector, education, respect for human rights, the establishment of the rule of law, an effective and independent judiciary, the fight against corruption, all of which are the prerequisites of societies that build on trust and in which peace is possible and stability and economic growth and development. This is exactly what we want to achieve through our influence and action outside the European Union. We need to simplify the EU External Action Instruments System, all of you have pointed out, and more clearly correlate with the expected objectives, and to establish a better quality monitoring of results. That is why I fully agree with the statement of Commissioner Mimica, who pointed out that we need to adapt the instruments to policies, our mission and objectives, and not vice versa — policy instruments. Likewise, achieving results must be above the set plan and flexibility in use is key.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I want to speak about the proposed merger of the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights (EIDHR) with other financial instruments, because this continues to be of great concern to those of us who care about human rights.  The EIDHR is a one-of-a-kind programme. It is the largest human rights and democracy fund in the world, and was established by us – the European Parliament – in 1994. It is the only current programme that provides independent and impartial funding to civil society and human rights defenders, including protection and support for human rights defenders at risk. It is unique among EU external action instruments. Many organisations and individual human rights defenders will simply not be able to access funds without it. The maintenance of a dedicated, separate instrument would also allow for better parliamentary scrutiny of funding, with greater accountability and transparency. A separate instrument for human rights and democracy guarantees funding for these key priorities in European external action and promotes key aspects of sustainable development, societal resilience and the root causes of migration.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, the mechanisms for financing the Union's external action must operate in such a way that human rights are fully respected. It is not possible to finance countries such as Turkey which violates human rights. A moment ago we discussed the unfair and illegal detention of the two Greek soldiers in Turkey's prisons, where there are thousands of political prisoners. It is not possible to give Turkey low-interest loans from the European Investment Bank. Similarly, external action cannot support countries in which labour rights are not respected, countries where child labour is carried out, countries where the right to health and safety is violated and, from then on, obviously, these mechanisms cannot be finance actions in countries which do not respect the protection of the environment.

name: Neven Mimica
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I thank the honourable Members for this debate. The Commission will publish its proposal for the next MFF on 2 May. We are looking forward to an intensive exchange and negotiations with Parliament thereafter. This would be a true opportunity to fully justify the background to the Commission’s proposals, as well as to address and clarify some of the concerns flagged in the report and in the debates today.  Let me conclude by reiterating that simplification is not an end in itself. It will enable us to become more coherent, exploit complementarities, create synergies, overcome fragmentation and silo approaches and reduce artificial boundaries and inconsistencies between instruments. With the new architecture, we intend to make our cooperation more efficient and effective. In this manner, we will also make the EU visible as a major global actor.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would especially like to thank all the colleagues who broadly support the compromise in the resolution. In replying after the debate, we have one key question left that can be summarised in one word, and that is ‘how’. We hear, on the one hand, that the mid-term review concludes that the instruments are fit—for—purpose. On the other hand, we get a proposal to radically change the instruments. I think the Commission and the External Action Service really urgently need to explain how – and not only to us (we are budget and foreign policy geeks, not a big group of people, although we would have been interested in an actual outline and we have asked for it before), but what about our citizens and what about our partner countries? This cannot wait until the last minute, if you really want this to be a success. I think, generally, the notion of better communication has been raised by MEPs throughout many discussions we have had. So I unfortunately have to conclude that there is still no clarity on governance. It is a broad ask and, frankly, I think it is a missed opportunity that this debate was not used to outline how the reform of the instruments will be governed. On a number of focus areas that you outlined in your introduction, such as public diplomacy, the Western Balkans and a digital values—based approach, I think we generally have common ground, but I am concerned when I hear things like ‘we will work according to what the people want’. Of course, this is a highly political discussion and I suspect it will be for the entire multiannual period that we are talking about, and I urge the External Action Service and the Commission not to lose sight of long-term goals and objectives: even though short-term solutions can be very tempting, they can also be a populist trap. I really think that we, the EU, have a bigger promise than only to look at short-term goals. Certainly when everything gets framed in the context of migration management, I do not think that that is a long-term and a sustainable and values-based solution. I know a lot of colleagues are very unhappy if that is the direction we are going in. To conclude: yes, our money should be focused on policy goals, and should be spent efficiently with the appropriate oversight and parliamentary scrutiny, while respecting our values. We can only really talk about whether we agree with the new architecture if we know how it is going to be governed.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Wednesday 18 April 2018. Written declarations (article 162)

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. - I welcome the report on the implementation of the EU's external financing instruments, as the Union's external action is becoming increasingly important for European citizens. These financing instruments include the Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (IPA II), the European Neighbourhood Instrument (ENI) and the Instrument for Stability and Peace (ICSP) which is important for Ukraine. I think it is important to emphasise that I do not support the pooling of instruments, and I am pleased that we are in agreement here in the European Parliament. The budget of the instruments must show an upward trend, as these instruments are the main mechanism to support the Union's action on the global stage. In the interests of successful projects, it would also be worthwhile to increase the visibility of external financing instruments in the regions concerned by means of communication and information campaigns. I share the rapporteur's view that the programming priorities of the European Neighbourhood Instrument should include socio-economic development, youth and sustainable management of energy resources. I support the process of enlargement of the Union, which requires credible financial assistance, so that a stronger Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance and the European Neighbourhood Instrument are of fundamental interest to me.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. — We are in a particular historical moment. Theatres of conflict and death multiply, the instability and chaos of 'distant' but 'neighbouring' countries resonate threatening in an unprepared European Union, unable to speak with a single voice and project itself as an internationally credible actor. Syria, Yemen, Libya, Turkey: just a few examples of external challenges intertwining with internal ones, fueling the sense of citizens' insecurity. In such a dramatic context, a clear and long-term political vision underlying the Union's foreign policy of the financial instruments of external action is needed. Greater coherence, transparency, conditionality and democratic control must be the essential ingredients of a possible reform of the present architecture. I also reiterate the importance of the EIDHR instrument, which must not be assembled to others, because the only one not to require state consent for direct support to civil society and defenders of the human rights. Only in this way, we could concretely contribute to sustainable and bottom-up development of third countries.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. — Ladies and gentlemen, I welcome the part of the report that recognised the strategic importance of the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance, the current so-called IPA 2. However, I believe that the pre-accession financial assistance to the candidate States has little regard to the financial resources of the European Union and the reforms facing the candidate countries and their costs. Serbia is eligible for financial assistance of approximately EUR 1.5 billion over the seven-year period, i.e. EUR 200 million per person per year, which is EUR 28 per inhabitant per year. Although this is a significant amount, it is far behind the resources needed to implement the reforms. For example, the tasks to be carried out in the field of environmental protection are estimated to take EUR 4 billion until accession. I believe that it is essential to take into account the real needs of the candidate countries, in particular the two leading countries, Serbia and Montenegro, when drawing up the next multiannual financial perspective. This would help to implement reforms faster and more efficiently, which is essential to achieving the 2025 accession deadline set in the enlargement strategy. Thank you for listening to me.

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: in writing. — The proposed, inter alia, by the Mogherini High Representative, to increase flexibility in the use of existing EU financial instruments to better respond to regional and global challenges. The European Parliament in the Schaake report agrees that the mechanism of the instrument needs review and updating, mainly because of the lack of strategic and overarching vision and the fact that it is managed by various services in both the Commission and the EEAS. However, it seems that the idea of combining all instruments into one for its simplification is too far-fetched. In particular, we support the central European countries' demands to leave the European Neighbourhood Instrument (ENI) as separate, according to the principle of “let's not spoil what works well.” We support the simplification and alignment of financial mechanisms for political purposes. Nevertheless, it seems that the secrecy of the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance (IPA II) and the European Instrument for the Support of Democracy and Human Rights (EIDHR) should be maintained precisely for the sake of EU political objectives. The preservation of separate ENIs and geographical and thematic baskets is significant as a signal that the EU recognises the European aspirations of the partners of the Eastern Partnership. The reform of financial instruments should be carried out in such a way as to strengthen EU policy, particularly with regard to neighbourhood countries.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The next item is the joint discussion on፦ the recommendation by Francisco José Millán Mon, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the framework agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Australia, of the other part (15467/2016 - C8-0327/2017 - 2016/0367 (NLE)) (A8-0110/2018), and - the report by Francisco José Millán Mon, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, containing a non-legislative motion for a resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Framework Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Australia, of the other part (2017/2227 (INI)) (A8-0119/2018).

name: Francisco José Millán Mon
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, today we are discussing the adoption of the Framework Agreement between the European Union and Australia in this House. The Recommendation on the Agreement and the accompanying report obtained broad support in the Committee on Foreign Affairs a few weeks ago. I look forward to the support of the plenary tomorrow. But I would first of all like to thank the shadow rapporteurs of the political groups for their cooperation. And I also thank the European External Action Service for its cooperation in preparing the report on this Framework Agreement. Next, I will highlight some aspects of the Agreement and the relations between the European Union and Australia. The relationship is very solid, based on many historical links, values and common principles. There is, yes, a physical, geographical remoteness, but there is a great political and value proximity. Australia is, so to speak, a natural ally of the European Union in that vast Asia-Pacific area, which is very dynamic and increasingly important in today's world. In the White Paper on Foreign Policy 2017, the Australian Government stressed the vital importance of relations with the European Union. These relations have increased in recent years: this is demonstrated by this Framework Agreement, also the leadership forum, or the first contacts already concluded with a view to negotiating a free trade agreement. Furthermore, we agree on many high-level dialogue mechanisms taking place in Asia-Pacific. At the bilateral level, I stress the importance of launching negotiations on a free trade agreement. Australia is a country that believes in free trade in the face of unfortunately booming protectionism. We have a growing trade and economic relationship in which the European Union enjoys a significant surplus. There are many other areas of dialogue and cooperation established by the Agreement, for example: foreign and security policy, human rights, economy and trade, education, culture, research, innovation, energy, transport, justice and global challenges such as terrorism, climate change, weapons of mass destruction, global governance or development. Australia is indeed an important regional player and is also a very active member of global agencies in the face of these global challenges. For example, he was recently on the Security Council, now on the UN Human Rights Council, and is also a member of the G20 since its founding and chaired it in 2014. Australia is also present in numerous Asia-Pacific regional and subregional organizations. I would also like to emphasize its alignment with the European Union's positions on sanctions against Russia, North Korea and Syria. I will also mention their participation in anti-Daesh operations and its many peacekeeping missions at the UN. He is also present in the so-called Combined Maritime Forces, in anti-piracy and terrorism operations in the Western Indian Ocean. The Framework Agreement also provides for cooperation on other major global and regional challenges. I refer, for example, to climate change, migration issues and development issues, all of which are addressed in the resolution which we will vote tomorrow. Finally, the positions of the European Union and Australia, at the international level and in the face of the challenges of our time, often coincide. Australia, like the European Union, is also an actor committed to global governance based on international law and multilateralism, which we too want to preserve. It also supported free trade, development aid and the fight against terrorism. The European Union wants to be increasingly present in Asian regional forums; its positions are very similar to those of Australia, and I therefore hope that Australia will cooperate with the Union Europe closely in these forums and to give all the facilities to be fully integrated into all of them, including the so - called East Asia Summit. In this large and complex Asia-Pacific region, Australia is very close to our values and interests; these relations need to be further strengthened and precisely for that the Framework Agreement will be a very useful instrument. I hope that support for the Agreement Recommendation and the accompanying report will remain very large.

name: Neven Mimica
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, thank you for the opportunity for this debate on the EU—Australia Framework Agreement. The Agreement reflects our wish to give a modern framework to relations with one of the EU’s closest partners in the Asia—Pacific region. It will allow the promotion and expansion of our cooperation with Australia across a broad range of areas of mutual interest.  EU relations with Australia are excellent and I sincerely believe that they will continue to evolve further. We are geographically very far apart but we work together on a daily basis on the global stage. Our cooperation on foreign policy has been constant and intense. Just to name a recent example, Australia has shown great solidarity in condemning the Salisbury attack and took concrete actions in response to it. We take part in the same military missions to preserve peace and security around the world and we particularly appreciate Australia’s participation in our operation off the coast of the Horn of Africa. We also have good development cooperation, especially in the Pacific, focusing on sustainable development, economic growth and gender equality. We are incredibly like—minded and, as a consequence, political dialogue with Australia has been intensifying and an ever—increasing number of political contacts have taken place over the past years. In 2016, we launched the EU—Australia Leadership Forum, a unique platform for European and Australian political business, media and civil society leaders to meet and nurture the relationship with new ideas and proposals. In 2008, the EU and Australia signed a partnership framework, which opened new avenues for cooperation. We also hold a regular security dialogue at senior official level.  The signing of our Framework Agreement last summer by High Representative Mogherini and Foreign Minister Bishop came as a natural evolution of our partnership. Our Framework Agreement makes our relationship fit for the 21st century. The European Union and Australia share the same world view. We support democracy, the rule of law and human rights and we are active players in multilateral organisations such as the United Nations and the World Trade Organization. We have also shared interests in tackling key global challenges, such as sustainable development, humanitarian aid and the fight against terrorism. We work together against climate change and to better manage migration. We both want international trade to be free and fair at the same time. EU—Australia cooperation in the Pacific is growing. We have many shared interests in sustainable energy, climate change and ocean governance. We are also looking into how to associate like—minded donors, like Australia, in the post—Cotonou process.  To complete the advancing political relationship, we have decided to work towards launching negotiations for a free trade agreement. We have gone through a number of important stages of the preparatory process. The Commission has carried out an impact assessment and held free trade agreement (FTA) co—opening discussions with Australia. The draft directives for negotiating the free trade agreement were published by the Commission in September. The discussions in the Council are ongoing.  The European Parliament has fed into these deliberations with a dedicated report adopted at the end of October. I trust that the Council will adopt the negotiating directives soon, enabling the Commission to launch the free trade agreement negotiations before the summer. The Commission looks forward to continuing cooperation with the Parliament in this matter.

name: José Ignacio Salafranca Sánchez-Neyra
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Madam President, I thought I was going to retire another half minute. I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Millán, for his report in which, as always, he presents us with serious and rigorous work, which, moreover, comes at a very opportune moment on our timetable. This morning we were discussing with the French President, Mr Macron, the need for the European Union to have reliable partners on the political board in order to deal with global challenges... the Commissioner referred, a moment ago, to world governance, his participation — as the rapporteur reminded us a moment ago — in the G20, to the fight against terrorism, to the issue of migration or climate change. Australia, moreover, has seriously committed itself to a very close defensive relationship with the United States, as stated in the report, and also has an excellent relationship on its continent and with other countries, such as China. Therefore, Madam President, not only in the political sphere but also in the economic field, it is very important to develop a relationship with a country that believes in the advantages of free trade, which constitutes an asset within the world organisation and which, as the rapporteur pointed out, has a very important relationship with us. which amounts to more than 45 billion annual trade. We therefore understand that this Agreement puts into the rank of the first division of relations that the European Union has relations between Australia and the European Union, and we hope that the same success as this report by the Committee on Foreign Affairs has, I am sure, will be in plenary tomorrow.

name: Francisco Assis
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (PT) Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating the author of the report, Mr Millán Mon, on the quality of the report and the openness he has shown to the contributions made by the various shadow rapporteurs. There is no need to stress the importance of the relationship between the European Union and Australia. We have common political cultures, coinciding views with regard to our internal institutional organization model and, as such, we have a very similar interpretation of major international issues. As has already been mentioned here, from political issues, economic issues, trade issues, environmental issues, issues relating to the promotion of human rights, there are many coincidences of views between the European Union and Australia, and so we have, in this particular historical circumstance, strengthen our links with Australia. At the same time, we must pave the way for a trade agreement. We live in times very dominated by protectionist fears. On the left and right protectionism is gaining ground. We must oppose this, I believe, in order to affirm our own European values, the principle of freedom of trade properly framed by agreements duly established with other regions. Australia is precisely one of the countries with which we must seek to establish as soon as possible a trade understanding that will certainly be beneficial for both sides.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, the rationale for closer links between the EU and Australia require little explanation. It is a country that, apart from its geographical position, could easily and seamlessly become a member of the European Union itself. The Framework Partnership Agreement (FPA) provides now a formal underpinning by ministerial meetings to enhance cooperation and coordinate policies, and will see us working together to combat shared challenges – whether that be fighting the effects of climate change or combating international terrorism.  Alongside the FPA, we are also seeing negotiations progressing for an EU-Australia free trade agreement. These efforts also mark a wider engagement by the EU in the Pacific region, and we already see plans moving ahead for FTAs with New Zealand and Japan to complement existing ones with Singapore and South Korea.  Sadly, my country, the UK, has failed totally to appreciate the importance of the 62 FTAs negotiated by the EU, preferring – via Brexit – to go it alone as ‘global Britain’. I continue to regard Brexit as a selfish and destructive act against a peace and prosperity project: the EU. I also have no doubt that the hopes from some Brexiteers to see the Anglosphere and the Commonwealth become a cohesive economic bloc to substitute the EU as our main trading partner are pure fantasy. Today, we see what the EU is really doing: concluding meaningful trade and political partnerships and relationships with countries across the globe that share our values throughout the whole world, so I too fully support the excellent Millán Mon report on EU-Australia relations.

name: Ivo Vajgl
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would like, firstly, to stress the excellent work by our rapporteur, Mr Millán Mon. It was a pleasure to work with you, as you are a very committed and professional rapporteur. Australia and the European Union and its Member States are strong and like-minded partners with deep bilateral relations and a long history of cooperation based upon common values and principles. The conclusion of the Framework Agreement provides a legally-binding instrument to upgrade and strengthen EU-Australia bilateral relations and to increase cooperation. Australia and the EU are both committed to advancing the protection and promotion of human rights, democratic principles and the rule of law. They are closely aligned in foreign policy issues, both being important actors in development cooperation and humanitarian assistance in the Pacific region, and in dialogue with the countries of Southeast Asia. The high level of global mobility requires a multilateral approach based on multinational cooperation and shared responsibility. Furthermore, the partners are dedicated to intensifying dialogue and cooperation on migration and asylum. Moreover, the EU and Australia engage in cooperation on combating terrorism, as well as in the fields of migration and asylum, research and innovation, education, culture and environmental protection. Finally, let me stress that in 2016, the European Union was Australia’s second-largest trading partner. Therefore, I also support the EU-Australia Free Trade Agreement, which must be conducted in a spirit of reciprocity and mutual benefit, while taking into account the sensitivity of certain products.

name: Jordi Solé
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I welcome the conclusion of the EU-Australia Framework Agreement and also Mr Millán Mon’s report. This Agreement will strengthen the relationship between two partners who are geographically distant, but close to each other in terms of values and mind-sets. The report points out the most important areas where this partnership should deliver. We particularly welcome the renewed alliance to promote peace, sustainable development and fight against climate change, good governance and human rights. On human rights, I would like to make two comments. Firstly, we acknowledge the progress made by Australia in the protection of the rights of the Aboriginal people, but we encourage our partner to do more in order to involve them in policy-making and consultation processes. Secondly, we are critical of Australia’s asylum policies. Many refugee advocates and international agencies consider them to be too punitive. We call on both the EU Member States, especially those who consider Australia’s approach to be the solution to the European refugee crisis, and the Australian Government, to place human rights at the heart of migration management. Finally, it is surely nothing new to you that my Group does not support the opening of yet more bilateral FTA negotiations. We prefer to stick to the multilateral framework.

name: Anja Hazekamp
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (NL) Mr President, the Commission considers that this agreement with Australia is in the interests of the citizens and the world. But is it also in the interests of animals? Like the EU, Australia sends live animals to the Middle East and Asia. Last week, we saw shocking images of thousands of sheep collapsing under the heat aboard such a large Australian sheep ship, and thousands of kangaroos are hunted and killed every night in Australia. Baby kangaroos are kicked to death and left helpless after their mother is murdered. Europe is a major importer of kangaroo meat and therefore partly responsible for these abuses. Moreover, the EU fails to protect its citizens against kangaroo meat contaminated with salmonella and E. coli. Article 19 of that agreement deals with animal welfare. I call on the Commission to take action and to put forward an import ban on Australian kangaroo meat in the interests of humans and animals as soon as possible. I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Elmar Brok (PPE).
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. If I have just heard this last speech, then the demise of the world is imminent again, and it is not recognised what opportunities exist in these negotiations. We have to recognise that Australia is a democracy like us, based on the same values, and that it is necessary to strengthen cooperation between democracies in this world of cooperation between states that are not just democracies and in which the previous speaker never sees a problem — be it China, be it Russia in these times of geostrategic uncertainties. Strengthening free world trade is a strengthening of our own prosperity, our social policy, as well as a strengthening of the stability of the world, and we must see that, following the withdrawal of Americans from TPP and some of the United States' implied cooperation with China, at the expense of other states in the Pacific region — such as Japan — it is extremely important for the European Commission to enter into this vacuum and make treaties as it did with South Korea — which will soon be concluded — in June with Japan, now Australia, New Zealand, and I believe that we should get stronger in Latin America. I believe that the democracies of the world should unite for the social and economic benefits of our citizens and for the defence of peace and justice in a world order that provides security, and that is why I thank the Commission for its policy to move forward quickly here.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE).
text: — I congratulate my colleague Millán Mon on the excellent report with clear highlights and I am happy to follow my colleague Brok's address. It's time for a new chapter in relations between the European Union and Australia. And I welcome the process which will lead to the conclusion of a free trade agreement through the framework agreement. By doing so, both sides not only express their commitment to common values, principles and interests, but raise the level of ambition in developing mutual cooperation in the future. By doing so, they also demonstrate a dissenting attitude towards protectionism. It's not just another agreement, it's a strategic decision. I assume that even with this agreement there will be no lowering of social, environmental and labour standards and that we will share high ambitions on services with Australia. I'm in favour of dynamic negotiations.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: — Madam President, it is a fact that Australia is an important trading partner of the European Union, there is cooperation at a great many levels and, of course, we must not forget that in 2015 there were investments of EUR 117 billion by the European Union in Australia. Obviously, in the context of the European Union's competition with China, but also with the United States in the Pacific, cooperation between the European Union and Australia is considered particularly important. However, I would like to dwell on point 5 of the report on the conclusion of the free trade agreement, since it is assumed that from this agreement we will have a massive import of cheap Australian agricultural products into the European Union market, especially at a stage when the Greeks, but also other European farmers are facing too many problems. So this is an issue that we must take seriously: it will be to the detriment of agriculture at European Union level.

name: Neven Mimica
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, honourable Members, this has been a very useful exchange and I thank the rapporteur, Mr Millán Mon, and the honourable Members for their interventions. I greatly appreciate the discussion and your interest in the EU—Australia Framework Agreement. This debate has shown strong support for the strengthening of EU—Australia relations through this Agreement.  Although the European Union and Australia are geographically distant – they are distant places indeed – our dialogue and cooperation has never been so close as today. This new agreement gives us the chance to consolidate our achievements and advance on a range of issues relevant to the challenges of our time, to the benefit of both sides. We are ready to implement the Agreement and we hope for continued support from the European Parliament for our bilateral relations with Australia.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, thank you all for your interest in this matter and thank you, in particular, for the kind words that some have addressed to my work. It seems to me that there is a wide convergence of views, a majority, but not unanimous, support for the Framework Agreement with Australia and also for the resolution accompanying Parliament's adoption of the Agreement. I would like to conclude my speech on this matter with three or four considerations. Firstly, EU-Australia relations are very strong at all levels and we must continue to strengthen these relations. The Framework Agreement will contribute to that, and also, as you know, I would like to see that free trade agreement which has not yet begun to be concluded soon. We will thus have two main pillars to sustain the relationship: the political and the economic. And I believe that in the report that we will be adopting this trade issue tomorrow is treated in a balanced manner and that it must be a mutually beneficial relationship, without disregarding the challenge posed by Australia's importance as an agricultural exporter. But let us not forget that the European Union is also a major agri-food exporter. Second consideration: we are natural allies, I usually repeat it. This closeness of principles, values and interests allows us to cooperate closely in addressing global and regional challenges. I am thinking of development aid, the fight against terrorism, and we must also stress again Australia's alignment with European positions on sanctions against Russia or North Korea. Then, if the European Union — the third consideration — wants to be a global player, it must be increasingly present in the Asia-Pacific region, and as a natural ally in those forums we have Australia. The new scenario that opens Brexit has been evoked here. I think this is the time to deepen relationships with Australia. Brexit must be an incentive, a stimulus to strengthen our positions there, and not the opposite. I conclude by reiterating my thanks to everyone for their cooperation, I repeat my hope that tomorrow the Agreement with Australia will be the broadest possible consensus. The convergence of views that I have seen today once again allows me to be optimistic about tomorrow's vote. Thank you all, I repeat.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The joint discussion is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Wednesday 18 April 2018.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Mady Delvaux, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, on the 2015-2016 annual reports on subsidiarity and proportionality (2017/2010 (INI)) (A8-0141/2018).

name: Mady Delvaux
text: rapporteur. — (FR) Madam President, I have been following the annual report on the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality for several years, and I am more and more pleased with it, apart from the fact that this report is the last dossier discussed in plenary at 10.30 p.m. I would like to point out that these principles are not a call for inaction, but a rule of division of powers between the Union and the Member States. Unless it has exclusive competence, the European Union can intervene only if it is able to act more effectively than the Member States at their national or local level. Similarly, the principle of proportionality provides that the means used by the Union to achieve the objectives set out in the Treaties cannot go beyond what is necessary. These principles have been adopted to ensure the effective functioning of the European Union. They are also essential means of ensuring the link between the Union and the citizens. They should therefore not be mistreated for the purpose of blocking or to nourish Euroscepticism, quite the contrary. This report covers the years 2015 and 2016 and identifies the large number of existing tools, some of which were implemented in 2015. There are a range of tools to participate in the stages of the European legislative procedure: impact assessments, public consultations, the REFIT platform, the IPEX platform, the internal Regpex and Connect platforms, dialogues through COSAC and the Committee of the Regions, and the yellow card procedure. Furthermore, since 2014, national parliaments have shown increased interest in European policy through the new instruments put in place, notably REFIT. In 2016, 65 opinions were received from national parliaments, a substantial increase from 2015, which is encouraging. I am therefore not in favour of the creation and development of new instruments without fully exploiting the potential of existing tools. The procedure works when all the protagonists bring interest to him. Therefore, I stress the uselessness of adding instruments and procedures that would increase the bureaucratic burden and further slow down the legislative process. I believe that together, together with the shadow rapporteurs, we have produced a balanced report calling for an effective Union that respects differences and is responsive to the citizens. I would like to thank my colleagues for their collegial and pleasant cooperation. One last word about the Timmermans task-force. As you know, President Juncker has set up a working group to reflect on subsidiarity, to which representatives of national parliaments, the Committee of the Regions and the European Parliament were invited. The European Parliament's refusal to take part does not, in my view, express a lack of interest on the part of our Parliament, but a call for respect for its status as co-legislator. Thus, MEPs keep themselves completely free to express their views on the results of this task force. However, this absence of the European Parliament should in no way affect the relations of the European Parliament with COSAC and the Committee of the Regions. I also hope that our relations with the Committee of the Regions will be strengthened, and I have written a letter in this regard to the President of Parliament. Indeed, the Committee of the Regions is an indispensable institution since it is a valuable cord between the Union and its regions. That is why I emphasised the need for rapprochement between European, national and regional institutions. It is only together, each at its own level, that we must act and engage in policy in the interests of the well-being of our citizens.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Delvaux, for her excellent work and for the positive conclusions she has reached. Since taking office, the Juncker Commission has committed itself to give real effect to the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. We want to work with national parliaments and EU institutions to ensure that every proposal complies with these principles and we improve our shared understanding of what subsidiarity and proportionality mean. The interinstitutional agreement on better law—making, which the three institutions signed two years ago, puts renewed focus on ensuring that these principles are fully respected when developing the Union’s legislation and assessing its impact. We have shown this joint commitment to bring about the change that citizens wish to see in Europe.  My colleague, First Vice—President Frans Timmermans would have liked to be here this evening, but had to travel to Luxembourg for the General Affairs Council. Under his steer, the College has invested heavily in the better regulation agenda. We have made important steps towards more transparency, more public participation and more evidence—based rule—making. This has truly been a cultural change and it has borne results.  To build on this, as announced by President Juncker in his 2017 State of the Union address, the Commission set up the task force on subsidiarity, proportionality and doing less more efficiently in November 2017. We want to ensure that decisions are balanced and taken at the appropriate level, whether it is European, national, regional or local, and we need to discuss whether there are policy areas where competences could meaningfully be re—delegated to Member States.  The Commission has taken note of the Parliament’s decision not to join the task force. We also continue to stress that the seats earmarked for Parliament remain open, should Parliament reconsider. However, we welcome that the report which we are discussing today confronts the Parliament’s interest in helping improve the application and monitoring of the subsidiarity principle.  Many of your suggestions are very similar to ideas currently being examined by the task force. As regards the subsidiarity control mechanism, we agree that national parliaments should be clear in explaining the reasons for which they consider that a proposal does not respect the subsidiarity principle. Your report also asked the Commission to share its replies to national parliaments’ reasoned opinions with this House. Let me recall that we publish our replies on our website. I note the suggestion for the Commission to reflect on excluding recess periods from the eight—week period, as we have done for the month of August. The eight—week period is laid down in the Treaty, but we are looking at the question in the task force on subsidiarity, proportionality and doing less more efficiently.  The Commission does not have a monopoly on good ideas. We are therefore always ready to discuss constructive suggestions from national parliaments. In 2015, a first green card initiative on food waste was supported by 18 chambers. Many of the suggestions made were then reflected in the Circular Economy package which the Commission adopted in December 2015. I agree with you that such an initiative shows how national parliaments can play a constructive role in the institutional framework. We believe our focus should now be on using the current mechanisms to the full, rather than embarking on a lengthy institutional debate when we know that formal changes could well require treaty changes.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. — (FR) Madam President, I would like to congratulate and thank Mrs Delvaux on the drafting of this report. I would also like to thank the Members of the Committee on Legal Affairs for taking into account a number of suggestions from the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs which I have drafted. There is a good convergence between our two committees on the fact that the annual reports on subsidiarity and proportionality are very useful tools for us to assess the implementation of these fundamental principles and safeguard the prerogatives that have been recognized in national parliaments. There is also a convergence that the mechanisms ensuring respect for the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality work essentially well. This can be seen clearly in the limited number of “yellow cards” adopted, the statistics on reasoned opinions and the diversity of the national chambers that issue them. There is clearly a strong interest in European affairs in our national parliaments and the European Parliament has become a privileged interlocutor in these exchanges. Finally, I would like to mention that in our opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, we stressed the need to introduce a dose of flexibility within the framework of the early warning system, in the interpretation of the eight-week deadline, as detailed in the Rangel report on the implementation of the Treaty provisions concerning the national parliaments.

name: Емил Радев
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Madam President, honourable Members, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and thank her especially for the good cooperation we had on this report. Thank you, of course, to the other shadow rapporteurs. I believe that the report is balanced and correctly reflects the main points of the European Commission's annual reports on subsidiarity and proportionality for 2015 and 2016. I also welcome the European Commission for its initiatives in recent years, which improve the implementation of both principles in the adoption of European legislation. It is today that the European Union is facing an unprecedented crisis in search of its identity, it is particularly important that we create strong European legislation where the European Union can make real progress and add value. Therefore, we must apply the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality correctly. If we do not do this, we will only give arguments in the hands of Eurosceptics. National parliaments, acting as representatives of European citizens at national level, also play their important role in addressing the differences between the European institutions and the public. I therefore believe that we should give them a real opportunity to participate in this process by providing for greater flexibility in calculating the eight-week period within which they can send a reasoned opinion. By respecting these two principles, we will do better law-making, which is not constantly criticised. Only in this way will we restore citizens' trust in our institutions and the policies we propose.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the report we are discussing is a very balanced report. I thank my colleague Mady Delvaux for this and the passion she put you into drawing it. The instrument of the annual report on subsidiarity and proportionality is an important instrument: it allows us to give substance to our democratic practice; it serves the Union. The Union needs in some areas to grow and disseminate regulation through more intensive legislation; in some other cases it has to organise legislation that already exists. And we have to give an important, but positive signal, if we can do that, to the people who look at us, to the people of Europe. We must answer the question that comes from below and we must do so taking into account the suggestions and requests from the national parliaments, what are commonly referred to as “the tags” greens”. I would like to give one example in this regard: in 2019 nine parliamentary chambers invited the Commission to submit a legislative proposal to implement the principles of corporate social responsibility . I also renew this request: it would be a nice way to respond to a requirement that has been confirmed by a significant number of requests arrived.

name: Sajjad Karim
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, thank you. I hope you will bear with me whilst I make some rather general comments that are possibly somewhat personal in nature as well. Ms Delvaux, I would first of all like to thank you for doing this tremendous work on behalf of our committee in this Parliament. In particular, thank you for always listening to the suggestions that I had to put forward – not always agreeing, but that is your prerogative – but thank you for at least being open to the ideas that I suggested.  For a number of years, I held the brief on subsidiarity and proportionality on behalf of the Committee, and the confidence of my fellow MEPs across the Group always was a sign of real strength when it came to presentation of this matter in Parliament. There are a number of issues on which I could not agree with you this time round. However, I will not vote against the report, because we are where we are. It has always been my position that we actually need to tie the national parliaments into our legislation-making and decision-making processes, otherwise we end up in the situation that my country is in today. This is the very last opportunity I have to address this House on this particular matter, but we end up with an ‘à la carte’ Europe, where what is popular is claimed by the governments for themselves, and what is not popular is placed at the doorstep of the European Parliament. We cannot allow that situation to continue. Make the parliaments responsible; tie them into what we do here. Thank you.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Madam President, first of all I can see an improvement in tone and content in this motion for a resolution on subsidiarity and proportionality compared to the previous ones. I am inclined to give the benefit of the doubt, but let me believe that it is only a year away from the European elections to continue, in another way, to divert this principle of subsidiarity in order to serve the objectives of the proponents of ever greater European integration and sovereignty. In any event, I will continue to be vigilant about the respect and effective application by the European institutions of this fundamental principle. Secondly, I welcome the increasing use by national parliaments of the possibilities provided for in Protocol 2. I also welcome the “green card” initiatives and reiterate my support for the creation of a “red card” procedure. Finally, I continue to believe that the possibility of giving a reasoned opinion should be extended throughout the legislative process or at least propose it at the beginning, mid-term and end. This is necessary, because national parliaments are the true democratic heart of Europe.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: — Madam President, I would therefore like to hear this report as a former Minister of Justice in the Czech Republic who addressed the issue of subsidiarity and proportionality. I am very pleased that we are discussing this report here. It is a pity that it is this late and that the report does not have more attention, because it is the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality that are fully key in advocating the legitimacy of European law. I welcome the report, I am very pleased that at last national parliaments are learning to use the possibility of reasoned opinions. We should do everything possible to ensure that, in the future, national parliaments use this instrument more and more. It will then remove that subsequent debate, which I see in my country, in the Czech Republic. National politicians distance themselves from European legislation, saying: “If we knew that such a proposal would be adopted, we would have expressed our negative opinions earlier.” It is an important important one. instrument and I very much support this — reasoned opinions of national parliaments. And I would also like to support the European Commission and Mr Juncker that we are adopting less and less legislation and that the principle is to focus on quality, not quantity.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, the report on subsidiarity and proportionality is particularly important. We note that, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, decisions are taken as close as possible to citizens. It is therefore a democratic principle, a principle which leads to the decentralisation of powers, and that means selecting the levels at which decisions are taken when it comes to matters which fall within what we call the European Union's concurrent competences ( powers in English). This is therefore a mechanism of legitimacy of the European project itself, as it also gives a very important role to the national parliaments, which have a veto right, a yellow card right, to question the possibility of Brussels deciding on the all of it. I therefore believe that if the principle of subsidiarity works properly, democracy is consolidated within the European Union.

name: Elmar Brok (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner. Thank you for the opportunity to say two sentences. I believe that these principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are crucial for legitimacy, but also for decision-making efficiency. Because it is an important instrument of legitimacy and organisation to make a difference here. But at the same time we have to see that these two principles have a sister, that is the principle of solidarity. That is why we should always remember that this must be in balance. After all, what some large countries regard as subsidiarity, small countries do not see as subsidiarity, what rich countries regard as subsidiarity, poor countries do not see as subsidiarity, but they demand solidarity there. And that's why the balance between things always needs to be seen. I would like to remind you that, of course, the European national parliaments play an important role here. There is always talk of the yellow card, but there is also the orange card in the Treaty of Lisbon, which must be taken into account and which is too rare and which strengthens the role of national parliaments much more than is the case with the yellow card. We should remember that too. But the decision should always be taken at the level on which the Treaty and the Constitution lay the competence — and no mixing of decisions.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me conclude by reassuring all Members that the Commission will make sure that subsidiarity and proportionality remain at the heart of the European democratic process. And we will continue to engage with Parliament, the Council and national parliaments on this and other important issues.

name: Mady Delvaux
text: rapporteur. — (FR) Madam President, this discussion ends in a beautiful way. Although there are nuances of interpretation, I think there is a great convergence of views on the fact that subsidiarity and proportionality are important principles. I would also like to thank Mr Brok for pointing out that these are not the only principles of the functioning of the European Union and that solidarity is a principle which also has its place in the European architecture. We must therefore continue to encourage national and regional parliaments to make full use of existing instruments, and we must, above all, make them accountable and make constructive proposals for the functioning of our continent instead of blaming Brussels for everything that is going wrong in this world. Of course, I invite everyone to vote for this excellent report.

name: La Présidente. –
text: Mrs Delvaux, we wish you the best possible success in this event. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Wednesday 18 April 2018. Written declarations (article 162)

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: in writing. — Compliance with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are the basis for the functioning of the European Union. They allow you to identify when the EU has the competence to create laws and can contribute to decision-making in terms of the principle “as close as possible to citizens” and which actions taken by institutions are necessary and necessary to achieve the objectives of the Treaties. These rules guarantee the efficiency of the European legislative procedure while respecting the sovereignty of individual states. Nevertheless, in recent years these rules have been abused by Eurosceptic politicians and applied to fight the European Union. The report on 2015 and 2016 annual reports on subsidiarity and proportionality is to remind that these principles serve the functioning of the community and should not undermine its effectiveness. From the Commission's reports for 2015 and 2016, it is clear that, starting in 2014, new tools introduced through REFIT, among other things, have enabled greater participation of national parliaments in the legislative procedure. Moreover, the European Commission continues to apply a streamlined programme of better lawmaking and its effects are becoming increasingly apparent.
